violation of such ordinance not set forth above may settle such subsequent ordinance violation charge by paying one and one-half (11/2) times the amount
required for settlement of an initial ordinance violation charge.
Counsel for the city or his or her designee may withdraw any such offer for settlement, refuse payment or refund payments previously made if the city
attorney or his designee believes that such settlement would not be in the best interests of the city, would not lead to future compliance with this code, or
would deprecate the seriousness of the offense.
If payment in full is not received ten (10) days or more before the listed court date of any such citation, the city may authorize the city attorney or his or her
designee to proceed with an ordinance violation charge by filing such charge with the Lee County circuit clerk's office. In the event the city proceeds with
the filing of an ordinance violation, the respondent shall be responsible for all costs to the extent permissible by law, in addition to any fine. (Ord. 2913, 6-3-
2013)
1-4-2: DEFAULT; LABOR:
(Rep. by Ord. 2243, 5-15-2000)
1-4-3: LICENSE:
When a person is convicted of a violation of any section of this code any license previously issued to him by the city may be revoked by the court or by the
governing body. (1963 Code)
1-4-4: APPLICATION:
The penalty provided in this chapter shall be applicable to every section of this code the same as though it were a part of each and every separate section.
Any person convicted of a violation of any section of this code where any duty is prescribed or obligation imposed, or where any act which is of a
continuing nature or declared to be unlawful, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day
such duty or obligation remains unperformed or such act continues, unless otherwise specifically provided in this code.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 32/357
In all cases where the same offense is made punishable or is created by different clauses or sections of this code the prosecuting officer may elect under
which to proceed; but not more than one recovery shall be had against the same person for the same offense; provided, that the revocation of a license or
permit shall not be considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other penalty being enforced.
Whenever the doing of any act or the omission to do any act constitutes a breach of any section or provision of this code and there shall be no fine or
penalty specifically declared for such breach, the provisions of this chapter shall apply and a separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day
during or on which a breach of violation occurs or continues2. (1963 Code)
1-4-5: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
No provisions of this code designating the duties of any officer or employee shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine or
penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intention of the governing body to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or employee is
specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the duty. (1963 Code)
Chapter 5
COUNCIL
1-5-1: MEMBERSHIP; POWERS AND DUTIES:
The council shall consist of a mayor and four (4) council members elected as provided in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/5-2-12. The council shall be the
governing body of the city and shall have the powers and duties as prescribed by state statute. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
1-5-2: TIME AND PLACE OF MEETINGS:
The regular meetings of the council shall be held on the first and third Mondays of each and every month at the hour of five thirty o'clock (5:30) P.M. in the
council room of city hall in the city of Dixon, Illinois. When such meeting days happen to fall on holidays, the council shall meet on the day following said
holiday at the same hour. Adjourned meetings may be held for the purpose of completing unfinished business of regular or special meetings at such times
as may be determined by the council. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
1-5-3: SPECIAL MEETINGS:
Special meetings of the council may be called by the mayor or any three (3) council members by giving to all members of the council written notice of such
meeting. Such notice shall be mailed or delivered to each member of the council at least forty eight (48) hours before the time set for the special meeting.
If all members of the council are present at a special meeting, however, no notice of such meeting is necessary. Notice to the public of special meetings
shall be given as specified in the Illinois open meetings act. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
1-5-4: QUORUM:
Three (3) members of the council shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business, and the affirmative vote of three (3) members shall be
necessary to adopt any motion, resolution or ordinance, unless a greater number is required by ordinance or state statute. A number of council members
less than three (3) may adjourn from time to time. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
1-5-5: RULES FOR ELECTRONIC ATTENDANCE AT MEETINGS:
(A) Any member of the council, or of any commission, committee or board of the city (each a "public body"), may attend any open or closed meeting of the
public body via electronic means (video or audio conference) provided that such attendance is in compliance with these rules.
(B) Before the public body shall consider electronic attendance at a specific meeting, the member desiring to attend electronically shall have notified the
city clerk at least four (4) hours before the meeting and assert one of the following reasons why he or she is prevented from physically attending the
meeting:
1. Personal illness or disability;
2. Employment purposes or the business of the city; or
3. A family or other emergency.
(C) The city clerk, after receiving proper notice of a request for electronic attendance at a specific meeting, shall inform the presiding officer of the public
body of the request.
(D) At the meeting of the public body where a member desires to attend electronically, after first establishing that there is a quorum physically present, the
presiding officer shall state that: 1) a notice was received from a member in accordance with these rules, and 2) that the member will be permitted to
attend the meeting electronically only upon the affirmative vote of a majority of the public body physically present at the meeting. If no motion
authorizing electronic attendance is made and seconded or such motion fails to achieve the required vote, the request by the member to attend the
meeting electronically shall be deemed denied by the public body and the presiding officer shall declare the requesting member absent. If such motion
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 33/357
receives the required vote, the requesting member shall be declared present and allowed to attend the meeting electronically. Such member shall be
entitled to participate in the meeting in the same manner as those members physically present.
(E) The electronic attendance shall be terminated if the member attending electronically and other members of the public body cannot communicate
effectively or members of the audience are unable to hear all such communications.
(F) The minutes of any meeting with a member attending electronically shall reflect whether each member of the public body is physically present or
present by electronic means. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
1-5-6: PRESIDING OFFICER; CONTRACTS:
The mayor shall preside at all regular and special meetings of the council; provided, that in the absence of the mayor, the council members who are
present shall select one of the members to serve as the presiding officer. The mayor shall sign on behalf of the city all contracts, licenses, deeds and
bonds, except as may be delegated to the city manager or as otherwise provided by state statute. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
1-5-7: RULES OF PROCEDURE:
The council shall at all its meetings and in the transaction of all its business be governed by such rules of procedure as usually govern parliamentary and
legislative bodies of a similar kind insofar as they are applicable and except as otherwise provided by state statute. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
1-5-8: ORDER OF BUSINESS:
When a quorum is present at regular meetings of the council, the council shall proceed to the business before them which shall be conducted in the
following order, unless the same is temporarily suspended or modified at the discretion of the presiding officer:
(A) Roll call of members.
(B) Reading, correcting and approving of the record of proceedings of the last preceding meeting or meetings, unless dispensed with by the council.
(C) Reading, consideration and approval of bills.
(D) Reports of city manager, officers and committees.
(E) Consideration of petitions and communications.
(F) Public comment.
(G) Unfinished business.
(H) Miscellaneous or new business.
(I) Closed session.
(J) Adjournment. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
1-5-9: PUBLIC COMMENT:
(A) Procedure: Any person seeking to address the members of the council, or any commission, committee or board of the city, at any public meeting will
be permitted to speak on any matter listed on the agenda or any other matter of public concern in accordance with these rules and applicable state
statutes.
(B) Council Meetings:
1. The agenda for each meeting of the council shall include a "public comment" item, during which any member of the public may address the council.
Any person so addressing the council shall state his or her name and the topic of discussion at the commencement of that person's comments.
2. No person shall speak or address the council unless first recognized by the presiding officer.
3. Public comment at a council meeting shall be limited to no more than five (5) minutes per commenter and to no more than one hour total per
meeting, unless either of said time limits is extended by majority vote of the council members present. The presiding officer may designate the city
clerk, chief of police or other officer of the city to monitor the time utilized by each speaker and to notify the speaker when the allotted time has
expired.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 34/357
4. At any meeting of the council, the presiding officer, at his or her discretion, may request that persons desiring to address the council at that meeting
sign in on a "request to comment" form, providing for the speaker's name and the topic to be discussed by the speaker.
5. If the presiding officer recognizes that more than twenty (20) persons wish to address the council at any one meeting, the presiding officer may limit
each speaker to comment of no more than three (3) minutes. Whenever any group of persons wishes to address the council on the same subject
matter, the presiding officer may request that a spokesperson be chosen from the group. If such spokesperson speaks on behalf of multiple
members of a group, the presiding officer may permit the spokesperson to address for a period longer than the otherwise specified time limits. If
other matters are to be presented by other persons in the same group, the presiding officer may request that the group limit the number of such
persons or may request that the additional comment be limited to information which has not already been presented by the group spokesperson or
by other members of the group in order that the total comment period for that meeting not be exceeded.
6. Any person invited by a member of the council to address the council at a meeting is subject to such time limitation, if any, as the majority of the
members of the council present may prescribe.
(C) Meetings Of Commissions, Committees And Boards:
1. The time limits specified above shall not apply to persons addressing the zoning board of appeals, plan commission or any other municipal body
when such body is conducting a quasi-judicial hearing. Any such body may establish reasonable rules and time limits regarding the number and
amount of time that persons advocating for or against pending matters must follow, so long as such rules conform to other requirements of state
statute.
2. Commissions, committees or other boards duly appointed or acting pursuant to authority of the council may establish rules for public comment and
for persons wishing to address that commission, committee or board. No rules adopted by any such commission, committee or board shall be
adopted that are more restrictive than the rules established for comment to the council. In the absence of the establishment of rules for public
comment by any commission, committee or board, the rules governing public comment for the council shall apply. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-
2015)
1-5-10: MEETING DISRUPTIONS:
It shall be unlawful to disturb or interrupt any regular or special meeting of the council or any meeting of any commission, committee or board of the city.
Any person violating any provision of this section may be prosecuted as provided by law and may be summarily removed from the council chambers and
city hall or such other place where the meeting is held. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
1-5-11: INDEPENDENT AUDITS:
The council shall provide for an annual independent audit of all accounts of the city for the prior fiscal year, which audits shall be conducted independently
of the city manager by some person or firm selected by the council. Full reports of such audits shall be filed in the public records of the city and as required
by statute. The power with respect to such audits by the council shall not be construed in any manner to limit the responsibility of the city manager or other
officers of the city for the proper expenditures of city funds. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
1-5-12: EMERGENCY INTERIM EXECUTIVE SUCCESSION:
(A) Definitions: Whenever the following words or terms are used in this section, they shall have the meaning hereinafter ascribed:
ATTACK: Any attack or series of attacks by an enemy of the United States causing, or which may cause, substantial damage or injury to civilian
property or persons in the United States in any manner by sabotage or by the use of bombs, missiles, shellfire, or atomic, radiological, chemical
bacteriological or biological means or other weapons or processes.
DISASTER: An occurrence or threat of catastrophic and widespread injury or loss of life or property within the city resulting from any natural or
manmade cause, including, but not limited to, fire, flood, earthquake, epidemic and explosion.
EMERGENCY INTERIM SUCCESSOR: A person designated pursuant to this section, in the event the lawful incumbent mayor is unavailable, to
exercise the powers and discharge the duties of the office of mayor until a successor is appointed or elected and qualified as may be provided by
Illinois law and this code or until the lawful incumbent mayor is able to resume the exercise of the powers and discharge the duties of the office of
mayor.
UNAVAILABLE: Either that a vacancy in the office of mayor exists or the lawful incumbent mayor is absent or unable to exercise the powers and
discharge the duties of the office of mayor.
(B) Order Of Successor: In the event of an attack or disaster resulting in the lawful incumbent mayor being unavailable, the emergency interim successor
shall exercise the powers and discharge the duties of the office of mayor. The emergency interim successor shall be the following persons in the order
hereafter set forth:
1. The councilman with the highest number of consecutive years and days in office;
2. The councilman with the second highest number of consecutive years and days in office;
3. The councilman with the third highest number of consecutive years and days in office; and
4. The councilman with the fourth highest number of consecutive years and days in office.
If two (2) or more councilmen share the same number of consecutive years and days in office, the emergency interim successor shall be the most
senior councilman by age.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 35/357
(C) Oath Of Office: At the time of designation, the emergency interim successor shall take the oath of office required of the office of mayor. The emergency
interim successor shall not be required to comply with any other provision of law relative to taking office.
(D) Powers; Termination: The emergency interim successor is empowered to exercise the powers and discharge the duties of the office of mayor only after
an attack or during a disaster. The council may, by majority vote of the corporate authorities, at any time terminate the authority of the emergency
interim successor and, if necessary, fill any vacancy in the office of mayor in accordance with applicable law. (Ord. 2967, 5-18-2015)
Chapter 6
MANAGER
1-6-1: ESTABLISHMENT OF OFFICE:
There is hereby established the Office of City Manager. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
1-6-2: APPOINTMENT; QUALIFICATIONS:
The City Manager shall be appointed by majority vote of the Council for an indefinite term. The Council shall choose the City Manager solely on the basis
of his or her professional qualifications, including education and experience, and without regard to his or her political beliefs. Within twelve (12) months of
his or her appointment, the City Manager shall reside within the geographic boundaries of Community Unit School District #170 (also known as the Dixon
Public School District). No member of the Council shall receive an appointment to the position of City Manager during the term for which such member
shall have been elected, nor within one year after the expiration of such member's term. (Ord. 3066, 11-6-2017)
1-6-3: ABSENCE OR DISABILITY; VACANCY IN OFFICE:
In the case of absence or disability of the City Manager, the Assistant City Manager shall perform the duties of City Manager during such absence or
disability. In the event of vacancy in the Office of City Manager, the Council shall fill the vacancy within one hundred twenty (120) days after the effective
date of such vacancy. (Ord. 3073, 12-18-2017)
1-6-4: REMOVAL:
The Council may remove the City Manager at any time by majority vote of Council, subject to the terms and conditions of the City Manager's employment
agreement, if any. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
1-6-5: DUTIES:
The City Manager shall be the Administrative Officer of the City and shall be responsible for the efficient administration of all departments. The duties of
the City Manager are as follows:
(A) To enforce the laws and ordinances of the City.
(B) To appoint, remove or suspend any officer, department head or employee of the City, except when such power is vested in the Council or other
commission, committee or board of the City under this Code or any applicable State Statute or pursuant to the terms of any collective bargaining
agreement. No appointment shall be made on any basis other than that of merit and fitness. Upon suspending or discharging any department head,
officer or employee, he or she shall submit to the Council a statement setting forth the reasons therefor.
(C) To recommend to the Council the wages and benefits for each position within the service of the City.
(D) To exercise control of all departments and divisions of the City that may be created by the Council.
(E) To receive notice of and attend all meetings of the Council unless excused therefrom by the Council. The City Manager shall have the privilege of
taking part in the discussion of all matters coming before the Council but he or she shall have no vote thereon.
(F) To recommend to the Council for adoption such measures as he or she may deem necessary or expedient.
(G) To investigate all complaints pertaining to the administration of the City and to services maintained by the public utilities of the City and see that all
franchises, permits and privileges granted by the City are faithfully observed.
(H) To have all powers and exercise all the duties granted to the City Clerk and City Treasurer with respect to the preparation of a report of estimated
funds necessary to defray the expenses of the City for the fiscal year for the consideration of the Council prior to the preparation of the annual budget
ordinance.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 36/357
(I) To prepare and submit an annual budget to the Council.
(J) To keep the Council advised of the financial condition and future needs of the City and make such recommendations as may be deemed desirable.
(K) To purchase all materials, supplies, equipment and services for which funds are provided in the City's budget, and to enter into contracts with respect
to the same; provided, that the City Manager may not purchase any items or enter into any contracts that exceed twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00)
without the prior approval of the Council. In the event of an emergency, the City Manager may purchase materials, supplies, equipment and services,
and enter into contracts with respect to the same, for the purpose of remediating the emergency; provided, that: 1) within fourteen (14) days the City
Manager shall file with the Council a certificate explaining the emergency and an itemization of all expenditures and contracts in connection therewith,
and 2) competitive bidding rules shall be followed unless waived by the Council in accordance with State Statute.
(L) To supervise the negotiation of all collective bargaining agreements between the City and unions representing employees of the City.
(M) To examine all other proposed contracts of the City, advise the Council with respect to the same, and supervise the performance of the terms and
conditions of any contract to which the City is a party.
(N) To perform such other duties as may be directed by the Council or as required by State Statute. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
1-6-6: COUNCIL'S RELATIONSHIP TO ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICE:
Except where such power is reserved to the Council, no member of the Council shall have the authority to direct the City Manager to appoint or remove
any person from employment by the City. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
1-6-7: ASSISTANT CITY MANAGER:
There is hereby established the Office of Assistant City Manager. The Assistant City Manager may be appointed, and may be removed, from time to time
by the Council with the advice of the City Manager. The Assistant City Manager shall be selected from among the department heads and superintendents
of the City. The Assistant City Manager shall have such duties and responsibilities as may be assigned by the City Manager and this Code. (Ord. 3073, 12-
18-2017)
Chapter 7
CLERK
1-7-1: ESTABLISHMENT OF OFFICE; APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby established the office of city clerk. The city clerk shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the council for a definite term not to
exceed the term of the mayor then holding office. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
1-7-2: DUTIES:
The duties of the clerk shall be as follows:
(A) The city clerk shall keep the corporate seal provided by the corporate authorities and all papers belonging to the city the custody and control of which
are not given to other officers.
(B) The clerk shall attend all meetings of the city council and shall keep a full and correct record of all its proceedings and shall perform all duties which
may be required by him of law and all other duties which, by usage and custom, devolve upon clerks of incorporated bodies.
(C) The clerk shall seal and attest all contracts of the city, and all licenses, permits and other documents which require this formality.
(D) The clerk shall keep accounts showing all money received by him, and the source and disposition thereof; and such other accounts as may be
required by statute or the applicable provisions of this code.
(E) In addition to the record of ordinances and other records which the clerk is required by statute to keep, he shall keep a register for all licenses and
permits issued, and a record of the payment thereon; he shall keep a record showing all of the officers and regular employees of the city, and such
other records as may be required by the council.
(F) The clerk shall be the custodian of the city seal and shall affix its impression on documents whenever required.
(G) The clerk shall keep and maintain a proper index to all documents and records kept by him, so that ready access thereto and use thereof may be had.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 37/357
(H) The clerk shall keep all records, papers, ordinances, notes and proceedings of the council, and of the city during the recess of the council, and of all
elections of city officers. He shall record and index in a book to be kept for that purpose, all ordinances passed by the council, and a record of the date
of passage and of the publication of the ordinance which record and memorandum, or a certified copy thereof, shall be prima facie evidence of the
passage and legal publication of such ordinances for all purposes whatsoever.
(I) He shall have all ordinances published immediately after their passage when required by law so to do.
(J) The clerk shall be registrar of vital statistics for the city of Dixon.
(K) The clerk shall act as secretary of the board of local improvements. (Ord. 764, 10-1-1973)
1-7-3: COMPLIANCE WITH FREEDOM OF INFORMATION ACT:
The city clerk shall be the custodian of all documents belonging to the city which are not assigned to the custody of some other office of the city by the
mayor or city council, and shall be responsible for maintaining the city's compliance with the freedom of information act. (Ord. 2769, 12-21-2009)
1-7-4: FOIA OFFICER:
(A) The city clerk, or any individual acting in the official capacity as designated city clerk, is hereby appointed by the city council to be the designated chief
freedom of information act officer for the city to be responsible for and to perform those duties required by the Illinois freedom of information act1
(herein the "act"). In such capacity the city clerk shall be responsible for maintaining the city's compliance with all statutory obligations of the act and be
empowered to consult with the city attorney in complying with all issues relating to the act. The deputy clerk shall also serve as a designated freedom
of information act officer and assist the city clerk in performing such duties as necessary to maintain the city's compliance with the act.
(B) The city clerk shall make: 1) the directory of FOIA officers; 2) the address where requests for public records should be directed; and 3) any fees
allowable under section 6 of the act; available for inspection and copying upon request or through the mail, and shall also cause that information to be
posted on the official website of the city. (Ord. 2769, 12-21-2009)
1-7-5: DEPUTY CITY CLERK:
(A) The deputy city clerk shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the council for a definite term not to exceed the term of the mayor then
holding office.
(B) The deputy city clerk, during any absence in the office of city clerk, shall perform the same functions and have the same authority and duties as the city
clerk. In addition, the deputy city clerk shall assist in the work of the city clerk under his or her direction. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
Chapter 8
ATTORNEY
1-8-1: ESTABLISHMENT OF OFFICE; APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby established the office of city attorney. The city attorney shall be appointed for an indefinite period of time by, and shall report to, the city
manager. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
1-8-2: DUTIES:
(A) To be the legal advisor to the city and to render advice on all questions of law affecting the city whenever requested to do so.
(B) To prosecute and defend any and all suits or actions at law or equity to which the city may be a party, or in which it may be interested, or which may be
brought against, or by, any officer of the city on behalf of the city, or in capacity of such person as an officer of the city.
(C) To see to the full enforcement of all judgments or decrees rendered or entered in favor of the city in all courts of law.
(D) To prosecute all actions for violations of the ordinances of the city and to conduct all proceedings in courts of law or on appeal therefrom.
(E) It shall be the duty of the city attorney to draft or supervise the phraseology of any contracts, leases or other documents and instruments to which the
city may be a party; and to draft ordinances and resolutions covering any subjects within the powers of the city. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
1-8-3: EMPLOYMENT OF ADDITIONAL COUNSEL:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 38/357
The council may authorize the employment of additional counsel to give legal advice or render service to the city. The city manager shall retain said
additional counsel. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
Chapter 9
TREASURER
1-9-1: ESTABLISHMENT OF OFFICE; APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby established the office of city treasurer. The city treasurer shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the council for a definite
term not to exceed the term of the mayor then holding office. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
1-9-2: DUTIES:
The duties of the city treasurer shall be as follows:
(A) The city treasurer shall receive all monies belonging to the corporation and shall keep a separate account of each fund and appropriation and the
debits and credits belonging thereto. He or she shall give to every person paying money into the treasury a receipt therefor, specifying the date of
payment and upon what account paid; and he or she shall file copies of such receipts with the city clerk at the date of his or her monthly report.
(B) The city treasurer shall keep an accurate register of all warrants redeemed and paid by him or her, showing the number, date and amount of each, the
fund from which paid; and he or she shall cancel all warrants as soon as redeemed.
(C) All monies received by the city treasurer on any special assessment or special tax shall be held by him or her as a special fund to be applied to the
payment of the improvement for which such special assessment or special tax was made and said money shall be used for no other purpose whatever
except to reimburse the city for money expended for such improvement.
(D) The city treasurer shall keep all monies in his or her hands belonging to the corporation separate and distinct from his or her own money; and he or
she is expressly prohibited from using, either directly or indirectly, the corporation money or warrants, in his or her custody and keeping, for his or her
own use and benefit, or that of any other person; and any violation of this subsection shall subject him or her to removal from office.
(E) The city treasurer shall keep his or her books and accounts in such manner as to show all monies received and disbursed by him or her for the city,
stating from whom and on what account received and to whom and on what account paid out, and in such way that the books and accounts may be
readily investigated and understood, and the same, together with all files and papers of the office, electronic or otherwise, shall be at all times open to
examination by the city manager, the city clerk or any member of the council.
(F) The city treasurer shall, at the end of each and every month, and more often if so required, render an account, under oath, to the council, showing the
state of the treasury at the date of such account and the balance of money in the treasury. He or she shall accompany such account with a statement
of all monies received into the treasury, and on what account received, together with all warrants redeemed and paid by him or her during the
preceding month, which warrants, with any and all vouchers held by him or her, shall be delivered to the city clerk and filed with his or her accounts in
the city clerk's office; and he or she shall return all warrants paid by him or her stamped or marked "paid".
(G) The city treasurer shall annually, within the time required by law, make out and file with the city clerk a full and detailed report of all receipts and
expenditures of the city, as shown by his or her books, and of all his or her transactions as such treasurer during the preceding fiscal year, and he or
she shall, in such report, show the state of the treasury at the close of such year, which report the city clerk shall cause to be published without delay.
(H) The city treasurer shall be ex officio custodian of the Oakwood Cemetery endowment fund.
(I) The city treasurer shall perform such other related duties as may be assigned by the city finance director from time to time and such additional duties as
are set forth in this code and as the council may determine necessary or as required by state statute. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
Chapter 10
CORPORATE SEAL
1-10-1: DESIGN AND SIZE OF CORPORATE SEAL:
The corporate seal of the city shall be circular in form, two and one-half inches (21/2") in diameter, with a portrait of Father John Dixon stamped or
engraved thereon and with the words, City of Dixon, Lee County, Illinois, and the figures 1857 engraved upon the face thereof. (1950 Code)
1-10-2: CUSTODY OF CORPORATE SEAL:
The clerk shall be the custodian of the corporate seal. He shall affix the impression of the seal to all commissions or other official documents required to be
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 39/357
issued by him, and attest or countersign the same. He shall affix the seal to all official acts of the mayor requiring it and if necessary, attest the same. He
shall also certify under the corporate seal, copies of all records, ordinances, documents or papers in his office, when required by any city officer or other
person, upon tender of his proper fees and charges therefor, where such fees or charges are authorized by any law. In no case shall the impression of the
seal be binding upon the city unless it be authorized by the laws thereof, and is attested by the official signature of the clerk.

Chapter 11
BONDS, OATHS AND SALARIES
1-11-1: BONDS OF CITY OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES:
(A) Before entering upon the duties of their separate offices, the Mayor, each member of the Council, the City Manager, the City Clerk, the City Treasurer
and all other required officers and employees of the City shall execute a bond with good and sufficient security to be approved by the Council payable
to the City in such penal sums as directed in this section, conditioned for the faithful performance of the duties of the office and the payment of all
money received by the officer, according to law and the ordinances of the City.
(B) All bonds shall be filed with the City Clerk, except that the bond of the City Clerk shall be filed with the City Treasurer.
(C) The bonds of the various elected officials, officers and employees shall be in the penal sums hereafter set forth:
1. The bond of the Mayor shall be three thousand dollars ($3,000.00).
2. The bond of each member of the Council shall be three thousand dollars ($3,000.00).
3. The bond of the City Manager shall be three thousand dollars ($3,000.00).
4. The bond of the City Treasurer shall be not less than the greater of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) or three (3) times the latest Federal census for
the City or any subsequent census figure used for Motor Fuel Tax purposes.
5. All other appointed officers and employees shall be covered by a commercial blanket bond in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). (Ord.
2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
1-11-2: OATH REQUIREMENT:
Before entering upon the duties of their offices, all officers, whether elected or appointed, shall take and subscribe the oath or affirmation required by the
Illinois Constitution or as otherwise required by State Statute. The subscribed oath or affirmation shall be filed in the Office of the City Clerk. (Ord. 2964, 4-
20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
1-11-3: SALARIES:
(A) The salary of the Mayor shall be nine thousand six hundred dollars ($9,600.00) per year, which sum shall be payable in monthly installments
commencing with the first month in office. Commencing with the four (4) year term of the Mayor that begins in 2019, and thereafter, the salary of the
Mayor shall be nineteen thousand five hundred dollars ($19,500.00) per year, which sum shall be payable in monthly installments commencing with the
first month in office. (Ord. 3037, 4-17-2017)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 40/357
(B) Until changed as hereafter set forth, the salary of each member of the Council shall be five thousand four hundred dollars ($5,400.00) per year, which
sum shall be payable in monthly installments commencing with the first month in office. With respect to those members of the Council commencing a
four-year term in 2019, and continuing thereafter, the salary of such members shall be nine thousand five hundred dollars ($9,500.00) per year, which
sum shall be payable in monthly installments commencing with the first month in office. With respect to those members of the Council commencing a
four-year term in 2021, and continuing thereafter, the salary of such members shall be nine thousand five hundred dollars ($9,500.00) per year, which
sum shall be payable in monthly installments commencing with the first month in office. (Ord. 3113, 10-1-2018)
(C) The City Manager shall receive such compensation as the Council shall fix from time to time, subject to the terms and conditions of the City Manager's
employment agreement, if any.
(D) The wages and benefits for all other positions within the service of the City, with the exception of employees subject to a union contract, shall be as
established annually by resolution of the Council. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)

CORPORATE LIMITS

Chapter 13
PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT
1-13-1: CREATION OF DEPARTMENT; APPOINTMENT OF DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS:
There is hereby established a department of public works, which shall be under the jurisdiction and control of the city manager. The head of the
department of public works shall be the director of public works, who shall be appointed by the city manager for an indefinite period of time. The
department of public works shall also include the superintendent of streets, the superintendent of public property, the superintendent of water, the
superintendent of wastewater treatment and such additional employees as the council may determine to be necessary. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-
2015)
1-13-2: DIVISIONS; SUPERVISION:
(A) The streets department, the department of public property, the water department and the wastewater treatment department are hereby combined into a
single department of public works and deemed separate divisions of the department of public works. The department of public works shall be under the
supervision and direction of the director of public works. Subject to the foregoing, the superintendent of streets shall supervise the streets division, the
superintendent of public property shall supervise the division of public property, the superintendent of water shall supervise the water division and the
superintendent of wastewater treatment shall supervise the wastewater treatment division.
(B) All employees of the city who are, as of the effective date hereof, employees of the streets department, the department of public property, the water
department and the wastewater treatment department shall be employees of the department of public works and shall be assigned as to the various
divisions as determined by the director of public works. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
1-13-3: QUALIFICATIONS:
The qualifications of the director of public works and the superintendents of the divisions of the departments of public works shall be as prescribed from
time to time by the council. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
1-13-4: DUTIES OF DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS:
The duties of the director of public works shall be as follows:
(A) Have charge of the construction and care of all public property, including public streets and alleys, in the city.
(B) Supervise the lighting of the public streets and alleys and keep the lighting system in efficient operation and good repair.
(C) Review or approve all plans, blueprints, and specifications of public improvements, made or caused to be made by the city; the director shall be the
city's chief supervisory official on and for all public improvements, and no work shall be accepted and payment made therefor except upon his or her
approval and certification.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 41/357
(D) Keep all city maps and plats current and be responsible for the procurement, care, and custody of such maps, plats, and plans necessary to the
efficient conduct of the department of public works.
(E) Oversee all contract engineering services and complete an engineering review of all development projects.
(F) In conjunction with the city manager and council, plan, design, document and supervise the construction of city projects.
(G) Work in conjunction with the superintendents of the divisions of the department of public works and the city building official to provide for the
maintenance and development of all public facilities, utilities, and property.
(H) Be responsible for communicating with the necessary state and federal regulatory bodies that govern the funding, planning, design and construction
processes of city projects.
(I) Give monthly reports of construction and maintenance activities with a yearly summary of all projects completed and proposed to the city manager and
council.
(J) Inform the public of the plans and goals of the city and the reasoning and goals of city projects.
(K) The director of public works shall perform such related duties as may be assigned by the city manager from time to time and such additional duties as
are set forth in this code and as the council may determine necessary.
(L) Supervise and direct the various divisions and superintendents of the department of public works, subject to the jurisdiction and control of the city
manager.
(M) Serve as city safety officer, as the same may be required under applicable law. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)

Chapter 15
FINANCE DEPARTMENT
1-15-1: ESTABLISHMENT OF DEPARTMENT; APPOINTMENT OF FINANCE DIRECTOR:
There is hereby established a department of finance, which shall be under the jurisdiction and control of the city manager. The head of the department of
finance shall be the finance director, who shall be appointed by the city manager for an indefinite period of time. The department of finance shall include
such additional employees as the council may determine to be necessary. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
1-15-2: QUALIFICATIONS:
The qualifications of the finance director shall be as prescribed from time to time by the council. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
1-15-3: DUTIES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 42/357
The duties of the finance director shall be as follows:
(A) Plan, organize and direct all accounts and finance department operations and employees.
(B) Provide financial and other analysis to the council, city manager and department heads.
(C) Develop, implement and monitor policies and procedures to assure preservation of city assets and accounting control of city finances.
(D) Participate in the preparation of the annual budget of the city, including financial framework for budget projections and budgetary activities and monitor
the budget during the fiscal year.
(E) Participate in coordination of risk management programs, negotiation of liability and health insurance contracts and coordinate insurance claims.

(G) Oversee the city's annual audit process.
(H) Review proposals for the development of the city, including economic and financial aspects of annexations, and residential, commercial and industrial
growth.
(I) Participate in the development of plans for multiyear capital improvement programs.
(J) Prepare all required national, state and county fiscal reports and monthly financial reports.

council may determine necessary. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)

Chapter 16
EMPLOYEES ETHICS ACT
1-16-1: ADOPTION OF ACT:
(A) The regulations of section 5-151 and article 102 of the state official and employees ethics act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/1-1 et seq. (hereinafter
referred to as the "act" in this section), are hereby adopted by reference and made applicable to the officers and employees of the city to the extent
required by 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5.
(B) The solicitation or acceptance of gifts prohibited to be solicited or accepted under this act, by an officer or any employee of the city, is hereby
prohibited.
(C) The offering or making of gifts prohibited to be offered or made to an officer or employee of the city under the act, is hereby prohibited.
(D) The participation in political activities prohibited under the act, by an officer or employee of the city, is hereby prohibited.
(E) For purposes of this section, the terms "officer" and "employee" shall be defined as set forth in 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5(c).
(F) The penalties for violations of this section shall be the same as those penalties set forth in 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/50-5 for similar violations of
the act.
(G) This section does not repeal or otherwise amend or modify any existing ordinances or policies which regulate the conduct of the city officers and
employees. To the extent that any such existing ordinances or policies are less restrictive than this section, however, the provisions of this section shall
prevail in accordance with the provisions of 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5(a).
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 43/357
(H) Any amendment to the act that becomes effective after the effective date of this section shall be incorporated into this section by reference and shall
be applicable to the solicitation, acceptance, offering and making of gifts and to prohibited political activities. However, any amendment that makes its
provisions optional for adoption by municipalities shall not be incorporated into this section by reference without formal action by the city council.
(I) If the Illinois supreme court declares the act unconstitutional in its entirety, then this section shall be repealed as of the date that the Illinois supreme
court's decision becomes final and not subject to any further appeals or hearings. This section shall be deemed repealed without further action by the
city council if the act is found unconstitutional by the Illinois supreme court.
(J) If the Illinois supreme court declares part of the act unconstitutional but upholds the constitutionality of the remainder of the act, or does not address the
remainder of the act, then the remainder of the act as adopted by this section shall remain in full force and effect; however, that part of this section
relating to the part of the act found unconstitutional shall be deemed repealed without further action by the city council. (Ord. 2483, 5-17-2004; amd.
Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
1-16-2: ETHICS ADVISOR:
(A) The mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council shall designate an ethics advisor for the city. The duties of the ethics advisor may be
delegated to an officer or employee of the city unless the position has been created as an office by the city.
(B) The ethics advisor shall provide guidance to the officers and employees of the city concerning the interpretation of and compliance with the provisions
of this chapter and state ethics laws. The ethics advisor shall perform such other duties as may be delegated by the city council. (Ord. 2483, 5-17-
2004; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
1-16-3: ETHICS COMMISSION:
(A) There is hereby created a commission to be known as the ethics commission of the city of Dixon. The commission shall be comprised of three (3)
members appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council. No person shall be appointed as a member of the commission who is
related, either by blood or marriage up to the degree of first cousin, to any elected officer of the city.
(B) At the first meeting of the commission, the initial appointees shall draw lots to determine their initial terms. Two (2) commissioners shall serve two (2)
year terms, and the third commissioner shall serve a one year term. Thereafter, all commissioners shall be appointed to two (2) year terms.
Commissioners may be reappointed to serve subsequent terms.
At the first meeting of the commission, the commissioners shall choose a chairperson from their number. Meetings shall be held at the call of the
chairperson or any two (2) commissioners. A quorum shall consist of two (2) commissioners and official action by the commission shall require the
affirmative vote of two (2) members.
(C) The mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council, may remove a commissioner in case of incompetency, neglect of duty or malfeasance in
office after service on the commissioner by certified mail, return receipt requested, a copy of the written charges against the commissioner and after
providing an opportunity to be heard in person or by counsel upon not less than ten (10) days' notice. Vacancies shall be filled in the same manner as
original appointments.
(D) The commission shall have the following powers and duties:
1. To promulgate procedures and rules governing the performance of its duties and the exercise of its powers.
2. Upon receipt of a signed, notarized, written complaint, to investigate, conduct hearings and deliberations, issue recommendations for disciplinary
action and refer violation of this chapter to the appropriate attorney for prosecution. The commission shall, however, act only upon the receipt of a
written complaint alleging a violation of this chapter and not upon its own prerogative.
3. To receive information from the public pertaining to its investigation and to require additional information and documents from persons who may have
violated the provisions of this chapter.
4. To compel the attendance of witnesses and to compel the production of books and papers pertinent to an investigation. It is the obligation of all
officers and employees of the city of Dixon to cooperate with the commission during the course of its investigations. Failure or refusal to cooperate
with requests by the commission shall constitute grounds for discipline or discharge.
5. The powers and duties of the commission are limited to matters clearly within the purview of this chapter.
(E) The following procedures shall govern the filing of complaints:
1. Complaints alleging a violation of this chapter shall be filed with the ethics commission.
2. Within three (3) business days after the receipt of a complaint, the commission shall send by certified mail, return receipt requested, a notice to the
respondent that a complaint has been filed against him or her and a copy of the complaint. The commission shall send by certified mail, return
receipt requested, a confirmation of the receipt of the complaint to the complainant within three (3) business days after receipt by the commission.
The notices to the respondent and the complainant shall also advise them of the date, time, and place of the meeting to determine the sufficiency of
the complaint and to establish whether probable cause exists to proceed.
3. Upon not less than forty eight (48) hours' public notice, the commission shall meet to review the sufficiency of the complaint and, if the complaint is
deemed sufficient to allege a violation of this chapter, to determine whether there is probable cause, based on the evidence presented by the
complainant, to proceed. The meeting may be closed to the public to the extent authorized by the open meetings act. The commission shall issue
notice to the complainant and the respondent of the commission's ruling on the sufficiency of the complaint and, if necessary, on probable cause to
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 44/357
proceed within seven (7) business days of receiving the complaint.
If the complaint is deemed sufficient to allege a violation of this chapter then the commission shall notify in writing the attorney designated by the city
council to prosecute such actions and shall transmit to the attorney the complaint and all additional documents in the custody of the commission
concerning the alleged violation. If the complaint is deemed not sufficient to allege a violation or if there is no determination of probable cause, then
the commission shall send by certified mail, return receipt requested, a notice to the parties of the decision to dismiss the complaint, and that notice
shall be made public. (Ord. 2483, 5-17-2004; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
Chapter 17
FIRE DEPARTMENT

The chief of the fire department may be removed or discharged by the city manager; provided, that the city manager shall file with the council the reasons

Chapter 19
LEGAL DEFENSE AND INDEMNIFICATION
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 45/357
1-19-1: LEGAL DEFENSE AND INDEMNIFICATION DESCRIBED:
(A) To the extent permissible under law, the city shall defend, save harmless and indemnify its current and former commissioners, council members, board
members, officers, or employees against any civil, criminal or administrative action, suit or proceeding instituted or threatened to be instituted against
them, based upon any act, error or omission that could be reasonably construed to be within the exercise of their lawful duties or scope of employment,
and against judgments, fines and other costs and liabilities, including amounts paid in settlement sustained as a result of, and reasonable expenses,
including attorney fees, incurred in connection with the investigation, defense, adverse decision, compromise or settlement of any such action, suit or
proceeding or threat thereof.
(B) This chapter shall not apply to providing defense or indemnification to any such action, suit or proceeding instituted by or on behalf of the city against
such commissioner, council member, board member, officer or employee, or situations involving claims of wilful and wanton misconduct or acts outside
the scope of authority.
(C) The rights expressed in this chapter shall not be exclusive of any other rights which any current or former commissioner, council member, board
member, officer or employee may have as a matter of law or fact. The foregoing rights, shall, in the case of the death of a commissioner, council
member, board member, officer or employee, accrue to the benefit of his or her heirs and successors.
(D) The liability of the city for payments under this chapter may be insured to the extent permitted by law but to the extent not insured shall be payable out
of the funds and monies of the city.
(E) The indemnification provided by this chapter shall not be subject to retroactive revocation as to any person entitled to indemnification. It shall not be
deemed exclusive of any other rights to which a person seeking indemnification may be entitled.
(F) Nothing in this chapter shall be deemed to limit or modify the authority of the city under state law to defend or indemnify parties or persons as
otherwise provided and permitted by law. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
Chapter 20
CITY ADMINISTRATOR
1-20-1: OFFICE CREATED:
There is hereby created the office of administrator of the city of Dixon. Said administrator shall be appointed by the city council. (Ord. 2925, 9-16-2013;
amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
1-20-2: SUPERVISION:
The administrator shall be directly under the supervision of the city council and shall serve subject to its orders and shall perform such duties as are
required of him in the operation and general administration of the affairs of the city of Dixon. (Ord. 2925, 9-16-2013; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-
2015)
1-20-3: QUALIFICATION FOR OFFICE:
Candidates for the office of administrator shall have such qualifications as may be required from time to time by the city council. (Ord. 2925, 9-16-2013;
amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
1-20-4: DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
The duties and responsibilities of the administrator are as set forth in the job description for city administrator adopted by the city council on August 5,
2013, as the same may be amended from time to time by the city council. (Ord. 2925, 9-16-2013; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
1-20-5: SALARY:
The administrator shall receive an annual salary as established from time to time by the city council. (Ord. 2925, 9-16-2013; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015,
eff. 5-4-2015)
1-20-6: REPEALER:
This chapter is hereby repealed effective upon the city's hiring of a city manager pursuant to section 1-6-2 of this title. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-
2015)

Title 2
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
Chapter 1
PLAN COMMISSION
2-1-1: CREATION OF COMMISSION:
A plan commission consisting of ten (10) members shall be and the same is hereby created. The mayor and the president of the board of local
improvements shall be an ex officio nonvoting member of the commission. (Ord. 794, 10-7-1974)
2-1-2: TERM OF OFFICE:
The members of the plan commission shall be appointed by the mayor and shall serve with the consent of the council. Each member of the present plan
commission is hereby reappointed for the term for which such member has heretofore been appointed by the mayor and the city council. Successors to
the members so appointed are to be appointed for terms of four (4) years. One member of the plan commission shall be selected as chairman of the plan
commission. The chairman shall be selected after recommendation by majority vote of the members of the plan commission and shall be appointed after
obtaining approval by the mayor and consent of the city council. The term of chairman shall be for a period of one year unless the term such member is
serving is less than one year in which event he shall be appointed for the balance of his term as a member on the plan commission. The chairman shall
preside at all meetings of the plan commission and shall designate a member of the plan commission to act as chairman in his absence. (Ord. 794, 10-7-
1974)
2-1-3: POWERS OF COMMISSION:
The plan commission shall have the following powers:
(A) To prepare and recommend to the council a comprehensive plan of public improvements looking to the present and future development of the city,
such plan after its adoption by the council, to be known as the official plan of the city. The commission may thereafter, from time to time, recommend
any changes in the official plan. The plan may include reasonable requirements in reference to streets, alleys and public grounds in unsubdivided lands
within the corporate limits and in contiguous territory outside of and distant not more than one and one-half (11/2) miles from such limits and not
included in any city, village, or incorporated town, such requirements to be effective whenever such lands shall be subdivided after the adoption of the
plan.
(B) To prepare and recommend to the council and board of local improvements, from time to time, plans for specific improvements in pursuance of the
official plan.
(C) To give aid to the officials of the city charged with the direction of projects for improvements embraced within the official plan, to further the making of
such improvements and generally to promote the realization of the official plan1. (1950 Code)
2-1-4: ALTERNATE MEMBERS:
(A) The mayor with the approval of the city council may appoint two (2) alternate members of the plan commission. The mayor shall designate a first
alternate and second alternate member. Alternate members shall serve in the order of their designation.
(B) Term of the alternate members of the plan commission shall be for four (4) years.
(C) When a regular appointed member is absent for any reason from a meeting of the plan commission, an alternate member shall have such powers and
may exercise such duties as a regularly appointed member. (Ord. 1025, 1-7-1980)
(D) When there is a vacancy of a regular member and a new appointment is to be made, the alternate member who has been designated first alternate
shall then be appointed as a regular member. When the first alternate member is appointed as a regular member, the second alternate member shall
become the first alternate member. The second alternate member shall become the first alternate member and the new appointment shall be the
second alternate member. (Ord. 1113, 11-2-1981)
Chapter 2
AIRPORT BOARD
2-2-1: AIRPORT ESTABLISHED:
The Dixon Airport, Charles R. Walgreen Field shall be located on the following described premises, as supplemented from time to time by acquisitions of
real estate made by the city council for Dixon Airport purposes:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 47/357
Part of the Southeast Quarter (SE 1/4) and part of the Southwest Quarter (SW 1/4) of Section 3, Township 21 North, Range 9 East of the Fourth Principal
Meridian, Lee County, Illinois, bounded and described as follows: Beginning at the Northeast corner of the said Southeast Quarter (SE 1/4) of Section 3;
thence southerly on the East Line of said Section 3 a distance of 2504.0 feet to the Northerly Right of Way line of the Chicago and Northwestern Railway
Company; thence westerly on the said Northerly Right of Way line a distance of 4651.30 feet to a point 2000 feet west of the East line of the said
Southwest Quarter (SW 1/4) of Section 3; thence Northerly parallel with the said East line of the Southwest Quarter (SW 1/4) a distance of 848.8 feet;
thence Northeasterly at an angle of 99° 52' measured counterclockwise from the last described course a distance of 2029.8 feet to the said East line of the
Southwest Quarter (SW 1/4); thence Northerly on the said East line of the Southwest Quarter (SW 1/4) a distance of 546.6 feet thence westerly
perpendicular to the last described course a distance of 396.0 feet; thence Northerly parallel with the said East line of the Southwest Quarter (SW 1/4) a
distance of 528.0 feet; thence easterly perpendicular to the last described course a distance of 396.0 feet to the said East line of the Southwest Quarter
(SW 1/4); thence extending easterly parallel with the North line of the said Southeast Quarter (SE 1/4) a distance of 161.04 feet; thence Northerly parallel
with the west line of the said Southeast Quarter (SE 1/4) a distance of 330.0 feet to the North line of the said Southeast Quarter (SE 1/4); thence easterly
on the said North line of the Southeast Quarter (SE 1/4) a distance of 2483.06 feet to the said point of beginning.
(Ord. 2985, 12-7-2015)
2-2-2: MANAGEMENT OF AIRPORT; AIRPORT MANAGER:
The Dixon Airport shall be under the jurisdiction and control of the city manager. The city manager may appoint an airport manager, who shall report to the
director of public works. The qualifications of the airport manager shall be as prescribed from time to time by the city council. (Ord. 2985, 12-7-2015)
2-2-3: AIRPORT BOARD; MEMBERSHIP:
The city council shall appoint an airport board to advise the city council and the city manager on all matters relating to the Dixon Airport. The airport board
shall be advisory only. The airport board shall make no purchase, lease, agreement, expenditure, sale of property or personnel decision without the prior
consent of the city council. The airport board shall consist of five (5) members who, excepting in case of appointments to fill vacancies, shall hold office for
three (3) years and until their successors are appointed. The mayor, with the consent and approval of the city council, on or before January 1 of each year
shall appoint members to succeed the members whose terms expire. The mayor, with the consent and approval of the city council, may remove any
member at any time. (Ord. 2985, 12-7-2015)
2-2-4: VACANCIES; NO COMPENSATION:
Vacancies on the airport board, caused by removals, resignations, death or otherwise, shall be reported to the city council and shall be filled in like manner
as the original appointments. No member of the airport board shall receive compensation for his or her services as such. (Ord. 2985, 12-7-2015)
2-2-5: OFFICERS; RULES:
The airport board shall, from its members, elect a president and a secretary, and shall make and adopt such rules, bylaws and regulations for their own
guidance and action as may to them seem expedient and not inconsistent with the best interests of the Dixon Airport, and which shall not be in conflict with
any of the provisions of this code or other laws and policies of the city. (Ord. 2985, 12-7-2015)
2-2-6: FINANCES:
The city council shall have control of the expenditures of all monies collected, levied or donated to the credit of the Dixon Airport fund, subject to the
recommendation of the airport board. All monies received for the Dixon Airport shall be deposited in the treasury of the city to the credit of the Dixon
Airport, and the treasurer shall keep the funds separate and apart from any other monies of the city. The treasurer may draw upon the Dixon Airport fund
solely for properly authorized expenditures by the city council or by the city manager in accordance with the city's procurement policy. The treasurer shall
provide the airport board with a monthly financial statement of the Dixon Airport fund. (Ord. 2985, 12-7-2015)
2-2-7: REPORTS OF AIRPORT BOARD:
The airport board shall render written reports of each meeting to the city council or as may be further requested by the mayor from time to time. (Ord.
2985, 12-7-2015)
2-2-8: CITY NOT LIABLE FOR DEBTS:
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as any obligation or liability of the city to levy any tax or expend any city money, or assume any liability to pay
any existing or future encumbrances of the foregoing described real estate, or to pay any obligation created by the airport board or any indebtedness or
obligation created or arising on account of the Dixon Airport. (Ord. 2985, 12-7-2015)

BOARD OF LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS

The mayor shall be a member and president of the board of local improvements. (1950 Code)

Chapter 4
EMERGENCY SERVICES AND DISASTER AGENCY (ESDA)
2-4-1: ESTABLISHMENT:
There is hereby created within the city an entity to be known as the emergency services and disaster agency, hereinafter referred to as the ESDA. This
entity shall be responsible for the coordination of all emergency management programs within its jurisdiction and with private organizations, other political
subdivisions, and the state and federal government in accordance with the provisions of the Illinois emergency management act of 19921 (hereinafter "the
act").
The purpose of the ESDA shall be the coordination of emergency services functions which may be necessary or proper to prevent, minimize, repair or
alleviate injury and damage resulting from any natural or technological cause.
The ESDA shall consist of the coordinator and such additional members as may be selected by the coordinator.
All emergency services functions of the ESDA shall at all times be in accordance with the provisions of the act and all rules and regulations promulgated
thereunder. (Ord. 1647, 2-18-1992; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-4-2: COORDINATOR:
The coordinator of the city ESDA shall be appointed by the mayor with the consent of the council and shall serve until removed by the same.
The coordinator shall have direct responsibility for the organization, administration, training and operation of the ESDA, subject to the direction and control
of the mayor, as provided by statute.
In the event of the absence, resignation or death or inability to serve as the coordinator, the mayor or any person designated by him shall be and act as
coordinator until a new appointment is made as provided in this chapter. (Ord. 941, 4-3-1978; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-4-3: FUNCTIONS:
The city ESDA shall perform such ESDA functions within the city as shall be prescribed in and by the state emergency operations plan, and programs,
orders, rules and regulations as may be promulgated by the Illinois emergency management agency and/or by the governor, and in addition, shall perform
such duties outside the corporate limits as may be required under mutual aid agreements with any other political subdivision, municipality, or quasimunicipality
entered into as provided in the act. (Ord. 1647, 2-18-1992; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-4-4: SERVICE AS MOBILE SUPPORT TEAM:
All or any members of the city ESDA organization may be designated as members of a mobile support team created by the director of the state of Illinois
emergency management agency or by the governor as provided by law.
The leader of such mobile support team shall be designated by the coordinator of the city ESDA organization.
Personnel of a mobile support team who are city employees or officers, while on duty pursuant to a call to duty by the governor or state director or while
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 49/357
engaged in regularly scheduled training exercises, whether within or without the state, shall receive the compensation and have the powers, duties, rights
and immunities incidental to such employment or office. Any such member who is not a paid officer or employee of the city, while so serving, shall receive
compensation from the state as provided under the act.
Personnel of a mobile support team who suffer disease, injury or death arising out of or in the course of emergency duty, shall for the purposes of benefits
under the workers' compensation act or workers' occupational disease act only, be deemed to be employees of the state of Illinois.
All personnel of mobile support teams shall, while on duty under such call, be reimbursed by the state of Illinois for all actual and necessary travel and
subsistence expenses, as provided in the act. (Ord. 1647, 2-18-1992; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-4-5: AGREEMENTS WITH OTHER POLITICAL SUBDIVISIONS:
The coordinator may, in collaboration with other public agencies within his immediate vicinity, develop or cause to be developed mutual aid arrangements
with other political subdivisions within this state for reciprocal disaster response and recovery assistance in case a disaster is too great to be dealt with
unassisted. Any mutual aid agreements shall be consistent with the state emergency operations plan and state emergency management program. No
such mutual aid agreement shall be effective until it has been approved by the council and by the other political subdivision or subdivisions as provided by
law. (Ord. 1647, 2-18-1992; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-4-6: EMERGENCY ACTION:
If the governor proclaims that a disaster emergency exists in the event of actual enemy attack upon the United States or the occurrence within the state of
Illinois of a major disaster resulting from enemy sabotage or other hostile action, or from manmade or natural disaster, it shall be the duty of the city ESDA
to cooperate fully with the Illinois emergency management agency and with the governor in the exercise of emergency powers as provided by law. (Ord.
1647, 2-18-1992; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-4-7: COMPENSATION:
Members of the ESDA who are paid employees or officers of the city, if called for training by the state director of the Illinois emergency management
agency, shall receive for the time spent in such training the same rate of pay as is attached to the position held. Members who are not such city employees
or officers shall receive for such training time such compensation as may be established by the council. (Ord. 1647, 2-18-1992; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-
2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-4-8: REIMBURSEMENT BY STATE:
The state treasurer may receive and allocate to the appropriate fund, any reimbursement by the state to the city for expenses incident to training members
of the ESDA as prescribed by the state director of the Illinois emergency management agency, compensation for services and expenses of members of a
mobile support team while serving outside the city in response to a call by the governor or state director of the Illinois emergency management agency or
other political subdivision pursuant to a mutual aid agreement as provided by law, and any other reimbursement made by the state incident to ESDA
activities as provided by law. (Ord. 1647, 2-18-1992; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-4-9: PURCHASES AND EXPENDITURES:
The council may, upon recommendation of the city coordinator of ESDA, authorize any purchase or contracts and incur obligations necessary to place it in
a position to effectively combat such disasters in order to protect the health and safety of persons and to protect property, and to provide emergency
assistance to victims of those disasters.
In event of enemy caused or other disaster, the city coordinator of ESDA is authorized, on behalf of the city, to procure such services, supplies, equipment
or material as may be necessary for such purposes, in view of the exigency, without regard to the statutory procedures or formalities normally prescribed
by law pertaining to city contracts or obligations, as authorized by the act, provided, that if the council meets at such time, the city coordinator shall act
subject to the directions and restrictions imposed by that body. (Ord. 1647, 2-18-1992; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-4-10: OATH:
Every person appointed to serve in any capacity in the city ESDA organization shall, before entering upon his duties, subscribe to the following oath, which
shall be filed with the coordinator:
I, , do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support and defend and bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of the United States and the
Constitution of the State of Illinois, and the territory, institutions, and facilities thereof, both public and private, against all enemies, foreign and domestic;
that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties upon which I
am about to enter. And I do further swear (or affirm) that I do not advocate, nor am I nor have I been a member of any political party or organization that
advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this State by force or violence; and that during such time as I am affiliated with the
Dixon ESDA organization, I will not advocate nor become a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government
of the United States or of this State by force or violence.
(Ord. 941, 4-3-1978; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-4-11: OFFICE:
The mayor is authorized to designate space in a city building, or elsewhere, as may be provided for by the council for the city ESDA as its office. (Ord.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 50/357
941, 4-3-1978; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-4-12: APPROPRIATIONS; LEVY OF TAXES:
The council may make an appropriation for ESDA purposes in the manner provided by law, and may levy in addition for ESDA purposes only, a tax to
exceed five cents ($0.05) per one hundred dollars ($100.00) of the assessed value of all taxable property in addition to all other taxes, as provided by 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-3-16; however, that amount collectible under such levy shall in no event exceed twenty five cents ($0.25) per capita. (Ord.
1647, 2-18-1992; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-4-13: ORDERS, RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The city council shall have the authority to promulgate orders, rules and regulations upon the advice of the ESDA coordinator for the purpose of
emergency management and in times of disaster, so long as such orders, rules and regulations are not inconsistent with and permissible under the state
emergency operations plan, programs, orders, rules and regulations of the Illinois emergency management agency and/or the governor, or the act.
The ESDA shall execute and enforce such orders, rules and regulations as may be made by the governor under the authority of the act. The ESDA shall
have available for inspection at its office all orders, rules and regulations made by the governor, or under the governor's authority and which have been
provided by the Illinois emergency management agency. (Ord. 1647, 2-18-1992; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-4-14: LOCAL DISASTER DECLARATIONS:
A local disaster may be declared only by the mayor, or his interim emergency successor, as provided in the emergency interim executive succession act2.
It shall not be continued or renewed for a period in excess of seven (7) days except by or with the consent of the council. Any order or proclamation
declaring, continuing, or terminating a local disaster shall be given prompt and general publicity and shall be filed promptly with the city clerk. (Ord. 1647,
2-18-1992; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-4-15: LIMITATIONS:
(A) Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to interfere with the course or conduct of a labor dispute, except that actions otherwise authorized by this
chapter or other laws may be taken when necessary to mitigate imminent or existing danger to public health or safety.
(B) Interfere with dissemination of news or comment of public affairs; but any communications facility or organization (including, but not limited to, radio
and television stations, wire services and newspapers) may be requested to transmit or print public service messages furnishing information or
instructions in connection with a disaster.
(C) Affect the jurisdiction or responsibilities of police forces, firefighting forces, units of the armed forces of the United States, or any personnel thereof,
when on active duty; but state and political subdivision emergency operations plans shall place reliance upon the forces available for performance of
functions related to emergency management.
