Each application for an excavation permit shall be subject to such conditions and requirements as are herein and hereinafter set forth. (Ord. 2781, 5-3-
2010)
3-2-6: APPLICATION PERMIT; DEPOSITS:
Each application for an excavation permit shall state the name of the person desiring to make such excavation, the purpose for which the excavation is to
be made and the person for which the excavation is to be made, the location of the cut in the street, the house number and street name or lot and block
number and name of addition, and type of street surface to be cut. A two hundred dollar ($200.00) deposit shall be required for all excavations, including,
but not limited to, excavations in concrete pavement or sidewalk, bituminous concrete, brick pavement or sidewalk, tarvia or gravel street, or a dirt road.
Provided, however, if a person or business entity has been a registered contractor with the city of Dixon building department for a period in excess of one
year and maintains said registration in accordance with title 7, chapter 1 of this code, said person or business entity may pay a five hundred dollar
($500.00) deposit for multiple openings, not to exceed eight (8) in number at one time. (Ord. 2781, 5-3-2010)
3-2-7: APPLICATION PERMIT; REQUIREMENTS:
The application and permit shall state that the person to whom the permit shall be issued agrees to prosecute the excavation work, and backfilling with the
utmost vigor, with as little delay and inconvenience to the public and the city as possible, in strict conformity with the provisions of this code, with provisions
of all barricades, flares, lights, signs, and any other safeguards as are necessary or shall be deemed necessary by the building official; the person desiring
to obtain an excavation permit shall further agree to remove all surplus materials of whatever nature from the excavation site and restore the site to as
good or better condition than existed before excavation commenced, to perform all work in conjunction with the particular excavation so as to comply with
all requirements as shall be set forth by this code, to hold and save harmless and indemnify the city, its agents, officers, and employees from any liability or
responsibilities for damages to any person or property injured by the performance of any excavation work or by the carelessness or neglect of the person
to whom the permit shall be issued or persons to whom the permit shall have been issued. All permits issued pursuant to this chapter shall expire ninety
(90) days after date of issuance. Upon request, the building official may grant an extension at the time of issuance for jobs which would require additional
time. No extension shall be permitted to extend beyond three hundred sixty five (365) days from the date issued. (Ord. 2781, 5-3-2010)
3-2-8: FRANCHISE HOLDERS:
(A) No permit shall be issued to any person or business entity not registered as a contractor in accordance with title 7, chapter 1 of this code.
(B) Utilities having a current franchise agreement with the city of Dixon shall notify the building department in writing prior to the commencement of
construction of any street opening. In case of an emergency, notification may be provided after the completion of the work, but in no instance later than
ten (10) days after the work has commenced. (Ord. 2781, 5-3-2010)
3-2-9: BACKFILLING:
All trenches and excavations shall be backfilled to the natural line or finished surface as rapidly as the condition of the utility will permit or within thirty (30)
days of the date the permit is issued, whichever is sooner. The backfill material shall consist of the excavated material or of trench backfill, as herein
specified. All backfill material shall be deposited in the trench or excavation in such a manner as not to damage the utility. The filling of the trench shall be
carried on simultaneously on both sides of the pipe in such a manner that injurious side pressures do not occur. The backfill for trenches and excavations
made in the subgrade and for all trenches outside of the subgrade where the inner edge of the trench is within two feet (2') of the edge of the pavement,
curb, or gutter, shall be made with trench backfill material unless the excavated material meets the requirements of the city.
All backfill material up to the height of twelve inches (12") above the pipe shall be carefully deposited in uniform layers not exceeding four inches (4") thick
(loose measure). The material in each layer shall be firmly compacted by ramming or tamping with tools approved by the city, in such a manner as not to
disturb or injure the pipe. The backfilling above this height, except trench backfill or excavated material meeting the requirements of state highway backfill
material, shall be done by one of the following methods:
Method 1: The material shall be deposited in uniform layers not exceeding twelve inches (12") thick (loose material), and each layer shall be compacted by
ramming or tamping with tools approved by the city.
Method 2: The material shall be deposited in uniform layers not exceeding twelve inches (12") thick (loose measure), and each layer shall be either
inundated or deposited in water.
Method 3: The trench shall be backfilled with loose material, and settlement secured by introducing water through holes jetted into the backfill to a point
approximately two feet (2') above the top of the pipe. The holes shall be spaced as directed by the inspector but shall be no farther than six feet (6') apart.
The water shall be injected at a pressure just sufficient to sink the holes at a moderate rate of speed. The pressure shall be such that the water will not cut
cavities in the backfill material nor overflow the surface. If water does overflow the surface, it shall be drained into the jetted holes by means of shallow
trenches. Water shall be injected as long as it will be absorbed by the backfill material and until samples taken from test holes in the trench show an
approved moisture content. The contractor shall bore the test holes not more than fifty feet (50') apart and at such other locations in the trench as
designated by the engineer. As soon as the water soaking has been completed, all the holes shall be filled with soil and compacted by ramming with a tool
approved by the inspector.
Backfill material which has been water soaked shall be allowed to settle and dry for at least ten (10) days before any surface course or pavement is
construed on it. The length of time may be altered if deemed necessary by the inspector. Where the inner edge of the trench is within two feet (2') of the
edge of the pavement, curb, gutter or curb and gutter, the provisions of this paragraph shall apply also.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 67/357
At the end of the settling and drying period, the crusted top of the backfill material shall be scarified, and, if necessary, sufficient backfill material added, as
specified in method 1 of this section, to complete the backfilling operations.
Trench backfill material or excavated material meeting city requirements and above the first twelve inches (12") above the pipe, shall be compacted by
either method 2 or method 3 of this section.
The method used for backfilling and compacting the backfill material shall be at the discretion of the contractor. However, if the method used by the
contractor does not produce results satisfactory to the building inspector, the contractor shall be required to alter or change the method being used to a
method approved by the building inspector.
When sheeting and bracing have been used, sufficient bracing shall be left across the trench as the backfilling progresses to hold the sides as firmly in
place as practicable. Any depressions which may develop within the area involved in the construction operation due to settlement of the backfilling material
shall be filled in a manner meeting the approval of the engineer. (Ord. 2781, 5-3-2010)
3-2-10: PAVEMENT REPLACEMENT:
The existing pavement shall be removed for a width of one foot (1') along each side of the trench.
If the existing surface is either concrete or brick, the trench backfill material shall be placed to a depth of eight inches (8") below the finished surface
elevation. The surface shall then be replaced by pouring and finishing an eight inch (8") concrete slab of class SI concrete to meet the existing surface.
If the existing surface is bituminous concrete over aggregate, the trench backfill shall be placed to a depth of ten inches (10") below the finished surface
elevation. An eight inch (8") concrete slab of class SI concrete shall then be placed to a depth of two inches (2") below the existing surface and a
bituminous concrete surface (B-5 or I-11) shall be placed and thoroughly compacted to meet the existing surface.
Cold patch material or concrete with a double layer of five (5) mil poly (minimum) separation may be used to surface the trench only as a temporary
measure when hot mix material is not available. Within thirty (30) days of hot mix material being available, the cold patch or concrete shall be removed and
replaced by hot mix.
If the existing surface is bituminous concrete over brick or concrete, the trench backfill shall be placed to a depth of ten inches (10") below the existing
surface. An eight inch (8") concrete slab of class SI concrete shall then be placed to a depth of two inches (2") below the existing surface. A two inch (2")
hot mix surface shall then be placed and compacted over the concrete slab after it has been cured and primed.
Cold patch material or concrete with a double layer of five (5) mil poly (minimum) separation may be used to surface the trench only as a temporary
surface until hot mix material is available. Within thirty (30) days of hot mix material being available, the cold patch or concrete shall be removed and
replaced by hot mix.
When the existing surface is gravel or crushed stone, the trench backfill material shall be placed to a depth of eight inches (8") below the existing surface.
Eight inches (8") of crushed stone surface course shall then be placed and compacted to meet the existing surface. (Ord. 2781, 5-3-2010)
3-2-11: TUNNELING UNDER STREETS:
No person shall be permitted to tunnel under any street, alley, sidewalk, road, pavement or public place unless authorized by the city. (Ord. 2781, 5-3-
2010)
3-2-12: INTERFERING WITH ACCESS TO VITAL EQUIPMENT:
Excavation work done by any person shall be performed and conducted so as not to interfere with access to fire hydrants, fire stations, fire escapes, water
gates, hospitals and any other vital equipment designated by the city. (Ord. 2781, 5-3-2010)
3-2-13: PROTECT ADJOINING PROPERTY:
Any person making an excavation shall at all times and at his own expense preserve and protect from damage or injury all adjoining property by providing
proper sheeting, bracing, shoring, and drainage. The person making the excavation shall be solely responsible for all damage to public or private property
resulting from or occasioned by the excavation. On all excavations in any public place in the city the person making the excavation shall provide at his own
expense such barriers, barricades, fences, lights, flares, torches, sign and warning devices as the building official shall require for safety and for
convenience of any or all the general public. (Ord. 2781, 5-3-2010)
3-2-14: REFUND OF DEPOSITS; LIEN:
(A) Deposits shall be kept separate from the other city funds. After the person to whom the permit has been issued has completed all requirements as set
forth in this code, said person shall return the permit copy marked "For Deposit Return" to the building official. The building official shall inspect said
excavation site and if all code requirements have been met to his satisfaction, the building official shall sign said copy and forward it to the city
treasurer who shall refund the amount deposited for the specific excavation.
(B) A deposit for multiple openings shall be retained by the city building department until a request for refund is made by the contractor. Upon completion
and approval of all work performed under all open permits issued to the contractor, the building official shall authorize the city treasurer to refund the
deposit.
(C) If within thirty (30) days of the date the permit was issued or on such date otherwise specified in the permit, the person to whom the permit was issued
has not restored the street, alley, sidewalk, pavement or public place to as good a condition as prior to the opening as determined by the building
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 68/357
official or his designee, the deposit shall be used by the city to restore the excavated area to as good a condition and such portion, if any, of the deposit
not expended to complete the restoration shall be refunded to the depositor. Any costs incurred by the city in excess of the deposit shall be reimbursed
to the city by the applicant within thirty (30) days of the date the city requests reimbursement for payment of the costs incurred in excess of the deposit.
(D) Such cost, if not paid within said thirty (30) days, shall be a lien upon the real estate affected if, within sixty (60) days thereafter, the city or the person
performing the repair work files notice of lien in the office of the recorder of deeds. Such notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting out: 1) a
description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof, 2) the amount of money incurred or payable for the repair work, 3) the date, or dates,
when such costs and expense were incurred. The person to whom the tax bill was sent for the general taxes on the property for the last preceding year
shall be served a copy of the notice of lien; service shall be made personally or by certified mail.
(E) Upon payment of the cost and expense after notice of lien has been filed, the city or person in whose name the lien has been filed shall provide a
release of lien. (Ord. 2781, 5-3-2010)
3-2-15: VIOLATION:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter or failing or neglecting to comply with any requirements shall be deemed guilty of a separate
misdemeanor for each and every day during any part of which such violation or noncompliance occurs. Any person who violates any provisions of this
chapter may further be refused any permits until he shall have complied with the provisions of this chapter. Any incidence of violation of this chapter shall
be cause for the building official to immediately revoke or suspend an excavation permit without prejudice to other action on the violation. (Ord. 2781, 5-3-
2010)
Chapter 3
STREET OBSTRUCTIONS
3-3-1: ENCROACHMENTS PROHIBITED:
No person shall make or cause to be made any enclosure, bay window, building or structure of any kind upon, over or across any street, alley or sidewalk.
(1950 Code)
3-3-2: BUILDING MATERIAL:
No contractor, builder or other person shall, with any building material, encumber or obstruct more than one-third (1/3) of the driveway portion of any street
or alley or one-half (1/2) of any sidewalk; nor shall such obstruction continue in any case longer than may be necessary in the diligent and prompt
execution of his work. (1950 Code)
3-3-3: REMOVAL OF OBSTRUCTIONS:
The owner of any building, fence or other structure which extends into or encroaches upon any street, alley or sidewalk shall remove it. The council may
direct the removal of such obstruction or encroachment at the expense of the person maintaining, causing or erecting it. (1950 Code)
3-3-4: THROWING ASHES OR DEBRIS:
No person shall throw, place or leave or permit to be thrown, placed or left, any ashes, dirt, filth, garbage, rubbish or the sweepings from any building in or
upon any street, alley or sidewalk. (1950 Code)
3-3-5: SNOW OR WATER ON SIDEWALKS:
(A) No person shall pile, deposit or cause to be piled or deposited or allow any other entity with which it has contracted, to cause to be piled or deposited,
any snow or ice upon or against a fire hydrant or upon any sidewalk or upon a public right of way, except for the public right of way immediately
adjacent to the person's property. Further, no person shall pile or cause to be piled any snow so as to obstruct the vision of any intersection of any
street, avenue, boulevard or alley within the city. (Ord. 1918, 12-18-1995)
(B) Every owner and every person in charge or control of any building or lot of land in any area of the city zoned "B-1 limited neighborhood business
district", or "B-2 general business district", or "CBD central business district", shall remove and clear away or cause to be removed and cleared away
snow, ice, sleet, or freezing rain from the sidewalks in front or abutting said lands within twenty four (24) hours after the cessation of any fall of snow,
ice, sleet, or freezing rain. In the event snow, ice, sleet, or freezing rain on a sidewalk has become so hard that it cannot reasonably be removed, the
owner and/or person in charge or control shall cause enough sand or suitable abrasive material to be put on the sidewalk to make travel thereon
reasonably safe and shall maintain the sidewalk in such condition until weather permits the owner to clear the sidewalk. (Ord. 2685, 3-17-2008)
(C) Any person found guilty of violating this section, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not exceeding five
hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as
such hereunder. (Ord. 2565, 1-3-2006)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 69/357
3-3-6: MERCHANDISE ON SIDEWALKS:
No person, while receiving or delivering goods, wares or merchandise, shall permit them to remain on any sidewalk longer than two (2) hours, and, for this
purpose, shall occupy only so much of the outer edge of the sidewalk in front of a building as will leave an unoccupied space of at least four feet (4') in
width of any such sidewalk for the use of pedestrians. (1950 Code)
3-3-7: USE FOR STORAGE OR DISPLAY:
(A) Daily storage and display of wares, merchandise and other material adjacent to a building shall be allowed on streets, sidewalks, alleys, parkways or
public places; providing, such public display and usage does not exceed thirty six inches (36") on said sidewalk or said public place.
(B) On special occasions, permission may be granted by the mayor to ban automobile traffic from streets, alleys, parkways and public places, and
approval given to use sidewalk areas for display and sale of wares, merchandise and other material; providing, adequate pedestrian thoroughfares are
allowed and pedestrian safety is maintained. (Ord. 703, 8-7-1972)
3-3-8: REMOVAL OF TOOLS AND MATERIALS:
Whoever constructs, builds or repairs any street, alley or sidewalk shall remove all materials, tools, appliances or other articles used in or about said
construction, building or repairing within twenty four (24) hours after the completion of the construction, building or repairing. (1950 Code)
3-3-9: LOADING MATERIALS ACROSS SIDEWALKS:
No person shall load or unload any coal, gravel, stone, grain, junk or other loose materials into or from any railroad car, vehicle, building or bin, where the
same shall be carried across any sidewalk or above the heads of passing pedestrians unless, in such loading or unloading, chutes or carriers shall be
used having sides of sufficient height and strength to prevent the falling of any such materials from such chute or carrier upon sidewalks or persons, and
unless adequate barricades are erected to prevent injury to passing pedestrians. (1950 Code)
3-3-10: SIDEWALK OPENINGS; SPECIFICATIONS; BOND:
Every opening in any sidewalk over any vault or coal hole shall have a metal or cement cover flush with the walk; the upper surfaces shall be roughened
and all parts of the sidewalks, including illuminating tile or other structural parts, shall be capable of sustaining a load at all points simultaneously equal to
four hundred (400) pounds for each superficial foot of the surface thereof. The construction of all vaults and coal holes shall be subject to the supervision
and direction of the commissioner of streets and public improvements or such other officer as may be designated by the council. All persons who maintain
any vault or coal hole shall execute and file with the clerk a bond to the city in such a reasonable sum as may be fixed by the mayor, with good and
sufficient sureties to be approved by him, conditioned that the person will pay all damages that may be recovered against the city by any person on
account of any injuries to person or property occasioned by or in any manner resulting from the coal holes or openings and to save and keep the city free
from all damages and costs which may be incurred in defending such claims1. (1950 Code)
3-3-11: REFLECTIVE MARKINGS ON DUMPSTERS:
(A) No contractor, builder or other person shall allow a dumpster to be parked on a street in the city, unless that dumpster has reflective devices
permanently attached to all four (4) sides of the dumpster.
(B) Any person found guilty of violating this section, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined an amount not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each
day such a violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder. (Ord. 1725,
4-5-1993)
Chapter 4
INJURY TO STREETS, SIDEWALKS OR CITY PROPERTY
3-4-1: PROTECTION OF SIDEWALKS AND CURBS:
No person shall drive, draw or propel any truck or other heavy vehicle across any sidewalk or curb without first protecting the sidewalk or curb from injury
by planking or other adequate protection. No persons shall deface, discolor, mar, or otherwise damage any sidewalk, curb, any other public way or other
area of pedestrian traffic of whatsoever kind or nature within the city. (Ord. 2760, 10-19-2009)
3-4-2: REPAIR WORK; LIABILITY TO CITY:
Any person who shall injure, deface, discolor, mar, or otherwise damage any street, alley, sidewalk, curb, gutter, or any other public way whatsoever, or
any part thereof, or dig any hole, trench, ditch, drain, or dig or remove any sod, stone, curb, earth, sand, or gravel from any street, alley, sidewalk, parkway
or other public way of whatsoever kind or nature shall be responsible and liable to the city for all costs of repair. In addition, any such person shall
indemnify and hold the city harmless from all damages to persons or property in consequence of such damage for which the city is adjudged liable to any
other person or entity. (Ord. 2760, 10-19-2009)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 70/357
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 3140 - CLEANUP AND RESTORATION. Go to new ordinance.
3-4-3: REPAIRING INJURY TO STREETS AND PUBLIC WAYS:
If any person shall break, deface, discolor, mar, or otherwise damage any portion of the pavement of any street, sidewalk, or other public way of
whatsoever kind or nature within the city, he or she shall, within twenty four (24) hours thereafter, cause the same to be restored to as good a condition as
before the damage. In the event such person does not repair the damaged property to as good a condition as before the injury, said person shall be liable
to the city for any and all costs of repair or remediation incurred by the city in repairing said damage. (Ord. 2760, 10-19-2009)
3-4-4: DAMAGE TO UNCOMPLETED WORK:
No person other than the contractor building the same or his employees shall go upon, either by walking, riding or driving, any cement, concrete, asphalt,
bitulithic or other type of hard surfaced sidewalk, pavement, curb or gutter being constructed under employment of the city until the sidewalk, pavement,
curb or gutter has been properly cured or hardened and opened for public use. (Ord. 2760, 10-19-2009)
3-4-5: LIABILITY FOR DAMAGE:
Any person injuring any such pavement, sidewalk, curb, or gutter before it has been properly cured or hardened shall be liable to the city or to the
contractor, as the case may be, for all the costs of repairing the damage. (Ord. 2760, 10-19-2009)
3-4-6: REMOVAL OF BARRIERS:
Where, in the course of making any walk, pavement, curb or gutter, any barriers are placed by a contractor or by the city to prevent the use of the uncured
improvements, no person shall remove them1. (Ord. 2760, 10-19-2009)
3-4-7: INJURY TO PROPERTY:
No person shall wilfully, maliciously, or negligently cut, break, climb on, carry away, conceal, transfer, tamper with, mark on, or in any way injure, damage,
or deface any tree, shrub, plant, turf, grass, statue, bust, lamppost, hydrant, regulating device, transformer, meter, wire, wiring, pole, curbstone, flagstone,
fence, wall, bridge, balustrade, railing, bench, building, or other structure of any kind or property, or take down, alter, mar, move, injure, or destroy any sign,
trailmarker, placard, notice, post, pile, or buoy posted or placed by the city or authorized to be posted or placed by the city engineer or chief of police. (Ord.
2829, 7-5-2011)
3-4-8: USE OF PUBLIC FOUNTAIN:
No person shall bathe, wade in the standing water of, wash clothes or items in, urinate in, defecate in, enter into, or climb on any structure of, nor throw or
otherwise place or cause to be placed any rubbish, waste debris, garbage, refuse or other trash, or any toxic substance, in the waters or fixtures of the
fountain located at the south end of Hennepin Avenue, known as "Heritage Crossing". No person shall allow an animal in their custody or control to commit
any of the above acts. (Ord. 2829, 7-5-2011)
3-4-9: PENALTIES:
Notwithstanding and in addition to the foregoing, any person found guilty of a violation of any provision of this chapter shall be punished by a fine of not
less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). (Ord. 2760, 10-19-2009; amd. Ord. 2829, 7-5-2011)
Chapter 5
NUMBERING OF LOTS
3-5-1: DECIMAL SYSTEM ADOPTED:
The numbering of all lots, houses, or buildings fronting upon the public thoroughfares within the city shall be in conformity with the decimal system and the
regulations following. (Ord. 556, 7-25-1967)
3-5-2: SIZE OF LOT NUMBERED:
Every twenty five feet (25') of street frontage, exclusive of streets and inclusive of alleys, shall, for the purpose of numbering, be deemed a lot and each lot
is hereby provided with a number according to the following plan. (Ord. 556, 7-25-1967)
3-5-3: DIVIDING LINE, NORTH AND SOUTH:
Rock River shall be the dividing line between Dixon and North Dixon as the same are hereinafter designated. (Ord. 556, 7-25-1967)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 71/357
3-5-4: DIVIDING LINE, EAST AND WEST:
Galena Avenue in Dixon and North Galena Avenue in North Dixon shall be the base or dividing line east and west. (Ord. 556, 7-25-1967)
3-5-5: PREFIX TO NAMES OF STREETS:
That portions of all avenues running north and south of Rock River shall have the prefix "North" to the names of all streets, or avenues, that lie north of
Rock River and the prefix "South" to the names of all avenues which lie south of said Rock River; that portions of all streets running east and west and
lying west of Galena Avenue and North Galena Avenue shall have the prefix "West" to their names and that all portions of such streets lying east of
Galena Avenue and North Galena Avenue shall have prefixed to their names the word "East". (Ord. 567, 10-3-1967)
3-5-6: ODD AND EVEN NUMBERS:
On streets running north and south the odd numbers shall be on the west side of the street and the even numbers on the east side of the street; on all
streets running east and west the odd numbers shall be on the north side of the street and the even numbers on the south side of the street. (1950 Code)
3-5-7: WHERE NUMBERING COMMENCES:
In Dixon the numbering of lots on streets running south and north shall commence at 1st Street; in North Dixon the numbering of lots on streets running
north and south shall commence at Rock River. (1950 Code)
3-5-8: NUMBERING BY SERIES OF HUNDREDS:
The numbering of said streets and avenues shall be by series of hundreds as follows: the first twenty five feet (25') in the northeast corner of block number
sixteen in the original town (now city) of Dixon and abutting Galena Avenue shall be numbered 101 and the lot directly opposite in block number seventeen
and abutting Galena Avenue shall be numbered 102 and said numbering shall so continue until all lots abutting Galena Avenue in the blocks have been
numbered; the first twenty five feet (25') in the northeast corner of block number twenty nine in the original town (now city) of Dixon and abutting Galena
Avenue shall be numbered 201 and the first twenty five feet (25') directly opposite in block number twenty eight shall be numbered 202 and so on the
entire length of Galena Avenue, each new set of blocks commencing with a new series of hundreds. On all streets and avenues running parallel or in the
same general direction with Galena Avenue the lots shall be numbered to correspond with the numbering of the corresponding or opposite lots on Galena
Avenue. (1950 Code)
3-5-9: NUMBERING BETWEEN ROCK RIVER AND FIRST STREET:
All lots abutting Galena Avenue and lying between 1st Street and Rock River shall be numbered by commencing with the first twenty five feet (25') on the
southeast corner of block number five in the original town (now city) of Dixon, which shall be numbered 99, and the first twenty five feet (25') directly
opposite, being in the southwest corner of block number four in the original town (now city) of Dixon shall be numbered 98; the next twenty five feet (25')
lying north of and adjoining number 99 in block number five shall be numbered 97, and so on down until all of the lots abutting Galena Avenue in said
block have been numbered. On all streets and avenues running parallel or in the same general direction with Galena Avenue and lying between 1st Street
and Rock River the lots shall be numbered to correspond with the numbering of the corresponding or opposite lots on Galena Avenue. (1950 Code)
3-5-10: SYSTEM APPLIED IN NORTH DIXON:
In North Dixon the lot at the northeast corner of North Galena Avenue and Water Street shall be numbered 102 and the lot at the northwest corner of North
Galena Avenue and Water Street shall be numbered 101. All lots in North Dixon on streets and avenues running parallel with or in the same general
direction as North Galena Avenue shall have numbers corresponding with the opposite lots on North Galena Avenue. (1950 Code)
3-5-11: STREETS EAST AND WEST FROM GALENA AVENUE:
Lots on streets running east and west from Galena Avenue and North Galena Avenue shall be numbered easterly and westerly from said avenue, starting
with numbers 100 and 101 and proceeding in the same manner as is hereinbefore provided for the numbering of Galena Avenue. (1950 Code)
3-5-12: STREETS RUNNING EAST AND WEST NOT INTERSECTING GALENA AVENUE:
Lots on all streets running east and west that do not intersect with Galena Avenue or North Galena Avenue shall be numbered to correspond with the lots
directly opposite on parallel streets. (1950 Code)
3-5-13: NUMBERING OF HOUSES REQUIRED:
All owners of houses shall number their houses in conformity with the foregoing provisions1. (1950 Code)
3-5-14: STREET NAMING COMMITTEE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 72/357
The street naming committee be, and the same is hereby given power and authority to make future changes in street names and to provide that the
changes heretofore made by said committee be made permanent, or until further action is taken by said committee or by the council.
All developers of subdivisions or annexed territory to the city be and they are hereby required to submit street names to said street naming committee
before their presentations of the plats of their subdivisions to the city for its approval. (Ord. 556, 7-25-1967)
3-5-15: NAME CHANGES:
That the following changes shall be made in the names of existing streets in various sections of the city:
(A) That Park Row and Anglo Place in Swarthouts Subdivision shall be and the same is hereby changed to Anglo Court.
(B) That Part Street in River View Subdivision shall be and the same is hereby changed to Doran Street.
(C) That Johnson Street in Steinmann's Subdivision shall be and the same is hereby changed to Steinmann Street.
(D) That Ash Street in Prescott's Second Subdivision shall be and the same is hereby changed to Dorothy Street.
(E) That Marclare Court in Lowell Wilson Subdivision shall be and the same is hereby changed to Brigadoon Drive.
(F) That Forest Avenue extending north of Washington School shall be and the same is hereby changed to Washington Avenue.
(G) That North Forest Drive shall be and the same is hereby changed to East Graham Street.
(H) That South Forest Drive shall be and the same is hereby changed to Sproul Street.
(I) That that portion of Fellows Street lying east of Assembly Place until it intersects with Eustace Drive shall be and the same is hereby changed to
Eustace Drive. (Ord. 567, 10-3-1967)
Chapter 6
TREES AND SHRUBBERY1
3-6-1: PLANTING; PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to plant any trees or bushes in any public street or parkway or any other public place or between the curb line and a distance of five
feet (5') inside the property line of any property without first having secured a permit therefor from the clerk. No such permit shall be issued by the clerk
until the same has been referred to and approved by the commissioner of streets. (Ord. 286, 9-15-1959)
3-6-2: REMOVAL; PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person shall remove or cut down any tree or shrub in any such public place without a permit. Applications for such permits shall be made to the clerk
and shall be referred to and approved by the council before issuance. (1950 Code)
3-6-3: INJURY:
No person shall injure any tree or shrub planted or growing in any public place. (1950 Code)
3-6-4: ADVERTISEMENTS; NOTICES:
No person shall attach any sign, advertisement or notice to any tree or shrub in any public place. (1950 Code)
3-6-5: DANGEROUS TREES:
Any tree or shrub which overhangs any sidewalk, street or other public place in such a way as to impede or interfere with traffic or travel shall be trimmed
by the owner of the premises abutting or of the premises on which the tree or shrub grows so that the obstruction shall cease. (1950 Code)

Chapter 7
CEMETERY REGULATIONS
3-7-1: MANAGEMENT OF CEMETERY:
The City Manager shall have custody of Oakwood Cemetery and supervision over the Superintendent of the cemetery and all employees having duties
concerned with the care and maintenance of said cemetery. (Ord. 3040, 5-15-2017)
3-7-2: PROMULGATION OF REGULATIONS:
Subject to the approval of the City Council, the City Manager shall prescribe the rules and regulations for the government of Oakwood Cemetery and the
sale and use of lots therein. (Ord. 3040, 5-15-2017)
3-7-3: RECORD OF LOTS, VALUES AND SALES TO BE KEPT:
The Clerk shall keep an accurate plat of the Oakwood Cemetery and also a record of the blocks or squares or lots in each division thereof, with the
amounts of the appraised values of the lots or blocks at which the same shall be offered for sale, and, when sold, the name of the purchaser, the amount
sold for, and the date of sale. (Ord. 102, 2-1-1955)
3-7-4: APPLICATION FOR PURCHASE OF CEMETERY LOTS:
All applications for the purchase of cemetery lots shall be made to the Superintendent of Oakwood Cemetery, to the Clerk, or when it is desired to
purchase any lot the title to which has not yet passed to the City but is yet vested in a trustee, then to such trustee. All applications must be accompanied
by a down payment of fifty percent (50%) of the purchase price. No conveyance to the purchaser shall be made until the full amount of the purchase price
of the lot has been paid. All unpaid balances shall accrue interest at the rate of five percent (5%) per annum. (Ord. 2641, 5-21-2007)
3-7-5: CONTRACTS NOW IN FORCE TO CONTINUE:
Nothing contained in this chapter shall be held or taken to impair or modify the terms of a certain contract entered into on behalf of the City under and by
virtue of the terms of an ordinance entitled "an ordinance to provide for the purpose of land to be used as an addition to Oakwood Cemetery, to be owned
and controlled by the City of Dixon", passed by the Council July 3, 1903, and approved by the Mayor July 14, 1903, but said ordinance and any and all
agreements or contracts entered into by virtue thereof, shall be and remain in full force and effect. (Ord. 102, 2-1-1955)
3-7-6: SUPERINTENDENT OF OAKWOOD CEMETERY:
The Director of Public Works shall be the Superintendent of Oakwood Cemetery. (Ord. 3040, 5-15-2017)
3-7-7: CUSTODY OF CEMETERY:
The Superintendent shall, subject to the direction of the Commissioner of Public Property and the Council, have the care, control, charge and management
of the cemetery controlled by the City and known as "Oakwood Cemetery". (Ord. 102, 2-1-1955)
3-7-8: MONTHLY REPORT:
The Superintendent of Oakwood Cemetery, or other person in charge or control of the same, shall, on or before the first Monday in each month, furnish to
the Clerk for the information of the Council a report, in writing, showing the number of interments in the cemetery during the preceding month with the
name, sex, race and color of each person so interred, the date and place of death, the cause of death, and when practicable, the age, occupation,
nationality and place of residence of the deceased together with a report in detail of receipts and disbursements. (Ord. 102, 2-1-1955)
3-7-9: PAYMENT FOR SERVICES RENDERED:
It shall be the duty of the Superintendent of Oakwood Cemetery to collect from the persons for whom work or services are performed in the cemetery such
amounts as shall be prescribed from time to time by the City Council. All foundation work shall be performed by cemetery employees and charges for the
same must be paid in advance prior to commencement of installation. (Ord. 3040, 5-15-2017)
3-7-10: SUPERINTENDENT TO CARE FOR GROUNDS:
The Superintendent of Oakwood Cemetery shall have charge of the cemetery subject to the direction of the City Manager and shall keep and preserve the
buildings, grounds and fences in good order and repair and the monuments, tombstones, shrubbery and every other thing erected and placed in the
cemetery, for ornament or otherwise, free from injury or defacement and the walks and avenues in good condition and free from obstructions. He shall
enforce the provisions of this Code in relation to cemeteries and the rules and regulations established for the government of the same and shall report all
violations. (Ord. 3040, 5-15-2017)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 74/357
3-7-11: BURIAL PERMITS REQUIRED:
No burial or interment shall take place nor shall the body of any person be removed without a permit for such burial or removal from the Clerk. No burial
permit shall be issued unless the purchase price of the lot has been paid in full. No burial or interment shall take place except that of a human being and
no dog, cat or bird or any other previously living animal shall be buried or interred in Oakwood Cemetery or any part thereof, at any time in the future. (Ord.
2641, 5-21-2007)
3-7-12: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT; ISSUANCE:
Any person desiring a burial permit shall file with the Clerk a certificate, in writing, signed by the attending physician or coroner, stating the name, age, sex,
nationality, residence and occupation of the deceased, if known, and the cause or manner of death; and in case of any death where there has been no
attending physician or coroner, the certificate signed by the parent of the deceased; or, if none, by some member of the family, not a minor; or, if none, by
the resident householder, where the death occurred; or, if none, by any reputable citizen acquainted with the facts and circumstances of the death. Upon
the filing of such certificate, the Clerk shall issue a burial permit.
In the event of the absence or inability to act of the Clerk, or Deputy Clerk, the Commissioner of Public Health and Safety is authorized, empowered and
directed to issue such burial permit upon compliance with the requirements of this section. (1950 Code)
3-7-13: RECORD OF BURIAL PERMITS:
It shall be the duty of the Clerk to enter in a suitable book to be kept in his office for that purpose, a record of all permits so issued, specifying the date of
issue, and to whom issued, together with all the items of information contained in the certificates upon which such permits were issued. (1950 Code)
3-7-14: RECORD OF INTERMENTS:
The Superintendent of Oakwood Cemetery, upon receiving the Clerk's permit and making an interment, shall enter the name of the deceased with the date
of interment and the number of the lot in which interred, in a book to be kept for such purpose; he shall make no interment without the delivery to him of a
permit. Double stacking of interments is prohibited. (Ord. 2641, 5-21-2007)
3-7-15: DELIVERY OF CEMETERY PROPERTY TO SUCCESSOR:
The Superintendent, upon the appointment of his successor in office, shall deliver to him all property, books, records, maps and effects of every description
in his possession or under his control belonging to the City or pertaining to his office; and, in case of his neglect or refusal to deliver the same, within three
(3) days after demand being made therefor, he shall be subject to the general penalty provided by this Code. (1950 Code)
3-7-16: RECEIPTS:
All monies, receipts, income and revenue from Oakwood Cemetery collected or received by an officer or employee of the City shall be turned over to the
Clerk who shall give a receipt therefor and keep a separate account of the revenue. (1950 Code)
3-7-17: EXPENDITURES:
The separate fund provided for in section 3-7-16 of this chapter shall be the primary fund and first applied toward defraying the expenses of Oakwood
Cemetery and the disbursements thereof. The remaining expenses, if any, shall be paid from the proper appropriation and levy. (1950 Code)
3-7-18: ENDOWMENTS:
All lots sold in Oakwood Cemetery (including Oaklawn Addition) shall only be sold with the perpetual endowment thereof provided within the sale price of
the lots. Twenty five percent (25%) of the total sale price of the lots in Oakwood Cemetery shall be deposited with the Treasurer to create a perpetual care
endowment fund of the lots.
Each and every lot endowed shall, at all times, be kept to a proper and established grade, well seeded with grass and the grass cut and neatly trimmed
around the base of any and all monuments, trees, shrubbery or bushes placed or growing thereon1. (Ord. 782, 6-3-1974)
3-7-19: DOGS PROHIBITED:
No dog shall be permitted in Oakwood Cemetery. The owner of any dog which is found within Oakwood Cemetery shall be subject to a fine as provided in
section 9-4-7 of this Code. (Ord. 1874, 5-1-1995)
Chapter 8
WATERWORKS SYSTEM
3-8-1: SCOPE; DEFINITIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 75/357
The following rules and regulations specified in this chapter shall be established by the City. Such rules and regulations shall be controlling in the use of
water to the respective water users of the City in the future.
CONSUMER OR CUSTOMER: The person who is responsible for the payment of water bills.
OWNER: The actual owner of the property to be supplied with water service.
UTILITY SERVICE FEE: The utility service fee is comprised of the following, as applicable: a) the actual cost of the installed water meter; b) the deposit
provided for in section 3-8-2 of this chapter; and c) the tapping fee provided for in section 3-8-3 of this chapter.
WATER DIVISION: The Water Division of the City of Dixon, Illinois.
Any references herein to a measurement in diameter shall mean the measurement of the inside diameter, or the applicable industry standards of
measurement thereto. (Ord. 3110, 9-17-2018)
3-8-2: APPLICATION FOR WATER SERVICE:
Any customer desiring water service shall make application through the City website or at City Hall, using forms furnished by the Water Division. The
customer shall make a deposit based upon the size of the water meter to be installed in accordance with the following schedule:
5/8" or 3/4" $ 100.00
1" 125.00
11/2" 175.00
2" 225.00
3" 325.00
4" 425.00
6" 625.00
8" 825.00
10" 1,025.00
Upon the termination of water service in accordance with this chapter, the deposit shall be applied to any outstanding balance remaining on the
customer's final water bill. The remainder of the deposit, if any, after payment of the final water bill shall be returned to the customer. (Ord. 3114, 11-
5-2018)
(A) If a multiple-family dwelling is served by a single meter, the appropriate deposit shall be made based upon the size of the water meter to be installed,
plus an additional deposit of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each additional unit.
(B) For all properties having more than one tenant and only one meter, the meter shall be in the landlord's name. The landlord shall be responsible for
payment of the water bills and any damages to said meter.
(C) Notwithstanding the foregoing, for any person owning more than one property used for leasing to tenants, and provided further that each such property
has more than one meter, then the owner may elect to make a landlord deposit in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). In the event the
amount of the landlord deposit made falls below one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for any reason, the owner shall, within fifteen (15) days of notice
from the City of the same, deposit with the City such amounts as may be necessary to return the landlord deposit on file to one thousand dollars
($1,000.00). In the event the owner fails to return the landlord deposit to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) as required in the preceding sentence, the
landlord deposit option made available pursuant to this subsection (C) shall be unavailable to the owner and such owner shall be required to comply in
all respects with other deposit provisions set forth in this section. (Ord. 3110, 9-17-2018)
3-8-2-1: CONNECTION RESTRICTION:
No customer or owner of property located outside the corporate limits shall be allowed to connect to the City's waterworks system except where
annexation to the City is legally prohibited. Upon removal of the prohibition, the property must be immediately annexed to the City.
Connection to the City waterworks system by a customer located outside the corporate limits of the City shall be allowed only under the following
conditions:
(A) The owner of the property to be connected to the City waterworks system is unable to annex to the City because the property is not adjacent or
contiguous to the City.
(B) The owner of the property agrees in writing to petition the City for annexation to the City when the property becomes contiguous to the City.
Meter Size Fee
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 76/357
(C) Annexation to the City can be anticipated in the foreseeable future.
(D) The City derives and will continue to derive a significant benefit from the user or there is a potential economic benefit from the user that the City will
derive.
(E) The economic benefit derived by the City shall exceed the cost, if any, incurred by the City for the extension of such waterworks service.
(F) The owner or user shall pay the cost of extending waterworks service from existing water lines to the extremities of the property for easy access by
future upstream extensions, and all engineering and maintenance costs. The City may, at its discretion, contribute to the cost of extending the
waterworks line if the City requires the user or owner to install waterworks line of larger than standard size as defined elsewhere in this Code. (Ord.
1519, 2-20-1990)
3-8-3: CONNECTION WITH WATER MAIN:
The Water Division will make the necessary service connection at the water main, the cost of which is to be paid by the owner or contractor. The cost is to
be regulated by the Water Division in accordance with the prevailing cost of labor and materials at the time of installation or replacement.
All new connections from a family dwelling to any water main of the City shall cost the sum of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for services up to one
inch (1"). This section, however, does not apply to installations where the cost of such installation has been paid by the developer of a subdivision, or such
other person as may be applicable pursuant to section 3-8-12 of this chapter.
All commercial and industrial connections to any water main of the City shall require a one thousand dollar ($1,000.00) connection fee and a two hundred
fifty dollar ($250.00) tap fee. In addition, there shall be a two hundred fifty dollar ($250.00) fee if the tapping sleeve and valve are put on by the Water
Division. All materials shall be furnished by the owner or contractor.
The owner shall lay and maintain the service pipe from the water main to the premises and shall, for single-family dwellings, install a Mueller H-15155 or
A.Y. McDonald 6107BQ curb stop in an easily accessible place near the wall where the service pipe enters the building. For multiple-family dwellings, the
owner shall install a separate outside shutoff for each dwelling and a "lock type" stop valve in an easily accessible place near the wall where the service
pipe enters the building. The owner shall also install a valve on the outlet side of the meter. The owner shall install, on every service pipe, a curb stop and
curb box. The curb stop shall be located within the street right-of-way and shall be approximately six feet (6') from the property line.
In the event that repairs to the water service are necessary, existing meter pits must be replaced. The meters must be moved inside the building and the
pits filled in and abandoned.
All new and repaired water service pipes two inches (2") in diameter and smaller shall be type K soft copper pipe or SDR9 ADS polyflex (200 psi rating)
one inch (1") or greater in diameter. All service pipes larger than two inches (2") in diameter shall be ductile iron thickness, Class No. 52 cable bond. The
property owner must install a tracer wire from the water main to the premises. All installations or replacements of water service pipes shall be subject to
the inspection and approval of the City building inspector, consulting engineer or authorized agent of the Water Division.
The type and manufacture of fire hydrants, valves, street boxes and water meters must be in accordance with standard specifications approved by the
Water Division. (Ord. 3110, 9-17-2018)
3-8-4: WATER METERS:
All water used by every water customer shall be measured and recorded with a water meter. The water meter shall be supplied and installed by the Water
Division and shall be and remain at all times the property of the Water Division. The Water Division will install meters that are one inch (1") and smaller into
completed plumbing. All other meters shall be installed by the owner and inspected and approved by the Water Division after installation. For all new
installations, the utility service fee and the costs of installation shall be paid in full, together with hook-on fees and any other fee due to the Water Division
at City Hall before installation shall be made. All new installations or remodeling of properties shall have a smartpoint and, in the Water Manager's
discretion, a touchpad. The water meter shall be installed at a location protected from freezing or heat and other hazards, and the outside reading device
(remote transmitter), if any, shall be installed at a point that is visible from the front or side street. It shall be the customer's responsibility to keep the meter
from being damaged or frozen. If such damage or freezing occurs, it shall be the customer's responsibility to pay for the costs of replacement or repair,
including any applicable charges or fees provided for herein as a result. The cost of all water meters shall be established from time to time by the Water
Manager. Forty five (45) days after installation of a new meter, the prior meter will be disposed of by the Water Division. Customers shall have the
opportunity, during such forty five (45) day period, to dispute the accuracy of the removed meter. Any commercial building served with water service shall
include in the meter installation a proper bypass, approved by the Water Division, which allows for continued use of water when a meter is removed for
maintenance or testing. Lock valves shall also be included on such bypasses at the owner's expense.
Charges for testing residential, commercial and industrial meters shall be based on the actual cost for labor and materials expended by the Water Division.
Should the customer desire the test to be made, the Water Division employee will, in the customer's presence, seal the meter before he leaves the
customer's presence. If the results of the water meter test indicate that the meter is measuring higher than the standards set forth by the American Water
Works Association (AWWA), then the meter shall be repaired or replaced at no cost to the customer and all testing fees shall be reimbursed.
When the water meter fails to register, the charge for water used during the period of non-registration will be determined from an average corresponding
period. When such an average is obviously unfair to either the customer or the Water Division, an average will be agreed to by both parties. If both parties
cannot agree, all the facts will be submitted to the City Council and their decision will be final.
Illegal use of water or of property of the Water Division or of the meter devices shall result in criminal prosecution. (Ord. 3110, 9-17-2018)
3-8-5: PROTECTION OF WATER DIVISION PROPERTY:
All piping, gauges, appliances, equipment and other devices installed by the Water Division, and all water meters, regardless of who performed the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 77/357
installation, which may be in or about the customer's premises shall be and remain the property of the Water Division. The customer shall protect and be
responsible for such property in the case of loss or damages. Only authorized agents of the Water Division will be permitted to remove, install or replace
such property. The owner or customer shall maintain free access to all Water Division property. The owner or customer shall not store or construct any
obstacles which will interfere with the reading, repairing or removal of the water meter. The owner shall keep his or her curb box and curb stop free from
obstruction so that the water can be turned on or off whenever necessary without delay. (Ord. 3110, 9-17-2018)
3-8-6: ACCESS TO PREMISES:
Authorized agents of the Water Division shall at all reasonable hours have access to the premises for the purpose of inspecting the customer's installation
and of reading, repairing, testing, terminating service, restoring service or removing the water meter or other Water Division property. All authorized agents
of the Water Division can and shall present an identification card if asked to do so. Upon the presentation of the card, the authorized agent shall have free
access at any reasonable hour to any premises supplied with City water for the purpose of making an inspection of the entire supply, upon the premises or
reading or repairing the water meter or other Water Division property. Failure to allow access to premises will result in termination of service. Cost of
terminating service and service restoration will be the responsibility of the property owner. (Ord. 3110, 9-17-2018)
3-8-7: DISCONTINUING OF SERVICE FOR REPAIRS:
When it is necessary for the Water Division to interrupt water service for the purpose of repairing or extending the main, it will endeavor to give notice of
interruption and shut off the water at a time when it will cause the least inconvenience to the customer. In case of a break in the main or pumping
equipment requiring an immediate shutdown or interruption of service, the Water Division shall not be required to provide prior notice to its customers. All
boilers or tanks on the customer's premises that are connected directly with the service pipe shall be provided with reduced pressure zone backflow
preventers that adequately prevent their collapse in the event water is suddenly shut off. Only persons authorized by the Water Manager shall turn on or
off water valves or curb stops. (Ord. 3110, 9-17-2018)
3-8-8: NOTICE TO PLUMBERS AND EXCAVATORS:
All plumbers and contractors shall contact the Manager of the Water Division prior to performing any excavating. The Water Manager or his or her
authorized representatives will mark the appropriate location of any underground water main or service. The plumber or contractor shall take every
precaution to prevent damage to the water main or service pipe. If any damages do occur, the plumber or person that caused the damage shall pay the
cost of repairing same to the Water Division. The person causing the damage to the water main or service shall also be responsible for any other liability
resulting from the broken service pipe or water main. No person shall tap, repair, change or otherwise disturb the mains or service pipes without the
permission of the Water Manager or his or her authorized representative. (Ord. 3110, 9-17-2018)
3-8-9: FIRE HYDRANTS:
Fire hydrants are for the use of the Fire Division for the purpose of extinguishing fires. Persons other than members of the Fire Division and persons
authorized by the Water Manager shall not open or attempt to draw water from any fire hydrant.
(A) Filling of swimming pools from a fire hydrant is prohibited. In addition, filling of tanker trucks from fire hydrants is prohibited.
(B) Any party requesting water from a fire hydrant shall be responsible to make application at City Hall. The party shall be charged the normal water rate
as specified in this Code, plus a twenty five dollar ($25.00) setting fee and the required deposit as established from time to time by the Water Division.
The setting fee shall include the installation and removal of a hydrant meter. The deposit will be applied to the final water bill. In addition, all tanker
trucks must fill at the water plant and not at the hydrants. No hydrant may be operated without the prior permission of the Water Manager or his or her
designee. (Ord. 3110, 9-17-2018)
3-8-10: PAYMENT OF WATER BILLS:
(A) Billings:
1. Due Date; Delinquency: All water bills shall be paid on or before the due dates as noted on the water bill. A bill becomes delinquent twenty two (22)
days after rendition of the bill for such services. A ten percent (10%) penalty shall be assessed and added to all delinquent bills. If the bill, together
with any applicable penalty charge, is not paid within such period, service may be discontinued and terminated pursuant to section 3-8-16 of this
chapter. An administrative fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be applied to all bills not paid within thirty eight (38) days from the bill statement period. In
such cases where service has been discontinued pursuant to section 3-8-16 of this chapter, the water service will not be reconnected until the water
bill has been paid in full.
2. Billing: Bills and notices shall be mailed to the customer's last address as shown by the records of the Water Division. If the customer has elected to
receive water bills electronically, said bill will be sent to the last email address on file with the Water Division.
3. Paperless Billing: A customer may elect to receive his, her or its water bills electronically to the customer's email address.
4. Payment: A water bill may be paid: a) online through the City's website established for such purpose; b) by mail; or c) in person at City Hall. Failure
to receive a water bill will not relieve the customer from his, her or its obligation to pay the bill.
5. Delayed Payment Agreements: The City may, in the discretion of the Water Manager, enter into a delayed payment agreement with a delinquent
customer. The customer shall comply with such agreement in all respects and, upon failure to comply, shall be subject to the lien and termination of
service provisions provided for in this chapter.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 78/357
(B) Person Responsible For Payment: The owner of the premises, the occupant thereof, and the user of the water service shall be jointly and severally
liable to pay for the service to such premises and the service is furnished to the premises by the City only upon the condition that the owner of the
premises, occupant and user of the service are jointly and severally liable thereof to the City.
(C) Lien Notice Of Delinquency:
1. Lien: In the event charges for water service remain unpaid for twenty two (22) days after rendition of the bill for such services, such charges shall be
deemed and are hereby declared to be delinquent, and thereafter such delinquency may constitute a lien upon the real estate for which service is
supplied, and the City Clerk be and is hereby authorized and directed to file with the County Recorder of Deeds of Lee County a notice of lien claim
at any time after the bill has become delinquent. The filing of such statement shall be deemed notice of the lien for said water service. This notice
shall consist of a sworn statement setting out:
(a) A legal description of the premises served;
(b) The amount of money due for such water service; and
(c) The date when such amount became delinquent.
2. Notification: If the user whose bill is unpaid is not the owner of the premises and the City has notice of this, notice shall be mailed to the owner of the
premises, if his or her address be known to the Water Division, whenever the bill remains unpaid for a period of twenty two (22) days after rendition
of the bill. The notice shall be sufficient to inform the owner of the premises that the charges or rates have become delinquent and that unpaid
charges may create a lien on the real estate under subsection (C)1 of this section. The procedure for customer disputes contained in subsection 3-8-
16(E) of this chapter shall be available to the owner of the premises should the owner wish to dispute imposition of the lien on the premises where
service was provided. Failure of the City to mail such notice or the failure of the owner to receive such notice shall not affect the right of the City to
file and foreclose the lien for unpaid bills, as provided in this chapter.
3. Foreclosure Of Lien: Property subject to a lien for unpaid charges shall be foreclosed in the manner as provided by the Illinois Compiled Statutes.
4. Costs: In all cases where the charges or rates established under this chapter become delinquent, and it becomes necessary to file a statement
thereof in the Office of the Recorder of Deeds, there shall be added as part of such delinquent charge the Recorder's fee for the filing of said
statement and the costs verifying the legal description of the property on which such lien is attached and the City Clerk is hereby directed and
authorized to include said additions in her sworn statements showing such delinquency.
(D) Filing Of Notice: When this chapter shall become effective, a copy thereof properly certified by the City shall be filed in the Office of the Recorder of
Deeds of Lee County and shall be deemed notice to all owners of real estate of their liability for charges for the water system supplied to any occupant
or user of such service on their property. (Ord. 3110, 9-17-2018)
3-8-11: CESSATION OF WATER SERVICE:
Whenever a premises is to be vacated or closed for any period of time, application shall be made to the Water Division to have the water supply shut off.
The Water Division shall then shut off the water and remove (if applicable) and read the meter. The water customer will then be given a bill based on the
meter reading, along with any additional fees or charges permitted or required by this chapter. If the customer is moving from the premises, the deposit will
be applied to the final bill. (Ord. 3110, 9-17-2018)
3-8-12: WATER MAIN EXTENSIONS FOR NEW SUBDIVISIONS AND OTHERWISE:
All subdividers shall submit plans for water main extension to the Water Manager for approval. The plans shall indicate the size and the location of all
water mains, valves and fire hydrants. The plans shall also indicate the size and location of all lots and streets. After the plans have been approved by the
Water Manager, Consulting Engineers, Building Official, and the Fire Chief, the plans must then be submitted to the Illinois EPA Division of Public Water
Supplies, Springfield, Illinois, for approval. No work shall be started on any extension until approval has been received by the Water Division and a
construction permit is received. A new installation shall not be put in service until after an operating permit has been received by the Water Division. The
entire water system shall be installed by and paid for by the subdivider.
Fire hydrants shall be located at the corner of each block and on the end of all dead end mains. Intermediate hydrants will be required on long blocks as
required by the Water Manager or City Engineer. All hydrants must be set so that the center of the nozzle should be not less than eighteen inches (18")
from ground level. The water main shall be extended to the extremities of the subdivision so that future water main extensions will not require excavation in
the subdivision.
RW valves will be installed on the lead to all fire hydrants. RW valves shall be located on all but one of the branches at each intersection. In no event shall
RW valves be located more than eight hundred feet (800') apart. The water main shall be connected into the existing water system at every possible
location. Dead end water mains shall be avoided wherever possible.
In such cases where the subdivider is required to provide larger diameter mains for future expansion and said subdivider believes he is entitled to
additional reimbursement, he shall appear before the City Council. The City Council will study the facts of the case and may or may not give additional
reimbursement. The reimbursement is to be made based on the size of the pipe which the City Council may require be installed and the size main which
must be installed in the subdivision to satisfy the fire flow in each subdivision or instance. This would be based on eight inch (8") minimum size of the
main. The installation of the water main shall be inspected and the entire installation shall be approved by the Water Division, the consulting engineer, and
the Manager of the Water Division prior to final acceptance of the subdivision by the City. In such cases where, after a showing of good cause by the
subdivider that the requirements of this section or of section 3-8-12-1 of this chapter cannot be met, the Water Manager may approve such suitable
replacements as he or she may allow in his or her absolute discretion.
For connections outside the City limits, the following shall apply:
All persons making connections to any main outside of the City limits shall pay the same hook-on fee, meter and deposit as required within the City. The
water billing rate is one hundred fifteen percent (115%) of the rate applicable within the City limits. Also, the property owner shall sign a written agreement
that the water user will annex his or her property to the City when and if said property shall become contiguous to said City.

https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 79/357
The provisions of this section shall also apply to any water main extensions, including those not done for the construction of new subdivisions. (Ord. 3110,
9-17-2018)
3-8-12-1: WATER MAIN EXTENSIONS AND SUBDIVISION SPECIFICATIONS:
(A) All water main fittings shall be Class 52 cable bonded ductile iron pipe conforming to AWWA C151 and C111. All water mains shall not be less than six
inches (6") in diameter.
(B) All ductile iron pipe shall be wrapped in polyethylene encasement and will meet the requirements of ANSI/AWWA C105/A21.5.4.
(C) Polyethylene encasement shall be V-Bio Poly Wrap.
(D) All valves shall be gate valves Mueller RW or Clow RW. Valves shall be designed with a direction of opening to the right (clockwise) with resilient
wedge, ductile iron body with mechanical joint ends.
(E) Fire hydrants shall be Mueller Centurion or Clow Medallion with break flange construction. All fire hydrants shall be designed with a direction of
opening to the right (clockwise) with a six inch (6") mechanical joint shoe. Hydrants shall have two (2) 2.5-inch hose nozzles and one integral factory
installed five inch (5") Storz connector. The nozzles shall have national standard hose threads. All fire hydrant runs shall have an RW valve installed on
them for hydrant maintenance. All fire hydrants shall be safety orange in color.
(F) All new and repaired water service lines two inch (2") in diameter and smaller shall be type K soft copper pipe or SDR9 ADS polyflex (200 psi rating)
one inch (1") or greater in diameter. All SDR 9 pipe must have a tracer wire ran with it. Service lines greater than two inches (2") in diameter must be
Class 52 cable bonded ductile iron pipe.
(G) Curb stops shall be Mueller H-15155 or A.Y. McDonald equivalent.
(H) Corporation stops shall be Mueller H-15008 or A.Y. McDonald equivalent.
(I) Curb boxes shall be Mueller H-10300 complete with pentagon nut.
(J) Megalugs shall be used for mechanical joint restraints.
(K) Distribution valve boxes shall be Tyler 664S box with a lid marked "water". (Ord. 3110, 9-17-2018)
3-8-13: REPLACING OR REPAIRING WATER SERVICE:
(A) Between The Water Main And Premises: When a leak or break occurs in a water service between the water main and the premises, the property
owner is responsible for repair or replacement. If the property owner has not taken action within twenty four (24) hours after the owner has been
notified, the Water Division shall disconnect or shall cause the service to be disconnected. The Water Division is authorized to undertake said
disconnection by using Water Division employees or by employing an independent contractor to perform such service. The property owner shall be
responsible for and shall pay all costs incurred by the Water Division in disconnecting said service. If the Water Division employees disconnect said
service, costs shall be calculated on a time and material basis; if the Water Division employs an independent contractor to perform said service, the
amount of the charges incurred by the City shall be paid by the property owner. The property owner shall make payment in full within thirty (30) days of
receipt of said bill. If payment is not made within said thirty (30) days, the water service shall be disconnected until the bill is paid in full, plus payment
of a fifty dollar ($50.00) fee. The owner shall also be responsible for any fees for re-establishing service.
(B) Pipe One Inch Or Smaller: If a leak or break occurs in a water service pipe having a one inch (1") or smaller diameter and said water service pipe
supplies more than one premises, then, at the time repairs are undertaken, each property owner shall cause an individual service line to be installed
from the main to the building on the premises. The cost of such installation shall be split between the property owners.
(C) Serious Damage: The Water Division has the right to shut off any service leak or break at any time that said leak or break, in the opinion of the Water
Division, is causing or could cause serious damage to the street or property. The property owner shall pay the Water Division on a time and material
basis.
(D) Street Reconstruction: All water services which are not type K soft copper or SDR9 ADS polyflex (200 psi rating) shall be replaced prior to any street
improvements program where the street surface is completely removed and thereafter replaced with either a portland cement concrete surface or a
bituminous concrete surface. The property owner may select a plumber of his or her choice to replace the water service or it will be replaced by the
Water Division at the owner's expense. Water service shall also be extended to vacant lots containing fifty feet (50') or more frontage. If the Water
Division performs the work, it will charge three hundred dollars ($300.00) to replace each gooseneck and eight hundred dollars ($800.00) to replace
water service from the water main to the curb stop. The owner shall pay the full amount of the bill within thirty (30) days to the Water Division. Failure to
make said payment shall result in the water service being terminated until said bill is paid in full, plus a fifty dollar ($50.00) fee.
(E) Razed Properties: Disconnection at the water main shall be required on all existing services where the property is being razed, except where otherwise
agreed by the Water Manager. Upon failure to do so, the Water Division may disconnect service or cause the service to be disconnected at the owner's
cost. Owner shall pay all applicable fees and costs permitted under this chapter which arise from such disconnection. (Ord. 3110, 9-17-2018)

3-8-15: WATER RATES:
(A) Basic Water Service Charges: The water service charge for the use of and for service supplied by the Water Division of the City shall consist of a basic
user charge, a debt service charge, and a capital improvement charge.
1. Basic User Charge: The basic user charge is the basic assessment levied on all users of the City water system and is levied on all users to recover
the operation, maintenance plus replacement (OM&R) costs and shall be based on water usage as recorded by water meters.
The basic user charge shall be computed as follows:
(a) Estimate the annual water volume;
(b) Estimate the projected annual revenue required to operate and maintain the Dixon Water Division, including a replacement fund for the year, for
all works categories; and
(c) Compute costs per one gallon.
2. Debt Service Charge: The debt service charge shall be the amount to be paid each billing period for payment of interest and principal of debt
outstanding and is computed by apportioning the annual debt service as a fixed charge per billing period.
3. Capital Improvement Charge: The capital improvement charge is levied on users to provide for capital improvements, extensions or reconstruction of
the waterworks. The capital improvement charge is computed by apportioning the annual amount to be accrued as a fixed charge per billing period.
4. Measurement Of Flow: The volume of flow used for computing basic user charges shall be the metered water consumption read to the lowest even
increments of one gallon.
5. Adequacy Of Charge Reviewed: The adequacy of the water service charge shall be reviewed, not less often than annually, by certified public
accountants for the Water Division in their annual audit report. The water service charge shall be revised periodically to reflect a change in local
capital costs or OM&R costs.
6. Other Sources Prohibited: No consumer or owner shall procure any part, or all, of his or her water from sources other than the City waterworks
system.
(B) Rates: Rates for all metered customers shall be as follows:
1. Basic User Charge: There shall be and there is hereby established a basic user charge of eight dollars eighty cents ($8.80) for the first two thousand
two hundred forty four (2,244) gallons of metered water consumption per meter each month to be applied to all users to recover OM&R costs.
2. Debt Service Charge: There shall be and there is hereby established a debt service charge of nine dollars fifty three cents ($9.53) per meter each
month to each user of the water facility.
3. Capital Improvement Charge: There shall be and there is hereby established a capital improvement charge of two dollars thirty nine cents ($2.39)
per meter each month to each user of the water facility.
4. Minimum Charge: A minimum charge of twenty dollars seventy two cents ($20.72) per meter each month shall be applied to all users whose water
consumption does not exceed two thousand two hundred forty four (2,244) gallons per month. This minimum charge consists of eight dollars eighty
cents ($8.80) for OM&R costs, nine dollars fifty three cents ($9.53) for debt service costs and two dollars thirty nine cents ($2.39) for capital
improvement costs.
5. Excess Usage: Usage in excess of two thousand two hundred forty four (2,244) gallons up to and including seven hundred forty seven thousand two
hundred fifty two (747,252) gallons per meter each month will be charged at a rate of $0.0035 per one gallon. This rate consists of $0.0029 cents for
OM&R costs, $0.0006 cents for debt service costs and zero dollars ($0.00) for capital improvement costs. Usage in excess of seven hundred forty
seven thousand two hundred fifty two (747,252) gallons up to and including seven million four hundred seventy nine thousand two hundred fifty two
(7,479,252) gallons per meter each month will be charged at a rate of $0.0024 cents per one gallon. This rate consists of $0.0018 cents for OM&R
costs, $0.0006 cents for debt service costs and zero dollars ($0.00) for capital improvement costs. Usage in excess of seven million four hundred
seventy nine thousand two hundred fifty two (7,479,252) gallons per meter each month will be charged at a rate of $0.0015 cents per one gallon.
This rate consists of $0.0015 cents for OM&R costs, zero dollars ($0.00) for debt service costs and zero dollars ($0.00) for capital improvement
costs.
6. Computation Of Water Service Charge: The water service charge shall be computed on a per meter basis according to the following formula:
CW = CC + CD + CM + (Vu-X)CU
Where:
CW = Amount of water service charge ($) per billing period
CC = Capital improvement charge
CD = Debt service charge
CM = Minimum charge for operation, maintenance and replacement
Vu = Water volume for the billing period
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 81/357
X = Allowable consumption in gallons for the minimum charge
CU = Basic user charge for operation, maintenance and replacement
