12. Surcharge Rates: The unit rates for wastewater surcharge shall be:
(a) For biochemical oxygen demand (BOD): Twenty two cents ($0.22) per pound;
(b) For suspended solids (SS): Eighteen cents ($0.18) per pound,
with exception to Dean Foods, Amboy Specialty Division, k/n/a Bay Valley Foods.
The unit rates for wastewater surcharge for Dean Foods, Amboy Specialty Division, k/n/a Bay Valley Foods shall be:
(a) For biochemical oxygen demand (BOD): Thirteen cents ($0.13) per pound;
(b) For suspended solids (SS): Nine cents ($0.09) per pound.
13. Computation Of Wastewater Service Charge: The wastewater service charge shall be computed by the following formula:
CW = CM + Vu (Cu + CD + CR) + CS
Where:
CW = Amount of wastewater service charge in dollars per billing period
CM = Fixed administrative expenses in dollars per billing period
Vu = Wastewater volume in gallons per billing period
Cu = Basic user rate in dollars per gallon
CD = Debt service rate in dollars per gallon
CR = Capital improvement charge in dollars per gallon for users located outside of the City corporate limits
CS = Surcharge if applicable, as determined by the following formula:
CS = Vu (0.00000834) [A (BOD5 - 200) + B (SS - 320)]
Where:
CS = Amount of surcharge in dollars per billing period
Vu = Wastewater volume in gallons per billing period
0.00000834 = Unit of weight of water x 10-6 per gallon
A = Unit charge for BOD5 per pound
BOD5 = 5 day biochemical oxygen demand of wastewater in mg/L
200 = Allowable average strength in mg/L
B = Unit charge for suspended solids per pound
SS = Suspended solids concentration of wastewater in mg/L
320 = Allowable average suspended solids strength in mg/L
14. Exceptions To Charge: Provided the residential user complies with the provisions of this section, the following usages of the wastewater facilities
shall be exempt from the wastewater service charges established in this chapter:
(a) Swimming Pools:
(1) Any property owner intending to fill a swimming pool located on the owner's property may make a request to the City to pay only the water
usage charges incurred in said filling by submitting a written request to City Hall. The request must be submitted prior to the filling of the
swimming pool along with a ten dollar ($10.00) fee. Upon approval of the request by the Manager, the wastewater service charge shall not be
charged for the filling of said swimming pool, but the property owner shall be charged the normal water rate in accordance with the provisions of
section 3-8-15 of this title. The meter shall be read by the Water Division immediately before filling the swimming pool and again three (3) days
later. Discharging of any swimming pool water into the City's sanitary sewer system is prohibited.
(2) The exemption provided under this subsection (A)14(a) shall be granted only once per calendar year. Any other water added to a residential
pool shall be charged as provided in this Code.
(3) Filling of a swimming pool from a metered fire hydrant is prohibited.
(b) Newly Sodded Or Seeded Lawn:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 96/357
(1) The wastewater service charge shall not be charged for the watering of a newly seeded or sodded lawn only if the owner or the occupant of the
residence notifies the wastewater treatment plant in writing at least five (5) days prior to the installation of the new seeding or sod.
(2) The determination of whether a lawn is newly seeded or sodded shall be made by and at the sole discretion of the Manager of the wastewater
treatment plant.
(3) The exemption granted under this subsection (A)14(b) shall:
A. Only apply to lawns where the sod is installed or the seed is planted either in the entire front yard and/or back yard;
B. Not exceed thirty (30) days from the date said lawn is newly seeded or sodded; and
C. Not be applicable to any other watering or outside use.
(4) The method of computing the amount of the exempt fee shall be determined by the Manager of the wastewater treatment plant. Provided,
however, the amount of the wastewater service charge shall first be paid by the owner or user and the amount of the charge determined to be
exempt shall thereafter be rebated by the City.
15. Miscellaneous Wastes Rates; Conditions:
(a) The unit rates for miscellaneous wastes shall be: 1) for holding tank waste: Ten dollars sixty cents ($10.60) per one thousand (1,000) gallons; 2)
for septage: Eighty four dollars eighty cents ($84.80) per one thousand (1,000) gallons; 3) for leachate, shall be established by special agreement
between both parties.
The unit rates for miscellaneous wastes were established based on typical strength holding tank waste (600 mg/L BOD and 1800 mg/L SS) and
typical strength septage (5000 mg/L BOD and 15 000 mg/L SS). If analytical testing determines the strength of the holding tank waste or septage
to be higher than the typical values as indicated above, an additional charge may be levied. This additional charge shall be based upon the unit
charges as indicated in subsection (A)12 of this section, and upon the increased pounds of BOD and/or SS over and above the typical strengths
indicated in this subsection.
(b) The City may accept for treatment holding tank wastes, septage or other miscellaneous wastes subject to the following conditions:
(1) Should the City determine that excess capacity exists at the wastewater treatment plant, and that the conditions of the NPDES permit granted
by the State for operation of the wastewater treatment plant will be met, the City may accept for treatment septage, holding tank waste or other
miscellaneous wastes.
(2) Miscellaneous wastes shall only be accepted by the City if such wastes are delivered by the hauler to the wastewater treatment plant, and
discharged at a location and under such conditions as approved by the City.
(3) All approvals for miscellaneous hauled waste disposal shall be subject to such conditions as deemed necessary by the City, including the
condition that acceptance of miscellaneous hauled wastes may be restricted or suspended, should the wastewater treatment plant have
operational problems, maintenance problems, or the threat of NPDES permit violations which are indirectly or directly related to the acceptance
of the miscellaneous hauled waste.
16. Increase In Rates:
(a) Except as provided in subsection (A)16(b) of this section, each of the rates set forth in subsections (A)5, (A)6, (A)7, (A)8, (A)9, (A)12 and (A)15(a)
of this section shall increase by six percent (6%) per annum over the previous year on May 1, 2017, and May 1, 2018. Except as provided in
subsection (A)16(b) of this section, each of the rates set forth in subsections (A)5, (A)6, (A)7, (A)8, (A)9, (A)12 and (A)15(a) of this section shall
automatically increase by two and one-half percent (2.5%) per annum over the previous year on May 1 of each year commencing May 1, 2019.
(b) The rate increase set forth in subsection (A)16(a) of this section shall not apply to the fifteen thousand nine hundred seventeen dollar
($15,917.00) debt service charge assessed Dean Foods, Amboy Specialty Division, k/n/a Bay Valley Foods pursuant to subsection (A)7 of this
section.
(B) Billings: Rates or charges for sewerage service shall be computed and billed on a monthly basis (or quarterly for those customers without a Sensus
water meter). Bills for the sewerage service shall be mailed or emailed, as applicable, within thirty (30) days after the end of the period for which the
service is billed. All bills are due and payable twenty one (21) days after being sent out. All bills for sewerage service become delinquent twenty two
(22) days from the date thereon. A ten percent (10%) penalty shall be assessed and added to all delinquent bills. If the bill, together with any applicable
penalty, is not paid within such period, the customer shall be subject to further penalty as set forth in this chapter. An administrative fee of fifty dollars
($50.00) shall be further applied to all bills not paid within thirty eight (38) days from the bill statement period. In such cases where service has been
discontinued pursuant to this chapter, the sewerage service will not be reconnected until the bill has been paid in full.
(C) Person Responsible For Payment: The owner of the premises, the occupant thereof, and the user of the sewerage service shall be jointly and severally
liable to pay for the service to such premises and the service is furnished to the premises by the City only upon the condition that the owner of the
premises, occupant and user of the service are jointly and severally liable thereof to the City.
(D) Appeals: The method for computation of rates and service charges established for the user charges in subsection (A) of this section, shall be made
available to a user within ten (10) days of receipt of a written request for such. Any disagreement over the method used or in the computations thereof
shall be remedied by the Manager and the City Treasurer within ten (10) days after notification of a formal written appeal outlining the discrepancies.
(E) Lien Notice Of Delinquency:
1. Lien: In the event charges for sewerage service remain unpaid for twenty two (22) days after rendition of the bill for such services, such charges
shall be deemed and are hereby declared to be delinquent, and thereafter such delinquency may constitute a lien upon the real estate for which such
service is supplied, and the City Clerk be and is hereby authorized and directed to file with the County Recorder of Deeds of Lee County a notice of
lien claim at any time after the bill has become delinquent. The filing of such statement shall be deemed notice of the lien for said sewerage service.
This notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting out:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 97/357
(a) A legal description of the premises served.
(b) The amount of money due for such sewerage service.
(c) The date when such amount became delinquent.
2. Notification: If the user whose bill is unpaid is not the owner of the premises and the City Clerk has notice of this, notice shall be mailed to the owner
of the premises if his or her address be known to the Water Division, whenever the bill remains unpaid for a period of twenty two (22) days after
rendition of the bill. The notice shall be sufficient to inform the owner of the premises that the charges or rates have become delinquent and that
unpaid charges may create a lien on the real estate under subsection (E)1 of this section. The procedure for customer disputes contained in
subsection 3-15-10(E) of this title shall be available to the owner of the premises should the owner wish to dispute imposition of the lien on the
premises where service was provided. Failure of the City Clerk to mail such notice or the failure of the owner to receive such notice shall not affect
the right of the City to file and foreclose the lien for unpaid bills, as provided in this chapter.
3. Foreclosure Of Lien: Property subject to a lien for unpaid charges shall be foreclosed in the manner as provided by the Illinois Compiled Statutes.
4. Costs: In all cases where the charges or rates established under this chapter become delinquent, and it becomes necessary to file a statement
thereof in the Office of the Recorder of Deeds, there shall be added as part of such delinquent charge the Recorder's fee for the filing of said
statement and the costs verifying the legal description of the property on which such lien is attached and the City Clerk is hereby directed and
authorized to include said additions in her sworn statements showing such delinquency.
(F) Revenues: All revenues and monies derived from the operation of the sewerage system shall be deposited in the sewerage account of the Sewerage
Fund. All such revenues and monies shall be held by the City Treasurer separate and apart from all other funds of the City and all of said sum, without
any deductions whatever, shall be delivered to the City Treasurer not more than ten (10) days after the receipt of the same, or at such more frequent
intervals as may from time to time be directed by the City Council.
The City Treasurer shall receive all such revenues from the sewerage system and all other funds and monies incident to the operation of such system
as the same may be delivered and deposit the same in the account of the fund designated as the "Sewerage Fund for the City of Dixon".
(G) Accounts: The City Treasurer shall establish a proper system of accounts and shall keep proper books, records, and accounts in which complete and
correct entries shall be made of all transactions relative to the sewerage system, and at regular intervals shall cause to be made an audit by an
independent auditing concern of the books to show the receipts and disbursements of the sewerage system.
In addition to the customary operating statements, the annual audit report shall also reflect the revenues and operating expenses of the wastewater
facilities, including replacement cost, to indicate the sewer service charges under the waste cost recovery system do in fact meet these regulations. In
this regard, the financial information to be shown in the audit shall include the following:
1. Flow data showing the total gallons received at the wastewater treatment plant for the current fiscal year.
2. Billing date to show total number of gallons billed per year.
3. Debt service for the next succeeding fiscal year.
4. Number of users connected to the system.
5. Number of non-metered users.
6. A list of users discharging nondomestic and industrial waste and the volume of waste discharged.
(H) Access To Records: The Illinois Environmental Protection Agency or its authorized representative shall have access to records of the City's which are
applicable, City's system of user charges for the purposes of making audit, examination, excerpts and transcriptions thereof to ensure compliance with
the terms of the special and general conditions of the State grant of loan agreement. (Ord. 3110, 9-17-2018)
Chapter 10
MUNICIPAL BAND
3-10-1: BAND ESTABLISHED:
There shall be maintained by the city a municipal band for municipal purposes, to be known as the "Dixon Municipal Band" and the same shall be
assigned to the department of public affairs. (1950 Code)
3-10-2: DIRECTOR; APPOINTMENT:
The mayor shall recommend to the council the appointment of a director of the band and the director shall be elected by a majority vote of the council.
(1950 Code)
3-10-3: DIRECTOR; TERM:
The director shall hold office until the end of the fiscal year for which he is appointed. The council may remove the director at any time. (1950 Code)
3-10-4: COMPENSATION:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 98/357
The director shall be paid a salary of one thousand two hundred dollars ($1,200.00) per annum, payable in semimonthly installments. (1950 Code)
3-10-5: DUTIES:
The director shall organize a band and prepare such rules for the band as may to him seem expedient and not inconsistent with the best interests of the
band and the city and not in conflict with any of the provisions of this code or any law, which rules must be submitted to the council for approval before
becoming effective. The director shall have general supervision of all details pertaining to the band except as otherwise directed by the council or by the
mayor between meetings of the council. The director shall appoint or employ such assistants and employees as may be authorized by the council and fix
their compensation, subject to the approval of the council, and he may, by and with the consent of the council, remove such appointees. (1950 Code)
3-10-6: FUNDS:
The council shall have the exclusive control of the expenditures of all monies collected, levied or donated to the credit of the band fund; all monies
received for the band, either by levy or otherwise, shall be deposited in the treasury to the credit of the band fund and the treasurer shall keep the funds
separate and apart from other monies of the city and the director shall approve all accounts charged against the band fund before any payment is made1.
(1950 Code)
Chapter 11
SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS
3-11-1: JURISDICTION:
Wherever any subdivision of land shall hereafter be laid out within the city or within contiguous territory and not more than one and one-half (11/2) miles
beyond the incorporated boundary of the city, the subdivider thereof or his agent shall submit both a preliminary and a final subdivision plan to the city. The
plans, proposed improvements, and all procedures relating thereto, shall in all respects be in full compliance with the regulations hereinafter contained in
this chapter.
All lands offered to the city for use as streets, highways, alleys, parks and other public use, shall be referred to the plan commission for review and
recommendation before being accepted by the council or by any other governing authority. (Ord. 680, 1-17-1972)
3-11-2: APPROVALS; INTERPRETATIONS; EXCEPTIONS:
(A) No land lying within the corporate limits, after the adoption of these regulations, shall be subdivided or filed for record, nor any street laid out, nor any
improvements made to the land, until the plan of the subdivision or plan of the street improvements has been certified to and approved by action of the
council. This approval must be in writing and placed on the original tracing of the final plans, according to the procedure outlined in section 3-11-5 of
this chapter. (Ord. 2784, 5-17-2010)
(B) No lot, tract or parcel of land within any subdivision lying within the corporate limits, shall be offered for sale nor shall any sale, contract for sale, or
option be made or given until such subdivision plans have been properly reviewed by the plan commission and officially approved by the council.
(C) No improvements, such as sidewalks, water supply, stormwater drainage, sewerage facilities, gas service, electric service or lighting, or grading,
paving or surfacing the streets, shall hereafter be made within any such subdivision of the city, by any owner or his agent, or by any public service
corporation at the request of the owner or his agent until the plans for the subdivision and also the plans for improvements thereto have been formally
recommended by the plan commission and approved by the council.
(D) Subdivision of land lying outside of the city and within one and one-half (11/2) miles of the corporate limits, shall also be required to conform with the
requirements of this chapter, in accordance with the provisions of the Illinois municipal code. (Ord. 680, 1-17-1972)
3-11-3: DEFINITIONS:
ALLEY: A strip of land, not less than twenty feet (20') in width and not more than forty feet (40') along the side of or in the rear of properties, intended to
provide access to these properties.
BUILDING LINE: A line within a lot or other parcel of land, so designated on the plat of the proposed subdivision, between which, and the adjacent
boundary of the street upon which the lot abuts, the erection of an enclosed structure or portion thereof is to be prohibited.
CROSSWALK WAY: A strip of land dedicated to public use, which is reserved across a block to provide pedestrian access to adjacent areas.
CUL-DE-SAC: A street having one open end and being permanently terminated by a vehicular turnaround.
EASEMENT: A grant by a property owner for the use of a strip of land by the general public, a corporation, or a certain person for a specific purpose.
LOT: A portion of a subdivision or other parcel of land intended for transfer of ownership or for building development.
MARGINAL ACCESS STREET: A minor street which is parallel to and adjacent to primary streets and highways, and which provides access to abutting
properties and protection to local traffic from fast through moving traffic on the primary streets.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 99/357
MINOR STREET: A street intended primarily as access to abutting properties.
PRIMARY STREET: A principal street which collects traffic from minor and secondary streets serving large areas, and connecting with state and U.S.
highways or extending to principal points of destination.
PUBLIC STREET: All primary and minor streets which are shown on the subdivision plat and are to be dedicated for public use.
SECONDARY STREET: A street which collects traffic from minor streets and connecting with primary streets or state and U.S. highways or extending to
points of destination.
STREET: An area which serves or is intended to serve as a vehicular and pedestrian access to abutting lands or other streets.
STREET WIDTH: The shortest distance between lines of lots delineating the public street.
SUBDIVISION: The division of a lot, tract or parcel of land into two (2) or more lots, parcels or other divisions of land, for the purpose, whether immediate
or future, of transfer of ownership or building development, including all changes in street or lot lines; provided, however, that the following divisions of land
shall be exempted from the definition of "subdivision":
(A) A division of land for agricultural purposes in parcels of more than five (5) acres not involving any new street or public utility easement or easement
of access; or
(B) The transfer of less than ten feet (10') of property in a recorded subdivision to an adjoining property owner where each lot, tract or parcel, after said
transfer, contains the minimum square footage required under this code; or
(C) The division of a lot, tract or parcel of land of less than one acre in a recorded subdivision into two (2) or more lots, parcels or other divisions of land
not involving any new streets, public utility easements or easements of access where each lot, tract, or parcel of land resulting from such subdivision:
1) contains the minimum square footage required under this code, and 2) complies in all other respects with the provisions of this code.
Each owner of a lot, tract or parcel of land asserting an exemption under subsection (B) or (C) of this definition shall file a plat of survey, prepared by
an Illinois registered land surveyor with the city's building official, showing the resulting lots or tracts and giving the legal descriptions therefor. (Ord.
680, 1-17-1972; amd. Ord. 2093, 6-15-1998)
3-11-4: DESIGN STANDARDS:
(A) Street Plan: The subdivision of land, including the arrangement, character, extent, width, grade and location of all streets, alleys, or other land to be
dedicated for public use, shall conform to the general development plan of the city as approved and adopted by the council and other responsible
governmental bodies; and shall be considered in their relation to existing and planned streets, to topographical conditions, to public convenience and
safety, and in their appropriate relation to the proposed uses of the land to be served by such streets.
(B) Minimum Street Standards:
1. All rights of way shall conform to the following minimum dimensions:
(a) Primary streets shall conform to the major street plan and in no instance shall be less than one hundred feet (100').
(b) Secondary or collector streets shall be sixty six feet (66').
(c) Minor streets shall be sixty feet (60').
(d) Cul-de-sac shall be sixty feet (60').
(e) Crosswalks shall be ten feet (10').
(f) Utility easements shall be ten feet (10').
2. Minor streets shall be so laid out that their use by through traffic will be discouraged.
3. Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than one hundred twenty five feet (125') shall be avoided.
4. Clear visibility, measured along the centerline of the street, shall be provided for at least three hundred feet (300') on all primary streets, two hundred
feet (200') on minor streets, and at least one hundred feet (100') on all other streets.
5. It must be evidenced that all street intersections and confluences encourage safe traffic flow.
6. Alleys are not permitted, except where deemed necessary, and at the discretion of the plan commission or the council.
7. The maximum length cul-de-sac shall be five hundred feet (500') measured along the centerline from the intersection at origin through center of
circle to end of right of way. Each cul-de-sac shall have a terminus of nearly circular shape with a minimum diameter of one hundred feet (100').
8. Half streets shall be prohibited, except where essential to the reasonable development of the subdivision in conformity with the other requirements of
these regulations; and where the plan commission or the council finds it will be practicable to require the dedication of the other one-half (1/2) when
the adjoining property is subdivided. Wherever a half street is adjacent to a tract to be subdivided, the other one-half (1/2) of the street shall be
planned within such tract.
9. No street names may be used which will duplicate, or be confused with, the names of existing streets. Existing street names must be projected
wherever possible.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 100/357
(C) Easements:
1. Easements across lots or centered on rear or side lot lines shall be provided for utilities where necessary and shall be at least ten feet (10') wide.
2. Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, drainageway, channel, or stream, there shall be provided a stormwater easement or drainage
right of way conforming substantially with the lines of the watercourse, and such further width or construction, or both, as will be adequate for the
purpose. Parallel streets or parkways may be required in connection therewith. (Ord. 680, 1-17-1972)
(D) Block Standards:
1. The maximum lengths of blocks shall be one thousand eight hundred feet (1,800'). All blocks over eight hundred feet (800') will ordinarily require
crosswalks at the approximate centers. The use of additional crosswalk ways in any instance to provide safe and convenient access to schools,
parks or other similar destinations will be approved by the city council and city engineer. (Ord. 2784, 5-17-2010)
2. No specific rule concerning the shape of blocks is made, but blocks must fit easily into the overall plan of the subdivision and their design must
evidence consideration of lot planning, traffic flow, and public areas.
3. Blocks intended for commercial and industrial use must be designated as such, and the plan must show adequate off street areas to provide for
parking, loading docks and such other facilities that may be required to accommodate motor vehicles.
(E) Lot Standards:
1. The minimum lot dimensions for residential development shall be fifty feet (50') wide at the established building line and not less than one hundred
feet (100') in average depth, and containing not less than six thousand (6,000) square feet in area, except that a corner lot may be of less depth;
provided, that neither the width nor depth is less than eighty five feet (85'), where permitted under the provisions of the zoning title. This minimum
requirement shall not apply to land subdivided for nonresidential development.
2. Corner lots shall be sufficiently larger than interior lots to allow maintenance of building lines on both streets.
3. All lots shall abut on a publicly dedicated street.
4. Side lines of lots shall be approximately at right angles or radial to the street line.
5. Double frontage lots are forbidden except where lots back upon a primary street (major thoroughfare) and in such instances, vehicular access
between the lots and the thoroughfare is prohibited. Such lots shall have an additional depth of at least ten feet (10') in order to allow for a protective
screen planting.
6. Lots abutting a watercourse, drainageway, channel or stream shall have additional minimum width or depth as required to provide an adequate
building site and afford the minimum usable area required in the zoning title for front, rear and side yards.
(F) Parks, Schools, And Public Areas:
1. Where a proposed park, playground, school or other public use area, shown in the general development plan for the city and adjacent
unincorporated areas, is located in whole or in part in a subdivision, the plan commission may recommend and the governing body may require the
dedication or reservation of such area, in whole or in part, within the subdivision in those cases in which the plan commission or the proper governing
body deem such requirements to be reasonable. However, in no case shall the total amount of required public areas to be dedicated or reserved, in
addition to public streets, exceed ten percent (10%) of the total gross acreage owned or controlled by one developer. The acquisition of the additional
area needed for parks, playgrounds, schools or other public uses, other than streets and alleys, shall be secured by the proper governing body, or
arrangements made for securing the area from the owner within a period not to exceed ninety (90) days.
2. In the subdividing of any land within the city, or within one and one-half (11/2) miles of the corporate limits, due regard shall be shown for all natural
features, such as tree growth, watercourses, historic spots, or similar conditions which, if preserved, will add attractiveness and value to the
proposed development. (Ord. 680, 1-17-1972)
3-11-5: PROCEDURE AND REQUIREMENTS:
(A) Procedure For Filing Of Preliminary Plans:
1. Filing:
(a) Any owner of land which is within the corporate limits of the city or within one and one-half (11/2) miles of the corporate limits on unincorporated
land, wishing to divide the same into building lots for purposes of sale or assessment or both, or wishing to dedicate streets, alleys or other lands
for public use, shall first submit to the city a preliminary plan in triplicate.
(b) The council shall, by motion, refer the preliminary plan to the plan commission and shall at the time instruct the engineer to collaborate with the
subdivider and the plan commission in assembling plans for the design and construction of streets and such other public improvements as are
required by this chapter or any other provisions of this code. The plan commission shall, within thirty (30) days from referral, submit its written
recommendations for approval or disapproval to the council.
(c) The preliminary plans shall be referred to the plan commission at least ten (10) days prior to the regular meeting of the commission to receive
action thereon at the meeting.
2. Preliminary Plat; Contents:
(a) Proposed name of the subdivision.
(b) Location by township, section, town and range, or by other legal description.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 101/357
(c) Names and addresses of developer and designer who made plat.
(d) Scale of plat, one inch to one hundred feet (1" = 100') or larger.
(e) Date.
(f) North point.
(g) Boundary lines of proposed subdivision indicated by solid heavy line and the total approximate acreage encompassed thereby.
(h) Location, widths and names of all existing or prior platted streets or other public ways, railroad and utility rights of way, parks and other public
open spaces, permanent buildings and structures, houses or permanent easements, and section and corporation lines, within or adjacent to the
street.
(i) Existing sewers, water mains, culverts or other underground facilities within the tract indicating pipe sizes, grades, manholes, and exact location.
(j) Boundary lines of adjacent tracts of unsubdivided or subdivided land, showing ownership where possible.
(k) Existing zoning of proposed subdivision and adjacent tracts, in zoned areas.
(l) Contours at two foot (2') intervals except where topography of the tract demands one foot (1') contour intervals.
(m) Layout of streets, widths of rights of way and also the widths of crosswalks and easements.
(n) Layout, numbers and dimensions of lots.
(o) Parcels of land intended to be dedicated or temporarily reserved for public use or set aside for use of property owners in the subdivision.
(p) Building setback lines, showing dimensions.
(q) Easements shall be provided for any and all public utilities where alleys are not provided. Proper continuity for the utilities from block to block
shall be maintained.
3. Qualifications For Approval Of Preliminary Plat:
(a) The approval of a preliminary plan by the plan commission and the council is tentative only, involving merely the general acceptability of the
layout.
(b) The plan commission or the council may require such changes or revisions as are deemed necessary in the interest and needs of the community.
(c) Subsequent approval will be required of the engineering proposals pertaining to water supply, storm drainage, sewerage and sewage disposal,
gas and electric service, street lighting, fire hydrants, grading, gradients and roadway widths, and the surfacing of streets by the engineer, and the
county officials, where concerned, prior to the approval of the final plat by the city.
(d) Tentative approval shall be effective for a maximum period of twelve (12) months unless, upon application of the developer, the council grants an
extension. If the final plat has not been recorded within this time limit, the preliminary plat must again be submitted for approval. (Ord. 680, 1-17-
1972)
(B) Approval Of Final Plat:
1. Filing:
(a) After approval of the preliminary plat by the city council and the fulfillment of the requirements of these regulations, at least two (2) tracings of the
final plat of the subdivision, printed on drafting mylar not to exceed thirty six inches by forty eight inches (36" x 48") in size, shall be submitted to
the council for approval. (Ord. 2784, 5-17-2010)
(b) Action must be taken by the council within sixty (60) days after the final plat has been submitted for approval. (Ord. 1622, 9-16-1991)
(c) Upon approval by the council, the developer shall record the plat with the recorder of Lee County within three (3) months. If not recorded within
this time, the approval shall be null and void.
(d) A print of the final plat, after the plat is recorded, will be filed and retained in the offices of the city.
2. Final Plat; Contents:
(a) Name of subdivision.
(b) Location by township, section, town and range, or by other legal description.
(c) Names of owners and certification by a licensed surveyor.
(d) Scale one inch to one hundred feet (1" = 100') or larger, shown graphically.
(e) Date.
(f) North point.
(g) Boundary of plat, based on an accurate traverse, with angular and linear dimensions.
(h) Exact location, width and name of all streets within and adjoining the plat, and the exact location and widths of all crosswalk ways. Proposed
street names shall be checked with the proper city officials.
(i) True angles and distances to the nearest established street lines or official monuments (not less than 3), which shall be accurately described in
the plat.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 102/357
(j) Municipal, township, county or section lines accurately tied to the lines of the subdivision by distances and angles.
(k) Radii, internal angles, points and curvatures, tangent bearings and lengths of all arcs.
(l) All easements for rights of way provided for public services and utilities.
(m) All lot numbers and lines, with accurate dimensions in feet and hundredths.
(n) Accurate location of all monuments, which shall be concrete six inches by six inches by thirty inches (6" x 6" x 30") with iron pipe case in center.
Permanent stone or concrete monuments shall be set at each corner or angle of the outside boundary. Steel pipes or steel pins shall be set on
each lot corner, other than those for permanent stone or concrete monuments. All U.S., state, county, or other official bench marks, monuments or
triangular stations in or adjacent to the property shall be preserved in precise position.
(o) Accurate outlines and legal descriptions of any areas to be dedicated or reserved for public use, with the purposes indicated thereon, and of any
area to be reserved by deed covenant for common uses of all property owners.
(p) Building setback lines accurately shown by dimensions.
(q) Protective covenants which meet with the approval of the plan commission shall be lettered or typed on the final plat.
(r) Certification by a registered surveyor to the effect that the plat represents a survey made by him and that monuments and markers shown thereon
exist as located and that all dimensional and geodetic details are correct.
(s) Notarized certification by the owner, or by any mortgage holder on record, of the adoption of the plat and the dedication of streets and other public
areas.
(t) Certifications showing that all taxes and special assessments due on the property to be subdivided have been paid in full.
(u) Proper form for the approval of the council with space for signature.
(v) Approval by signature of city, county and state officials concerned with the specification of utility installations.
(w) Approval by signature of the plan commission. This approval of the final plat shall not be deemed to constitute or effect an acceptance by the
public of the dedication of any street or other proposed public way or space shown on the plat. (Ord. 680, 1-17-1972)
3-11-6: AGREEMENTS:
The final plat to be filed on record shall be accompanied by a statement signed by the owner and subdivider, setting forth the following:
(A) Plans and specifications for such improvements previously approved by the engineer clearly describing the same.
(B) Agreement executed by the owner and the subdivider wherein they agree to make and install the improvements provided for in section 3-11-7 of this
chapter, in accordance with the plans and specifications accompanying the final plat. (Ord. 680, 1-17-1972)
(C) Bond or a letter of credit in the amount of the estimate of the engineer of the cost of the installation of such improvements with good and sufficient
surety thereon to be approved by the council, conditioned upon the installation of the required improvements within two (2) years of the approval of the
final plat.
(D) In lieu of the provisions of subsections (B) and (C) of this section, in the event that the owner and subdivider shall submit said evidence of the
existence of the binding agreement with a responsible contractor agreeing to accept all bonds which may be issued under any local improvement
proceeding for the installation of such improvement or a bona fide and subsisting bid by a responsible person for the purchase for cash of such local
improvement bonds at par value or more, then the requirements of subsections (B) and (C) of this section may be waived.
(E) All improvements proposed (and/or required) to be made under the provisions of this chapter shall be inspected, during the course of construction, by
the city engineer or a duly designated deputy. Fees and costs shall be paid according to the following schedule:

construction plans for improvements; said fee to be computed in accordance with the following table:

3-11-7: REQUIRED LAND IMPROVEMENTS:
No subdivision of land shall be approved without receiving a statement signed by the engineer certifying that the improvement described in the
subdivider's plans and specifications, together with agreements, meet the minimum requirements of all the provisions of this code and that they comply
with the following:
(A) Sewers:
1. Sanitary sewers with laterals extending to lot lines shall be installed to comply with specifications established by the engineer and shall be connected
to the sanitary disposal system of the city if reasonably accessible; otherwise, to a specially constructed sanitary sewage disposal plant in
accordance with plans acceptable to the city. The sanitary sewers shall be designed to carry all of the sewage flow within the drainage basin within
the limits of one and one-half (11/2) miles from the corporate limits of the city. The sanitary sewer shall be sized to carry a peak flow of two and onehalf
(21/2) times the average flow of one hundred (100) gallons per capita per day. Unless there is supporting data to the contrary, the sewers shall
be designed for sixteen (16) people per acre. A subdivision plat shall in no case be approved, which shall be dependent upon individual septic tanks,
except where lots therein contain not less than ten thousand (10,000) square feet each, and the installation meets the requirements of the state and
county health department specifications for the construction and installation of individual septic systems.
2. Storm sewers shall be constructed throughout the entire subdivision which shall be separate and independent of the sanitary sewer system and
which shall provide an adequate outlet, or connection with the storm sewer system of the city. The storm sewers shall be extended to the extremities
of the subdivision for easy access by future upstream developments. The storm sewers shall be sized to carry the runoff from the entire drainage
area according to the rational runoff formula Q = CiA where Q is the volume of stormwater in cubic feet per second; C is the runoff coefficient, which
is that part of the rainfall rate which will contribute to the runoff rate; i is the average intensity of the rainfall in inches per hour during the time required
for all parts of the watershed to contribute to runoff; and A is the area of the drainage basin in acres. Where the major portion of the drainage basin is
or will be a residential area, a factor of eight-tenths (0.8) shall be used for the product of C and i. When commercial, industrial or other large runoff
areas are within the drainage area, the values used for C and i shall be approved by the city engineer. (Ord. 680, 1-17-1972)
3. After all sewer and water lines installed in city streets have been fully tested and approved by the city, and paid for by the subdivider, the subdivider
shall be required to execute a bill of sale transferring ownership of said sewer and water lines to the city. (Ord. 1061, 12-1-1980)
(B) Street Improvements:
1. Grades of streets shall not be in excess of five percent (5%) on primary streets, nor in excess of eight percent (8%) on other streets except in cases
of necessity and with the permission of the plan commission.
2. All streets within the corporate limits shall be improved with roadways, bounded by integral concrete curbs and gutters, to an overall width in
accordance with the following minimum dimensions:
Type Of Street
Dedicated
Street Width Roadway Width
Primary streets Conform to major street plan and in no instance less than 100 feet
2 24-foot roadways, divided by a median strip
Secondary or collector streets
66 feet 45 feet BC-BC
Minor streets 60 feet 37 feet BC-BC
3. Roadways shall be constructed of such base material and surfacing as to be suitable for the volume and character of traffic expected to use the
street, and as approved by the city officials and the city engineer. The surface shall be finished by constructing a minimum three inch (3") combined
hot mix asphalt binder and surface course conforming to section 406 of the state of Illinois, "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge
Construction", adopted January 1, 2007, or latest revision thereof.
4. Curbs and gutters on minor residential streets shall be type B6.18 combination concrete curb and gutter in accordance with IDOT standards, not less
than twenty five inches (25") in overall width.
5. Stormwater inlets shall be provided within the roadway improvement at points approved by the city engineer.
6. All curb corners shall have a radii of not less than fifteen feet (15') and at important intersections not less than twenty five feet (25'). All curb corners
shall be designed for the appropriate design vehicle for that location.
7. Roadway improvements in subdivisions lying outside the corporate city area, but within the one and one-half (11/2) mile area, shall conform to
standards of improvements suitable for the character of the proposed subdivision development, recommended by the plan commission and approved
by the governing authorities.
8. All curbs and gutters shall conform to the design standard of the Illinois department of transportation.
(C) Public Utilities:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 104/357
1. All utility pole lines for telephone and electric service shall be placed in rear line easements where practicable. Electric distribution centers and gas
regulating centers shall be placed where necessary to serve the immediate area, with the definite location being approved by the city engineer.
Underground utilities are desired. (Ord. 2784, 5-17-2010)
2. Where telephone and electric service lines are placed underground entirely throughout a subdivided area, the conduits or cables shall be placed
within easements or dedicated public ways, in a manner which will not conflict with other underground services. Further, all transformer boxes shall
be located so as not to be unsightly or hazardous to the public. (Ord. 680, 1-17-1972)
(D) Sidewalks:
1. Concrete sidewalks to a width of not less than five feet (5') shall be required by the plan commission or governing authorities as a part of the
dedicated street improvements. (Ord. 2784, 5-17-2010)
(E) Landscaping: All parkways within the dedicated street area or other public use areas shall be graded and seeded in an approved manner. (Ord. 680, 1-
17-1972)
(F) Street Lighting: Provisions shall be made by the subdivision developer or his agent for the adequate lighting of public streets within the proposed
subdivision, in accordance with the standard requirements established by the governing authorities. If the street lighting system will be turned over to
the city, the underground cables shall be placed in conduits. (Ord. 2784, 5-17-2010)
(G) Water Mains: Water mains shall be installed as specified in section 3-8-12 of this title. (Ord. 1249, 12-3-1984)
(H) Backfilling: All trenches within the limits of the proposed curbs, sidewalks and street surfaces shall be backfilled using trench backfill conforming to
section 208 of the state of Illinois "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction", adopted January 7, 2007, or latest revision thereof.
Trenches may be backfilled without the use of trench backfill providing the trenches are thoroughly jetted with water and allowed to settle for a period of
twelve (12) months prior to the construction of sidewalks, curbs and street surfaces. If trench backfill is not used, the subdivider shall provide the city a
satisfactory bond insuring the repair of all damages caused by the settlement of trenches for a period of five (5) years.
(I) Private Streets: "Private streets" defined herein as a private thoroughfare permanently reserved or otherwise intended to provide access to more than
one zoning lot or to more than one principal building on a zoning lot, shall be improved as follows: (Ord. 2784, 5-17-2010)
1. Pavement Width: A minimum pavement width of twenty six feet (26') (exclusive of shoulders or curb) shall be provided.
2. On Street Parking: On street parking along a private street shall be permitted only when the following minimum pavement width (exclusive of
shoulders or curb) is provided:
Parallel parking permitted on one side: Twenty eight feet (28').
Parallel parking permitted on both sides: Thirty six feet (36').
3. Fire Lanes: All private streets shall be designed as fire lanes, and signs prohibiting on street parking shall be installed and maintained on both sides
of private streets with a pavement width of less than twenty seven feet (27'); and on one side of any private street with a pavement width of more
than twenty seven feet (27') but less than thirty six feet (36').
4. Cul-De-Sacs: The pavement of any cul-de-sac or vehicle turnaround area at the terminus of a private street shall have a minimum diameter of ninety
feet (90'). (Ord. 1544, 7-16-1990)
5. Construction: Roadways shall be constructed of base materials consisting of crushed stone or gravel not less than eight inches (8") after
compaction, suitable for the volume and character of traffic expected to use the street, and as approved by the city officials and the city engineer.
The surface shall be finished by constructing a three inch (3") combined hot mix asphalt binder and surface course conforming to section 406 of the
state of Illinois "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction", adopted January 1, 2007, or latest revision thereof.
6. Grade: Grades of streets shall not be in excess of five percent (5%) on primary streets, nor in excess of eight percent (8%) on other streets except in
cases of necessity and with the permission of the plan commission.
7. Drainage: All private streets shall be drained by means of ditches and/or a piped stormwater drainage system as follows: (Ord. 2784, 5-17-2010)
(a) Where drainage is by ditches, the ditches shall be placed on both sides of the road outside any shoulders (shoulders shall have a minimum width
of 2 feet), and shall have a minimum depth of two feet (2') below the edge of the roadway with maximum back slope of three to one (3:1), the fore
slope to be three to one (3:1). Maximum ditch gradient without erosion protection shall be two percent (2%). All culverts shall be designed to
accommodate a 20-year storm frequency for the total watershed area tributary to the culvert. Minimum culvert sizes shall be twelve inches (12") for
driveways and fifteen inches (15") for road crossings. At locations where culverts cross roadways, a minimum of twelve inches (12") will be
maintained between the top of the pipe and the pavement surface. Pavement edge radii shall be a minimum of twenty five feet (25') at connecting
side street locations. (Ord. 1544, 7-16-1990)
(b) Where roadway drainage is by a pipe storm sewer system, the system shall be designed to accommodate a 20-year storm frequency of one hour
duration for a total tributary area. Curbs and gutters shall be type B6.18 combination concrete curb and gutter in accordance with IDOT standards,
not less than twenty five inches (25") in overall width, not less than nine inches (9") thick where curb abuts the street pavement and shall conform
to the standard cross section established by the city. The type and location of stormwater inlets shall be provided within the roadway improvement
at points approved by the city engineer. Back of curb radii shall be a minimum of fifteen feet (15') at connecting side street locations or larger as
appropriate for the design vehicle at that location.
8. Sidewalks: Where sidewalks are planned, they shall be constructed of concrete to a width of not less than five feet (5'), and on each side of a private
street, unless a variance is approved. (Ord. 2784, 5-17-2010)
9. Street Lighting: Provisions shall be made by the subdivision developer or his agent for the adequate lighting of public streets within the proposed
subdivision, in accordance with the standard requirements established by the Illinois department of transportation guidelines in effect from time to
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 105/357
time, unless a variance is approved.
10. Snow Removal, Plowing: The city shall not be responsible for snow removal or plowing of any private street. Nor shall the city be responsible for
any cleaning, repairing, maintenance, resurfacing or any other improvement to any private street. Nor shall the city enforce any parking regulations
or other traffic regulations on a private street. (Ord. 1544, 7-16-1990)
3-11-8: VARIANCES AND EXCEPTIONS:
(A) Variances: The plan commission may recommend variances from the requirements of this chapter in specific cases which in its opinion do not affect
the general plan or the spirit of this chapter or where a strict application of the terms of this chapter would impose a practical difficulty or particular
hardship. Such recommendations shall be communicated to the council in writing and the reasons therefor. The council may approve variances from
these requirements in specific cases which in its opinion do not affect the general plan or the spirit of this chapter. (Ord. 1544, 7-16-1990; amd. Ord.
2093, 6-15-1998)
(B) Exceptions: (Rep. by Ord. 2093, 6-15-1998)
(C) Hearing: No variance permitted by this section shall be granted until the plan commission has conducted a hearing and filed a written report of its
finding and recommendations to the council.
(D) Plat: Each application for a variance under this section shall include a plat of survey, prepared by an Illinois registered land surveyor, showing the
resulting lots or tracts, and giving the legal descriptions therefor. (Ord. 1524, 3-19-1990)
3-11-9: OCCUPANCY PERMIT:
No occupancy permit shall be granted by any governing official for the use of any structure within a subdivision approved for platting until required utility
facilities have been installed and made ready to service the property, and until roadways providing access to the subject lot have been constructed, or are
in the course of construction. (Ord. 680, 1-17-1972)
3-11-10: ENFORCEMENT:
No plat of any subdivision shall be entitled to record in the county recorder's office or have any validity until it shall have been approved in the manner
prescribed by this chapter. (Ord. 680, 1-17-1972)
3-11-11: RECORD OF PLATS:
All such plats of subdivision, after the same have been submitted and approved as in this chapter provided, shall be copied upon a book of plats of the city
and shall be filed and kept by the city among the records of the city1. (Ord. 680, 1-17-1972)
Chapter 12
DIXON HOME TELEPHONE COMPANY FRANCHISE
3-12-1: FRANCHISE GRANTED:
Dixon Home Telephone Company, its lessees, successors and assigns (hereinafter referred to as the "grantee") is hereby granted the nonexclusive
permission, authority, right and privilege for a period of fifty (50) years to use the streets, alleys, bridges, rivers and other public places of the city, as the
same may exist from time to time, for the purpose of erecting, maintaining and operating a telephone system, including all necessary appurtenances, and
to use, jointly or otherwise, the property of other companies and to permit other companies to use its property under such arrangements as such
companies and the grantee may agree upon. (Ord., 9-8-1964)
3-12-2: LOCATION OF INSTALLATIONS:
All poles, wires, cables, conduits or other fixtures installed by the grantee under this chapter shall be located so as not to interfere unreasonably with the
ordinary travel and use by the public of the streets, alleys, bridges, rivers and other public places of the city. (Ord., 9-8-1964)
3-12-3: MOVING BUILDINGS:
No person shall move, over the public ways and places within said city, any building or other object or take any other action which will necessitate the
relocation of any of the grantee's equipment, without first agreeing to reimburse the grantee for the cost of such relocation, including the cost of
maintaining temporary service during such relocation, and securing a permit from said city. (Ord., 9-8-1964)
3-12-4: LIABILITY OF GRANTEE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 106/357
The grantee shall properly repair or replace any sidewalk or street surface which may be displaced or damaged by it in the erection and maintenance of its
telephone system. Upon failure of the grantee so to do and after thirty (30) days' notice in writing given by the city to the grantee, the city may repair or
replace such portion of the sidewalk or street surface as may have been disturbed by the grantee and collect the costs so incurred from the grantee. (Ord.,
9-8-1964)
3-12-5: CITY TO REGULATE:
The city hereby expressly reserves the right to establish, by ordinance or resolution, reasonable regulations for the convenience, safety and protection of
its inhabitants under the police power as the same now or hereafter exists in said city. (Ord., 9-8-1964)
3-12-6: LOW TENSION SIGNAL WIRES:
Upon request of said city, the grantee shall, during the life of this chapter, allow free use or sufficient space on a telephone cross arm or pin of each pole
and within the conduits of the grantee for carrying necessary police, fire alarm and other low tension signal wires belonging to or used by said city,
provided that, if, at the request of said city, the grantee shall install, relocate or maintain any such low tension signal wires, said city shall pay to the
grantee the actual costs incurred by the grantee in performing such installation, relocation or maintenance. (Ord., 9-8-1964)
3-12-7: OFFICIAL CITY USE:
The grantee agrees to install free of local exchange service charges such telephone equipment as the city council may request, for the official use of the
city at such places within the city served by the grantee as the city council may designate, the charges for which, in the absence of this provision, would be
equivalent to the gross subscriber station rental for thirty (30) main line business telephones, provided that, if the city shall hereafter impose upon the
grantee any fees, charges, licenses, taxes, or assessments other than: a) ad valorem taxes imposed generally upon all real and personal property situated
within the corporate limits of the city; and b) special assessments for special benefits accruing to property originated by the board of local improvements of
the city, the grantee shall no longer be obligated to furnish any service to the city free of charge pursuant to this section. (Ord., 9-8-1964)
3-12-8: EFFECTIVE DATE:
This chapter shall become effective thirty (30) days after its passage according to law. If, however, the grantee shall fail during said thirty (30) day period to
file in the office of the city clerk a written and unconditional acceptance of its provisions, this chapter shall be void and of no effect. And if during said thirty
(30) day period this chapter is suspended from going into operation pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/4-5-14 of the Illinois municipal code, it shall
thereafter take effect only in accordance with the provisions of said 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/4-5-14 of the Illinois municipal code. (Ord., 9-8-1964)
Chapter 13
ILLINOIS BELL TELEPHONE COMPANY FRANCHISE
(Rep. by Ord. 2024, 9-30-1997)
Chapter 14
CABLE TELEVISION FRANCHISE ORDINANCE
3-14-1: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the CABLE TELEVISION FRANCHISE ORDINANCE. (Ord. 1520, 3-5-1990)
3-14-2: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this ordinance, hereinafter referred to as "chapter", the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have the meanings
given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular
number, and words in the singular number include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory.
CITY: City of Dixon, Illinois.
COMMUNITY ANTENNA TELEVISION SYSTEM: A facility, consisting of a set of closed transmission paths and associated signal generation, reception,
and control equipment, or other communications equipment, that is designed to provide the cable service and other service to subscribers. Said term shall
also be referred to as "CATV system" or "system".
COUNCIL: Dixon city council.
EFFECTIVE DATE: January 1, 1990.
GRANTEE: An entity that is granted a franchise agreement under the terms of this chapter.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 107/357
PERSON: Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. (Ord. 1520, 3-5-1990; amd. Ord. 2777, 4-5-2010)
3-14-3: GRANT OF NONEXCLUSIVE AUTHORITY:
(A) There is hereby granted by the city to the grantee the nonexclusive right and privilege to construct, erect, operate and maintain, in, upon, along,
across, above, over and under the streets, alleys, public ways and public places now laid out or dedicated, and all extensions thereof and additions
thereto, in the city, poles, wires, cables, underground conduits, manholes, and other television conductors and fixtures necessary for the maintenance
and operation in the city of a CATV system for the interception, sale and distribution of television and radio signals, in accordance with the laws and
regulations of the United States Of America, the state of Illinois, and the ordinances and regulations of the city for the period provided in this chapter.
(B) The right to use and occupy said streets, alleys, public ways and places for the purpose herein set forth shall not be exclusive, and the city reserves
the right to grant a similar use of said streets, alleys, public ways and public places, to any person at any time during the period of this franchise. In the
event the city enters into a franchise, permit, license, authorization or other agreement of any kind with any other person or entity other than the
grantee for the purpose of constructing or operating a cable system or providing cable service to any part of the franchise area which contains terms
more favorable to such person or entity in any regard than similar provisions of this chapter, then this chapter shall be deemed amended as of the
effective date of the other franchise, permit, license, authorization, or other agreement, so as to give the grantee the benefit of any such more favorable
terms. (Ord. 1520, 3-5-1990)
3-14-4: COMPLIANCE WITH APPLICABLE LAWS AND ORDINANCES:
Grantee shall, at all times during the life of this franchise, be subject to all city ordinances and the lawful exercise of the police power by the city and to
such reasonable regulations as the city shall hereafter provide insofar as such ordinances and regulations are not materially inconsistent with this chapter
or a degradation of grantee's rights under this chapter, and insofar as such ordinances and regulations do not impose material obligations on the grantee
without the grantee's approval or except as otherwise provided in this chapter. (Ord. 1520, 3-5-1990)
3-14-5: TERRITORIAL AREA INVOLVED:
The area for which this franchise is granted shall encompass the present corporate limits of the city. The grantee shall construct and provide service to
those customers which are currently served by the cable television system. Grantee agrees to extend its service via aerial lines, in accordance with normal
installation rates, to any locations within the franchise area not now having service available which has a density of fifteen (15) homes per one-fourth (1/4)
mile measured from the nearest trunk line. All installation to areas not now having service and which do not meet the standard described above, will be on
a time plus materials basis. (Ord. 1520, 3-5-1990)
3-14-6: LIABILITY AND INDEMNIFICATION:
(A) Grantee shall pay and by its acceptance of this franchise the grantee specifically agrees that it will pay all damages and penalties which the city may
legally be required to pay as a result of grantee's operations under this franchise. These damages or penalties shall include, but shall not be limited to,
damages arising out of copyright infringements and all other damages arising out of the installation, operation, or maintenance of the CATV system
authorized herein, whether or not any act or omission complained of is authorized, allowed, or prohibited by this franchise.
(B) Grantee shall pay and by its acceptance of this franchise specifically agrees that it will pay all expenses incurred by the city in defending itself with
regard to all damages and penalties mentioned in subsection (A) of this section, except for negligent acts by the city or its employees or ultra vires acts
by the city. These expenses shall include all out of pocket expenses, such as reasonable attorney fees. (Ord. 1520, 3-5-1990)
3-14-7: COLOR TELEVISION:
The facilities used by the grantee shall be capable of distributing color television signals, and when the signals the grantee distributes are received in color,
they shall be distributed in color where technically feasible. (Ord. 1520, 3-5-1990)
3-14-8: SIGNAL QUALITY REQUIREMENTS:
(A) Grantee shall construct, install, operate and maintain its system in a manner consistent with those guidelines set forth by the federal communications
commission.
(B) Grantee shall limit failures to a minimum by locating and correcting malfunctions promptly.
(C) Grantee shall demonstrate by instruments and otherwise to subscribers that a signal of adequate strength and quality is being delivered. (Ord. 1520, 3-
5-1990)
3-14-9: NUMBER OF CHANNELS:
Grantee's cable distribution system shall have a minimum of thirty one (31) activated channels. The grantee's cable television system shall maintain one
channel which shall be available for public, governmental, educational and leased access for use by appropriate parties. (Ord. 1520, 3-5-1990)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 108/357
3-14-10: OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF SYSTEM:
(Rep. by Ord. 2777, 4-5-2010)
3-14-11: CARRIAGE OF SIGNALS:
Grantee shall receive and distribute television and radio broadcast signals which are disseminated to the general public only in accordance with all
applicable rules and regulations of the federal communications commission. (Ord. 1520, 3-5-1990)
3-14-12: PROGRAM ALTERATION:
All programming of broadcasting stations carried by the grantee shall be carried in accordance with applicable law. (Ord. 1520, 3-5-1990)
3-14-13: CABLE DISTRIBUTION OF OBSCENE MATERIAL:
Regarding obscene programming, the city and grantee shall comply with the rules and regulations of the cable communications policy act of 1984. (Ord.
1520, 3-5-1990)
3-14-14: SUBSCRIBER CONTROLLED PROGRAM SELECTION:
Grantee shall make available, by sale or lease, a parental control device by which a subscriber can prohibit the viewing of a premium service (a service for
which a fee in addition to the basic service fee is charged) during periods selected by that subscriber. (Ord. 1520, 3-5-1990)
3-14-15: SERVICE TO PUBLIC INSTITUTIONS:
Grantee shall provide basic service free of charge for one drop in the city hall, the city library, city police department, city fire department (collectively
referred to as "governmental buildings"), and in each public, private and parochial school within the present city limits and passed by cable upon request of
the city. All attachments to the governmental buildings and to the schools shall be at the expense of the grantee but distribution of the system within such
buildings shall be at the expense of the schools or the responsible public agencies. This requirement is for the term of the franchise. (Ord. 1520, 3-5-1990)
3-14-16: EMERGENCY USE OF FACILITIES:
(Rep. by Ord. 2777, 4-5-2010)
3-14-17: SAFETY REQUIREMENTS:
(A) Grantee shall at all times employ ordinary care and shall install and maintain in use commonly accepted methods and devices for preventing failures
and accidents which are likely to cause damage, injuries, or nuisances to the public.
(B) Grantee shall install and maintain its wires, cables, fixtures, and other equipment in accordance with the requirements of the national electrical safety
code promulgated by the National Bureau Of Standards and the national electrical code of the National Board Of Fire Underwriters and in such manner
that they will not unreasonably interfere with any installments of the city or of a public utility serving the city.
(C) All structures, lines, equipment and connections in, over, under, and upon the streets, sidewalks, alleys and public ways or places of the city, wherever
situated or located, shall at all times be kept and maintained in a safe, suitable, substantial condition, and in good order and repair. (Ord. 1520, 3-5-
1990)
3-14-18: CONDITIONS ON STREET OCCUPANCY:
(Rep. by Ord. 2777, 4-5-2010)
3-14-19: ERECTION, REMOVAL AND COMMON USE OF POLES:
(A) No poles or other wire holding structures shall be erected by the grantee without prior approval of the council with regard to location, height, type and
any other pertinent aspect. No location of any pole or wire holding structure of the grantee shall be a vested interest and such poles or structures shall
be removed or modified by the grantee at its own expense whenever the council reasonably determines that the public convenience would be
enhanced thereby.
(B) Where poles or other wire holding structures already exist for use in serving the city are available for use by the grantee, but grantee does not make
arrangements for such use, the council may require the grantee to use such poles and structures if the council determines that the public convenience
would be enhanced thereby and the terms of the use available to the grantee are just and reasonable.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 109/357
(C) Where the city or a public utility serving the city desires to make use of the poles or other wire holding structures of the grantee, but agreement therefor
with the grantee cannot be reached, the council may require the grantee to permit such use for such consideration and upon such terms as the council
shall determine to be just and reasonable, if the council determines that the use would enhance the public convenience and would not unduly interfere
with the grantee's present or future operations, subject to de novo review if requested by either party. (Ord. 1520, 3-5-1990)
3-14-20: RATES:
Grantee shall inform the city clerk, in writing, of any rate changes at least thirty (30) days before the effective date of the rate change. (Ord. 1520, 3-5-
1990)
3-14-21: PREFERENTIAL OR DISCRIMINATORY PRACTICES PROHIBITED:
Grantee shall not, as to service, service facilities, rules, regulations, or in any other respect, make or grant any undue preference or advantage to any
person nor subject any person to any prejudice or disadvantage. (Ord. 1520, 3-5-1990)
3-14-22: REMOVAL OF FACILITIES UPON REQUEST:
Upon termination of service to any subscriber, grantee shall promptly remove all its facilities and equipment from the premises of such subscriber upon the
terminating subscriber's request. (Ord. 1520, 3-5-1990)
3-14-23: TRANSFER OF FRANCHISE:
Grantee shall not transfer this franchise to another person without prior written consent of the city, which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld. The
requirements of this section shall not apply if the transfer is to an entity under the control of the grantee. No such consent shall be required, however, for a
transfer in trust, by mortgage, by other hypothecation, or by assignment of any rights, title or interest of grantee in the franchise or cable system, in order to
secure indebtedness. (Ord. 1520, 3-5-1990)
3-14-24: FORFEITURE OF FRANCHISE:
(A) In the event that the city determines that the grantee has not complied with the terms of this franchise, it shall notify grantee in writing of the exact
nature of the alleged noncompliance.
(B) Grantee shall have thirty (30) days from receipt of the notice described in subsection (A) of this section to: 1) respond to the city contesting the
assertion of noncompliance, or 2) cure default or, in the event that by the nature of default such default cannot be cured within the thirty (30) day
period, to initiate reasonable steps to remedy such default and notify the city of the steps being taken and the projected date that such default will be
cured.
(C) In the event that grantee fails to respond to the notice described in subsection (A) of this section pursuant to the procedures set forth in subsection (B)
of this section, or in the event that the alleged default is not remedied for any reason within sixty (60) days after the grantee is notified of the alleged
default pursuant to subsection (A) of this section, the city council shall schedule a public meeting to investigate the default. Such public meeting shall
be held during the council's next regularly scheduled meeting or at a special meeting of the council which shall be scheduled not less than five (5)
business days from the day of the giving of notice therefor. The city shall notify the grantee of the time and place of such meeting and provide the
grantee with an opportunity to be heard.
(D) Subject to applicable federal and state law, if, after such meeting, the council determines that grantee is in default of any provision of this chapter, the
council may:
1. Foreclose on all or any part of any security provided under this chapter, if any, including without limitation, any bonds or other surety; provided,
however, the foreclosure shall only be in such a manner and in such amount as the council reasonably determines is necessary to remedy the
default;
2. Commence an action at law for monetary damages or other equitable relief;
3. Declare the franchise to be revoked; or
4. Seek specific performance of any provision which reasonably lends itself to such remedy as an alternative to damages.
Grantee shall not be relieved of any of its obligations to comply promptly with any provision of this chapter by reason of any failure of the city to
enforce prompt compliance.
(E) Grantee shall not be held in default, violation or noncompliance with the provisions of this chapter, nor suffer any enforcement or penalty relating
thereto, where such noncompliance or alleged defaults are caused by strikes, acts of God, power outages, or other events reasonably beyond its ability
to control. (Ord. 1520, 3-5-1990)
3-14-25: CHANGE OF CONTROL OF GRANTEE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 110/357
Prior written consent of the city council, which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld, shall be required if ownership or control of more than fifty
percent (50%) of grantee is acquired by a person or group of persons, none of whom own or control fifty percent (50%) or more of grantee on the effective
date hereof. By its acceptance of this franchise, the grantee specifically grants and agrees that any such acquisition occurring without prior approval of the
city shall constitute a violation of this franchise by the grantee. (Ord. 1520, 3-5-1990)
3-14-26: FILINGS AND COMMUNICATIONS WITH REGULATORY AGENCIES:
Upon request, copies of all petitions, applications and communications submitted by the grantee to the federal communications commission, securities and
exchange commission, or any other federal or state regulatory commission or agency having jurisdiction in respect to any matters affecting CATV system
operations authorized pursuant to this franchise, shall be submitted within thirty (30) days to the city clerk. (Ord. 1520, 3-5-1990)
3-14-27: CITY RIGHTS IN FRANCHISE:
(A) The right is hereby reserved to the council to adopt, in addition to: 1) the provisions contained herein, and 2) existing applicable ordinances, such
additional rules, regulations and ordinances as it shall find necessary in the exercise of its lawful police power; provided that such rules, regulations, or
ordinances shall not be inconsistent with the rights granted herein.
(B) City shall have the right on a confidential basis to inspect the books, records, maps, plans and other like materials of the grantee necessary for
enforcement of this chapter, upon reasonable written notice, at any time during the normal business hours.
(C) City shall have the right, during the life of this franchise, to install and maintain, free of charge, upon the poles of the grantee, any wire and pole fixtures
necessary for a police alarm system, on the conditions that: 1) such wire and pole fixtures do not interfere with the present and future CATV operations
of the grantee, and 2) the city indemnify the grantee against any damage or injuries arising therefrom.
(D) City shall have the right to supervise all construction or installation work performed subject to the provisions of this franchise and make such
inspections as it shall deem necessary to ensure compliance with the terms of this chapter and other pertinent provisions of law.
(E) Subject to federal and state laws, at the expiration of the term for which this franchise is granted, or upon its termination and cancellation as provided
for herein, the city shall have the right to require the grantee to remove, at grantee's sole expense, all portions of the CATV system from all public ways
within the city.
(F) This franchise shall be renewable under the rules and regulations of the cable communications policy act of 1984 and any amendments thereto.
(G) City may schedule and hold public meetings or meetings with the grantee to review the performance by the grantee under this chapter, including future
plans of operation and performance.
(H) From time to time, and at any time, grantee has the right to modify its rates and charges including, but not limited to, the implementation of additional
charges and rates; provided, however, that grantee shall give notice to the city of any such modifications or additional charges thirty (30) days prior to
the effective date thereof. (Ord. 1520, 3-5-1990)
3-14-28: MAPS, PLATS AND REPORTS:
(A) Upon request, the grantee shall file with the city clerk true and accurate maps or plats of all existing distribution systems.
(B) Grantee shall file annually with the city clerk, not later than April 1 of each year, a statement of gross revenues applicable to its operations during the
preceding twelve (12) month calendar, upon which the franchise fees levied under this chapter are computed. These reports shall be certified as
accurate by the chief financial officer of the grantee and there shall be submitted along with said reports such other reasonable information as the
council shall request for the enforcement of this chapter. (Ord. 1520, 3-5-1990)
3-14-29: PAYMENT TO THE CITY:
(Rep. by Ord. 2777, 4-5-2010)
3-14-30: WRITTEN PERMISSION REQUIRED TO SELL SUBSCRIBER LISTING:
Grantee shall comply with the rules and regulations concerning subscriber privacy contained in section 631 of the cable communications policy act of
1984. (Ord. 1520, 3-5-1990)
3-14-31: CATASTROPHIC DAMAGE:
Grantee shall not be held in default or noncompliance with the provisions of the franchise, nor suffer any enforcement or penalty relating hereto, where
such noncompliance or alleged defaults are caused by acts of God or other events reasonably beyond its ability to control. (Ord. 1520, 3-5-1990)
