https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 152/357
(H) The city council, or its designee, may promulgate such further or additional regulations concerning the administration and enforcement of this chapter,
consistent with its provisions, as may be required from time to time and shall notify all telecommunications retailers that are registered pursuant to
section 3-22-2 of this chapter of such regulations. (Ord. 2023, 9-30-1997)
3-22-5: COMPLIANCE WITH OTHER LAWS:
Nothing in this chapter shall excuse any person or entity from obligations imposed under any law, including, but not limited to:
(A) Generally applicable taxes; and
(B) Standards for construction on, over, or within, use of or repair of the public rights of way, including standards relating to freestanding towers and other
structures upon the public rights of way, as provided; and
(C) Any liability imposed for the failure to comply with such generally applicable taxes or standards governing construction on, over, under, or within, use of
or repair of the public rights of way; and
(D) Compliance with any ordinance or provision of this code concerning uses or structures not located on, over, or within the right of way. (Ord. 2023, 9-30-
1997)
3-22-6: EXISTING FRANCHISES AND LICENSES:
Any franchise, license, or similar agreements between telecommunications retailers and the city entered into before the effective date of this chapter
regarding the use of public rights of way shall remain valid according to and for their stated terms except for any fees, charges or other compensation to
the extent waived. (Ord. 2023, 9-30-1997)
3-22-7: PENALTIES:
Any telecommunications provider who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects, or refuses to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to
fine in accordance with the general penalty provisions of this code. (Ord. 2023, 9-30-1997)
3-22-8: ENFORCEMENT:
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as limiting any additional or further remedies that the city may have for enforcement of this chapter. (Ord. 2023,
9-30-1997)
3-22-9: SEVERABILITY:
If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or portion of this chapter is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent
jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct, and independent provision and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining
portions hereof. (Ord. 2023, 9-30-1997)
3-22-10: CONFLICT:
This chapter supersedes all chapters or parts of chapters adopted prior hereto which are in conflict herewith, to the extent of such conflict. (Ord. 2023, 9-
30-1997)
3-22-11: WAIVER AND FEE IMPLEMENTATION:
(A) The city hereby waives all fees, charges, and other compensation that may accrue, after the effective date of the waiver, to the city by a
telecommunications retailer pursuant to any existing city franchise, license, or similar agreement with a telecommunications retailer during the time the
city imposes the telecommunications infrastructure maintenance fee. This waiver shall only be effective during the time the infrastructure maintenance
fee provided for in this chapter is subject to being lawfully imposed on the telecommunications retailer and collected by the telecommunications retailer
from the customer.
(B) The city clerk shall send a notice of the waiver by certified mail/return receipt requested to each telecommunications retailer with whom the city has a
franchise.
(C) The city infrastructure maintenance fee provided for in this chapter shall become effective and imposed on the first day of the month not less than
ninety (90) days after the city provides written notice by certified mail to each telecommunications retailer with whom the city has an existing franchise,
license, or similar agreement that the city waives all compensation under such existing franchise, license, or similar agreement during such time as the
fee is subject to being lawfully imposed and collected by the retailer and remitted to the city. The infrastructure maintenance fee shall apply to gross
charges billed on or after the effective date as established in the preceding sentence. (Ord. 2023, 9-30-1997)

Title 4
PUBLIC HEALTH AND SANITATION
Chapter 1
VITAL STATISTICS
4-1-1: REPORT TO REGISTRAR:
A report of all births, stillbirths and deaths shall be made to the registrar of vital statistics, which report shall contain all information required by an act of the
general assembly of the state of Illinois, entitled "an act in relation to births, stillbirths, and deaths, and to provide for the registration and establishment of
records thereof", as amended. (1950 Code)
4-1-2: RECORDS TO BE KEPT:
The registrar shall keep a record showing all births, stillbirths and deaths occurring within the city and of all burial permits issued, which record shall
include all information required to be kept by the act hereinabove described. (1950 Code)
Chapter 2
CONTAGIOUS DISEASES
4-2-1: DISEASES TO BE REPORTED:
Every physician or other person having knowledge of any known or suspected case of contagious disease shall, within twelve (12) hours after first
discovering the existence of such disease, make a report thereof to the health officer, which report shall give the name, if known, and the place of dwelling
of persons suspected. (1950 Code)
4-2-2: REMOVAL:
No case of contagious disease shall be removed from the house or building in which found to another except by permission of the health officer and then
only by private conveyance and after due care has been taken to prevent the spread of the disease; provided, that when a case of contagious disease is
discovered in a school or other public building the patient may be immediately sent to his usual residence or to a hospital, by private conveyance only, and
such vehicle shall be properly disinfected before it shall be further used. (1950 Code)
4-2-3: QUARANTINE:
As soon as the attending physician makes a diagnosis of a contagious disease, the attending physician shall advise the family and the patient as to the
nature of the disease and isolate the patient or advise the family to do so and shall also advise the family not to permit children to attend school. The
health officer is hereby charged with the enforcement of the rules and regulations that may from time to time be adopted by the Illinois department of public
health for the control, suppression and eradication of contagious diseases and all provisions of this code relating thereto.
He shall have power and authority to place any premises within which a contagious disease occurs under quarantine, to quarantine any case, carrier,
contact or exposure and to determine when the quarantine shall end.
The procedures for the administrative control of contagious diseases prescribed by the Illinois department of public health are hereby adopted and
declared to be the effective procedure to be followed by the health officer of the city and to which all persons in the city shall hereafter be subject. (1950
Code)
4-2-4: PLACARDING:
Whenever a contagious disease is reported to the health officer, he or one of his duly authorized inspectors or nurses or a police officer acting at his
request may affix at the outside of the entrance or entrances to the building, house, flat or room a red warning card not less than ten inches by fourteen
inches (10" x 14") in size on which shall be printed in black with boldface type the name of the contagious disease in type not less than three and one-half
inches (31/2") in height and "Keep Out" in similar type not less than two and one-half inches (21/2") in height. Defacement or concealment of warning cards
or their removal by any other than a duly authorized person of the health officer is prohibited. (1950 Code)
4-2-5: DELIVERIES TO QUARANTINED PREMISES:
No person engaged in the delivery of food or drink intended for human consumption shall enter into any premises which are quarantined. No containers or
bottles shall be removed from such premises until the termination of the quarantine; and no such containers which have been left at the premises during
the quarantine shall be placed in use until they have been sterilized. (1950 Code)
4-2-6: FUMIGATION:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 154/357
Premises which have been quarantined shall be thoroughly fumigated or otherwise freed from all risk of infection when directed by the health officer before
the quarantine shall be lifted. (1950 Code)
4-2-7: SCHOOL REPORTS:
Whenever any schoolchild, teacher or person employed on school premises has been in contact with, exposed to, or is suffering from a contagious
disease it shall be the duty of the health officer to immediately report such fact to the school authorities. (1950 Code)
4-2-8: VACCINATION FOR ADMISSION TO SCHOOLS:
No principal of any school shall at times of any epidemic of smallpox or of threatened epidemic thereof, or whenever there reasonably appears to be
danger of the contagion of smallpox, admit to any school any child who shall be reasonably considered a contact to a case of smallpox and who shall not
have been vaccinated within five (5) years next preceding the admission or application for admission to any school of such child, or who shall not
previously have had smallpox. (1950 Code)
4-2-9: EVIDENCE OF IMMUNIZATION:
The evidence of vaccination or of previously having had smallpox to be presented to any principal shall be a certificate signed by the health officer or any
physician duly licensed by the state department of registration and education. (1950 Code)
4-2-10: SCHOOL INSPECTION:
The health officer is hereby empowered to inspect schools in the city as often as he may deem necessary to secure compliance with the provisions hereof.
(1950 Code)
4-2-11: DEATH FROM CONTAGIOUS DISEASE:
It shall be the duty of each physician in the city to report in writing to the health officer the death of any of his patients who shall have died in the city of a
contagious disease and to state in such report the specific name and type of the disease1. (1950 Code)
Chapter 3
SOLID WASTE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL
4-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
When used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the following meanings:
BAG(S): A plastic sack embossed with the city logo and sold by area merchants designed to store refuse for the purpose of collection. Total weight of a
bag and its contents shall not exceed fifty (50) pounds.
BULKY WASTE: Rubbish such as stoves, refrigerators, water heaters, washing machines, "white goods", furniture, automobile tires and other waste
materials (with weights or volumes greater than those allowed for containers) other than construction debris, dead animals, garbage, rubbish, yard wastes,
stable material and hazardous waste.
BULKY WASTE STICKER: A biodegradable sticker, stamped with the city logo, sold through retailers to the public, wherein the purchase price of the
sticker includes collection, processing, and disposal costs for one bulky waste item.
BUNDLE: Tree, shrub and brush trimmings securely tied together forming an easily handled package not exceeding forty eight inches (48") in length, four
inches (4") in diameter or fifty (50) pounds in weight.
CITY: City of Dixon, Illinois.
CONSTRUCTION DEBRIS: Waste building materials resulting from construction, remodeling, repair or demolition operations.
CONTAINER: As used herein, the term container or containers may refer collectively to the four (4) defined types of receptacles defined herein: a) bags, b)
yard waste receptacle, c) toters, and d) recyclable container, or the term may refer to any one of said four (4) defined types of receptacles where the text
clearly evidences an intent to specifically limit such reference to one of the four (4) defined receptacles, or the term may refer only to the appropriate
receptacle or receptacles for the specific type of waste where the text clearly evidences an intent to limit such reference to the receptacles allowed to be
used for the containment of such specific waste.
CONTRACTOR: The person, corporation or partnership performing refuse collection and disposal pursuant to a written agreement with the city.
CURBSIDE COLLECTION: The collection of all refuse and yard waste placed in accordance with city ordinances regulating the placement of same
including alley collection.
DEAD ANIMALS: Animals or portions thereof equal to or greater than twenty (20) pounds in weight that have expired from any cause, except those
slaughtered or killed for human use or consumption.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 155/357
DWELLING UNIT: Any single- or multi-family dwelling units and condominiums of less than four (4) units within the corporate limits of the city containing a
kitchen and occupied by a person or group of persons. A dwelling unit shall be deemed occupied when either water or domestic light and power services
are being supplied thereto. Each single-family dwelling within any multi-family dwelling unit or condominium shall be billed separately as a dwelling unit.
GARBAGE: All animal and vegetable matter originating from the handling, preparation, cooking, consumption, storage, decay or decomposition of food
(meats, fish, fowl, fruits, grains) or any other animal or vegetable matter whatsoever subject to decay which may putrefy or generate noxious or offensive
odors, be a food source for rodents, or a breeding or feeding place for insects or vermin and all dead animals of less than twenty (20) pounds in weight but
excluding yard waste, construction debris, bulky waste, stable material, hazardous waste and rubbish. The term "garbage" shall not include waste from
any manufacturing process, construction materials, broken concrete, lumber, large rocks, automobile parts other than tires, or dangerous substances
which may create a danger to the health, safety, comfort or welfare of the residents of the city.
GARBAGE AND REFUSE COLLECTION OR COLLECTION: The taking up and collecting of all refuse accumulated in containers at residential dwelling
units within the corporate limits of the city and the transportation to an approved disposal site.
HARD YARD WASTE: Brown stemmed branches and shrub pruning with large diameter stems/trunks not to exceed four inches (4") in diameter or forty
eight inches (48") in length individually. Evergreen Christmas trees are included in this definition, except for collection and disposal purposes.
HAZARDOUS WASTE: Waste, in any amount, which is defined, characterized or designated as hazardous by the United States environmental protection
agency, the Illinois environmental protection agency, or any other federal or state agency having jurisdictional authority thereof. The term hazardous waste
shall also include motor oil and gasoline.
PRODUCER: Occupant(s) of a dwelling unit who generates refuse.
RECYCLABLE MATERIALS OR RECYCLABLES: Nonhazardous household materials, newspaper, cardboard, mixed paper, corrugated cardboard, paper
grocery bags, paperboard, glass bottles and containers, aluminum and tin cans, HDPE plastic containers, HDPE plastic water jugs, and PET plastic two
(2) liter pop bottles. Other materials may hereinafter be added to or deleted from this definition by the city.
RECYCLING: The technical ability of a material to be reused in manufacturing with the requirement that a recycling collection, processing and market
system be in place and economically functioning in order for recyclable materials to be recyclable.
RECYCLING COLLECTION: The collection of all recyclable materials accumulated in containers at dwelling units receiving curbside collection.
RECYCLING CONTAINERS: A plastic twenty (20) gallon container serial numbered, purchased and distributed by the contractor to residents receiving
residential curbside collection. Said container shall have attached to it the city logo in a form and size to be approved by the city. It shall be the
responsibility of the contractor to purchase said stickers.
REFUSE: All wastes which normally result from the operation of a household including all garbage, rubbish, and bulky wastes.
RUBBISH: All solid wastes consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, including, but not limited to, paper, plastics, bottles, glass, soiled
cardboard, metal, cans, bricks, ashes, sod, dirt, rocks, cement, trees, wood, leather, and other like materials small enough for one man to handle. The
term rubbish shall not include yard waste, construction debris, bulky waste, dead animals, garbage, stable matter, and hazardous waste. The term rubbish
shall not include waste from any manufacturing process, construction materials, broken concrete, lumber, large rocks, automobile parts other than tires, or
dangerous substances which may create a danger to the health, safety, comfort or welfare of the residents of the city.
SOFT YARD WASTE: Grass clippings, leaves, prunings of small diameter, green stemmed shrubs (i.e., new growth on a privet hedge) and plant stalks.
STABLE MATTER: All manure and other waste matter normally accumulated in or about a stable, or any animal, livestock or poultry enclosure, and
resulting from the keeping of animals, poultry or livestock.
TOTER: Container having a maximum capacity of sixty (60) gallons. Toters shall be placed in service throughout the city and shall be owned and provided
by the contractor. Each toter must have an attached lid, a handle and wheels having a minimum of six inches (6") in diameter. The term "toter" is used in a
generic sense and is not intended to refer to a specific brand name.
UNACCEPTABLE RECYCLABLE MATERIAL: Materials not properly prepared, separated and/or located in accordance with this chapter.
WASTE: All discarded or useless matter of any type including yard waste, recyclable materials, refuse, stable matter or any carcass of any animal or any
putrid or unsound flesh, fish, offal or any unclear or nauseous liquid or any putrid, unsound or unsanitary substance or liquids.
WHITE GOODS: Refrigerators, freezers, air conditioners, dehumidifiers and other similar large appliances that contain chlorofluorocarbon gases, or
electric switches containing mercury, or any device that contains or may contain PCBs in a closed system.
WHITE GOODS STICKER: A biodegradable sticker, stamped with the city logo, sold through retailers to the public, wherein the purchase price of the
sticker includes collection, processing, and disposal costs for one white good item.
YARD WASTE: Combustible, organic material consisting of dead plants, weeds, Christmas trees, tree or hedge trimming, grass clippings and leaves but
excluding tree limbs over four inches (4") in diameter or forty eight inches (48") in length.
YARD WASTE COLLECTION: The taking and collecting of all yard waste accumulated in a yard waste receptacle at all dwelling units in the city.
YARD WASTE RECEPTACLE: (A) A (maximum) forty (40) gallon container clearly marked with an X; or
(B) A biodegradable kraft paper brown bag holding fifty (50) pounds or less. Clear plastic lawn/leaf bags may not be used. (Ord. 1758, 8-16-1993; amd.
Ord. 2079, 4-20-1998, eff. 5-1-1998; Ord. 2363, 12-3-2001; Ord. 2634, 4-16-2007)
4-3-2: ADMINISTRATION:
(A) All matters relating to or affecting the accumulation, collection, removal or disposal of refuse, recyclable materials, yard waste, and other waste, unless
otherwise provided herein, shall be subject to and under the supervision of the commissioner of public properties or his designee.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 156/357
(B) The operation and enforcement of this chapter are subject to such rules and regulations as may be adopted by the commissioner of public properties
or his designee and to the provisions of the statutes and regulations of the state and the federal government.
(C) For purposes of this chapter, the commissioner of public properties is hereby authorized and directed to cause all refuse and recyclable materials to be
collected regularly and systematically at least once each seven (7) days and yard waste as often as hereinafter indicated from all dwelling units in the
city.
(D) All containers shall be subject to inspection, approval or condemnation by the commissioner of public properties. (Ord. 1758, 8-16-1993; amd. Ord.
1877, 5-15-1995)
4-3-3: RESIDENTIAL SOLID WASTE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL:
(A) Residential Service Required: Every person in possession of a dwelling unit in the city shall, except as otherwise herein provided, be required to have
accumulations of refuse collected and disposed of regularly and systematically at least once each seven (7) days by the contractor. The occupancy of a
dwelling unit for residential purposes shall be prima facie evidence that refuse is being produced and accumulated at such dwelling unit. The city shall
have the authority to inspect the premises of any dwelling unit and cause to be removed therefrom any and all refuse found. The owner of the property
upon which the dwelling unit is located and the producer shall be jointly and severally responsible for the collection and removal of the waste and liable
for payment of the fee established hereunder. The garbage and refuse collection service is furnished to the dwelling unit only upon the condition that
the owner of the residential dwelling unit and the producer are jointly and severally liable for said service to the city and contractor.
(B) Authorization: At any dwelling unit all refuse, recyclable material and yard waste shall be collected and disposed of by the contractor and, except as
otherwise may be provided herein, shall not be collected or disposed of in any other manner.
(C) Exclusive Contract: All refuse, recyclable material and yard waste shall be collected from all dwelling units within the city by the contractor under
exclusive contract with the city. No persons shall use the services of any other scavenger for the collection of any waste, except construction debris,
unless specifically provided for herein. (Ord. 1758, 8-16-1993)
(D) Collection: The contractor shall provide collection services to each dwelling unit within the city at least one time per week. Refuse, yard waste and
recycling shall be performed on the same collection day.
1. Regular Weekly Refuse Collection Services: All refuse shall be placed in a toter supplied by the contractor or a bag. Bags may be purchased by the
resident and shall be used by the resident for refuse that exceeds toter capacity.
Residents of age sixty five (65) years or older or residents with a physical disability may, in lieu of using a toter, purchase five (5) bags per month.
Residents using this option may purchase the bags at the office of the contractor employed by the city by making the quarterly payment required
herein, in advance. Said residents may prepay and purchase up to fifteen (15) bags at any one time per any quarterly period. (Ord. 2079, 4-20-1998,
eff. 5-1-1998)
The contractor shall collect all toters or bags filled with refuse from the curbside from each dwelling unit on a weekly basis as designated by the city.
Residents may use up to two (2) toters provided that the resident pays for the additional toter based on the monthly fee. The resident of the dwelling
unit shall place the toter or the bag at curbside or as close as practicable to collection vehicle routes by six o'clock (6:00) A.M. on the designated
collection day. Any refuse placed in a toter or bag for collection shall be drained free of all liquids and shall be less than fifty (50) pounds. Fats, oils
and grease shall be placed in sealed containers to prevent leakage. No toter or bag may be filled with materials which may cause injury to persons
handling the toter or bag including, but not limited to, poisons, acids or caustic materials. The cost of this service is included in the fee schedule set
forth in subsection 4-3-5(A) of this chapter. The contractor shall provide replacement toters for a reasonable fee when notified by a resident that a
toter is damaged or missing. If the damage is caused by an employee of the contractor, the contractor must promptly replace the toter without charge
to the resident. If the toter is stolen, the resident must report the theft to the city police department. Upon verification of theft, the contractor will
secure a replacement toter to the resident at the contractor's expense. Residents moving into a new home within the city shall contact the contractor
for a toter. Residents moving into a previously owned home will be given the toter assigned to the prior resident. Toters will be registered to the
dwelling unit's street address by serial number. (Ord. 2634, 4-16-2007)
2. Recycling Collection: The contractor shall provide collection of recyclables to each dwelling unit within the city at least one time per week as
designated by the city.
All recyclable materials must be placed in a recycling container provided by the contractor for recycling collection. A resident may be provided at no
charge, upon reasonable request made to the contractor, with additional recyclable containers. The monthly cost shall remain the same regardless of
the number of recycling containers. The contractor shall provide replacement recycling containers for a reasonable fee when notified by a resident
that a recycling container is damaged or missing. If the damage is caused by an employee of the contractor, the contractor must promptly replace the
recycling container without charge to the resident. If the recycling container is stolen, the resident must report the theft to the city police department.
Upon verification of theft, the contractor will secure a replacement recycling container to the resident at the contractor's expense.
Residents moving into a new home within the city shall contact the contractor for a recycling container. Residents moving into a previously owned
home will be given the recycling container assigned to the prior resident. Recycling containers will be registered to the dwelling unit's street address
by serial number. (Ord. 1758, 8-16-1993)
The resident of the dwelling unit shall place the recyclables at curbside or as close as practicable to collection vehicle routes by six o'clock (6:00)
A.M. on the designated collection day. The cost of this service is included in the charges set forth in subsection 4-3-5(A) of this chapter. The following
procedures shall be used in preparing the recyclable materials for collection: (Ord. 1758, 8-16-1993; amd. Ord. 1911, 11-6-1995; Ord. 1955, 9-3-
1996; Ord. 2014, 9-2-1997; Ord. 2079, 4-20-1998, eff. 5-1-1998; Ord. 2634, 4-16-2007)
(a) Newspaper, Mixed Paper And Cardboard:
(1) Newspapers and newspaper inserts are acceptable.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 157/357
(2) Magazines, junk mail, catalogs, phone books, paper grocery bags, corrugated cardboard, stationery, copy paper, envelopes, notepaper,
computer paper, paperboard, cardboard, cereal boxes and paper tubes are also acceptable.
(3) Newspaper should be stacked loosely on the bottom of the recycling container to reduce litter problems.
(4) Paperboard and cardboard must be free of food debris and grease.
(5) Cardboard must be flat; cardboard can be placed in the recycling container or in a brown paper sack or underneath the bin. Cardboard cannot
be larger than three feet by three feet (3' x 3').
(6) Mixed paper can be placed in the recycling container or in a brown paper bag.
(b) Glass Containers:
(1) Only unbroken bottles and jars are acceptable.
(2) Clear, brown and green glass are all acceptable.
(3) Glass containers should be rinsed and free of visible food debris.
(4) Caps or lids must be removed.
(5) Labels and rings may be left on.
(6) No Pyrex, window glass, crystal, mirrors, dishes, ovenware or ceramics.
(c) Cans:
(1) Includes all beverage, food, and aerosol cans.
(2) Aluminum and tin cans are acceptable.
(3) No other metal containers or aluminum products are acceptable.
(4) Crushing cans is recommended.
(5) Cans must be rinsed and free of visible food debris.
(6) Nonaerosol, pesticide, chemical, paint thinner, or solvent cans are not acceptable.
(7) Containers of petroleum or hazardous material are not acceptable.
(d) Plastic Containers:
(1) Only plastic containers with the no. 1 through no. 6 recycling symbols are acceptable.
(2) Plastic (HDPE) clear or colored milk containers and water jugs are acceptable.
(3) Soda (PET) bottles are acceptable.
(4) Milk jugs must be rinsed and free of food debris. (Ord. 2079, 4-20-1998, eff. 5-1-1998)
(e) Loading The Recycling Container: Recyclables shall be arranged in the recycling container before placing the recycling container at the curb as
follows:
(1) All newspapers must be placed loosely at the bottom or side of the recycling container or in brown paper bags.
(2) Glass, cans, and plastic may be commingled and be placed on top of the newspapers. (Ord. 1758, 8-16-1993)
3. Yard Waste Collection: The contractor shall provide curbside collection of yard waste for each dwelling unit within the city. The contractor shall collect
soft yard waste contained in yard waste receptacles on a weekly basis for the periods of March 1 through November 30 and the first two (2) weeks in
January (at which time discarded Christmas trees shall be collected at no cost to the dwelling unit) and twice a month for the remainder of the year.
Residents shall furnish the yard waste receptacle. Brush and tree limbs shall be placed in a bundle. The cost of this service is included in the
charges set forth in subsection 4-3-5(A) of this chapter. (Ord. 1758, 8-16-1993; amd. Ord. 1911, 11-6-1995; Ord. 1955, 9-3-1996; Ord. 2014, 9-2-
1997; Ord. 2079, 4-20-1998, eff. 5-1-1998)
4. Special Haul Services For Bulky Waste: The contractor shall provide collection service of bulky waste. Bulky waste shall be collected at a cost of two
dollars seventy five cents ($2.75) per bulky waste item; fifteen dollars ($15.00) per white goods item; two dollars seventy five cents ($2.75) per small
or large furniture items, which include chairs, small tables, couches, mattresses and beds; and ten dollars ($10.00) per loose pile not to exceed two
(2) cubic yards or such other amounts as shall be determined from time to time by the city council. Said amount shall be paid by the resident by
purchasing a bulky waste sticker or white goods sticker. Loose pile charges shall be billed by the contractor. The aforesaid rates may be amended
from time to time by the city council.
5. Hours Of Operation By Contractor And Scavengers: No collections by the contractor or any other scavenger licensed to do business in the city shall
begin prior to six o'clock (6:00) A.M., nor continue after six thirty o'clock (6:30) P.M. (Ord. 2634, 4-16-2007)
6. Construction Debris: Removal of construction debris shall be the responsibility of the owner of the premises and person or building contractor
performing such work. The owner, person or contractor may employ a licensed scavenger to remove such construction debris provided the
scavenger shall not remove refuse generated by the occupants of any dwelling unit whether or not the dwelling unit is under repair or construction.
Such scavenger need not be the contractor employed by the city but must be licensed to do business by the city pursuant to section 4-3-11 of this
chapter.
(E) Containers:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 158/357
1. Except as may otherwise be provided for herein, no person shall permit any waste to accumulate on his/her premises except in containers. Each
person in possession of any premises in the city where persons reside shall provide and at all times properly maintain sufficient containers for the
weekly collection of such waste. Each person in possession of such premises shall cause to be deposited in such container all waste produced in or
on, or brought into or on such premises, as soon as practicable after the same is produced in or on, or brought therein.
2. Contractor may decline to collect any container, bundle or bulky waste not placed as provided herein. Containers which are other than as specified in
this chapter shall not be disposed of by the contractor. Waste shall be sufficiently bagged, bundled or covered in such manner as may be necessary
to prevent scattering and shall be deposited in an appropriate container. (Ord. 1758, 8-16-1993)
3. Yard waste and bulky waste (provided doors are removed from appliances prior to placement at the curb) shall be placed within six feet (6') behind
the curb. All waste shall be placed in an orderly fashion by the resident of the dwelling unit at or prior to six o'clock (6:00) A.M. on the day scheduled
for pick up but in no event prior to four thirty o'clock (4:30) P.M. on the evening preceding a scheduled pick up. All bulky waste shall have hazardous
wastes, including freon and compressor oils, removed prior to placement at the curb. (Ord. 2634, 4-16-2007)
4. All containers and waste shall be removed from the curb, so as to be hidden from the street and adjacent property owners within twenty four (24)
hours after the contractor has been present for the purpose of collection. The contractor's refusal to collect such waste does not limit the
requirements provided for herein.
(F) Hazardous Waste: The contractor shall not collect hazardous waste and no hazardous waste shall be deposited in any container for collection by the
contractor. (Ord. 1758, 8-16-1993)
(G) Disposal Of Rubbish By Permit:
1. The owner or resident of a dwelling unit shall be allowed to utilize a commercial container provided by a licensed scavenger at that dwelling unit as a
container for the disposal of "rubbish" (as that term is defined in this chapter) in accordance with this subsection (G). Such scavenger need not be
the contractor employed by the city but must be licensed to do business by the city pursuant to section 4-3-11 of this chapter. No commercial
container shall be allowed or utilized unless a permit therefor shall have been issued by the city building department prior to placement of the
commercial container at the dwelling unit.
2. Upon application of the owner or resident of a dwelling unit and payment of the permit fee established from time to time by the city, a commercial
container permit shall be issued to such owner or occupant for the disposal of rubbish generated at the designated dwelling unit. Such permit shall
be issued for a period of thirty (30) days. No commercial container permit shall be issued for the same dwelling unit more than two (2) times in any
one calendar year. The permit, when issued, shall be displayed prominently in a front window of the dwelling unit so as to be visible from the street
upon which the dwelling unit fronts with the date of expiration facing the street.
3. The application for commercial container permit shall be upon forms as prescribed from time to time by the city building department and shall include
at least the following information: the name, address and phone number of the applicant; the address of the dwelling unit for which the permit is
sought; and the name of the licensed scavenger providing the commercial container. No permit shall be granted to an applicant or for a dwelling unit
whose city water or sewer account is in arrears or whose account with the city's contractor for residential solid waste collection and disposal is in
arrears.
4. Commercial containers placed in accordance with this subsection (G) shall be utilized only for the disposal of rubbish, and no other materials or
wastes shall be placed therein nor disposed of using the commercial container. The commercial container shall be "tipped" or dumped at least one
time during the thirty (30) day period for which a permit is issued and shall be maintained in such manner, including covering, as may be necessary
to prevent scattering of rubbish. Any other materials or waste generated at the dwelling unit for which the commercial container permit is issued shall
be disposed of in otherwise approved containers and in accordance with the requirements of this chapter.
5. Each application for a commercial container permit shall be accompanied by the payment of a fee in the amount of ten dollars ($10.00). The permit
fees and copies of the application shall be deposited with the city building department. The city building department shall maintain a record of each
application and permit granted, the date when granted, the date of expiration, and copies of each application. (Ord. 2900, 12-17-2012)
4-3-4: NONRESIDENTIAL WASTE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL:
(A) Service Required:
1. Other than owners of dwelling units, it shall be the duty of every property owner, including multi-family dwelling units, commercial, business and
industrial establishments, to provide for the collection and removal of all waste of any quantity whatsoever generated on such property at least once
every seven (7) day period, or more frequently if required, so as to avoid health hazards or unreasonable accumulations of waste.
2. It shall be the duty of every property owner who provides for the collection and removal of waste generated by such property, to effect proper
placement of containers so as to not be visible from the street or adjacent properties if reasonably possible.
(B) Containers: Containers for such waste shall be watertight, equipped with tightfitting covers and be so designed as to prevent waste deposited therein
from being blown or scattered about the premises.
(C) Location: All areas set aside for the collection of waste shall be so located as to not be unsightly in appearance and offensive in odor and shall be so
maintained as to prevent waste from scattering and becoming windblown.
(D) Licensing Requirements: It shall be the duty of every property owner who provides for the collection and removal of waste, in any quantity whatsoever
generated by that property, to see that such collection is effected by the contractor or a scavenger duly licensed to do business in the city pursuant to
section 4-3-11 of this chapter.
(E) Hours Of Operation By Scavengers: The hours of operation specified in subsection 4-3-3(D)5 of this chapter shall also apply to nonresidential
collection and disposal.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 159/357
(F) Hazardous Waste: The applicable state regulations shall govern the removal and disposal of hazardous waste. (Ord. 1758, 8-16-1993)
(G) Property Owner: No owner of any "nonresidential property" (hereinafter defined as any real property exclusive of a dwelling unit) shall allow waste
generated at any dwelling unit to be placed in any container belonging to or used by said nonresidential property owner. No resident of a dwelling unit
shall deposit waste generated at any dwelling unit in a container belonging to or used by a nonresidential property owner. (Ord. 1769, 10-4-1993)
4-3-5: RESIDENTIAL SOLID WASTE COLLECTION FEES:
(A) Residential Collections: Commencing January 1, 2007, the monthly fees to be charged for the dwelling unit's waste collections and disposal services,
recycling and yard waste shall be eleven dollars ninety six cents ($11.96) per month for the first toter and an additional six dollars ninety six cents
($6.96) per month for a second toter until January 1, 2008, at which time said amounts shall be increased to twelve dollars twenty four cents ($12.24)
per month for the first toter and an additional seven dollars fourteen cents ($7.14) per month for a second toter until January 1, 2009, at which time said
amounts shall be increased to twelve dollars forty two cents ($12.42) per month for the first toter and an additional seven dollars thirty two cents ($7.32)
per month for a second toter until January 1, 2010, at which time said amounts shall be increased to twelve dollars sixty seven cents ($12.67) per
month for the first toter and an additional seven dollars forty seven cents ($7.47) per month for a second toter until January 1, 2011, at which time said
amounts shall be increased to twelve dollars ninety two cents ($12.92) per month for the first toter and an additional seven dollars sixty two cents
($7.62) per month for a second toter. Commencing January 1, 2007, the fee for bags shall be one dollar forty cents ($1.40) per bag until January 1,
2008, at which time the fee shall be increased five cents ($0.05) per bag for each year thereafter.
Any or all of the aforesaid rates may be adjusted from time to time by the city council. The city council may also, upon adoption of a resolution,
implement an eighty cent ($0.80) per month per dwelling unit charge for the costs of a citywide pick up. (Ord. 2634, 4-16-2007)
(B) Billing: The monthly fees specified herein for collection services at dwelling units shall be billed by the contractor and paid by the person in whose
name the city water and/or sewer account then appears. The contractor shall be responsible for collecting any and all delinquent accounts. Such
charges may be billed on a quarterly basis in advance for service to be rendered. The contractor shall be entitled to assess a charge of fifty cents
($0.50) as a late penalty for each month of service for accounts more than thirty (30) days in arrears. (Ord. 2079, 4-20-1998, eff. 5-1-1998)
(C) Delinquent And Closed Accounts: Upon a resident's failure to make payment within thirty (30) days of its due date the contractor may discontinue
refuse collection service at any dwelling unit after having given fifteen (15) days' prior written notice to the resident. The contractor may remove or
cause the removal of the containers from the dwelling unit. Upon satisfactory payment by the resident, contractor shall resume refuse collection to said
resident on the next regularly scheduled collection day. The contractor may assess a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) for return of the container to the
dwelling unit. (Ord. 1797, 4-18-1994)
(D) Deposits Required: Accounts in arrears for a period greater than six (6) months or with a payment history of three (3) consecutive late payments may
be required to pay a deposit equal to two (2) months of regular collection services by the contractor.
(E) Nonresidential Collections: Waste collection and disposal service to nonresidential establishments and collection of waste other than refuse, yard
waste, recyclable material and bulky waste by dwelling units shall be performed by a scavenger duly licensed to do business in the city in accordance
with section 4-3-11 of this chapter at such schedules and rates as may be mutually agreed upon between the licensed scavenger and such
nonresidential accounts. (Ord. 1758, 8-16-1993)
(F) Suspension Of Rates: Residents shall not be charged the monthly rate provided herein for refuse services to any dwelling unit if the dwelling unit has
been disconnected from city water services for an entire calendar month. Provided, however, if water services are terminated between the first day and
the fifteenth day of a calendar month, the changes shall be reduced by one-half (1/2); if water services are terminated between the sixteenth day and
the last day of a calendar month, the charges provided for herein shall not be terminated for said calendar month. (Ord. 2079, 4-20-1998, eff. 5-1-1998)
4-3-6: DISPOSAL OF SOLID WASTE OTHER THAN BY COLLECTION:
(A) Burning Restricted; Burying Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to burn waste within the city except in accordance with section 8-3-5-1 of this
code. Properly designed and installed kitchen garbage disposal units may be used for the disposal of garbage into the city's sanitary sewer system. It
shall be unlawful for any person to bury waste anywhere within the city or to permit the same to be placed or accumulated at any place or manner other
than in a proper container.
(B) Accumulation Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for the occupant and/or owner of any premises in the city to accumulate thereon any waste except in
compliance with the provisions hereof.
(C) Depositing Containers On Another's Premises: It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit his refuse or other waste upon the property of another for
the purpose of having such waste picked up by a scavenger or the contractor. Any person committing this prohibited act shall, in addition to violating
this chapter, be deemed to have committed the offense of littering. (Ord. 1758, 8-16-1993)
4-3-7: FAILURE OF OWNER TO REMOVE WASTE:
(A) If the owner of private property in the city upon which there is deposited any waste in violation of this chapter refuses or neglects to remove such waste
or to have the same removed as herein provided, within seven (7) days after written notice shall have been given to the property owner by personal
delivery or by certified mail, the city or its designee may remove such waste and may collect from such owner the cost thereof. (Ord. 2121, 11-2-1998)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 160/357
(B) Such cost shall be a lien upon the real estate affected if within sixty (60) days after such cost and expenses incurred by the city or the person
performing the removal service by authority of the city in his or its own name files notice of lien in the office of the recorder of deeds. Such notice shall
consist of a sworn statement setting out: 1) a description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof, 2) the amount of money representing the
cost and expense incurred or payable for the removal service, 3) the date, or dates, when such costs and expense was incurred by the city, and 4) the
date when notice was served.
(C) Upon payment of the cost and expense of the owner or persons interested in such property after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be released
by the city or person in whose name the lien has been filed and the release may be filed of record as in the case of filing notice of lien. The lien may be
enforced by proceedings to foreclose as in the case of mortgages or mechanics' liens. (Ord. 1758, 8-16-1993)
4-3-8: THEFT OF RECYCLABLES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to collect, obtain, possess or pick up any recyclable material or other waste placed for collection at the curb as part of
the city's residential solid waste collection and disposal services contract intended for collection and disposal by the contractor as provided for in
subsection 4-3-3(C) of this chapter. (Ord. 1758, 8-16-1993)
4-3-9: DEPOSITS IN STREETS:
No person shall deposit any waste in any street, alley, or upon the portion of the banks of Rock River or any public place except as provided in this
chapter. (Ord. 1758, 8-16-1993)
4-3-10: DEPOSITS OF WASTE:
No person shall cast or leave exposed in or about any private premises or on any lot, street, or alley or about any sewer, gutter or sluiceway in the city any
waste. (Ord. 1758, 8-16-1993)
4-3-11: SCAVENGER'S LICENSE REQUIRED:
(A) No person, either as principal or agent, shall engage in the business of collection and hauling waste in the city without having first obtained a license as
a scavenger. As a condition to obtaining a scavenger's license, each applicant must offer recycling collection services. Provided, however, no license
shall be required for any charitable or religious organization which solicits donations of junk when such organization is operating not for profit to any
individual member thereof and the proceeds are applied to the object for which it exists.
(B) The licenses provided in this section shall be limited to eight (8) persons and in no event shall scavenger licenses be issued during any one year to
more than eight (8) collectors, operating either as an individual or as a firm of individuals. (Ord. 1758, 8-16-1993)
(C) Upon notification by the city that any licensee's equipment is being employed or services are being provided in violation of this chapter, including, but
not limited to, subsection 4-3-3(C) of this chapter, any licensee under this section shall be obliged, upon such notice, to promptly secure compliance or
otherwise to remove any of licensee's equipment used in violation of this chapter from any site within the city. Failure to comply with the requirements
of this section shall be grounds for suspension, revocation, or nonrenewal of the license issued under this section upon notice and opportunity for a
hearing to contest any alleged failure to comply. (Ord. 2878, 6-18-2012)
4-3-12: TRANSPORTATION OF LOOSE MATERIALS:
No person shall transport any sand, gravel, earth, ashes, stone, coal, wastepaper, filth, waste or other loose or offensive materials or liquids in any vehicle
upon the streets or alleys of the city unless the box or container of such materials upon the vehicle shall be sufficiently firm and tight so as to prevent the
falling or spilling of any such material from the vehicle upon the streets or alleys and the vehicles containing such material shall have a cover of canvas or
other suitable covering so as to prevent the blowing, falling and spilling of such material upon the streets or alleys. (Ord. 1758, 8-16-1993)
4-3-13: BURNING:
(A) It shall be unlawful to burn any waste in the city limits except as provided by the rules and regulations of the Illinois pollution control board promulgated
October 15, 1971, which are adopted as the rules and regulations for open burning for the city.
(B) Any resident desiring to burn any waste shall burn the same in an incinerator which conforms to the requirements and standards established by this
code, and approved by the building department of the city and the Illinois pollution control board.
(C) No commercial establishment or resident in the city shall cause, suffer or permit open burning of waste except as provided in this chapter and except
as conforms to the rules and regulations promulgated by the Illinois pollution control board and except as permission is granted by the building
inspector of the city. (Ord. 1758, 8-16-1993)
4-3-14: FINES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 161/357
(A) Any person who shall violate any provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00), nor more than
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each such violation. (Ord. 2913, 6-3-2013)
(B) The commissioner of streets or his designee shall have the authority to direct payment of twenty five percent (25%) of any fine revenue received by the
city from a violation of this chapter to the person or persons other than the violator who provided information that led to the conviction or plea of guilty. It
is at the sole discretion of the commissioner of streets or his designee to determine whether the information provided led to a conviction of a violation of
this chapter, and the commissioner of streets or his designee and the city shall not be subject to any suit, judgment, claim or appeal of this
determination. (Ord. 1758, 8-16-1993)
4-3-15: LANDFILL FEES:
The fees to be charged and assessed for depositing waste of any nature at the city landfill shall be as follows:
(A) Waste Of Any Nature, Except Tires:
1. Six dollars fifty cents ($6.50) per cubic yard for all "load packers" with an additional charge being made for excess material left in hopper, which
additional charge shall be based on the type of material and actual quantity in the hopper.
2. Five dollars fifty cents ($5.50) per cubic yard for all "open roll-offs". Said charge shall be based as if the box and/or container was fully loaded; there
shall be no reduction in charge for partially loaded boxes and/or containers.
3. A minimum charge for all other truck or auto vehicles of ten dollars ($10.00) per load.
(B) Each Tire Deposited: Two dollars ($2.00) per tire.
(C) Fees Paid: Such fees shall be paid to the clerk upon presentation by her of semimonthly statements of the number of loads or cubic yards deposited
by an individual scavenger; said payments to be made by the scavengers at the office of the clerk of the city hall within five (5) days after the receipt of
said statements.
(D) Surcharges: The commissioner of public property and the superintendent of the landfill are hereby specifically authorized to implement surcharges to
individuals and businesses depositing materials at the landfill, based upon the types of material and the quantities of waste materials deposited. (Ord.
1758, 8-16-1993)
Chapter 4
SMOKE AND DUST
4-4-1: DENSE SMOKE PROHIBITED:
No owner-occupant or operator of any machine or building within the city or within one mile of the city shall permit or allow dense smoke to issue or emit
from such machine or building excepting for periods aggregating not to exceed six (6) minutes in any one hour, whether consecutive or not. For the
purpose of testing and grading the density of smoke the Ringelmann smoke chart published and used by the United States bureau of mines is hereby
adopted as standard and smoke shall be deemed "dense" when it is of a degree of density of no. 3 of said chart. A copy of the chart shall be kept at all
times at the office of the clerk and shall be open to public inspection at reasonable hours. (1950 Code)
4-4-2: DENSE SOOT AND DUST PROHIBITED:
No owner or occupant of any machine or building within the city or within one mile of the city shall permit or allow dense or excessive soot or dust to issue
or to emit from such machine or building excepting for periods aggregating not to exceed six (6) minutes in any one hour, whether consecutive or not1.
(1950 Code)
Chapter 5
TRAILER COACH PARKS
4-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter the following terms shall have the meanings herein ascribed to them:
TRAILER COACH LOT: A unit of level adequately drained ground of definite size, clearly indicated by corner markers for the placing of a trailer coach or a
trailer coach and tow car.
TRAILER PARK: Any site, lot, field, or tract of ground upon which two (2) or more trailer coaches are placed, and shall include any building, structure, tent,
vehicle or enclosure used or intended for use as a part of the equipment of the park. (1950 Code)
4-5-2: PERMIT FOR PARKING OUTSIDE OF TRAILER PARK:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 162/357
(Rep. by Ord. 558, 8-1-1967)
4-5-3: PERMIT FOR TRAILER PARK:
(A) No person shall construct or operate a trailer park without first securing a permit.
(B) No trailer park shall be operated except as provided in this chapter. (1950 Code)
(C) The permit for a trailer park shall be obtained from the clerk with the approval of the commissioner of public health and safety. Each application for a
permit shall be accompanied by a license fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). Each permit shall expire at the end of the fiscal year in which issued, but in the
event a permit is issued more than a month after the beginning of any fiscal year, the fee to be paid shall be reduced in proportion to the full calendar
months which have expired in the fiscal year. Before any permit shall be renewed the premises shall be subject to inspection by the health officer. (Ord.
66, 10-13-1953)
(D) Permits for trailer parks must be conspicuously displayed at all times. (1950 Code)
4-5-4: APPLICATION FOR A TRAILER PARK PERMIT:
(A) Any applicant for permit to operate a trailer park shall agree in his application that a responsible attendant shall be in charge of the trailer park at all
times. At the time of application the names of the attendants to be in active charge of the proposed trailer park and their hours of duty shall be set forth.
Any changes after the permit is granted shall be filed with the authority issuing the permit within ten (10) days from the date of change. The attendant
shall supervise the park and be, together with the licensee, responsible for any violation of the provisions of this chapter which occurs in the operation
of the trailer park.
(B) With each application a park plan indicating the information required in section 4-5-5 of this chapter shall be submitted to the commissioner of public
health and safety for inspection and approval. The application for license must include the name and information required by section 4-5-5 of this
chapter. (1950 Code)
4-5-5: PARK PLAN:
The park plan required by section 4-5-4 of this chapter shall provide a legal description and map clearly setting out the following information:
(A) The extent and area to be used for park purposes.
(B) Driveways and entrances and exits, roadways and walkways.
(C) Location of sites for trailer coaches.
(D) Location and number of proposed sanitary conveniences, including proposed toilets, washrooms, laundries, laundry drying space, and utility rooms.
(E) Method and plan of sewage disposal.
(F) Method and plan of garbage removal.
(G) Plan of water supply.
(H) Plan of electric lighting.
(I) Incinerator and burning space.
(J) Children's play area. (1950 Code)
(K) Method and plan of stormwater drainage. (Ord. 683, 1-17-1972)
4-5-6: ZONING OF TRAILER PARKS:
Trailer parks shall be prohibited in fire zones. A trailer park may be permitted in any district in the city except where such use would conflict with the
provisions of the preceding sentence, or in the residence district; provided, that a license may be issued for a residence district only where the applicant for
the privilege presents the written consent of a majority of the property owners or occupants within two hundred feet (200') of the boundaries of the
proposed park. (1950 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 163/357
4-5-7: LOCATION AND SPACE:
(A) No trailer coach park shall be so located that the drainage of the park area will endanger any water supply. All trailer parks shall be well drained and
shall be located in areas free from ponds, swamps and similar places in which mosquitoes may breed. No wastewater from trailer coaches shall be
deposited on the surface of the ground.
(B) Each trailer coach shall be allotted a site of not less than one thousand (1,000) square feet. No trailer coach shall be parked closer than five feet (5') to
the side lot lines of a trailer coach park, if the abutting property is improved property, or closer than ten feet (10') to a public street, alley or building.
Each individual trailer site shall abut or face on a driveway or clear unoccupied space of not less than twenty feet (20') in width, which space shall have
unobstructed access to a public highway or alley. There shall be an open space of at least ten feet (10') between the sides of every trailer coach and at
least five feet (5') between the ends of every trailer coach. State department of public health may, upon application of a trailer park operator, waive such
requirements if such waiver does not affect the sanitation requirements herein mentioned or create or permit to continue any hazard to the health and
welfare of the community and the occupants of the park. (Ord. 75, 4-20-1954)
4-5-8: WATER SUPPLY:
An adequate supply of water of safe, sanitary quality, approved by the state department of public health shall be furnished at each trailer park. Where
water from other sources than that supplied by the city is proposed to be used, the source of the supply shall first be approved by the department. At least
one cold water supply outlet shall be provided within three hundred feet (300') of every dependent trailer site. Each independent trailer site shall be
provided with a cold water tap at least four inches (4") above the ground. (Ord. 75, 4-20-1954)
4-5-9: COMMUNITY SERVICE BUILDING:
(A) Adequate toilet, lavatory and bathing facilities for occupants of dependent trailer coaches shall be provided in a community service building. The
building shall be conveniently located, well constructed, having good natural and artificial lighting, adequate ventilation and floors of concrete or similar
impervious materials. Concrete curbings, extending at least six inches (6") above the floor, shall be provided and the floor sloped to adequate drains.
Walls and partitions shall be constructed of impervious material where subject to splash. The building shall be maintained at a temperature of at least
sixty eight degrees Fahrenheit (68°F) during the period from October 1 to May 1.
(B) The community service building shall be provided with toilet rooms for each sex, plainly marked by appropriate signs, in which shall be installed water
closets and lavatories adequate in number to serve the reasonable needs of occupants of dependent trailer coaches. Each water closet shall be placed
in a separate compartment, properly separated from other water closets and shall be not less than three feet (3') wide and shall be enclosed with
proper partition. The community building shall also be provided with tub or shower bath compartments, for both sexes, adequate in number to
accommodate the reasonable needs of occupants of dependent trailer coaches. In combination with each bath or shower stall, there shall be provided
an individual dressing compartment not less than two and one-half feet by three feet (21/2' x 3') in plan so arranged as to ensure privacy. The floor of
the compartment shall be waterproof and elevated three inches (3") above the floor of the shower stall or six inches (6") curbing provided, separating
shower compartment from dressing room. Mats, grids and walkways made of wood, cloth or other absorbent materials will not be approved for use in
bath sections of community service buildings.
(C) A laundry room or building constructed as specified in this section shall be provided containing laundry trays to accommodate the patrons of the trailer
coach park. No laundry trays shall be located in the toilet or bathrooms.
(D) An adequate water supply shall be provided at all times for the operation of all water closets in service buildings, and an adequate supply of hot and
cold water shall be provided at all times in the service buildings for all bathing, washing, cleansing and laundry facilities. (Ord. 75, 4-20-1954)
4-5-10: SEWAGE DISPOSAL:
All sewage and other water carried wastes shall be disposed of into the municipal sewer system whenever available. In trailer parks in which such
connections are not available, disposal shall be into a private system which includes a sanitary means of disposal, the operation of which creates neither a
nuisance nor a menace to health.
When a water carriage system of sewage is used, each trailer coach site shall be provided with a sewer connection for the combined liquid waste outlet of
each trailer coach, and trapped below the frost line. It shall be the duty of the owner or operator of the trailer park to provide an approved type of water and
odor tight connection from the trailer water drainage to the sewer connection, and it shall be the duty of the owner or operator to make such connection
and keep all occupied trailer coaches connected to the sewer while located in a trailer coach park. Sewer connections in unoccupied trailer coach sites
shall be so closed that they will emit no odors or cause a breeding place for flies. No water or waste shall be allowed to fall on the ground from a trailer
coach. (Ord. 75, 4-20-1954)
4-5-11: GARBAGE DISPOSAL:
A sufficient number of adequate flyproof and watertight containers shall be supplied for the storage of garbage except where an adequate incinerator is
provided.
Garbage containers shall be emptied at least every three (3) days and shall not be filled to overflowing, or allowed to become foul smelling, or a breeding
place for flies.
Garbage and rubbish shall be disposed of in a manner which creates neither a nuisance nor a menace to health and which is approved by the state
department of public health. (Ord. 75, 4-20-1954)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 164/357
4-5-12: INSECT AND RODENT CONTROL:
Adequate insect and rodent control measures shall be employed. All buildings shall be fly and rodent proof and rodent harborages shall not be permitted to
exist in the park. (Ord. 75, 4-20-1954)
4-5-13: FIRE PROTECTION:
Fire extinguishers of a type approved by the state fire marshal for use at trailer coach parks shall be placed at locations within two hundred feet (200') of
each individual trailer site. Each fire extinguisher shall be periodically examined and kept at all times in a condition for use. (Ord. 75, 4-20-1954)
4-5-14: STREETS AND DRIVEWAYS:
All streets and driveways in every trailer park must be maintained in a passable and reasonably dustproof condition at all times, and all streets and
driveways in every trailer park shall have a minimum width of twenty feet (20') for streets or driveways. (Ord. 75, 4-20-1954)
4-5-15: REGISTRATION:
Each trailer park shall be provided with a custodian's office where each trailer coach entering the trailer park shall be assigned a lot location, given a copy
of the trailer park rules, and registered according to the proscribed form. The registration shall include the name and address of every occupant of the
trailer coach; the license number of all units; the state issuing such licenses; and a statement indicating the exact location at which the trailer coach was
last parked, including the state, city, town or village where the parking occurred. The licensee shall keep a registry of all children of school age occupying
trailer coaches in the trailer park. The register shall be signed by an occupant of the trailer coach. Any person furnishing misinformation for purposes of
registration shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. The registration records shall be neatly and securely maintained, and no registration records shall
be destroyed until six (6) years have elapsed following the date of registration. The register shall be available at all times for inspection by law enforcement
officers. (Ord. 75, 4-20-1954)
4-5-16: REMOVAL OF WHEELS:
Any action toward the removal of wheels except for temporary purposes of repair or other action to attach the trailer to the ground by means of posts,
piers, foundation or skirting shall subject the owner of the trailer to the requirements of the zoning title as well as this chapter. (1950 Code)
4-5-17: MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS:
All plumbing installation, alteration, or repair in the park shall be done in accordance with the provisions of the state department of health.
All electrical work shall be in conformity with the most recent revision of the national electrical code.
No permanent additions of any kind whatsoever shall be built onto or become a part of the trailer coach.
It shall be the duty of the park attendant to immediately notify the health officer of any communicable diseases in the park. (1950 Code)
4-5-18: INSPECTION:
Before any renewal of trailer coach parking or trailer park permits, an inspection shall be made by the health officer to determine that all the requirements
of this chapter have been complied with. (1950 Code)
4-5-19: REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF PERMIT:
The health officer shall have the authority to enter and inspect for health and sanitation purposes any facility to which a permit has been issued hereunder.
If, upon inspection, it shall be found that the permit holder has violated any provision of this chapter, the commissioner of public health and safety shall
have the power to revoke or suspend any permit and order the trailer coach parking removed or the trailer park closed after notice and proper hearing1.
(1950 Code)
4-5-20: ILLINOIS TRAILER COACH PARK CONTROL LAW ADOPTED:
The standards set forth in this chapter shall meet the minimum standards of the Illinois trailer coach park control law, especially having reference to the
following provisions of said state law:
(A) Space requirements for each trailer coach space or site upon which each trailer coach is accommodated as provided in section 8.3 of said law.
(B) Streets and driveways in every trailer coach park as provided in section 11(B).
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 165/357
(C) Laundry trays as provided in section 8.7 of said Illinois trailer coach park control law.
All of the above refers to sections, subsections and paragraphs having reference to the said sections, subsections and paragraphs of the Illinois trailer
coach park control law and shall be considered and become a part of this chapter. (Ord. 604, 1-14-1969)
4-5-21: DRAINAGE:
When a trailer park is to be constructed on a lot or parcel of land that contains a natural waterway, the property owner shall be responsible for providing
the necessary drainage facilities to conduct the stormwater across the property. The drainage facilities shall be either a properly designed grass waterway
or a storm sewer. The facility shall be sized to carry the runoff from the entire drainage area according to the rational runoff formula Q = CiA where Q is the
volume of stormwater in cubic feet per second; C is the runoff coefficient, which is that part of the rainfall rate which will contribute to the runoff rate; i is the
average intensity of the rainfall in inches per hour during the time required for all parts of the watershed to contribute to runoff; and A is the area of the
drainage basin in acres. Where the major portion of the drainage basin is a residential area a factor of eight-tenths (0.8) shall be used for the product of C
and i. Grass waterways will only be permitted when the entire drainage area is within a one block area and in no case will be permitted when the drainage
area extends across a street. When commercial, industrial or other large runoff areas are within the drainage area the values used for C and i shall be
approved by the city engineer. The property owner shall submit plans showing size, depth, grade and location of the storm sewer to the building official
prior to issuance of a permit. The property owner shall furnish the city an easement agreement on the form of agreement furnished by the city for the
purpose of maintenance of the sewer. (Ord. 684, 1-19-1972)
Chapter 6
MILK
4-6-1: LICENSE TO SELL OR DISTRIBUTE MILK:
No person shall engage in the sale, delivery or distribution of milk or milk products within the city without first obtaining a license therefor, as herein
provided. (1950 Code)
4-6-2: LICENSE FEE:
Persons desiring to engage in the sale, delivery or distribution of milk or milk products within the city shall make written application to the clerk, who shall
issue a license upon the presentation to him of a permit for such applicant, issued by the health officer and satisfactory proof that the applicant has
complied with the terms of this chapter and is entitled to such license.
Any person who shall engage in the sale, delivery or distribution of milk or milk products shall have each vehicle from which milk is vended marked with
the name of the distributor and the license number issued by the clerk. (1950 Code; amd. Ord. 689, 4-17-1972)
4-6-3: PASTEURIZED MILK REQUIRED:
The health officer is hereby authorized and directed to issue permits and licenses only to those persons whose milk or milk products are pasteurized in a
pasteurizing plant approved by the state department of public health in accordance with 410 Illinois Compiled Statutes 635/1 et seq., of "an act regulating
the handling, processing, labeling, selling and distribution of pasteurized milk products". Pasteurized milk and milk products approved by the state
department of public health. (Ord. 10, 5-17-1951)
4-6-4: REVOCATION OF LICENSES:
Any license issued hereunder may be suspended or revoked by the mayor upon recommendation of the health officer, for violation of any provisions of this
chapter. Notice in writing of such suspension or revocation, signed by the mayor, shall be delivered immediately to the licensee. It shall also be the duty of
the mayor to revoke any licenses issued hereunder upon receipt of notice from the state department of public health that the permit of such person has
been refused, suspended or revoked. (1950 Code)
4-6-5: MILK OR MILK PRODUCTS WHICH MAY BE SOLD:
No milk or milk products shall be sold to the final consumer or to restaurants, soda fountains, grocery stores or similar establishments, unless the same
shall be pasteurized milk or milk products as the same are defined in 410 Illinois Compiled Statutes 635/1 et seq., of "an act regulating the handling,
processing, labeling, selling and distribution of pasteurized milk products". When such pasteurized milk or milk products are labeled grade A pasteurized
milk or milk products the same shall be grade A pasteurized milk or milk products as the same are defined in an act entitled, "an act in relation to grade A
milk and grade A milk products and to repeal a certain act named herein", filed July 17, 1945, as amended, of the laws of the state. (Ord. 10, 5-17-1951)
4-6-6: MILK TO BE SERVED IN ORIGINAL CONTAINERS:
It shall be unlawful for hotels, hospitals, soda fountains, restaurants, groceries and similar establishments to sell or serve any milk or milk products except
in the original container in which it was received from the distributor or from a container or dispenser of a design approved by the state department of
public health; provided, that this requirement shall not apply to cream consumed on the premises.
It shall be unlawful for any hotel, soda fountain, restaurant, grocery or similar establishment to sell or serve any milk or milk products which have not been
maintained, while in possession, at a temperature of fifty degrees Fahrenheit (50°F) or less. (1950 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 166/357
4-6-7: INSPECTION BY HEALTH OFFICER:
Every producer or distributor of milk or milk products maintaining a dairy or distribution center with the city shall permit inspection of such dairy or
distribution center by the health officer at any time the health officer deems it necessary to ensure and safeguard the public health and safety of the people
of the city1. (1950 Code)
Chapter 7
NUISANCES
4-7-1: DEFINITION; PROHIBITION:
The following acts, conduct and conditions are hereby declared and defined to be nuisances, and when committed, performed or permitted to exist by any
individual within the territorial limits of the city, are hereby declared to be unlawful and prohibited:
(A) Any act of offense which is a nuisance according to the common law of the state of Illinois, or declared or defined to be a nuisance by the ordinances
of the city. In addition, the officials of the municipality shall be authorized to abate any nuisance which, while not specifically defined within this chapter,
shall constitute the unreasonable, unwarrantable, or unlawful use by a person of property real or personal or from his own improper, indecent or
unlawful personal conduct which works an obstruction or injury to a right of another, or of the public, and produces such material annoyance,
inconvenience, discomfort, or hurt that the law will presume an actionable nuisance. Nuisances may be abated which are public or which are both
public and private in nature.
(B) To cause or suffer the carcass of any animal or any offal, filth or noisome substance to be collected, deposited or to remain in any place under his
ownership or control to the prejudice of others.
(C) To throw or deposit any offal or other offensive matter, or the carcass of any dead animal in any watercourse, lake, pond, spring, well or common
sewer, street or public highway.
(D) To corrupt or render unwholesome or impure the water of any spring, river, stream, pond or lake, to the injury or prejudice of others.
(E) To obstruct or encroach upon public highways, private ways, streets, alleys, commons, landing places and ways to burying places.
(F) To erect, continue to use any building or other place for the exercise of any trade, employment or manufacture, which, by occasioning noxious
exhalations, offensive smells or otherwise, is offensive or dangerous to the health of individuals, or of the public.
(G) To advertise wares or occupation by painting notices of the same on, or affixing them to fences, walls, windows, building exteriors, utility poles, or on
hydrants, other public or private property, or on rocks or other natural objects, without the consent of the owner, or if in the highway or other public
place, without the permission of the proper authorities.
(H) To harass, intimidate or threaten any person who is about to sell or lease or has sold or leased a residence or other real property or is about to buy or
lease or has bought or leased a residence or other real property, when the harassment, intimidation or threat relates to a person's attempt to sell, buy
or lease a residence, or other real property, or refers to a person's sale, purchase or lease of a residence or other real property.
(I) To dump, abandon, deposit, dismantle or burn upon any public property or right of way, highway, park, street or parkway anywhere in the city any trash,
garbage, ashes, junk, junked or wrecked motor vehicles or parts thereof, or miscellaneous waste. (Ord. 1063, 1-5-1981)
(J) To store, keep or maintain outside of a closed building, any junk, parts, machinery or equipment not in an operable condition; provided, however, that
this provision shall not apply to a properly licensed junkyard or other permitted outdoor storage use which is in full compliance with all of the ordinances
of the city governing the same. (Ord. 1420, 4-4-1988)
(K) To own, maintain or keep a dwelling unit unfit for human habitation or dangerous or detrimental to life, safety or health because of lack of repair,
defects in the plumbing system, lighting or ventilation, the existence of contagious diseases or unsanitary conditions likely to cause sickness among
persons residing in said premises or residing in proximity thereof.
(L) To store or place any materials in a manner which may harbor rats. (Ord. 1063, 1-5-1981)
(M) (Rep. by Ord. 3011, 5-16-2016)
(N) To keep an inoperable motor vehicle on public or private property and in view of the general public. As used in this section, "inoperable motor vehicle"
means any motor vehicle from which, for a period of at least seven (7) days, the engine, wheels or other parts have been removed, or on which the
engine, wheels or other parts have been altered, damaged or otherwise so treated that the vehicle is incapable of being driven under its own motor
power. "Inoperable motor vehicle" shall not include a motor vehicle which has been rendered temporarily incapable of being driven under its own motor
power in order to perform ordinary service or repair operations. (Ord. 1420, 4-4-1988)
