Nothing in this subsection shall apply to any motor vehicle that is kept within an enclosed building when not in use, to operable historic vehicles over
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 167/357
twenty five (25) years of age, or to a motor vehicle on the premises of a place of business engaged in the wrecking or junking of motor vehicles. (Ord.
2050, 12-15-1997)
(O) To disrupt, disturb, or interfere with any ditches or natural drains across public or private property in such a manner that such ditches or natural drains
shall fill or become obstructed with any matter which materially impedes or interferes, or which creates a reasonable likelihood of materially impeding or
interfering with the flow of water, or which redirects water onto another's property except as otherwise authorized by law, or to otherwise create or
permit the existence of a condition of standing water where the standing water may facilitate or encourage the breeding of mosquitoes. For purposes of
this subsection, "ditch" shall mean any artificially constructed open drain or natural drain that has been artificially improved, and "drain" shall mean any
ditch, watercourse or conduit, whether open, covered or enclosed, natural or artificial, or partially natural and partially artificial, by which surface waters
coming upon or falling upon lands are carried away in the normal course of drainage. (Ord. 2971, 8-3-2015)
4-7-2: NONSUMMARY ABATEMENT; NOTICE:
(A) Except where otherwise prohibited by the ordinances of the city, any officer of the city possessing police powers may serve or cause to be served a
notice, in writing, upon the owner, agent, occupant or person in possession, charge or control of any lot, building or premises or item of personalty in or
upon which any nuisance exists, requiring them or either or both of them, to abate the same within a specified reasonable time, which shall be not less
than seven (7) days in the case of inoperable motor vehicles, in such manner as the notice shall direct. (Ord. 1420, 4-4-1988)
(B) Any person may contest the determination that the vehicle is a nuisance as defined in this chapter, by filing written request for a hearing with the chief
of police within seven (7) days of receipt of notice provided under this section. Upon such request, a hearing will be conducted by the mayor of the city,
at which time such person will have the opportunity to present evidence that the vehicle does not constitute a nuisance. The decision of the mayor shall
be final. Failure to request a hearing within seven (7) days of receipt of the notice shall constitute a waiver of the right to a hearing. If a hearing is
requested in the manner set forth herein, no action will be taken with respect to the vehicle until the hearing is completed and the mayor's decision is
final. (Ord. 1459, 11-21-1988)
4-7-3: NONSUMMARY ABATEMENT:
If the person so served and notified does not abate the nuisance within the specified reasonable time, the corporate authorities may proceed to abate the
nuisance in any or all manner allowable by law, including, without limiting the generality thereof, the following:
(A) Seeking to impose a monetary penalty as defined by section 4-7-4-1 of this chapter by instituting an ordinance enforcement action.
(B) Seeking to enjoin the continuation of the nuisance by the filing of a lawsuit in a court of competent jurisdiction.
(C) In the case of an inoperable motor vehicle, authorizing a law enforcement agency, with applicable jurisdiction, to remove any inoperable motor vehicle
or part thereof. (Ord. 1420, 4-4-1988)
4-7-4: SUMMARY ABATEMENT:
Whenever, in the opinion of an officer of the city possessing police powers, the maintenance or continuation of a nuisance creates an imminent threat of
serious injury to persons or serious damage to persons or real property, or if the nuisance can be abated summarily without or with only minor damage to
the items or premises which are creating the nuisance, and the continuation of the nuisance poses a substantial threat of injury to persons or property or a
substantial interference with the quiet enjoyment of life normally present in the community, such officer shall proceed to abate such nuisance; provided,
further, that whenever the owner, occupant, agent or person in possession, charge or control of the real or personal property which has become a
nuisance is unknown or cannot readily be found, the municipal officer with police power may proceed to abate such nuisance without notice. Where the
abatement of the nuisance requires continuing acts by the corporate authorities beyond the initial summary abatement and any other additional emergency
abatements, it shall seek abatement of such nuisance on a permanent basis through judicial process as soon as readily possible. (Ord. 1063, 1-5-1981)
4-7-4-1: PENALTY:
Any individual violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be subject to the provisions of title 1, chapter 4 of this code. Each day
that a violation is allowed to exist shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 2258, 6-19-2000)
4-7-5: PLANTS, WEEDS AND GRASS:
(A) Declaration Of Nuisance: No owner of or other person occupying any lot, place, or area within the city, including the parkway located between the
sidewalk or property line and the improved and traveled portion of the public way adjacent to such lot, place, or area located within the city, shall permit
any weeds, grass, unhealthful or other noxious growth (all hereinafter referred to as "weeds") other than trees, bushes, flowers, or other ornamental
plants to grow to a height exceeding eight inches (8") on such lot, place, area, or parkway. Any weeds exceeding eight inches (8") in height are hereby
declared to be a nuisance. (Ord. 2005, 8-4-1997)
(B) Notice To Destroy: The building official is hereby authorized and empowered to notify, or cause to be notified, in writing, or by personal service, the
owner of any such parcel of real estate within the city limits to cut and destroy said weeds located upon said owner's real estate. Said notice shall be by
registered mail addressed to said owner at his last known address or by personal service. (Ord. 1050, 9-15-1980)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 168/357
(C) Refusal To Remove: Upon the refusal or neglect of any owners so notified to cut and destroy said weeds growing or located upon said owner's real
estate within five (5) days after receipt of the written notice provided for in subsection (B) of this section or within five (5) days after the date of said
notice in the event the same is returned to the city because of the inability to make delivery thereof, the building official is hereby authorized and
empowered to provide for the cutting and destroying of said weeds either by employees of the city or by persons performing this service by authority of
the building official. The city shall be entitled to collect the costs incurred in the cutting and destroying of said weeds from the owner or owners of said
real estate. In the event employees of the city cut and destroy said weeds, the minimum charge for said action shall be forty dollars ($40.00). (Ord.
1675, 7-20-1992)
(D) Lien: The cost incurred in cutting and destroying said weeds shall be a lien upon the real estate affected; provided, that within sixty (60) days after
such costs and expenses are incurred by the city or person performing the service by authority of the city, the city or the person performing service by
authority of the city files notice of lien in the office of the recorder of deeds of Lee County. The notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting forth: 1)
a description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof; 2) the amount of money representing the costs and expenses incurred or payable for
the service; and 3) the date or dates when such costs and expenses were incurred by the city. The person to whom the tax bill was sent for the general
taxes on the property for the last preceding year shall be served a copy of the notice of lien; service is to be made personally or by certified mail. (Ord.
2005, 8-4-1997)
(E) Penalty: Any person violating any provisions of this section, in addition to the provisions for lien contained herein, shall, on conviction, be fined not less
than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each violation. In any case in which an offense is of a continuing
nature, each day such violation continues shall be deemed a separate violation and shall subject the person so violating said provisions of this section
to a separate fine for each such day. (Ord. 1050, 9-15-1980)
4-7-6: CHRONIC NUISANCE PROPERTY:
(A) General Definitions: For purposes of this section, the following definitions shall apply:
DWELLING: A house, duplex, condominium unit, apartment building, mobile home, manufactured home, trailer or any other structure or place used or
intended to be used for human habitation, including common areas within the structure when buildings or structures are used for more than one
dwelling, and accessory buildings such as garages located on the same premises.
IN OR ON THE PREMISES OF ANY DWELLING: Either within a dwelling or the area within the boundary lines of any real property of the same
ownership on which such dwelling is located.
OCCUPANT: Any person who lives in or has possession of, or holds an occupancy interest in a dwelling; or any person residing in or frequenting the
premises of the dwelling with the actual or implied permission of the owner or lessee.
OWNER: Any person, agent, operator, firm or corporation having a legal or equitable ownership interest in the dwelling, as recorded in the official
records of the state, county, or municipality as holding title to the dwelling; or otherwise having control of the dwelling, including the guardian of an
estate of any such person, the executor or administrator of an estate or trustee lawfully entitled to possession or control of such property.
(B) Chronic Nuisance Property Defined: "Chronic nuisance property" is a dwelling within which, or on the premises of which, any three (3) of the following,
arising out of separate and distinct facts and circumstances, have occurred within a ninety (90) day consecutive period:
1. Any felony or misdemeanor involving or constituting a breach of the peace as defined by statutes of the state of Illinois and/or the ordinances of the
city of Dixon; or
2. Any violation of title 5 of this code, 1963, as amended, relating to alcoholic beverages arising out of separate and distinct facts and circumstances,
so long as such violation involves or constitutes a breach of the peace;
3. Disorderly conduct, as defined under 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/26-1;
4. Unlawful discharge of a firearm, as defined under 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-1, 5/24-1.2, 5/24-1.2-5, or 5/24-1.5;
5. Loud or disturbing noise in violation of section 4-7-7 of this chapter.
(C) Violation:
1. No owner or occupant of any dwelling shall allow or permit such dwelling to be, or become, a chronic nuisance property.
2. An owner and/or occupant shall be deemed to have allowed or permitted a dwelling to be, or become, a chronic nuisance property if:
(a) The owner or occupant has personally committed the acts set forth above;
(b) Such acts were committed by invitees of the occupant or owner; or
(c) Such acts were committed by persons attending events or functions sponsored, permitted, or allowed by the occupant or owner;
(d) Such acts were committed by a combination of subsection (C)2(a), (C)2(b) or (C)2(c) of this section.
(D) Notice Of Chronic Nuisance Property:
1. When the chief of police, or his or her designee, determines that property within the city has become "chronic nuisance property" as defined in
subsection (B) of this section, the chief of police shall notify the owner and/or occupant of the property that the property has been determined to be
chronic nuisance property and may be subject to closure.
2. The notice shall contain the following information:
(a) The street address and a legal description sufficient for identification of the property;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 169/357
(b) A statement that the Chief of Police, or his or her designee, has found the property to constitute chronic nuisance property with a concise and
detailed description of the actions, dates, times and persons committing the actions leading to that finding;
(c) A statement that the owner and/or occupant has the opportunity to respond in writing to the notice within fifteen (15) days from the date of the
notice, describing what steps the owner and/or occupant has or will take to remedy the chronic nuisance conditions on the property, or the property
may be subject to closure and/or penalties assessed;
(d) Such notice shall be deemed to be properly delivered if personally served or if sent via certified mail, to the owner's or occupant's last known
address with a copy of the notice posted conspicuously at the property in question;
(e) If the owner's and/or occupant's response to the notice is not satisfactory to the Chief of Police, or if the owner and/or occupant fails to respond to
the notice, then the Council of the City of Dixon may authorize the City Attorney to initiate proceedings in a court of competent jurisdiction seeking
closure of the chronic nuisance property or any part thereof, and/or the imposition of civil penalties against any or all of the owners and/or
occupants of the property or any other appropriate relief allowed by law.
(E) Action To Abate: In addition to prosecution of any offense defined under law or in pursuit of any other remedies available, the City Council may
authorize the City Attorney to prosecute an action for equitable relief, in the name of the City, to abate the chronic nuisance property and to enjoin any
person who owns, rents, or occupies the dwelling in question from using or permitting its use in violation of the provisions of this section. In any such
prosecution, the City shall bear the burden to show by a preponderance of the evidence that the property is "chronic nuisance property" as defined in
subsection (B) of this section. No judgment or finding of violation of this section shall be entered against an owner and/or occupant who has, in good
faith, endeavored to prevent or abate the nuisance. The burden of establishing good faith shall be that of the owner and/or occupant to show by a
preponderance of the evidence.
(F) Penalties:
1. Any property to be found "chronic nuisance property", as defined in this section, shall be closed and secured against all use and occupancy for a
period of not less than thirty (30) days nor more than one hundred eighty (180) days. If requested by the City, the court may authorize the City to
physically close the property against use or occupancy if the owner and/or occupant fails to do so within the time specified in the court's order, and
the owner and/or occupant shall be responsible for the cost thereof. In any such action seeking closure of the property, all persons with an interest of
record in the property including purchasers, beneficial owners of any Illinois land trust having title to the property, and lawful occupants shall be
named as defendants and served with process.
2. In addition to the remedies provided in subsection (F)1 of this section, the court may impose a civil penalty in an amount not less than fifty dollars
($50.00) per day nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day, for each day that the owner and/or occupant had actual knowledge that the
property was chronic nuisance property. The owner and/or occupant is presumed to have actual knowledge if notice was provided to the owner
and/or occupant in accordance with subsection (D) of this section. (Ord. 2585, 5-15-2006)
(G) Exceptions: This section shall not apply to the following situations, and the same shall not constitute chronic nuisance property hereunder, all as more
fully described and defined in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-2-1.5:
1. Contact made to police or other emergency services, if: a) the contact was made with the intent to prevent or respond to domestic violence or sexual
violence; b) the intervention or emergency assistance was needed to respond to or prevent domestic violence or sexual violence; or c) the contact
was made by, or on behalf of, or otherwise concerns an individual with a disability and the purpose of the contact was related to that individual's
disability;
2. An incident or incidents of actual or threatened domestic violence or sexual violence against a tenant, household member, or guest occurring in the
dwelling unit or on the premises; or
3. Criminal activity or a local ordinance violation occurring in the dwelling unit or on the premises that is directly relating to domestic violence or sexual
violence, engaged in by a tenant, member of a tenant's household, guest, or other party, and against a tenant, household member, guest, or other
party. (Ord. 3042, 6-5-2017)
4-7-7: NOISE CONTROL:
It shall be unlawful for any person to make, continue, or cause to be made or continued any excessive or unusually loud noise which either annoys,
disturbs, injures, or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace, or safety of others within the jurisdictional limits of the City.
(A) Application: This section applies to the control of all sound originating within the jurisdictional limits of the City.
(B) Definitions: As used in this section, the following terms shall have the meanings indicated:
EMERGENCY: An occurrence or set of circumstances involving actual or imminent physical trauma or property damage demanding immediate
attention.
EMERGENCY WORK: Any work performed for the purpose of preventing or alleviating physical trauma or property damage, whether actually caused
or threatened by an emergency, or work by private or public utilities when restoring utility service.
PERSON: Any individual, firm, association, partnership, joint venture, corporation, or limited liability company.
(C) General Prohibition: No person shall make, continue, or cause to be made or continued:
1. Any unreasonably loud or raucous noise;
2. Any noise which unreasonably disturbs, injures, or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace, or safety of reasonable persons of ordinary
sensitivity within the jurisdictional limits of the City; or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 170/357
3. Any noise which is so harsh, prolonged, unnatural, or unusual in time or place as to occasion unreasonable discomfort to any persons within the
neighborhood from which said noise emanates, or as to unreasonably interfere with the peace and comfort of neighbors or their guests, or operators
or customers in places of business, or as to detrimentally or adversely affect such residences or places of business.
(D) Determination Of Violation: The factors for determination of whether a sound violates the general prohibition set forth in subsection (C) of this section
include, but are not limited to, the following:
1. The proximity of the sound to residences;
2. The land use, nature, and zoning of the area from which the sound emanates and the area where it is received or perceived;
3. The time of night or day the sound occurs and the duration of the sound;
4. Whether the sound is recurrent, intermittent, or constant.
(E) Exemptions: Sounds caused by the following are exempt from the prohibitions of this section:
1. Repairs of utility structures which pose a clear and immediate threat to the life, health, or well being of the residents of the City or loss of property;
2. Sirens, whistles, or bells lawfully used by emergency vehicles or other alarm systems used in case of fire, collision, civil defense, police activity, or
imminent danger;
3. The emission of sound for the purpose of alerting persons to the existence of an emergency or the emission of sound in the performance of
emergency work;
4. Repairs or excavations of bridges, streets or highways by or on behalf of the City, the State of Illinois, or the Federal government, between the hours
of seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M., when public welfare and convenience renders it impractical to perform the work between
seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) P.M.;
5. Outdoor gatherings, public dances, shows, and other similar outdoor events, provided that a permit has been obtained from the City.
(F) Enforcement: The Police Chief or duly acting members of the Police Department will have primary responsibility for the enforcement of the noise
regulations contained in this section. Nothing in this section shall prevent the Police Chief or duly acting members of the Police Department from
obtaining voluntary compliance by way of warning, notice, or education.
(G) Penalty: A person who violates the provision of this section is subject to a fine as set forth in section 1-4-1 et seq., of this Code. (Ord. 3011, 5-16-2016)
Chapter 8
EMERGENCY VEHICLE AMBULANCE SERVICE
4-8-1: CHARGES FOR SERVICES:
(A) There is hereby established an emergency vehicle ambulance service charge for all residents of the city using emergency vehicle ambulance services
from a destination within the city limits to Katherine Shaw Bethea Hospital as follows:
1. Four hundred fifty dollars ($450.00) for basic life support; plus
2. Twenty dollars ($20.00) per loaded mile for each mile the ambulance travels; plus
3. Five hundred dollars ($500.00) for advance life support 1; or
4. Six hundred fifty dollars ($650.00) for advance life support 2. "Advance life support 2" shall mean a situation which requires administration of three
(3) medications administered, or defibrillation or intubation; plus
5. Thirty five dollars ($35.00) for oxygen.
(B) In addition to the charges set forth in subsection (A) of this section, all nonresidents of the city shall pay an additional charge as follows:
1. For basic life support, an additional one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00).
2. For advance life support 1, an additional two hundred dollars ($200.00).
3. For advance life support 2, an additional two hundred dollars ($200.00).
(C) For advance life support intercepts, the city shall charge the requesting agency a fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). (Ord. 2975, 9-8-2015)
4-8-2: LIMITATION OF SERVICE:
(Rep. by Ord. 2938, 4-21-2014)

All emergency vehicle ambulance service bills shall be paid on or before the due date as noted on the bill. Bills and notices will be mailed or delivered to

service become delinquent thirty (30) days after the date thereon. (Ord. 1049, 9-15-1980; amd. Ord. 1639, 12-2-1991)
Chapter 9
NO SMOKING ORDINANCE
4-9-1: PURPOSE:
Because the smoking of tobacco or any other weed or plant is a danger to health and is a cause of material annoyance and discomfort to those who are
present in confined places, the city council hereby declares that the purpose of this chapter is: a) to regulate smoking at city hall and b) to minimize the
toxic effects of smoking at city hall by requiring persons to smoke only in those designated areas. (Ord. 1359, 4-20-1987)
4-9-2: DEFINITIONS:
SMOKING: The carrying or holding of a lighted pipe, cigar or cigarette of any kind, or any other lighted smoking equipment or the lighting or emitting or
exhaling the smoke of a pipe, cigar or cigarette of any kind. (Ord. 1359, 4-20-1987)
4-9-3: REGULATION OF SMOKING IN CITY HALL:
Smoking or any use of tobacco is prohibited at all times within city hall, including the living quarters of the fire department. (Ord. 2479, 5-3-2004)
4-9-4: POSTING OF SIGNS:
Signs which designate nonsmoking areas shall be clearly, sufficiently and conspicuously posted. (Ord. 1359, 4-20-1987)
4-9-5: PENALTY:
Any person who shall violate any section of this chapter shall, on conviction, be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than five hundred dollars
($500.00) for each such violation. (Ord. 1359, 4-20-1987)
Chapter 10
LANDFILL OPERATIONS WITHIN CITY JURISDICTION
4-10-1: DEFINITIONS:
ADMINISTRATOR: The commissioner of accounts and finance of the city of Dixon or his designated agent.
AGENCY: The environmental protection agency as established by the environmental protection act, 415 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1 et seq.
CITY: Dixon, Illinois.
HAZARDOUS WASTE: A waste, or combination of wastes, which, because of its quantity, concentration of physical, chemical, or infectious characteristics,
may cause or significantly contribute to an increase in mortality or an increase in serious, irreversible, or incapacitating reversible illness; or pose a
substantial present or potential hazard to human health or the environment when improperly treated, stored, transported or disposed of, or otherwise
managed, and which has been identified, by characteristics or listings, as hazardous pursuant to section 3001 of the resource conservation and recovery
act of 1976, PL 94-580 (42 USCA section 6921), or pursuant to board regulations.
SANITARY LANDFILL: A facility permitted by the agency for the disposal of waste on land meeting the requirements of the resource conservation and
recovery act, PL 94-580 (41 USCA section 6901 et seq.) and regulations thereunder, and without creating nuisances or hazards to public health or safety,
by confining the refuse to the smallest practical volume and covering it with a layer of earth at the conclusion of each day's operation, or by such other
methods and intervals as the board may provide by regulation.
SOLID WASTE: Includes demolition materials, food and industrial processing waste, garden trash, land cleaning wastes, mixed refuse, noncombustible
refuse, rubbish and trash, as those terms are defined in section 3.01 through 3.06 of the solid waste management act. (Ord. 1529, 5-7-1990; amd. Ord.
1877, 5-15-1995)
4-10-2: SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT FUND:
(A) There is hereby created with the city a solid waste management fund constituted from fees collected pursuant to this chapter. Interest received on the
monies in the fund shall be credited to the fund.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 172/357
(B) Monies in the fund may be accumulated over a period of years to be expended by the city for solid waste management purposes, including long term
monitoring and maintenance of landfills, planning, implementation, inspection enforcement and other activities consistent with the solid waste
management act1 and the local solid waste disposal act2.
(C) In April of each year, the city shall prepare and distribute to the agency a report that details spending plans for monies from the solid waste
management fund. The report will include the following:
1. The total monies collected pursuant to this chapter.
2. The most current balance of monies in the fund.
3. An itemized accounting of all monies expended from the fund for the previous year.
4. An estimation of monies to be collected for the following three (3) years pursuant to this chapter.
5. A narrative detailing the general direction and scope of future expenditures from the fund for one, two (2) and three (3) years. (Ord. 1529, 5-7-1990)
4-10-3: FEES; EXCEPTIONS:
(A) The city shall assess and collect a fee in the amount set forth herein from the owner or operator of each sanitary landfill operating within the jurisdiction
of the city permitted or required to be permitted by the agency to dispose of solid waste if the sanitary landfill is owned, controlled and operated by a
person other than the generator of such waste. If a site is contiguous to one or more landfills owned or operated by the same person, the volumes
received by each landfill shall be combined for purposes of determining the fee. The city shall deposit all fees collected into the solid waste
management fund.
1. If more than one hundred fifty thousand (150,000) cubic yards of nonhazardous solid waste is received at a site in a calendar year, the owner or
operator shall pay a fee of forty five cents ($0.45) per cubic yard on waste received on or before December 31, 1991, and sixty cents ($0.60) per
cubic yard on waste received on or after January 1, 1992, unless the owner or operator weighs the quantity of the solid waste received with a device
for which certification has been obtained under the weights and measures act3 in which case the owner or operator shall pay a fee of ninety five
cents ($0.95) per ton of solid waste received on or before December 31, 1991, and one dollar twenty seven cents ($1.27) per ton on solid waste
received on or after January 1, 1992.
2. If more than one hundred thousand (100,000) cubic yards, but not more than one hundred fifty thousand (150,000) cubic yards of nonhazardous
solid waste is received at a site in a calendar year, the owner or operator shall pay a fee of twenty five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) per year on
waste received on or before December 31, 1991, and thirty three thousand three hundred fifty dollars ($33,350.00) per year on waste received on or
after January 1, 1992.
3. If more than fifty thousand (50,000) cubic yards, but not more than one hundred thousand (100,000) cubic yards of nonhazardous solid waste is
received at a site in a calendar year, the owner or operator shall pay a fee of eleven thousand three hundred dollars ($11,300.00) per year on waste
received on or before December 31, 1991, and fifteen thousand five hundred dollars ($15,500.00) per year on waste received on or after January 1,
1992.
4. If more than ten thousand (10,000) cubic yards, but not more than fifty thousand (50,000) cubic yards of nonhazardous solid waste is received at a
site in a calendar year, the owner or operator shall pay a fee of three thousand four hundred fifty dollars ($3,450.00) per year on waste received on or
before December 31, 1991, and four thousand six hundred fifty dollars ($4,650.00) per year on waste received on or after January 1, 1992.
5. If not more than ten thousand (10,000) cubic yards of nonhazardous solid waste is received at a site in a calendar year, the owner or operator shall
pay a fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per year on waste received on or before December 31, 1991, and six hundred fifty dollars ($650.00) per
year on waste received on or after January 1, 1992.
(B) The fees set forth in subsection (A) of this section shall not apply to:
1. Waste which is hazardous waste; or
2. Waste which is pollution control waste; or
3. Waste from recycling, reclamation or reuse processes which has been approved by the agency as being designed to remove any contaminant from
wastes so as to render such wastes reusable, provided that the process renders at least fifty percent (50%) of the waste reusable; or
4. Nonhazardous solid waste that is received at a sanitary landfill and composted or recycled through a process permitted by the agency; or
5. Any landfill which is permitted by the agency to receive only demolition or construction debris or landscape waste. (Ord. 1529, 5-7-1990)
4-10-4: EXEMPTIONS:
(A) The city shall grant exemptions from the fee requirements of this chapter for receipt or transport of solid waste meeting all of the following criteria:
1. Receipt of the solid waste is pursuant to a written contract between the owner or operator of the sanitary landfill and some other person, or transport
of the solid waste is pursuant to a written contract between the transporter and some other person; and
2. The contract for receipt or transport of solid waste was lawfully executed on or before April 1, 1990, and by its express terms continues beyond April
1, 1990; and
3. The contract for receipt or transport of solid waste establishes a fixed fee or compensation, does not allow the operator or transporter to pass the fee
through to another party and does not allow voluntary cancellation or renegotiation of the compensation or fee during the term of the contract.
4. Provided, however, that this exemption shall not apply to the permanent disposal of solid waste under any contract lawfully executed before June 1,
1986, under which more than one hundred fifty thousand (150,000) cubic yards (or 50,000 tons) of solid waste is to be permanently disposed of.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 173/357
(B) The city shall grant exemptions from the fee requirements of this chapter for solid waste meeting all of the following criteria:
1. The waste is nonputrescible and homogeneous and does not contain free liquids;
2. Combustion of the waste would not provide practical energy recovery or practical reduction in volume; and
3. The applicant for exemption demonstrates that it is not technologically and economically reasonable to recycle or reuse the waste.
An applicant shall be granted the exemption under this subsection upon providing proof that an exemption has been granted by the agency under
415 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/22.16a, for the same waste. The exemption shall be effective from the effective date of the exemption granted by the
agency.
(C) Exemptions granted under subsections (A) and (B) of this section shall cause the solid waste received by an owner or operator of a sanitary landfill to
be disregarded in calculating the volume or weight of solid waste received during a calendar year under this chapter.
(D) Applications for exemptions must be submitted with proof of satisfaction of all criteria for granting the exemption to the administrator. The administrator
shall notify the applicants in writing of the granting or denial of an application for exemption.
(E) Applications for exemptions under subsection (A) of this section may be granted retroactively. Applications for retroactive or prospective exemptions
under that subsection must be received by the administrator before July 1, 1990.
Exemptions under subsection (A) of this section shall expire upon the expiration, renewal or amendment of the exempted contract, whichever comes
first.
(F) It shall be the duty of an owner or operator of a sanitary landfill and transporter of the solid waste to keep accurate records and to prove to the
satisfaction of the administrator the volume or weight of solid waste received under an exemption or exception during a calendar year. (Ord. 1529, 5-7-
1990)
4-10-5: REPORTS AND PAYMENTS:
(A) Every owner or operator of a sanitary landfill permitted, or required to be permitted by the agency and located within the jurisdiction of the city shall file
a quarterly report specifying the quantities of waste received and the fee payments due to the city. The quarterly solid waste disposal report shall be
due within thirty (30) days following the end of each calendar quarter and shall be in the form provided by the city. Said reports shall be tendered to the
city clerk.
(B) The city clerk shall forward a copy of the report to the mayor of the city.
(C) Every owner or operator of a sanitary landfill shall make payment of the fees as set forth in this chapter to the city clerk, at the time the report required
in subsection (A) of this section is filed. (Ord. 1529, 5-7-1990)
4-10-6: CESSATION OF OPERATION:
The owner or operator of each sanitary landfill subject to this chapter shall notify the administrator, in writing, if he is intending to terminate the receipt of
solid waste during the calendar year. Unless the termination of operation is by emergency order of an authorized regulatory agency or court of competent
jurisdiction, notice must be given to the administrator ninety (90) days in advance of termination. Said notice shall include estimated date of termination.
(Ord. 1529, 5-7-1990)
Chapter 11
BODY ART ESTABLISHMENTS AND TECHNICIANS
4-11-1: DEFINITIONS:
Whenever the following words or terms are used in this chapter, they shall have the following meanings ascribed to them:
ANTISEPTIC: An agent that destroys disease causing microorganisms on human skin or mucosa.
BIOMEDICAL WASTE: Any solid or liquid waste which may present a threat of infection to humans. Biomedical waste includes, but is not limited to, the
following: a) nonliquid tissue, body parts, blood, blood products and body fluids, b) absorbent materials saturated with blood, blood products, body fluids or
excretions or secretions contaminated with visible blood and absorbent materials saturated with blood or blood products that have dried, c) nonabsorbent,
disposable devices that have been contaminated with blood, but have not been treated by an approved method, and d) discarded sharps.
BODY ART ESTABLISHMENT: Any permanent place or premises where body art procedures are performed.
BODY ART PROCEDURE: The practice of applying physical body adornment to an individual using such invasive methods as body piercing, tattooing,
cosmetic tattooing, branding, scarification, or similar procedures. This term does not include ear piercing or any procedure performed by a person licensed
to practice medicine pursuant to Illinois law.
BODY ART TECHNICIAN: A person who performs body art procedures.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 174/357
BODY PIERCING: To make a hole in the body in order to insert or allow the insertion of any ring, hoop, stud, or other object for the purpose of
ornamentation of the body.
DISINFECT: The destruction of disease causing microorganisms on inanimate objects or surfaces, thereby rendering these objects or surfaces safe for
use or handling.
EQUIPMENT: All machinery, including fixtures, containers, vessels, tools, devices, implements, furniture, display and storage areas, sinks, and all other
apparatus and appurtenances used in connection with the operation of a body art establishment.
GLOVES: Latex, disposable medical gloves.
HAND SINK: A sink equipped with hot and cold water running under pressure and with wrist or foot operated controls, used solely for washing hands,
arms, or other portions of the body.
INSTRUMENT: Hand pieces, needles, needle bars, and other instruments that can come into contact with a patron's body or may be exposed to bodily
fluids during a body art procedure.
LICENSEE: A person who has been issued a license by the mayor to operate a body art establishment or to perform body art procedures.
LIQUID CHEMICAL GERMICIDE: A disinfectant or sanitizer registered with the environmental protection agency, or an approximate one to one hundred
(1:100) dilution of household chlorine bleach made fresh daily and dispensed from a spray bottle (500 ppm; 1/4 cup/gallon or 2 tablespoons/quart of tap
water).
PERSON: Any person, individual, firm, corporation, association, partnership, or any other form of association or organization.
PROCEDURE SURFACE: The skin area adjacent to and including the area where a body art procedure is applied, any surface of an inanimate object that
contacts the patron's unclothed body during a body art procedure, or any associated work area which may require sanitizing.
SANITIZE OR SANITIZING PROCEDURE: A process of reducing the number of disease causing microorganisms on instruments, equipment or procedure
surfaces to a safe level in accordance with public health standards by a method approved by the department of public health.
SHARPS: Objects capable of puncturing, lacerating or otherwise penetrating the skin.
SHARPS CONTAINER: A rigid, leak and puncture resistant container designed primarily for the containment of sharps. Sharps containers shall be clearly
labeled with the international biological hazard symbol.
STERILIZATION: A very powerful process resulting in the destruction of all forms of microbial life, including highly resistant bacterial spores.
SUPPLIES: Products, other than equipment and instruments, used in the preparation, performance, aftercare and cleanup of body art procedures.
TATTOO OR TATTOOING: Any method of placing ink or other pigment into or under the skin or mucosa by the aid of needles or any other instruments
used to puncture the skin which results in permanent coloration of the skin or mucosa, including all forms of cosmetic tattooing. (Ord. 2669, 12-3-2007)
4-11-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
(A) It shall be unlawful for any person to perform body art procedures without first obtaining a body art technician license from the city as provided herein.
(B) It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a body art establishment without first obtaining a body art establishment license from the city as provided
herein.
(C) It shall be unlawful for any person to perform body art procedures except within a licensed body art establishment. Body art procedures shall not be
performed in mobile or temporary vehicles or structures.
(D) It shall be unlawful for any person operating a body art establishment to permit body art procedures to be performed by anyone who does not have a
valid body art technician license.
(E) Licenses shall not be transferable and must be renewed as provided in section 4-11-3 of this chapter.
(F) Licensees shall comply at all times with the requirements of this chapter and shall notify the city clerk within ten (10) days of any change of the
information required to be provided in accordance with section 4-11-3 of this chapter. (Ord. 2669, 12-3-2007)
4-11-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
(A) Every applicant for a license as a body art technician shall submit an application providing the applicant's name, date of birth, gender, residence
address, mailing address, home and work telephone numbers, place(s) of employment as a body art technician, and training and experience in body
art procedures.
(B) Every applicant for a license as a body art establishment shall submit an application providing the applicant's name (if a partnership or corporation, the
names and resident addresses of all partners, officers, directors and the registered agent shall be included); proposed name of the body art
establishment and its street address, mailing address and hours of operation; the names of all body art technicians and their duties; a description of all
body art procedures to be performed; an inventory of all equipment, instruments and supplies to be utilized; the names and addresses of
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 175/357
manufacturers and suppliers of all equipment, instruments and supplies to be utilized; and the name, local address and telephone number of the
individual who shall be responsible for operation of the body art establishment.
(C) Application forms may be obtained from, and returned to, the City Clerk during normal business hours.
(D) The fee for a body art establishment license shall be four hundred twenty dollars ($420.00) per year. The fee for a body art technician license shall be
fifty dollars ($50.00) per year. (Ord. 2669, 12-3-2007)
(E) Upon determination that an applicant for a license meets the requirements set forth herein and has paid the required license fee, the Mayor shall issue
the appropriate license to the applicant. All licenses shall be issued with an effective date of May 1 and, unless earlier suspended or revoked, shall
expire on April 30 of the following year. Licenses may be renewed by submitting a new application and paying the license fees required by this section.
The fees subject to this section shall be prorated for any license issued after May 1 on a per diem basis. (Ord. 3078, 1-16-2018)
(F) Prior to the issuance or renewal of a body art establishment license, the City building official and the Fire Chief shall inspect and determine that the
premises for which the license is sought complies with the City's building and fire regulations. The Mayor shall not issue or renew a license until the
City building official and the Fire Chief have certified that the premises are in compliance with said regulations. (Ord. 2669, 12-3-2007)
4-11-4: ESTABLISHMENT STANDARDS:
(A) All licenses shall be posted within the body art establishment in a prominent and conspicuous area where they may be readily observed by patrons.
(B) Body art establishments shall be well ventilated and shall have an artificial light source equivalent to at least twenty (20) foot-candles at three feet (3')
above floor level, and at least one hundred (100) foot-candles at the level where body art procedures are performed and where instruments and sharps
are assembled.
(C) All surfaces where body art procedures are performed, including patron chairs and benches, shall be of such construction as to be easily cleaned and
sanitized after each use. Liquid chemical germicide shall be used for cleaning and sanitizing such surfaces.
(D) A separate hand sink supplied with liquid soap and disposable paper towels shall be located within or immediately adjacent to all areas where body art
procedures are performed. Each hand sink shall serve no more than three (3) body art technicians. In the absence of a separate washing sink, hand
sinks may be used for initial cleaning of instruments and equipment prior to sanitation or sterilization procedures. In addition, the body art establishment
shall contain at least one bathroom with a sink and a toilet for use by patrons.
(E) A covered refuse receptacle shall be provided in each area where body art procedures are performed and in each bathroom. These receptacles shall
be emptied daily. Refuse shall be removed from the premises at least weekly. All refuse receptacles shall be covered and kept clean.
(F) Sharps shall be disposed of in sharps containers.
(G) All products used to check the flow of blood or to absorb blood shall be disposed of immediately after use in appropriate covered containers, unless
the disposable product meets the definition of "biomedical waste". All biomedical waste shall be disposed of as required by law.
(H) No animals of any kind shall be allowed in a body art establishment, except service animals used by persons with disabilities (e.g., seeing eye dogs).
Fish aquariums are allowed in waiting rooms and nonprocedural areas.
(I) No insects, vermin or rodents shall be present in any part of a body art establishment. (Ord. 2669, 12-3-2007)
4-11-5: PROHIBITIONS:
(A) No person, other than a person licensed to practice medicine under Illinois law, shall tattoo or offer to tattoo a person under twenty one (21) years of
age.
(B) Except as provided in subsection (A) of this section with respect to tattoos, no person, other than a person licensed to practice medicine under Illinois
law, shall perform or permit the performance of body art procedures upon a person under eighteen (18) years of age without the presence, photo
identification and written consent of the minor's parent or legal guardian. A licensee may refuse to perform a body art procedure on a person under
eighteen (18) years of age regardless of the parent's or guardian's consent.
(C) No person shall perform or permit the performance of body art procedures on any person who appears to be under the influence of alcohol or drugs or
is incoherent for any reason.
(D) No person shall perform or permit the performance of body art procedures on any skin or mucosa surface where a rash or any visible infection is
present.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 176/357
(E) No person affected with boils, infected wounds, open sores, abrasions, keloids, weeping dermatological lesions or acute respiratory infection shall work
in a body art establishment in any capacity in which the person could contaminate equipment, instruments, supplies or procedure surfaces with body
substances or pathogenic organisms.
(F) No person shall perform or permit the performance of any procedure implanting any objects under the skin, such as ball bearings or beads.
(G) No person shall perform any body art procedure while under the influence of alcohol or drugs. (Ord. 2669, 12-3-2007)
4-11-6: PATRON'S MEDICAL HISTORY:
(A) Prior to performing any body art procedure, in order to evaluate the patron's medical condition for receiving a body art procedure, the body art
technician shall specifically request from the patron verbally and in writing the following information:
1. History of diabetes;
2. History of hemophilia;
3. History of skin disease, skin lesions or skin sensitivities to soaps, disinfectants, etc.;
4. History of allergies or adverse reactions to pigments, dyes, or other skin sensitivities;
5. History of epilepsy, seizures, fainting, or narcolepsy;
6. Current or recent medications which thin the blood or interfere with healing expectations; and
7. Any other information that would aid in evaluating the patron's healing expectations.
(B) Prior to performing any body art procedure, the body art technician shall obtain a release form signed by the patron confirming that the body art
technician obtained the information required by subsection (A) of this section.
(C) The body art technician shall refuse to perform a body art procedure if the patron refuses to disclose the information requested. (Ord. 2669, 12-3-2007)
4-11-7: PERFORMANCE OF PROCEDURES:
(A) The body art technician shall at all times maintain a high degree of personal cleanliness, conform to hygienic practices, wear clean clothes, and keep
his or her skin free of rash or infection.
(B) Before performing a body art procedure, the procedure surface shall be washed with antiseptic liquid soap and water or an approved surgical skin
preparation. If shaving is necessary, a single use disposable razor shall be used and then discarded. The reusable holder for the shaver, if any, shall be
sterilized. After shaving, the procedure surface shall be washed with antiseptic liquid soap and water, and the washing pad shall be discarded.
(C) Immediately before performing a body art procedure on an individual, the body art technician shall thoroughly wash his hands in hot running water with
antiseptic liquid soap or other sanitizing agent. The body art technician shall then rinse his hands and dry them with disposable paper towels. This
process shall be done as many times as necessary to remove all contaminants from the body art technician's hands. The body art technician shall also
wash his hands according to the method set forth herein at the conclusion of each body art procedure.
(D) Body art technicians shall wear gloves on each hand during all body art procedures. The body art technician shall wash his hands as provided in
subsection (C) of this section prior to putting on gloves. The gloves shall be discarded after the completion of each body art procedure on an individual
patron. Under no circumstances shall the same gloves be used on more than one person or for more than one body art procedure.
(E) If, prior to or while performing a body art procedure, the body art technician's glove or gloves are pierced, torn or contaminated by contact with any
contaminated surface or object or by contact with a third person, the body art technician shall immediately discard the gloves, repeat the hand washing
procedures described in subsection (C) of this section and put on a new pair of gloves as described in subsection (D) of this section to complete the
procedure.
(F) If any equipment or instrument becomes contaminated during a body art procedure, the body art procedure shall immediately be halted. The
contaminated instrument shall be replaced immediately with a sterilized instrument and the contaminated equipment sanitized before the procedure
may resume.
(G) After completing the body art procedure, the skin surface shall be cleaned with an antiseptic liquid soap and allowed to dry. Sterile gauze dressing
shall then be fastened to the affected skin surface. The surface where the body art procedure was performed, including any chairs or benches, shall be
cleaned and sanitized with liquid chemical germicide.
(H) Licensees shall comply at all times with the regulations of the department of labor's occupational safety and health administration (29 CFR 1910.1030),
as presently existing or hereafter amended, with respect to occupational exposure to blood, bloodborne pathogens or other potentially infectious
materials. Said regulations are hereby incorporated into this chapter by this reference. (Ord. 2669, 12-3-2007)
4-11-8: PATRON INSTRUCTIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 177/357
(A) Every person receiving a body art procedure shall be provided with verbal and written instructions for aftercare of the body art procedure. The
instructions shall advise the patron of proper care for the healing of the body specific to the body art procedure performed and to consult a physician at
the first sign of infection or swelling. The instructions shall include the name, address and telephone number of the body art establishment and the
name of the body art technician who performed the body art procedure.
(B) The written instructions shall be signed and dated by both the patron and the body art technician. The body art establishment shall retain a signed
original of the instructions and shall give a copy to the patron. (Ord. 2669, 12-3-2007)
4-11-9: RECORDS:
(A) The body art establishment shall keep a record of all body art procedures performed. The record shall include: 1) the patron's name, date of birth and
address, 2) the date of the body art procedure, 3) the type and location of each body art procedure performed and 4) the name of the body art
technician who performed each body art procedure. Signed copies of the release form required by subsection 4-11-6(B) of this chapter and the
instructions required by section 4-11-8 of this chapter shall also be kept. All records shall be available for inspection by the city upon request.
(B) Records containing a patron's personal medical information shall be kept confidential, except to the extent disclosure is necessary and authorized by
Illinois law in the administration and enforcement of this chapter.
(C) All records shall be retained by the body art establishment for at least three (3) years. (Ord. 2669, 12-3-2007)
4-11-10: EQUIPMENT, INSTRUMENTS AND SUPPLIES:
(A) All equipment and instruments directly used in the performance of body art procedures shall be specifically manufactured for this purpose and used
according to the manufacturer's instructions.
(B) Sterilized equipment, instruments and supplies shall be stored in clean, dry, covered containers. No equipment, instruments or supplies that are
required to be sterilized shall be used if the package has been breached or the expiration date has expired, without first repackaging and resterilizing
the equipment, instruments or supplies.
(C) All products used to check the flow of blood or to absorb blood shall be disposable and discarded after a single use.
(D) All products applied to the skin, including body art stencils, shall be disposable and discarded after a single use, except that acetate stencils shall be
allowed for multiple use if disinfecting procedures are performed between each use. Petroleum jellies, soaps and other products used in the application
of stencils shall be dispensed and applied on the area to be tattooed with sterile gauze or in a manner to prevent contamination of the original container
and its contents. The gauze shall be used only once and then discarded.
(E) All inks, dyes, and pigments shall be specifically manufactured for the performance of body art procedures and used according to the manufacturer's
instructions. The mixing of approved inks, dyes or pigments, or their dilution with potable water, is acceptable. Immediately before applying a tattoo, the
quantity of the dye to be used shall be transferred from the dye bottle into single use paper or plastic cups or caps. Upon completion of the tattoo, these
single use cups or caps and their contents shall be discarded.
(F) When assembling instruments, the body art technician shall wear gloves and shall use medically recognized techniques to ensure that the instruments
and gloves are not contaminated.
(G) Single use items shall be discarded immediately after each use and shall not be used with more than one patron for any reason.
(H) Reusable cloth items shall be mechanically washed with detergent and dried after each use.
(I) The following process shall be followed after each use for all instruments used for body art procedures that are not single use instruments:
1. The instrument shall be cleaned by following the manufacturer's cleaning instructions. If there are no cleaning instructions, the instrument shall be
cleaned by scrubbing with an appropriate disinfectant and hot water to remove blood and tissue residue.
2. The instrument shall be placed in an ultrasonic sterilizing unit, which shall be operated in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions.
3. The instrument shall be packed individually in a peel pack containing either a sterilizer indicator or internal temperature indicator and sterilizer.
4. Peel packs shall be dated with an expiration date not to exceed six (6) months. (Ord. 2669, 12-3-2007)
4-11-11: INSPECTION:
(A) Licensees shall be inspected as often as the city deems necessary to ensure compliance with this chapter. At a minimum, inspections shall be made at
least every three (3) months. The costs of inspection shall be paid by the body art establishment.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 178/357
(B) Inspections shall be made by persons chosen and paid for by the body art establishment. Inspections shall be made by either: 1) a licensed
environmental health practitioner, 2) a registered nurse, or 3) a person with a bachelor of science degree in nursing, none of whom may be an
employee of the body art establishment. Additionally, the persons conducting the inspections shall have knowledge of the following:
1. Anatomy, skin diseases, disorders and conditions, including diabetes.
2. Infectious disease control, including waste disposal and hand washing.
3. Sanitizing, disinfecting and sterilization methods.
4. Operation of equipment and instruments.
(C) Immediately following an inspection, the person conducting the inspection shall furnish the inspection report to the city clerk. The inspection report
shall state that the licensee is in compliance with this chapter or, if not in compliance, the nature of any violations with reference to specific section
numbers. The person conducting the inspection shall also furnish a copy to the licensee.
(D) The city may conduct inspections of any licensee at any time to ensure compliance with this chapter. The person conducting an inspection on behalf of
the city shall be chosen and paid for by the city. In the event a licensee fails to satisfy an inspection paid for by the city, the licensee shall be required to
reimburse the city for the costs of the inspection in addition to any other penalties or fines set forth in this chapter.
(E) The person conducting an inspection shall identify himself upon entering a body art establishment. (Ord. 2669, 12-3-2007)
4-11-12: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSES; PENALTIES:
(A) The mayor may suspend or revoke any license issued under this chapter for any of the following reasons:
1. The licensee has violated any of the laws of the United States or the state of Illinois relating in any way to the performance of body art procedures, or
any ordinance enacted by the city council.
2. The licensee has made a false statement as to any material fact on its application for a license.
3. The licensee has permitted an unlawful, disorderly or immoral practice within the body art establishment.
4. An agent or employee of the licensee has been found to have committed any of the acts specified in subsections (A)1 through (A)3 of this section.
(B) All hearings to determine whether a license shall be suspended or revoked shall be conducted by the mayor. A notice of hearing shall be delivered to
the licensee by certified mail at the address listed in the licensee's application at least seven (7) days prior to the hearing. The notice shall specifically
set forth the nature of the violation and the time and place of the hearing. A certified court reporter shall be present and shall prepare an official record
of the proceedings. Within a reasonable time after the conclusion of the hearing, but not later than ten (10) days after such conclusion, the mayor shall
file his written decision.
(C) If the conduct of a licensee constitutes a clear and present danger to the public health, safety or general welfare, the mayor shall be authorized to
summarily suspend any license issued under this chapter until such time as a hearing may be conducted. The mayor shall conduct a hearing within ten
(10) days of the suspension of a license pursuant to this subsection.
(D) All appeals from any decision of the mayor shall be reviewed pursuant to the Illinois administrative review law.
(E) Any person convicted of a violation of any provision of this chapter shall be punished by a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each violation. Each day that a violation occurs or is permitted to continue shall be deemed a separate
violation. (Ord. 2669, 12-3-2007)
Chapter 12
WATER WELLS
4-12-1: PURPOSE:
This chapter provides for the issuance of permits for well drilling, construction, repair and modification of water wells for the reason that the groundwater of
the city will not be contaminated or polluted and that water obtained from wells will not jeopardize the health, safety or welfare of the people, and preserve
the present water table level. (Ord. 2006, 8-4-1997)
4-12-2: ACTS PROHIBITED, PERMITS REQUIRED:
No person shall, within the city limits, be permitted to drill their own well when said person's land is within two hundred feet (200') of the public water
supply. All well applications must be reviewed and approved by the city council before a permit can be issued for same. (Ord. 2053, 12-15-1997; amd. Ord.
2549, 10-3-2005)
4-12-3: DEFINITIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 179/357
CONSTRUCTION: Shall include, but not be limited to, the digging or excavating of any water well.
MODIFICATION OR REPAIR: Shall include, but not be limited to, the deepening of a well or the reperforation or replacement of a well casing.
WELL OR WATER WELL: Any artificial excavation constructed by any method for the purpose of extracting water from, or injecting water into, the
underground. (Ord. 2006, 8-4-1997)
4-12-4: PERMITS:
(A) Applications: Applications for permits to construct, repair or modify any water well shall be made to the building official of the city and shall include the
following:
1. A plot plan indicating the exact location of the well with respect to the following items within a radius of two hundred feet (200') of the well:
(a) Public water lines.
(b) Public sewer lines.
(c) Property lines.
(d) Existing wells.
(e) Septic systems.
(f) Existing or proposed buildings.
(g) Access roads or streets.
2. Location of the property.
3. Owner of the property.
4. Name of the person who will construct, repair and/or modify the well.
5. Depth of the well.
6. Use of the well.
7. Other information as may be necessary to determine if underground waters will be protected.
(B) Fees:
1. Permit Application Fee:
(a) Every permit application shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00), none of which shall be refundable.
2. Permit Fee:
(a) Same fee schedule as listed in subsection 7-1-9(B)3 of this code. (Ord. 2006, 8-4-1997)
(b) Prior to issuance of a permit the person applying for a permit shall appear before the Dixon city council for a review of the appropriate ordinances
of the city concerning public water supplies and for a review of the information provided in the application for permit. (Ord. 2006, 8-4-1997; amd.
Ord. 2549, 10-3-2005)
(C) Expiration: Permits shall expire six (6) months from the issuance date. (Ord. 2006, 8-4-1997)
4-12-5: INSPECTION:
The building official of the city and any water department employee may at any and all reasonable times enter any and all places, property enclosures and
structures for the purpose of making examinations and investigations to determine whether any provision of the codes of the city relating to the drilling of
wells and the public water supply are being violated. (Ord. 2006, 8-4-1997)
4-12-6: STANDARD:
Standards for the construction, repair and modification of water wells shall be as provided for under appropriate state agencies, county agencies and state
law. (Ord. 2006, 8-4-1997)
4-12-7: PENALTY FOR VIOLATION:
Any person, firm or corporation who does any work for which a permit is required by this chapter and who fails to apply for and pay the fee for a permit, or
who otherwise violates any other provision of this chapter, shall upon conviction be fined an amount not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more
than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense in accordance with the provisions of this code. (Ord. 2006, 8-4-1997)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 180/357
Title 5
BUSINESS REGULATIONS
Chapter 1
GENERAL LICENSES
5-1-1: APPLICATIONS:
Applications for licenses and permits required by this code shall be made in writing to the clerk in the absence of provision to the contrary. Each application
shall state the name of the applicant, the permit or license desired, the location to be used, if any, the time covered and the fee to be paid and shall contain
such additional information as may be required herein. If the applicant is a partnership the application shall be signed by all of the partners. (1950 Code)
5-1-2: FORMS:
Forms for all licenses and permits and applications therefor shall be furnished by the clerk. (1950 Code)
5-1-3: FEES:
In the absence of provision to the contrary all fees and charges for licenses and permits shall be paid in advance to the clerk at the time the application is
made, and when an applicant has not engaged in a business for which a license is sought until after the expiration of a part of the current fiscal year the
license fees shall be prorated by quarters and the fee paid for each quarter or fraction thereof during which the business has been or will be conducted.
Except as otherwise provided all license fees shall become a part of the general corporate fund. No licensee shall be entitled to a refund of any portion of
any license fee paid to the city by reason of the fact that he ceases to conduct the business for which the license was granted prior to the end of the term
of the license. (1950 Code)
5-1-4: DURATION OF LICENSES:
No license shall be granted for a longer period than one year and all licenses shall terminate on the last day of the fiscal year of the city. (1950 Code)
5-1-5: APPROVAL OF LICENSES:
All applications for licenses shall be referred to the mayor, council or local liquor control commissioner for approval or disapproval where required by the
provisions of this code. Upon the approval of the application for any license, where required, and the payment of the required license fee, the clerk shall
issue a license. Where the approval of the mayor, council or local liquor commissioner is required, licenses shall be executed by the mayor in the name of
the city and attested by the clerk under the corporate seal and shall state the name of the licensee, the time for which granted and any other information
that may be required. Where such approval is not required, the clerk shall execute and issue licenses in the name of the city and under the corporate seal
thereof, and each license shall state the name of the licensee, the time for which granted, and any other information that may be required. (1950 Code)
5-1-6: OBEDIENCE TO REGULATIONS:
All licenses which may be issued under any provision of this code shall be subject to the regulations which may be in force at the time of the issuing
thereof, or which may subsequently be established by the council. If any person so licensed shall violate any of the provisions thereof, he shall be liable to
be proceeded against for any fine or penalty imposed thereby, and his license shall be subject to be revoked by the council, unless otherwise provided in
this chapter. (1950 Code)
5-1-7: LICENSES NOT ASSIGNABLE:
Except as otherwise provided, no license granted under this chapter or any other provision of this code shall be assignable or transferable without
permission of the council, nor shall any such license authorize any person to do business or act under it but the person named therein. (1950 Code)
5-1-8: POSTING AND EXHIBITING:
Any person having obtained a license shall, when demanded by any officer of the city, forthwith exhibit the same to such officer and if the business of the
licensee be local he shall immediately upon the receipt of his license cause the same to be and remain posted in some conspicuous place in his business
establishment and if any such licensee shall fail or refuse to exhibit his license when demanded as aforesaid, or neglect or refuse to post the same as
herein required, he shall be subject to the general penalty regulation of this code. (1950 Code)
5-1-9: EXEMPTION:
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to licenses required for animals1. (1950 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 181/357
Chapter 2
OCCUPATION TAXES
5-2-1: MUNICIPAL RETAILERS' OCCUPATION TAX:
Commencing July 1, 2005, a nonhome rule municipal retailers' occupation tax of one-half (1/2) of one percent (1%) is hereby imposed upon all persons
engaged in the business of selling tangible personal property at retail in the city of Dixon. Such tax shall not apply to the sale of an item of tangible
personal property which is titled and registered by an agency of the state of Illinois; the sale of prescription and nonprescription medicines, drugs, and
medical appliances; the sale of insulin, urine testing materials, syringes, and needles used by diabetics; or the sale of food for human consumption that is
to be consumed off the premises where it is sold, other than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks, and food that has been prepared for immediate consumption.
(Ord. 2507, 11-15-2004)
5-2-2: MUNICIPAL SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX:
Commencing July 1, 2005, a nonhome rule municipal service occupation tax of one-half (1/2) of one percent (1%) is hereby imposed upon all persons
engaged within the city of Dixon in the business of making sales of service on the selling price of all tangible personal property transferred by such
servicemen or servicewomen either in the form of tangible personal property or in the form of real estate as an incident to a sale of service. Such tax shall
not apply to the sale of prescription and nonprescription medicines, drugs, and medical appliances; the sale of insulin, urine testing materials, syringes,
and needles used by diabetics; or the sale of food for human consumption that is to be consumed off the premises where it is sold, other than alcoholic
beverages, soft drinks, and food that has been prepared for immediate consumption. (Ord. 2507, 11-15-2004)
5-2-3: MUNICIPAL UTILITY TAX:
(A) Tax Imposed: A tax is imposed on all persons engaged in the following occupations or privileges:
1. Persons engaged in the business of transmitting messages by means of electricity, at the rate of three and one-half percent (31/2%) of the gross
receipts from such business originating within the corporate limits of the city.
2. Persons engaged in the business of distributing, supplying, furnishing, or selling gas for use or consumption within the corporate limits of the city,
and not for resale, at the rate of three and one-half percent (31/2%) of the gross receipts therefrom.
3. Persons engaged in the business of distributing, supplying, furnishing, or selling electricity for use or consumption within the corporate limits of the
city and not for resale, at the rate of three and one-half percent (31/2%) of the gross receipts therefrom.
(B) Exemptions: No tax is imposed by this chapter with respect to any transaction in interstate commerce or otherwise to the extent to which such business
may not, under the constitution and statutes of the United States, be made subject to taxation by this state or any political subdivision thereof; nor shall
any person engaged in the business of distributing, supplying, furnishing or selling gas or electricity, or engaged in the business of transmitting
messages be subject to taxation under the provisions of this chapter for such transactions as are or may become subject to taxation under the
provisions of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-1 of the "municipal retailers' occupation tax act" of the Illinois municipal code, as amended.
(C) Tax Additional Payment: Such tax shall be in addition to the payment of money, or value of products or services furnished to this municipality by the
taxpayer as compensation for the use of its streets, alleys or other public places, or installation and maintenance therein, thereon or thereunder of
poles, wires, pipes or other equipment used in the operation of the taxpayer's business. (Ord. 1383, 10-5-1987)
(D) Definitions: For the purposes of this section the following definitions shall apply:
GROSS RECEIPTS: The consideration received for the transmission of messages, or for distributing, supplying, furnishing or selling gas or electricity,
for use or consumption and not for resale, as the case may be; and for all services rendered in connection therewith valued in money, whether received
in money or otherwise, including cash, credit, services, and property of every kind and material and for all services rendered therewith; and shall be
determined without any deduction on account of the cost of transmitting said messages without any deduction on account of the cost of the service,
product or commodity supplied, the cost of materials used, labor or service cost, or any other expenses whatsoever. "Gross receipts" shall not include
receipts received from the city of Dixon for the sale to said municipality of any of the utility products or services mentioned above.
Gross receipts shall not include charges added to customers' bills to recover the surcharge imposed under the emergency telephone system act. For
utility bills issued on or after May 1, 1996, but before May 1, 1997, and for receipts from those utility bills, "gross receipts" shall not include one-third
(1/3) of: 1) amounts added to customers' bills under section 9-222 of the public utilities act, or 2) amounts added to customers' bills by taxpayers who
are not subject to rate regulation by the Illinois commerce commission for the purpose of recovering any of the tax liabilities described in section 9-222
of the public utilities act. For utility bills issued on or after May 1, 1997, but before May 1, 1998, and for receipts from those utility bills, "gross receipts"
shall not include two-thirds (2/3) of: 3) amounts added to customers' bills under section 9-222 of the public utilities act, or 4) amount added to
customers' bills by taxpayers who are not subject to rate regulation by the Illinois commerce commission for the purpose of recovering any of the tax
liabilities described in section 9-222 of the public utilities act. For utility bills issued on or after May 1, 1998, and for receipts from those utility bills,
"gross receipts" shall not include: 5) amounts added to customers' bills under section 9-222 of the public utilities act, or 6) amounts added to
customers' bills by taxpayers who are not subject to rate regulation by the Illinois commerce commission for the purpose of recovering any of the tax
liabilities described in section 9-222 of the public utilities act.
PERSONS: Any natural individual, firm, trust, estate, partnership, association, joint stock company, joint venture, corporation, municipal corporation or
political subdivision of this state, or a receiver, trustee, conservator or other representative appointed by order of any court.
TRANSMITTING MESSAGES: In addition to the usual and popular meaning of person to person communication, shall include the furnishing, for a
consideration, of services or facilities (whether owned or leased), or both, to persons in connection with the transmission of messages where such
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 182/357
persons do not, in turn, receive any consideration in connection therewith, but shall not include such furnishing of services or facilities to persons for the
transmission of messages to the extent that any such services or facilities for the transmission of messages are furnished for a consideration, by such
persons to other persons, for the transmission of messages. (Ord. 1383, 10-5-1987; amd. Ord. 1954, 9-3-1996)
(E) Effective Date: This chapter shall take effect after publication and the tax provided for herein shall be based on the gross receipts, as herein defined,
actually paid to the taxpayer for services billed on or after December 1, 1987. (Ord. 1383, 10-5-1987)
(F) Filing Tax Return: On or before the last day of January, 1988, the taxpayers described in subsection (A) of this section shall make a return of the city
treasurer for the month of December, 1987. Said returns shall state:
1. Taxpayer's name;
2. Taxpayer's principal place of business;
3. Taxpayer's gross receipts during those months upon which the basis of the tax is imposed;
4. Amount of tax;
5. Such other reasonable and related information as the corporate authorities may require.
On or before the last day of every month thereafter, each taxpayer shall make a like return to the city treasurer for a corresponding one month period.
The taxpayer making the return herein provided for shall, at the time of making such return, pay to the city treasurer, the amount of tax herein
imposed; provided that in connection with any return the taxpayer may, if he so elects, report and pay an amount based upon his total billings of
business subject to the tax during the period for which the return is made (exclusive of any amounts previously billed) with prompt adjustments of
later payments based upon any differences between such billings and the taxable gross receipts. (Ord. 1385, 10-13-1987)
(G) Erroneous Payment: If it shall appear that an amount of tax has been paid which was not due under the provisions of this chapter, whether as the
result of a mistake of fact or an error of law, then such amount shall be credited against any tax due, or to become due, under this chapter from the
taxpayer who made the erroneous payment; provided that no amounts erroneously paid more than three (3) years prior to the filing of a claim therefor
shall be so credited.
