5-13-9: RESTRICTIONS ON TIME OF SALE7:
No alcoholic liquor shall be sold, delivered, transferred, distributed or given away upon or about any licensed premises by anyone at any time except those
times permitted by this section.
(A) General Restrictions On Time Of Sale: No alcoholic liquor shall be sold, delivered, transferred, distributed or given away upon or about any licensed
premises by anyone except during the following periods of time on the following days:
1. On the days of Monday through Saturday from six o'clock (6:00) A.M. to one o'clock (1:00) A.M. of the following day. (Ord. 1610, 8-19-1991)
2. For those licenses only which include Sundays: On Sundays from eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. to eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. (Ord. 2764, 11-2-2009)
3. A licensee having a Class F, F-1, G-1, I, or I-1 license may remain open to the public to sell, deliver, transfer, distribute or give away alcoholic liquor
only: a) during regular retail store hours, b) during times specified in this section, and c) on the days specified for that license. (Ord. 2498, 9-7-2004)
(B) New Year's Eve Exception: On the evening of December 31 of one year to January 1 of the following year (which period is commonly known as New
Year's Eve), licensed premises may sell alcoholic beverages from six o'clock (6:00) A.M. of December 31 of one year until one o'clock (1:00) A.M. on
January 1 of the following year. If December 31 of any year is a Sunday, alcoholic liquor may be sold between the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00) noon
on December 31 to one o'clock (1:00) A.M. of January 1 of the following year. (Ord. 1610, 8-19-1991)
(C) Holiday Exception: On the Sunday evening of any Sunday which precedes a legal holiday as affirmed by the Mayor of the City of Dixon, licensed
premises may sell alcoholic beverages until one o'clock (1:00) A.M. of the following day. This exception shall only apply in those instances where the
Mayor of the City of Dixon has affirmed that the Monday following the Sunday in question is a legal holiday. (Ord. 2356, 11-5-2001)
(D) Rules For Class O License: Alcoholic liquor may be sold, delivered, transferred, distributed or given away on the premises during no more than thirty
(30) hours per calendar month. The holder of a Class O license shall, at least five (5) days before the commencement of each month, provide the Local
Liquor Control Commissioner with a written schedule of anticipated hours for the following month, including closing times. The schedule may be
amended only upon the prior approval of the Local Liquor Control Commissioner. Nothing in this subsection shall limit the ability of the holder of Class
O license to apply for a temporary license under subsection 5-13-5(M) of this chapter. (Ord. 3081, 2-20-2018)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 3138 - LIQUOR CODE - CHAMBER OF COMMERCE. Go to new ordinance.
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 3139 - LIQUOR CODE - ROSBROOK STREET FAIR. Go to new ordinance.
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 3141 - LIQUOR CODE - PETUNIA FESTIVAL. Go to new ordinance.
5-13-10: CLOSING HOURS; EXCEPTION8:
(A) General Closing Hours:
1. No person other than a licensee or an employee of a licensee shall remain upon any licensed premises for any period of time longer than one-half
(1/2) hour following the time specified in section 5-13-9 of this chapter as the time when the sale, distribution, transfer or gift of alcoholic liquor must
terminate. (Ord. 1612, 8-19-1991)
2. No person including a licensee or an employee of a licensee shall remain upon any licensed premises for any period of time longer than eighty (80)
minutes following the time specified in section 5-13-9 of this chapter as the time when the sale, distribution, transfer or gift of alcoholic liquor must
terminate. At no time while the licensee, or his employees or agents, are upon the premises for the purpose of operating, controlling, maintaining or
cleaning the premises, shall the licensee or employee or agent consume, sell, deliver, transfer, distribute or give away any alcoholic beverage on
said premises; and during said times the doors of the licensed premises shall be secured to the general public. (Ord. 1612, 8-19-1991; amd. Ord.
2205, 1-3-2000)
3. No licensee, employee or agent of a licensee shall permit any other person to remain on the licensed premises beyond the closing hours specified in
subsection (A)1 of this section and in section 5-13-9 of this chapter.
(B) Exception: Persons and premises having a Class A, A-1, B, B-1, C or C-1 license may remain open after the time designated in subsection (A) of this
section but only for the sale of food or beverages other than alcoholic liquor.
(C) Special Permit Application: A licensee may apply to the Liquor Commission for a special permit to allow the licensee, its agent or employees, to be
upon the licensed premises at other times for the purpose of remodeling or redecorating. Such permit shall be issued only if a valid building permit for
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 199/357
such redecorating or remodeling, if necessary, has been issued by the building official of the City. (Ord. 1612, 8-19-1991)
(D) Exception For Class F, F-1, G-1, I, Or I-1 License: Persons and premises having a Class F, F-1, G-1, I, or I-1 license may remain open after the time
designated in section 5-13-9 of this chapter but only for the sale of food products, drugs, gasoline and retail items other than alcoholic liquor. (Ord.
2498, 9-7-2004)
5-13-11: UNLAWFUL SALES:
(A) No licensee, nor any officer, associate, member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee shall sell, give, or deliver alcoholic liquor to any
persons under the age of twenty one (21) years, or to any intoxicated person or to any person known by him to be a habitual drunkard, spendthrift,
insane, mentally ill, mentally deficient or in need of mental treatment. No person, after purchasing or otherwise obtaining alcoholic liquor should sell,
give or deliver such alcoholic liquor to another person under the age of twenty one (21) years, except in the performance of religious ceremony or
service and under the conditions of subsection (D) of this section.
(B) Any licensee, or his agent or employee, may refuse to sell or serve alcoholic beverages to any person who is unable to produce adequate written
evidence of identity and of the fact that he or she is over the age of twenty one (21) years. For the purpose of this subsection, adequate written
evidence of age and identity of the person is a document issued by a Federal, state, county or municipal government, or subdivision or agency thereof,
including, but not limited to, a motor vehicle operator's license, a registration certificate issued under the Federal Selective Service Act, or an
identification card issued to a member of the armed forces.
(C) If a licensee or his agents or employees believes or has reason to believe that a sale or delivery of any alcoholic liquor is prohibited because of the
nonage of the prospective recipient, he shall, before making such a sale or delivery demand presentation of some form of positive identification,
containing proof of age, issued by a public officer in the performance of his official duties.
(D) This section does not apply to the possession, dispension or consumption of alcoholic beverages by persons participating in the performance of a
religious ceremony nor to minors consuming alcoholic beverages under the direct supervision and approval of a parent of such minor in the privacy of
the minor's home. (Ord. 1023, 12-27-1979, eff. 1-1-1980)
5-13-12: RESTRICTIONS OF PERSONS OF NONAGE:
(A) Purchase Or Consume Alcohol: No person under the age of twenty one (21) years shall purchase, attempt to purchase or consume alcoholic liquor in a
licensed premises. (Ord. 1023, 12-27-1979, eff. 1-1-1980)
(B) Remaining On Property: At premises having Class D or D-1 licenses, no person under the age of twenty one (21) years shall remain in or around the
licensed premises. No licensee to whom is issued a Class D or D-1 license or employee or agent of a Class D or D-1 licensee shall allow any person
under the age of twenty one (21) years to remain in, on or around the licensed premises. (Ord. 1611, 8-19-1991)
(C) Loitering: Persons sixteen (16) years of age or older are authorized to be present on premises having a Class A, A-1, B, B-1 or N license for the
purpose of purchasing food and nonalcoholic beverages. At premises having a Class F, F-1, G-1, I or I-1 license, persons under twenty one (21) years
of age are permitted for any lawful purpose, but shall not loiter on the premises or remain longer than necessary to accomplish their lawful purpose.
(Ord. 2713, 10-20-2008)
(D) Parent Or Guardian Present: Persons below the age of sixteen (16) years are allowed to be present at premises having a Class A, A-1, B, C, or E
license provided they are present with a parent or guardian. (Ord. 1263, 4-1-1985)
(E) Employees:
1. Except as provided for in this subsection (E), persons between sixteen (16) and twenty one (21) years of age may be employed by a licensee for the
purposes of cleaning, cooking or bussing only and may not be employed on the premises for any other purpose and may not be involved in the sale,
delivery, or distribution of alcoholic liquor. (Ord. 2344, 9-4-2001)
2. Persons between eighteen (18) and twenty one (21) years of age may be employed by a licensee holding a Class A, A-1, B, C or C-1 license as a
waiter or waitress, provided, however, said employee may take orders for and deliver alcoholic beverages only: a) in conjunction with the sale of
food, and b) under the supervision of the licensee or some other authorized person twenty one (21) years of age or older. (Ord. 2207, 1-3-2000)
3. Persons twenty one (21) years of age or older may be employed by a licensee for the purpose of selling or distributing alcoholic liquor as a
bartender, clerk or salesperson.
4. No person under the age of twenty one (21) years may sell, distribute or pour alcoholic beverages or be employed to sell, distribute or pour alcoholic
beverages as a bartender, clerk or salesperson except as otherwise provided in this Code. (Ord. 1211, 1-16-1984)
(F) Sitting At A Bar: Persons under the age of twenty one (21) years may not sit at a bar or primary place where alcoholic liquor or beverage is dispensed.
(Ord. 1095, 7-6-1981)
(G) Persons Of Nonage Performing Live Music: Persons under the age of twenty one (21) may be present on a licensed premises for the purpose of
performing live music from thirty (30) minutes in advance of such performance until thirty (30) minutes after for the set up and removal of any incidental
equipment. At least one-half (1/2) of the participants in the performance must be of age twenty one (21) or older. (Ord. 3056, 9-5-2017)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 200/357
(H) Class O License: During those times the holder of a Class O license is selling, delivering, transferring, distributing or giving away alcoholic liquor
pursuant to subsection 5-13-9(D) of this chapter, persons below the age of sixteen (16) years are allowed to be present on the premises provided they
are present with a parent or guardian. During such times, persons between the ages of sixteen (16) and twenty one (21) years are permitted to be
present on the premises for any lawful purpose, but shall not loiter on the premises or remain longer than necessary to accomplish their lawful purpose.
(Ord. 3081, 2-20-2018)
5-13-13: INSPECTION OF PREMISES:
The Mayor, Commissioners, Chief of Police and all members of the police force may enter and inspect the premises of each licensee hereunder, or any
adjacent premises occupied or controlled by the licensee or his agent, at any time, and they may take possession of and remove any intoxicating liquors
found upon the premises in violation of any provision of this Code and all licenses now in force or hereafter issued under this chapter shall be subject to
the reservation of such authority and refusal to permit such action shall constitute sufficient grounds for the immediate suspension or revocation of the
license by the Local Liquor Control Commissioner. (Ord. 715, 8-21-1972, eff. 11-1-1972)
5-13-14: GAMBLING:
(A) No licensee or his agents or employees shall permit any person upon the licensed premises to play any games or participate in any activities for
money or other article of value or permit any person to bring on the premises any wheel, machine, video gaming terminal, board, dice, slot machine,
punchboard, or other machine or device used for gambling, except video gaming terminals licensed under the Illinois Video Gaming Act.
(B) No licensee or his agents or employees shall allow in or about the licensed premises the sale or purchase wherein any part of the article or thing
received or to be received, either as to quantity or value, shall in any manner depend upon any chance or hazard, whether by means of checks, cards,
envelopes, dice, punchboard or by any means whatever, except at those premises where the licensee: 1) obtains applicable State license or permit to
conduct or allow others to conduct the game commonly known as "bingo", or 2) is a licensed establishment permitting it to do so under the Illinois
Video Gaming Act.
(C) Every clock, machine, slot machine, video gaming terminal, punchboard or other machine or device for the reception of money on chance or upon the
action of which money is staked, hazarded, bet, won or lost is hereby declared a gambling device and the same shall be seized, confiscated and
destroyed by the police of the City wherever found upon the licensed premises or place controlled by the licensee, except video gaming terminals
licensed and registered under the Illinois Video Gaming Act.
(D) Any individual, partnership or corporation intending to place a video gaming terminal in its establishment shall first file an application for a video gaming
licensed establishment permit, which application shall include the following information:
1. The location for which the license is sought;
2. A copy of the written, signed lease or rental arrangement or other written authority for use of the equipment at the location;
3. The number of video gaming terminals to be on the location for which a permit is requested; and
4. Each application shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00). The application fee shall be payable to the city by
certified check or money order.
(E) All permits issued hereunder shall be issued by the mayor and attested by the city clerk and no permit shall issue until the application therefor shall
have been approved by the mayor.
(F) An annual fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each video gaming terminal shall be paid in advance on or before May 1 of each year. Each permit
shall expire on April 30 of each year. There shall be no proration of license fees.
(G) Each licensee shall comply with all requirements of the Illinois video gaming act, as amended from time to time.
(H) Under no circumstances shall any person under the age of twenty one (21) years be permitted to use or play a video gaming terminal. Any licensee
who: 1) knowingly permits a person under the age of twenty one (21) years to use or play a video gaming terminal or 2) fails to fully comply with the
provisions of the Illinois video gaming act or this section, shall have all permits of the licensee suspended, terminated or revoked. All hearings to
determine whether said permit shall be suspended, terminated or revoked shall be conducted by the mayor. All appeals from any decision of the mayor
shall be limited to a review of the official record of the proceedings of the mayor. (Ord. 2879, 6-18-2012)
5-13-15: LOCAL LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSIONER:
(A) The mayor shall be the local liquor control commissioner and shall be charged with the administration of the appropriate provisions of this chapter and
such other provisions of this code relating to alcoholic liquor as may be enacted. He may appoint a person to assist him in the exercise of the powers
and the performance of the duties herein provided for the local liquor control commissioner.
(B) The local liquor control commissioner, with the approval of a majority of the council, may adopt rules and regulations for hearings to determine whether
any license should be suspended, terminated or revoked. (Ord. 715, 8-21-1972, eff. 11-1-1972)
5-13-16: POWERS OF LOCAL LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSIONER:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 201/357
(A) The local liquor control commissioner shall have all the powers as provided by the laws of the state. The local liquor control commissioner may
suspend or revoke any license issued under this chapter and, in addition to a suspension, may levy a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) against the licensee for any of the following reasons:
1. The licensee has violated any of the laws of the United States relating to the sale of alcoholic liquor, or any of the provisions of the Illinois liquor
control act, or any ordinance enacted by the city council.
2. The licensee has made a false statement as to any material fact on its application for a liquor license.
3. The licensee has permitted an unlawful, disorderly or immoral practice upon the licensed premises.
4. The licensee has refused to testify on oath as to all relevant and material questions propounded to him at any hearing conducted by the mayor in
which a violation of any law of the United States, of the state of Illinois or any ordinances of the city regulating the sale of alcoholic liquor has been
charged.
5. The state of Illinois liquor control commission has suspended or revoked the license of the licensee.
6. The licensee has failed during the term for which the license is issued to conform to any of the requirements for the initial issuance of a license to sell
alcoholic liquors.
7. Any agent or employee of the licensee has been found to have committed any of the acts specified in subsections (A)1 through (A)6 of this section.
(B) All hearings to determine whether any license shall be suspended, terminated, or revoked, or whether a licensee shall be fined, shall be conducted by
the local liquor control commissioner. A certified court reporter or certified shorthand reporter shall be present and shall prepare a certified official
record of the proceedings. All appeals from any decision of the local liquor control commissioner shall be limited to a review of the official record of the
proceedings of the local liquor control commissioner. (Ord. 1920, 2-5-1996)
5-13-17: FILING OF APPLICATION:
(A) In addition to any other requirements contained in an application for liquor license, an application for a liquor license or renewal thereof shall include
the following information:
1. The location for which the license is sought;
2. A copy of the written, signed lease or rental arrangement or other written authority for the use of the location if the applicant is not the owner of said
location;
3. Certificate of insurance showing evidence of dramshop insurance coverage;
4. Certificate of insurance evidencing public liability insurance in an amount not less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) to any one person or one
hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for any one accident. (Ord. 1341, 10-20-1986)
(B) Each application shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee of seventy five dollars ($75.00) for each person applying for the license. The application
fee shall be payable to the city by certified check or money order. (Ord. 2411, 10-7-2002)
(C) All licenses issued hereunder shall be issued by the mayor and attested by the clerk under the corporate seal and no license shall issue until the
application therefor shall have been approved by the local liquor control commissioner. All applications for licenses shall remain on file in the office of
the clerk to be listed in a record to be kept for this purpose. (Ord. 1341, 10-20-1986)
(D) Prior to the issuance or renewal of a license, the city building official and the fire chief shall inspect and determine that the premises for which the
license is sought complies with the city's building and fire regulations. The local liquor commissioner shall not issue or renew a license until the city
building official and the fire chief have certified that the premises is in compliance with said regulations. (Ord. 2233, 4-3-2000)
5-13-18: TIME OF APPLICATION:
Application for a license or renewal of license shall be made to the mayor on application blanks furnished to the city clerk. Such applications shall contain
sufficient information to enable the mayor to determine the eligibility of the applicant for such license. Each application for renewal of a license issued
under this chapter shall be filed with the city clerk by April 1 of each year. Each application for license or renewal shall be accompanied by the payment of
the annual fee prorated on the monthly basis from the date of filing the application to May 1 next succeeding the filing of application. License fees may be
paid in two (2) installments, each installment to be paid in advance semiannually. (Ord. 1095, 7-6-1981)
5-13-19: TEMPORARY LICENSE FOR THE ANNUAL CITY FAIR:
(A) Issuance Of License:
1. The local liquor control commissioner is hereby authorized to issue two (2) licenses for the sale of "beer" and "wine" only as defined in this chapter to
a corporation chartered by the state as the corporation having as its primary purpose the establishment, maintenance and operation of the
celebration commonly referred to as the Petunia Festival which has been designated as the official city fair or, to the Dixon chamber of commerce for
the maintenance and operation of the celebration referred to in this subsection.
2. Each license issued by this section shall be designated "city fair license" and shall not exceed two (2) in number per calendar year. (Ord. 1611, 8-19-
1991)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 202/357
(B) Restrictions On Locations:
1. The licenses issued pursuant to this section may be issued for use at the following premises:
(a) The premises owned by the Dixon park district provided said premises are within the corporate limits of the city of Dixon and comply with state
statutes and local ordinances concerning location of authorized premises with the exception of the ordinances on zoning;
(b) The premises owned by the city of Dixon and commonly known as the Dixon Airport; or
(c) The parking lot owned by the city of Dixon and commonly known as the Beanblossom Parking Lot. (Ord. 2788, 6-21-2010)
2. If the license authorized by subsection (B)1(a) of this section is to be issued for the premises owned by the Dixon park district, such license shall not
be issued without the express written approval of the board of commissioners of the Dixon park district as evidenced by the execution of a valid lease
to said premises by the licensee and the board of commissioners of the Dixon park district.
3. If the license authorized by subsection (B)1(b) of this section is to be issued for the premises known as the Dixon Airport, such license shall not be
issued without the express written approval of the Dixon airport board as evidenced by the execution of a valid lease agreement to said premises
between the licensee and the Dixon airport board. (Ord. 1262, 4-1-1985)
4. The sale and consumption of beer and wine shall be confined to the licensed premises.
5. All beer and wine sold shall be served only in disposable containers. (Ord. 1431, 6-20-1988)
(C) Restriction On Period Of License For The Dixon Park District Premises: The license issued for the premises owned by the Dixon park district shall be
issued for the limited period of the duration of the annual city fair as determined by the liquor control commissioner in the issuance of the license
pursuant to subsection (A) of this section. (Ord. 1262, 4-1-1985)
(D) Restrictions On Time Of Sale At The Dixon Park District Premises: For the days designated as the city fair, the sale of beer and wine shall be
authorized from twelve o'clock (12:00) noon to twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight. After that time all persons shall vacate the licensed premises with the
exception of those employees and agents of licensee who are delegated to operate, control, maintain, and clean the premises. All beer and wine shall
be removed from the licensed premises no later than one hour after the closing time on the days when sale of beer and wine is authorized. (Ord. 2539,
7-1-2005)
(E) Restrictions On City Owned Locations:
1. Restrictions On Dixon Airport Premises: The Dixon airport board shall establish such rules, regulations and restrictions, including the date, time,
place, location and such other limitations as it deems necessary to govern the use of the premises for which the license to be used at the Dixon
Airport is issued. Such rules, regulations, and restrictions shall be consistent with all federal, state, and city laws, ordinances, rules and regulations
and shall be incorporated in the lease agreement provided for in subsection (B)3 of this section.
2. Restrictions On Beanblossom Parking Lot: The license issued for the premises known as the Beanblossom Parking Lot shall be issued for one day
only, shall authorize the sale of beer and wine only, shall not permit the sale of beer and wine later than six o'clock (6:00) P.M., and shall be limited by
such other rules, regulations and restrictions as the local liquor control commissioner deems necessary to govern the use of the premises. (Ord.
2788, 6-21-2010)
(F) Restrictions On Persons Of Nonage:
1. No person under the age of twenty one (21) years shall purchase, attempt to purchase, possess, or consume any beer or wine or other alcoholic
beverage upon either licensed premises or other premises controlled by the licensee during the license period. (Ord. 1431, 6-20-1988)
2. Persons of any age are authorized to be present on the licensed premises issued as a city fair license under subsection (B)1(a) of this section.
Persons under the age of twenty one (21) are authorized to be present on the premises licensed under subsection (B)1(c) of this section during the
time for which the temporary license has been granted for the purpose of purchasing food and nonalcoholic beverages only. (Ord. 2788, 6-21-2010)
(G) Removal From Premises: Any duly authorized representative of licensee and any peace officer of the city, county of Lee or Dixon park district are
hereby empowered to remove any person from either licensed premises where such officer or agent has probable cause to believe that such person
may be under the influence of intoxicating beverages.
(H) Fee: The total annual fee for licenses shall be one dollar ($1.00). (Ord. 1262, 4-1-1985)
(I) Construction: It is the intent of the city council that this section of the liquor code be liberally construed for the express purpose of fulfilling the intent of
allowing the sale of beer and wine only at the city fair under the restrictive terms provided herein. Unless specifically excepted within this section all of
the terms and provisions of this code remain in full force and effect. (Ord. 1431, 6-20-1988)
5-13-19-5: TEMPORARY LICENSE FOR SALE AT DIXON RIVERFRONT/HERITAGE CROSSING:
(A) Issuance Of License:
1. Subject to the terms and conditions of this chapter, the local liquor control commissioner is hereby authorized to issue a license to any person or
entity for the sale, transfer or giving away of alcoholic liquor in the public area commonly known as the Dixon Riverfront/Heritage Crossing.
2. Each application for a license under this chapter shall include a certificate of insurance evidencing dramshop insurance and a certificate of insurance
evidencing public liability insurance in an amount not less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for any one person or one hundred thousand
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 203/357
dollars ($100,000.00) for any one accident. Said certificates of insurance shall name the city of Dixon, its city council, officers, agents and employees
of the city, and the riverfront commission as an additional insured.
(B) Restrictions On Locations:
1. The license issued pursuant to this section may be issued for use only at the public area owned by the city of Dixon and commonly known as the
Dixon Riverfront/Heritage Crossing. (Ord. 2796, 10-4-2010)
2. Any license authorized under subsection (A) of this section shall not be issued without the applicant first having entered into a lease agreement with
the Dixon riverfront commission (or its successor if the city has authorized any other entity to assume the day to day operations and management of
the Dixon Riverfront/Heritage Crossing). (Ord. 2941, 6-2-2014)
3. The sale, transfer and consumption of alcoholic liquor shall be confined to the area defined in said lease, and the defined area must be enclosed by
fencing. The location, composition, design and construction of the fence shall be approved by the mayor. No alcoholic liquor may be removed from
the enclosed area.
4. If alcoholic liquor is to be sold from the proposed licensed area, the application must be countersigned by the holder of a valid liquor license issued
under sections 5-13-3 and 5-13-5 of this chapter. In such case, the restrictions on the type of alcoholic liquor that may be sold under the holder's
liquor license shall be applicable. (Ord. 2796, 10-4-2010)
(C) Restriction On Period And Time Of Sale Of License: The license issued under subsection (A) of this section shall be issued for one day only and for a
length of time as determined by the local liquor control commissioner. Provided, however, under no circumstances shall alcoholic liquor be sold,
delivered, transferred, distributed or given away in the licensed area at times other than as provided for in section 5-13-9 of this chapter or on Sundays
from eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. to eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. (Ord. 2941, 6-2-2014)
(D) Restrictions On Sale Or Transfer:
1. No person under the age of twenty one (21) shall purchase, attempt to purchase, possess or consume any alcoholic liquor upon the licensed area.
2. No alcoholic liquor served in an open container may be removed from the licensed area.
3. No sales or dispensing of alcoholic liquor may be made from the licensed area to any person upon an adjoining property, public street, sidewalk or
alley.
4. Any license granted pursuant to this chapter may contain such other restrictions as the local liquor control commissioner deems warranted to protect
the use and enjoyment of the area and of adjacent properties.
5. Adequate security must be provided by applicant. (Ord. 2796, 10-4-2010)
(E) Restriction Of Riverfront Commission: The Dixon riverfront commission (or its successor if the city has authorized any other entity to assume the day to
day operations and management of the Dixon Riverfront/Heritage Crossing) shall establish rules, regulations, and restrictions governing use of the area
to be licensed. (Ord. 2941, 6-2-2014)
(F) Fee: The total fee for the license shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00).
(G) Violation: Any violation of this chapter shall also constitute grounds for the suspension or revocation of the liquor license if the applicant is also a
license holder under this chapter.
(H) Suspension And Termination: The mayor or the chief of police shall have the authority to immediately terminate or revoke the license granted under
this section if the mayor or the chief of police believes such action is necessary to prohibit the disturbing the peace of others, to terminate offensive
conduct, or to protect the health, safety and welfare of those present in the licensed area. (Ord. 2796, 10-4-2010)
5-13-20: CONDUCT IN OR UPON LICENSED PREMISES:
(A) Prohibited Conduct:
1. The following kinds of conduct on premises in the city of Dixon licensed to sell alcoholic liquor are prohibited:
(a) The performance of acts or simulated acts of sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation or any sexual acts
which are prohibited by law;
(b) The actual or simulated touching, caressing or fondling on the breast, buttocks, anus, or genitals;
(c) The actual or simulated displaying of the breast, pubic hair, anus, vulva or genitals;
(d) The displaying of films or pictures depicting acts, a live performance of which is prohibited by subsection (A)1(a), (A)1(b), or (A)1(c) of this
section.
(e) The permitting by a licensee, his agent or employee of any person to remain in or upon the licensed premises who exposes to public view any
portion of his or her genitals or anus;
(f) The allowance by a licensee, his agent, or employee of any person to perform, present, participate or direct in or upon the licensed premises any
play or dance or other performance which acts are prohibited by subsection (A)1(a), (A)1(b) or (A)1(c) of this section. (Ord. 901, 5-16-1977)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 204/357
(B) Tumultuous Conduct: No person shall disturb, tend to disturb, or aid in disturbing the peace of others by violent, tumultuous, offensive or obstreperous
conduct, and no person shall knowingly permit such conduct upon any premises owned or possessed by him or under his control and licensed to sell
alcoholic liquor. All liquor licensees shall aid city police to quell the aforesaid activities by reporting said conduct as soon as possible and shall
cooperate with city police in the investigation and prosecution of violators of this title. (Ord. 1382, 9-21-1987)
(C) Suspension And Revocation Of Liquor License: If, at any time, after the granting of a liquor license, any licensee shall have violated any of the
provisions of this code (and in particular, but not by way of limitation, any provision of this chapter) or any statute of the state (and in particular, but not
by way of limitation, the liquor control act) in the conducting of the licensee's business, the mayor may suspend or revoke the license therefor.
(D) Acts Of Agents Or Employees; Liability Of Licensee: Every act or omission of whatsoever nature constituting a violation of any of the provisions of this
code or any of the provisions of the liquor control act by any officer, director, manager or other agent or employee of any licensee, shall be deemed and
held to be the act of such licensee, and said licensee shall be punishable in the same manner as if said act or omission had been done or omitted by
the licensee. (Ord. 1463, 12-19-1988)
5-13-21: TRANSPORTING IN MOTOR VEHICLES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to transport, carry, possess or have any alcoholic liquor in or upon or about any motor vehicle except in the original
package and with the seal unbroken. (Ord. 1095, 7-6-1981)
5-13-22: OUTDOOR SALES AND SEATING:
(A) Prohibited Sales: Except as otherwise provided in this section, no outdoor sales of alcoholic liquor shall be carried on in connection with the premises
for which a license has been granted for the sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption upon property contiguous to the licensed premises. (Ord. 2545, 8-
1-2005)
(B) Outdoor Sales And Seating Permit: Each year the holder of a Class A, A-1, B, B-1, D, or D-1 license may apply for an outdoor sales and seating
permit, or renewal thereof, to sell alcoholic liquor outside of the permanent structure of the licensed premises for which the applicant's license has been
issued. The granting of an outdoor sales and seating permit is subject to the following terms and conditions: (Ord. 2883, 7-16-2012)
1. The area in which such sales are conducted must be enclosed and contiguous to and accessible only from the building where the sale of alcoholic
liquor is otherwise permitted.
2. Ingress and egress to the outdoor sales area must be from the permanent structure only and no access shall be permitted from the street, sidewalk
or adjoining property unless approved by the Mayor at the time the outdoor sales and seating permit is granted. (Ord. 2545, 8-1-2005)
3. The outdoor sales area shall be enclosed by fencing not less than five feet (5') in height. The location, composition, design and construction of the
fence shall be approved by the Mayor and the Building Official. (Ord. 2883, 7-16-2012)
4. Except as provided in subsection (B)13 of this section, no music of any kind may be played or broadcasted from the outdoor sales area after ten
o'clock (10:00) P.M. No music may be played or broadcasted within the adjacent licensed premises which is of such volume so as to disturb the
neighborhood in any manner. (Ord. 2548, 10-3-2005)
5. No sales or dispensing of alcoholic liquor may be made from the outdoor sales area to any person upon adjoining property, public street, sidewalk or
alley.
6. No alcoholic liquor served in an open container may be removed from the outdoor sales area or the licensed premises.
7. Adequate security must be provided by the licensee. (Ord. 2545, 8-1-2005)
8. The outdoor sales and seating permit shall be effective only from May 1 to April 30 of each year. Applications for renewal of an outdoor sales and
seating permit must be filed on an annual basis. (Ord. 2548, 10-3-2005)
9. No alcoholic liquor shall be sold, delivered, transferred, distributed or given away in the outdoor sales area by anyone except:
(a) Monday through Saturday from eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. to one o'clock (1:00) A.M. of the following day.
(b) On Sundays from eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. to ten o'clock (10:00) P.M.
Notwithstanding the foregoing, stricter hours of operation may be established by the Local Liquor Control Commissioner as part of the outdoor
sales and seating permit approval process.
10. All patrons of the outdoor area shall vacate the outdoor area no later than thirty (30) minutes following the time specified in subsection (B)9 of this
section.
11. No outdoor sales and seating permit shall be granted if the proposed area is located within one hundred twenty feet (120') of residentially zoned
property, a school, or a church, as measured in a straight line from the nearest property boundary of the residentially zoned property, school or
church. (Ord. 2545, 8-1-2005)
12. No outdoor sales and seating permit shall be granted unless the Finance Director shall certify that there are no outstanding fines, fees, taxes or
other charges due and owing to the City by the owners of the real property on which the proposed area is located or by the applicant. (Ord. 2545, 8-
1-2005; amd. Ord. 2887, 8-20-2012)
13. Upon approval of the application required by this subsection and payment of a twenty five dollar ($25.00) fee to the City, a temporary permit may be
issued to a permit holder to extend the time allowed for playing or broadcasting music in the outdoor sales area from ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. to either
eleven thirty o'clock (11:30) P.M. or twelve thirty o'clock (12:30) A.M., as may be approved by the Local Liquor Commissioner. Each temporary permit
issued hereunder shall be limited to a single outdoor event. Applications shall be made with the Local Liquor Commissioner not less than three (3)
days prior to the date of the intended outdoor event. The applicant shall include in the application the location and the specific time and date for
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 205/357
which the temporary permit is requested. No temporary permit shall issue until the application therefor shall have been approved by the Local Liquor
Commissioner. All applications shall remain on file in the Office of the Clerk to be listed in a record to be kept for this purpose. Holders of a temporary
permit shall not allow any unreasonably loud or raucous use or operation of a loudspeaker, amplifier, public address system or other device,
including musical instruments, for producing or reproducing sound. Sound measured from any location within five feet (5') of the boundary line of the
property for which the temporary permit is issued with a decibel meter set to A-weight that exceeds ninety (90) decibels shall be deemed
unreasonably loud and raucous and shall subject the holder of the temporary permit to violation under subsection (E) of this section. (Ord. 3029, 2-
21-2017)
(C) Application:
1. Application for an outdoor sales and seating permit or renewal thereof shall be submitted to the Mayor and shall include the following:
(a) A detailed drawing or sketch including the dimensions of the proposed outdoor area where the outdoor sales will occur.
(b) The location of the tables and chairs to be used.
(c) The type of fencing materials and dimensions.
(d) The number of seats that will be in the outdoor area.
(e) A one hundred dollar ($100.00) nonrefundable filing fee.
(f) Proof of dramshop insurance coverage on the outdoor sales area, consisting of a certificate of insurance including the outdoor sales area.
2. All applications shall be reviewed by the City Building Department to determine compliance with the requirements of this chapter and with the City
building code. No outdoor sales and seating permit shall be issued or renewed until the City Building Official has certified that the outdoor sales area
is in compliance with said requirements.
3. An outdoor sales and seating permit granted herein may contain such other conditions as the Local Liquor Control Commissioner deems warranted
to protect the use and enjoyment of adjacent properties.
4. The Mayor shall be the approving authority.
(D) Display: The outdoor sales and seating permit shall be displayed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
(E) Violation:
1. Any outdoor sales and seating permit issued pursuant to this section may be suspended or revoked for any violation of this chapter or any of the
provisions of this Code.
2. Any suspension of violation shall be conducted pursuant to this chapter.
3. Any violation of this section shall also constitute grounds for the suspension or revocation of the liquor license for the adjacent premises. (Ord. 2545,
8-1-2005)
5-13-23: OUTDOOR SIDEWALK CAFE:
(A) Outdoor Sidewalk Cafe Permit:
1. An outdoor sidewalk cafe permit shall be required to operate an outdoor sidewalk cafe. An "outdoor sidewalk cafe" shall mean a portion of an
immobile retail food establishment located on a public right-of-way directly adjacent to the retail food establishment. The granting of an outdoor
sidewalk cafe permit shall be subject to the terms and conditions set forth in subsection (B) of this section.
2. The permit area shall be that portion of the public right-of-way as delineated and approved on the permit application and restricted to a portion of the
right-of-way which is located between the curb line on the lateral line of the street and the adjacent property line, excluding any area required for use
by pedestrians.
(B) Terms And Conditions: The granting of an outdoor sidewalk cafe permit shall be subject to the following terms and conditions:
1. Proof that the applicant holds a valid retail food establishment license issued to the establishment that will provide food for the outdoor sidewalk cafe.
2. There shall be no live entertainment, amplified music, or mechanically amplified sound of any nature whatsoever within the permit area.
3. The permit shall be effective only from May 1 to October 31 of each year. Applications for renewal of an outdoor sidewalk cafe permit shall be filed
on an annual basis.
4. Stoves, ovens, hot plates, beverage coolers and similar restaurant equipment shall not be placed within the permit area.
5. No privately owned trash cans or electrical outlets shall be placed within the permit area. The permittee shall be solely responsible for maintaining
the permit area in a clean and sanitary condition. The permittee shall immediately remove trash or debris resulting from the operation of the outdoor
sidewalk cafe and shall collect and properly dispose of such debris as may be scattered from the permit area by patrons or weather conditions.
6. The permit area and adjoining sidewalks shall remain clear of litter, food scraps and soiled dishes at all times. Sidewalks and flooring areas must be
cleaned daily, including adjacent sidewalk areas.
7. The outdoor sidewalk cafe shall not open before eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. All patrons of the outdoor sidewalk cafe shall vacate the permit area no
later than ten o'clock (10:00) P.M.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 206/357
8. No alcoholic beverages may be served unless the outdoor sidewalk cafe permit was issued under subsection (D) of this section. (Ord. 2644, 6-18-
2007)
9. No permit shall be granted unless the Finance Director certifies that there are no outstanding fines, fees, taxes or other charges due and owing to
the City by the applicant or by the owners of the real property on which the proposed area is located. (Ord. 2644, 6-18-2007; amd. Ord. 2887, 8-20-
2012)
(C) Prohibited Sales: Except as otherwise provided in subsection (D) of this section, the outdoor sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption upon public
sidewalks contiguous to a licensed premises is prohibited. (Ord. 2644, 6-18-2007)
(D) Outdoor Sidewalk Cafe Permit Allowing The Sale Or Permitting The Consumption Of Alcoholic Liquor: Each holder of a Class A, A-1, B, B-1, D, or D-1
license may apply for an outdoor sidewalk cafe permit, or renewal thereof, to sell alcoholic liquor outside on the public sidewalk immediately adjacent to
the permanent structure of the licensed premises for which the applicant's license has been issued, and each holder of a Class N license may apply for
an outdoor sidewalk cafe permit, or renewal thereof, to permit consumption of beer or wine only brought onto the premises by a patron for personal
consumption while being served a meal in the establishment. In addition to the terms and conditions contained in subsection (B) of this section, the
granting of an outdoor sidewalk cafe permit to the holder of a liquor license is also subject to the following terms and conditions: (Ord. 2713, 10-20-
2008)
1. The applicant must have a valid liquor license issued under this Code and must provide food service in the licensed area.
2. All ingress and egress to the outdoor sales area from the sidewalk must be approved by the Local Liquor Control Commissioner at the time the
outdoor sidewalk cafe permit is granted.
3. The area in which such sales are conducted must be enclosed and contiguous to the building where the sale of alcoholic liquor is otherwise
permitted. The sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages in the permit area shall be restricted by the liquor license governing the applicant.
4. The outdoor sales area shall be enclosed by a rope, fence or other similar barrier at least thirty six inches (36") in height and have an access
opening within the barrier of not less than forty four inches (44") in width. The location, composition, design and construction of the fence shall be
approved by the Local Liquor Control Commissioner and the Building Official.
5. No sales or dispensing of alcoholic liquor may be made from the permit area to any person upon adjoining property, public street, sidewalk or alley.
6. No alcoholic liquor served in an open container may be removed from the permit area or the licensed premises. (Ord. 2644, 6-18-2007)
7. Beer, wine, or other alcoholic beverages may be served or consumed at an outdoor sidewalk cafe provided that the alcoholic beverage is purchased
from the outdoor sidewalk cafe, the purchaser is seated at a table, and the alcoholic beverage is served and consumed with food ordered from a
menu, prepared and served for pay by the outdoor sidewalk cafe permittee. Provided, however, the origin, consumption, and types of alcoholic
beverages and containers permitted at an outdoor sidewalk cafe for holders of Class N licenses are governed by subsection 5-13-5(S) of this
chapter. (Ord. 2732, 4-6-2009)
8. No patron may have more than one (1) alcoholic drink at any one (1) time.
9. All alcoholic beverages must be served in plastic or glass containers or aluminum cans. No bottles, taps, kegs, coolers or other alcoholic beverage
storage devices shall be allowed in the permit area.
10. Adequate security must be provided by the licensee.
11. No alcoholic liquor shall be sold, delivered, transferred, distributed or given away in the outdoor sales area after nine thirty o'clock (9:30) P.M. All
patrons shall vacate the permit area no later than ten o'clock (10:00) P.M.
12. Stricter hours of operation and such other conditions as the local liquor control commissioner deems necessary to protect the use and enjoyment of
adjacent properties may be required by the local liquor control commissioner as a condition of granting an outdoor sidewalk cafe permit which allows
the sale of alcoholic liquor as permitted under this subsection (D).
(E) Permit Application:
1. Application for an outdoor sidewalk cafe permit or renewal thereof shall be submitted to the mayor and shall include the following:
(a) A detailed drawing or sketch including the dimensions of the proposed outdoor area where the outdoor sales will occur with measurements
including a representation showing that at least five feet (5') of unobstructed sidewalk space will remain for pedestrians.
(b) The location and number of tables and chairs to be used. The application shall state the type of furniture that will be used.
(c) The type of fencing materials and dimensions.
(d) A nonrefundable filing fee in an amount as may be established from time to time by the mayor.
(e) A certificate of insurance evidencing commercial general liability insurance with limits of not less than five hundred thousand dollars
($500,000.00) per occurrence, and one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) in the aggregate combined single limit, for bodily injury, personal injury and
property damage liability. The city of Dixon shall be named as an additional insured on a primary, noncontributory basis for any liability arising
directly or indirectly from the operations of an outdoor sidewalk cafe and shall provide that the policy shall not terminate or be canceled prior to the
expiration date without thirty (30) days' advance written notice to the city. Proof of such insurance, issued by an insurance company licensed to do
business in the state of Illinois, shall be delivered prior to the issuance of an outdoor sidewalk cafe permit.
(f) Outdoor sidewalk cafes that are authorized to sell alcoholic beverages must also provide proof of dramshop insurance coverage on the permit
area.
(g) The application shall demonstrate that the outdoor sidewalk cafe will not unreasonably interfere with pedestrian flow, access to the building
entrances, pedestrian and traffic safety, and the aesthetic quality of the surrounding area.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 207/357
(h) Applicants having an A or A-1 liquor license shall provide proof that the applicant has a full service, fully equipped kitchen intended, designed and
used in the preparation of meals, other than only a counter with a hot plate, microwave oven or similar warming device.
2. All applications shall be reviewed by the city building department to determine compliance with the requirements of this chapter and with the city
building code. No outdoor sidewalk cafe permit shall be issued or renewed until the city building official has certified that the outdoor sales area is in
compliance with said requirements.
3. The following standards shall be applicable within the permit area:
(a) All barrier material must be maintained in good visual appearance.
(b) All furniture other than tables, chairs and umbrellas is prohibited. Furniture and fixtures must not be secured to street signs, hydrants or any other
street infrastructure. Tables and chairs are not permitted to be white plastic. All chairs used within a particular permit area must match each other
by being of visually similar design, construction and color. Umbrellas must be contained within the permit area; all advertisements on umbrellas
must be approved by the city building official.
(c) Sectional fencing must be of metal or wood construction. Such fencing must be portable and freestanding without any permanent or temporary
attachment to the sidewalks. Fabric inserts of any size are not permitted. The use of chainlink, cyclone fencing, chicken wire or similar
appurtenances is prohibited.
4. The mayor shall be the approving authority of all permit requests. Any permit for an outdoor sidewalk cafe may contain such conditions as the mayor,
or his designee, deems warranted to protect the use for adjacent right of way for its intended purpose and to otherwise carry out the purpose and
intent of this section and this code.
5. The mayor shall have the authority to promulgate regulations to carry out the purpose of this section, including, without limitation, regulations
governing location, arrangement, design, types of food and beverages, landscaping and other aesthetic components, the safety of pedestrians and
auto traffic, the prevention of an excessive number of outdoor sidewalk cafes, and any other matter pertaining to this section. All permittees shall
comply with the regulations promulgated pursuant to this section which shall have the full force and effect of a city ordinance.
6. An outdoor sidewalk cafe permit shall be for the exclusive use of the licensed retail food establishment stated on the application. Sharing or joint use
of the outdoor sidewalk cafe location by more than one retail food establishment shall not be permitted.
(F) Display: The outdoor sidewalk cafe permit shall be displayed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
(G) Termination: To the extent that a permit area is needed by the city for sidewalk purposes, or any other public purpose, the mayor may immediately
terminate the permit and assume full possession and control of the permit area. In such an event, the city shall be authorized to remove all furniture
and other objects of the permittee from the permit area.
(H) Violation:
1. Any outdoor sidewalk cafe permit issued pursuant to this section may be suspended or revoked for any violation of this chapter or any of the
provisions of this code.
2. Any suspension for violation shall be conducted pursuant to this chapter.
3. Any violation of this section shall also constitute grounds for the suspension or revocation of the liquor license of the applicant. (Ord. 2644, 6-18-
2007)
5-13-24: DIXON WELCOME CENTER:
(A) The city council does hereby authorize and permit the sale of wine only for consumption off the premises by the tourism development board from the
property having a common address of 106 W. River Street, Dixon, Illinois, and known as the Dixon Welcome Center.
(B) The sale of said wine is permitted during the following periods of time on the following days:
1. Mondays through Saturdays from ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. to ten o'clock (10:00) P.M.; and
2. Sundays from twelve o'clock (12:00) noon to five o'clock (5:00) P.M.
(C) The welcome center may be open to the public during other times but shall not be permitted to sell wine other than the times set forth in subsection (B)
of this section.
(D) The sale of wine to any person under the age of twenty one (21) years is expressly prohibited.
(E) Only persons twenty one (21) years of age or older may sell said wine from the premises.
(F) The city clerk is hereby authorized and directed to issue a liquor license designated as a "city license" to the tourism development board for the
premises located at 106 W. River Street, Dixon, Illinois, and is further authorized and directed to apply for a state liquor license with the Illinois liquor
commission for said premises. (Ord. 2749, 7-20-2009)
5-13-25: SALES BY LICENSEES AT LOCATIONS OTHER THAN LICENSED PREMISES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 208/357
(A) Temporary License: Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, either: 1) a holder of a class A, A-1, B, B-1, C, C-1, D or D-1 license, or 2) the
holder of a license equivalent or substantially equivalent to the foregoing issued by Lee County and whose licensed premises are connected to city
water or sewer service, may be issued a temporary license for sales of alcoholic beverages at off premises locations in conjunction with a religious,
charitable, civic, educational or literary event to be held within the corporate limits of the city. Applications for such temporary license shall be made
with the mayor at least fourteen (14) days prior to the date of the intended sale or distribution of alcoholic beverages and shall be made in accordance
with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 2974, 8-17-2015)
(B) Provisions: A temporary license issued under this section may be issued for a period not to exceed one day and shall be subject to the provisions of
sections 5-13-8, 5-13-9, and 5-13-10 of this chapter regarding the locations and time of sale, unless the Liquor Commissioner further restricts the
location and/or time of sale. Sunday sales may be permitted under such license.
(C) Application: In addition to any other requirements contained in an application for a liquor license, the applicant shall include the following information:
1. A description of the location and premises for which the license is sought;
2. A copy of an agreement or other written authority for the licensee's use of the location if the applicant is not the owner of the location;
3. A statement setting forth the purpose for the issuance of said license, to include a description of the intended function or event;
4. A statement setting forth the applicant's arrangements for security and crowd control;
5. A certificate of insurance showing evidence of dramshop and liability insurance coverage for the premises for which the temporary license is
requested;
6. A request for a specific time and date for the term of said license. (Ord. 2809, 1-3-2011)
(D) Fees: The fee for such a temporary license shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) for each calendar day or part thereof for which the license is issued and shall
be paid in full at the time that the license is issued. Notwithstanding the foregoing, for events where less than fifty dollars ($50.00) in retail cost of
alcoholic beverages are to be sold, the fee shall be five dollars ($5.00) for each calendar day or part thereof for which the license is issued. (Ord. 2986,
12-21-2015)
(E) Underage Persons: Persons under the age of twenty one (21) are permitted to be present on the premises during the time for which the temporary
license has been granted for the purpose of purchasing food or nonalcoholic beverages only and only if accompanied by a parent or guardian.
(F) Display: The license issued under this section shall be prominently displayed. (Ord. 2809, 1-3-2011)
5-13-26: DIXON THEATRE EVENT VENUE:
(A) Temporary License: The holder of a Class A, A-1, B, B-1, C, C-1, D or D-1 license may be issued a temporary license for the sales of alcoholic
beverages at the Dixon Theatre. Application for such temporary license shall be made with the Mayor at least fourteen (14) days prior to the date or
dates of the intended sale or distribution of alcoholic beverages and shall be made in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 2811, 1-18-
2011)
(B) Provisions: A temporary license for any such licensee for the sale or distribution of alcoholic beverages at the Dixon Theatre may be issued for a
period not to exceed four (4) days and shall be subject to the provisions of sections 5-13-9 and 5-13-10 of this chapter regarding such sales or
distributions unless the Liquor Commissioner further restricts the time of sale. Such temporary license may be issued to any such licensee for the
Dixon Theatre notwithstanding the provisions of subsection 5-13-8(A) of this chapter restricting the sale and retail of any alcoholic liquor within one
hundred feet (100') of certain specified institutions. Sunday sales may be permitted under a license issued pursuant to the terms of this chapter. No
such temporary license may be issued under this section except in conjunction with functions or events to be held at the Dixon Theatre. (Ord. 3058, 9-
18-2017)
(C) Application: In addition to any other requirements contained in an application for a liquor license, the applicant shall include the following information:
1. A copy of an agreement, lease, or other written authority from the Dixon Theatre for the licensee's use of the Dixon Theatre; (Ord. 2811, 1-18-2011)
2. A statement describing the purpose for the issuance of said license, to include a description of the intended functions or events; (Ord. 3058, 9-18-
2017)
3. A statement setting forth the applicant's arrangements for security and crowd control;
4. A certificate of insurance showing dramshop and liability insurance for the Dixon Theatre incident to the issuance of the temporary license; (Ord.
2811, 1-18-2011)
5. The specific times and dates for the term of said license. (Ord. 3058, 9-18-2017)
(D) Display: The license under this section shall be prominently displayed on site at the Dixon Theatre during the term of the license. (Ord. 2811, 1-18-
2011)
Chapter 14
AMUSEMENTS
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 209/357
5-14-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall conduct or manage any circus, carnival, show, sideshow, amusement, skating rink, menagerie, entertainment, moving picture or other
exhibition, or give any concert or musical entertainment, or conduct or manage any hall, opera house, theater or public dance, for amusement purposes
within the city without first obtaining a license therefor, as herein provided; provided, that this section shall not be construed to apply to any exhibition,
amusement or entertainment, concert or musical or other show, given by any lodge, society, church, fraternal or similar organization not engaged in the
business of giving such exhibitions, amusements, entertainment, concert or show, the total proceeds of which after payment of expenses of giving the
same, are to be devoted to benevolent, religious or charitable purposes. (1950 Code)
5-14-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; APPROVAL; ISSUANCE:
Upon the filing with him of a written application therefor, specifying the time for which such license is to be issued, the character and location of the place
where such intended exhibition, circus, show, carnival, public dance or other entertainment shall be held, or the location of such hall, opera house or
theater, and the payment to him of the fee herein provided, and the written approval of the mayor, or, in his absence, the commissioner of public health and
safety, the clerk shall issue a license for any of the purposes herein set forth. (1950 Code)
5-14-3: SHOWS AND ENTERTAINMENTS; LICENSE FEES:
The fees for licenses for the purpose herein set forth, excepting exhibitions, shows, moving pictures and other entertainments given in licensed halls and
theaters as hereinafter provided, shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day each. (1950 Code)
5-14-4: HALLS AND THEATERS; LICENSE FEES:
The owner or manager of any hall, opera house or theater and persons giving exhibitions, shows or entertainments in such hall, opera house or theater
during the term of such license, shall be exempt from the payment of the license fee provided in section 5-14-3 of this chapter.
The license for halls, opera houses or theaters shall be issued only upon payment to the clerk of the following fees:
(A) For halls, opera houses or theaters having a capacity of over eight hundred (800) persons, for one year, two hundred dollars ($200.00). For any period
less than one year and more than six (6) days, the proportionate part of the annual fee that the period bears to the year.
For each day from one day to six (6) days, where such days are consecutive except Sunday, ten dollars ($10.00).
(B) For halls, opera houses, or theaters having a similar seating capacity of from three hundred (300) to eight hundred (800) persons, the license fee shall
be two-fifths (2/5) of the fees required in subsection (A) of this section.
(C) For halls, opera houses or theaters having a capacity of three hundred (300) or less persons, the license fees shall be one-eighth (1/8) of the fees
required in subsection (A) of this section.
A hall, opera house or theater within the meaning of this chapter shall be held to be a place used, intended to be used and suitable to be used for the
giving of exhibitions, shows, moving pictures or other entertainments and not a tent or other temporary structure or a hall or room fitted up and intended
to be used temporarily for the purpose of giving shows, entertainments or exhibitions; provided however, that the fee for licenses for the purpose of
conducting a public dance in every case shall be three dollars ($3.00). (1950 Code)
5-14-5: SKATING RINKS; LICENSE FEES:
Any person operating a skating rink where ice or roller skates are used, shall first obtain a license. The fee for such license shall be fifty dollars ($50.00)
per year.
It shall be the duty of every operator of a skating rink to keep and preserve good order in and about the rink. (1950 Code)
5-14-6: INSPECTION:
Any such exhibitions, entertainments, public dances, moving picture shows, or other shows, or any hall, opera house or theater, licensed under the
provisions of this chapter, or any place where any exhibitions, shows, or public dances, moving picture or entertainment is held, shall at any and all times
be open and subject to the inspection of the mayor, attorney, health officer, chief of police, chief of the fire department, and commissioner of public health
and safety, who shall be admitted without admission fee, and any of such persons shall be authorized to stop such exhibition, show, dance or amusement
if the same is being conducted in violation of the provisions of this code or is indecent. (1950 Code)
5-14-7: REGULATIONS:
Every person so licensed shall keep good order in and about his place of exhibition, public dance or entertainment and shall permit no indecent shows or
pictures to be given or exhibited therein, or any indecent dances conducted, and no tickets shall be sold for any such entertainment, show, amusement or
public dance and no person shall be admitted to such hall, opera house, theater or other place of amusement except on official business when all of the
seats therein are occupied, nor shall persons be permitted to sit or stand in any aisle, doorway or exit of the hall, opera house, theater or place of
amusement during any performance or while any dance is being conducted therein. (1950 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 210/357
5-14-8: REVOCATION OF LICENSES:
All persons licensed under this chapter shall receive their licenses expressly subject to revocation and subject to such conditions as the council may from
time to time impose in the interests of public health, safety and morals1. (1950 Code)
Chapter 15
MECHANICAL AMUSEMENT DEVICES
5-15-1: DEFINITIONS:
AMUSEMENT CENTER: Any one place containing more than three (3) mechanical amusement devices set up or placed together in one location by an
"operator" as defined in and licensed by this chapter and used as an amusement center. Expressly excluded from this definition is any premises for which
a liquor license has been issued pursuant to chapter 13 of this title.
DISTRIBUTOR: Any person, firm or corporation who owns mechanical amusement devices.
MECHANICAL AMUSEMENT DEVICE: Any machine which upon insertion of a coin or slug operates or may be operated as a game or contest of skill or
amusement of any description and which contains no automatic payoff device for the payment of money, merchandise or other items of value except the
awarding of free plays according to an indicator upon the machine, and which in itself does not constitute a gambling device. The term shall also include
any machine or apparatus which is operated by projecting a ball up a sloping board with a plunger operated from outside a cabinet containing the board,
and the ball then being made to roll downward and rebound among electrical fixtures that light or ring upon being touched by the ball and thereby
recording a number of points and commonly known as a "pinball machine".
OPERATOR: As used in this chapter, is any person, firm or corporation who sets up for use a mechanical amusement device in his or its place of business
where such device belongs to a licensed distributor.
OPERATOR OF AN AMUSEMENT CENTER: Any person, firm or corporation who sets up for use more than three (3) mechanical amusement devices in
his or its place of business where such device belongs to a licensed distributor. (Ord. 1133, 4-30-1982; amd. Ord. 1613, 8-19-1991)
5-15-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall be an operator of an amusement center, or a distributor, without first having obtained the license for that purpose. No operator shall set up
a mechanical amusement device for operation unless: a) a license is first issued to a distributor, and b) a decal has been issued for the number of
mechanical amusement devices authorized to be placed upon the operator's property pursuant to section 5-15-4 of this chapter. The license issued
hereunder shall be nontransferable and nonassignable and shall be prominently displayed upon the premises where the machines are operated. (Ord.
1192, 8-1-1983)
5-15-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application for a license, as an operator of an amusement center, or a distributor, shall be made in writing to the council, and said application shall set forth
the full name of the applicant, the address, the location and character of the building or place where such mechanical amusement devices are to be
located, and the number of such devices. Any application for a license under this chapter shall include the names and addresses of all partners, if the
proposed licensee is a partnership, and shall include the names and addresses of all officers and directors if such proposed licensee is a corporation.
Upon receipt of the application accompanied by the proper license fee as herein provided, the chief of police shall investigate the character of the
applicant, the premises in which it is proposed to carry on the business of the applicant, and the type of machine to be used. The chief of police shall then
transmit the results of his investigation to the council, together with his recommendation as to the granting or denial of such license. (Ord. 1133, 4-30-
1982)
5-15-4: LICENSE OR DECAL:
The city clerk shall issue a decal stating the number of mechanical amusement devices licensed hereunder and authorized to be distributed within the
municipal limits by a distributor annually to the distributor. The city clerk shall issue a decal stating the number of mechanical amusement devices licensed
hereunder and authorized to be present upon an operator's property annually to the operator and/or operator of an amusement center. Prior to the
issuance of said decal, all license and annual fees shall be paid and evidence of ownership shall be filed with the clerk, and the location of the operation of
the machine. The decal of the distributor shall be retained by the distributor at his place of business. The decal of the operator and/or operator of an
amusement center indicating the number of machines permitted on the property shall be prominently displayed in the operator and/or operator of an
amusement center's place of business. (Ord. 1192, 8-1-1983)
5-15-5: UNOBSTRUCTED VIEW:
All such devices shall at all times be kept and placed in plain view of all persons who may frequent or be in any place of business or other place where
such devices are kept or used. (Ord. 1133, 4-30-1982)
5-15-6: GAMBLING:
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to authorize, permit or license any gambling service of any nature whatsoever which is prohibited by the
provisions of this code or of the laws of the state and no device shall be used in any manner whatsoever for gambling. (Ord. 1133, 4-30-1982)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 211/357
5-15-7: DISTRIBUTOR'S LICENSE AND FEES:
(A) Any person having a distributor's license shall be responsible for reporting to the city clerk the list of the devices that are licensed and the places that
the devices are located in operation. Said list shall be filed semiannually with the city clerk.
(B) The annual fee for a license as a distributor is the sum of two hundred dollars ($200.00) per annum beginning May 1 of each calendar year and
payable annually in advance.
(C) In addition to subsection (B) of this section, a distributor shall pay a fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) per machine per annum payable in advance for each
device operated or set up for operation.
(D) No distributor shall set up for operation, lease or distribute more than two hundred (200) machines at any one time upon any license granted herein.
(E) In the event that a distributor shall increase the total number of amusement devices distributed within the city limits after May 1 of each year, then said
distributor shall be responsible for reporting to the city clerk a list of the increased number of devices that are located within the city and placed in
operation for which an additional thirty dollars ($30.00) prorated in accordance with the remainder of the year shall be paid to the clerk. (Ord. 1192, 8-1-
1983)
5-15-8: OPERATOR OF AMUSEMENT CENTER LICENSE AND FEE:
(A) No person shall set up, operate or control an amusement center without first having obtained an amusement center license from the council. Said
application shall comply with section 5-15-3 of this chapter. No person shall establish or operate an amusement center without a separate person, firm
or corporation having first obtained a distributor's license for the mechanical amusement devices to be used in the amusement center as provided by
this chapter. (Ord. 1192, 8-1-1983)
(B) The annual license fee for an operator of an amusement center shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) per annum payable in advance beginning May
1 of each calendar year. In addition, each operator of an amusement center shall pay a fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) per annum payable in advance of
each device operated or set up for operation on the premises of the operator of an amusement center. Public governmental bodies are exempt from the
payment of the fees as outlined in this subsection. (Ord. 1219, 4-23-1984)
(C) Each mechanical amusement device and amusement center shall comply with the provisions of section 5-15-4 of this chapter. (Ord. 1192, 8-1-1983)
(D) In the event that an operator shall increase the total number of amusement devices operated in his place of business after May 1 of each year, then
said operator shall be responsible for reporting to the city clerk a list of the increased number of devices placed in operation in his business for which
an additional thirty dollars ($30.00) prorated in accordance with the remainder of the year shall be paid to the clerk. Public governmental bodies are
exempt from the payment of the fees as outlined in this subsection. (Ord. 1219, 4-23-1984)
5-15-9: OPERATOR'S LICENSE AND FEE:
(A) No person shall set up for use or control of a mechanical amusement device in his or its place of business without first complying with the provisions of
sections 5-15-2 and 5-15-4 of this chapter. (Ord. 1192, 8-1-1983)
(B) Each operator shall pay a fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) per machine per annum payable in advance on May 1 of each year for each device operated or
set up for operation in his or its place of business. Public governmental bodies are exempt from the payment of the fees as outlined in this subsection.
(C) In the event that an operator shall increase the total number of amusement devices operated in his place of business after May 1 of each year, then
said operator shall be responsible for reporting to the city clerk a list of the increased number of devices placed in operation in his business for which
an additional thirty dollars ($30.00) prorated in accordance with the remainder of the year shall be paid to the clerk. Public governmental bodies are
exempt from the payment of the fees as outlined in this subsection. (Ord. 1219, 4-23-1984)
5-15-10: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
Every license issued under this chapter is subject to the right, which is hereby expressly reserved, to revoke the same. Should the licensee permit the
operation of any mechanical amusement device contrary to the provisions of this chapter, the ordinances of the city of Dixon, or the laws of the state of
Illinois, said license may be revoked by the city council. (Ord. 1133, 4-30-1982)
5-15-11: PENALTY:
Any licensee, operator, operator of an amusement center or distributor, or employee or agent of the same who violates any of the provisions of this chapter
shall be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) or more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each violation and each day the violation occurs
shall be considered a separate violation. (Ord. 1133, 4-30-1982)
