known as the Dixon Public School District). All other persons appointed or employed as a fireman shall, within six (6) months after such appointment or
employment, establish his or her domicile within five (5) miles of the City limits of Dixon, Illinois. Any person failing to adhere to this subsection shall be
discharged. (Ord. 3067, 11-6-2017)
8-1-4: PERIOD OF INSTRUCTION:
Each person employed as a member of the Fire Department shall, during the first six (6) months of his employment take a course of instruction to be
prescribed by the Commissioner of Public Health and Safety with the approval of the Council. If the person does not satisfactorily complete such course
within the period of six (6) months he shall be discharged immediately and shall not be reappointed as a member of the Fire Department during the period
of one year next following such discharge. (1950 Code)
8-1-5: FIRE CHIEF; POWERS:
The Chief of the Fire Department shall, subject to the jurisdiction and control of the City manager, have the management and control of the fire
department. All regulations and orders thereof shall be promulgated through the chief of the fire department. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
8-1-6: DUTY TO DEVOTE ENTIRE TIME TO OFFICE:
The chief of the fire department shall devote his entire time to the discharge of the duties of his office, except that time designated and approved by the
commissioner of public health and safety with the consent of the council, for other employment or duties. (Ord. 606, 1-28-1969)
8-1-7: CHIEF CUSTODIAN OF PROPERTY:
The chief of the fire department shall have the custody of the engines, buildings and rooms, trucks, ladders, fire alarm system and all other property and
equipment belonging to the fire department. (1950 Code)
8-1-8: CAUSES OF FIRES; DAMAGES; RECORDS:
The chief of the fire department shall make, or cause to be made, an inquiry into the cause of all fires which may occur in the city and the damage, if any,
sustained; and shall cause a record to be kept thereof. (Ord. 606, 1-28-1969)
8-1-9: CHIEF'S YEARLY REPORT:
A report shall be submitted by the chief of the fire department to the council thirty (30) days prior to the ending of the city's fiscal year. This report shall
contain the condition of the fire apparatus and the buildings in which the same are kept and what future alterations, additions, improvements or repairs that
are necessary for the effective operation of the fire department. (Ord. 606, 1-28-1969)
8-1-10: POWERS OF CHIEF AT FIRE:
The chief of the fire department may prescribe certain limits in the vicinity of any fire within which no persons excepting firemen and policemen and those
admitted by order of any officer of the fire department shall be permitted to come. (1950 Code)
8-1-11: MAY REMOVE PROPERTY:
The chief of the fire department shall have the power to cause the removal of any property whenever it shall become necessary for the preservation of
such property from fire or to prevent the spreading of fire or protect the adjoining property. (1950 Code)
8-1-12: ABSENCE OF CHIEF:
In the case of the absence or temporary disability of the chief of the fire department, the deputy chief shall take charge of the organization and he/she shall
have and exercise all of the powers of the chief of the fire department. If both the chief of the fire department and the deputy are absent or temporarily
disabled, the senior captain shall take charge of the organization and he/she shall have and exercise all of the powers of the chief of the fire department.
(Ord. 2923, 8-19-2013)
8-1-13: DISCONNECTION OF ELECTRIC AND WATER SUPPLY:
The chief of the fire department shall have the power and authority, whenever the safety of the public or of property in the city is endangered by fire, or
other casualty, to cause to be disconnected temporarily, or for such period of time as is in his judgment necessary for public safety, any and all electric
wires and all water pipes and connecting private property with the public water supply system in the city. (1950 Code)
8-1-14: DUTIES OF SUBORDINATES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 267/357
The duties of all members of the fire department below the rank of chief shall be such as are now or may hereafter be prescribed by the rules and
regulations of the department or such as may be assigned to them by the chief. (1950 Code)
8-1-15: INTERFERENCE:
No person shall interfere, or attempt to interfere, with the chief of the fire department or any of his assistants in the discharge of their duties or shall,
without the permission of the chief of the fire department, connect or attempt to connect any electric wire or water pipe or connection after it has been
disconnected by the chief of the fire department or under his order. (1950 Code)
8-1-16: REPORT OF IMPROPER CONDUCT:
It shall be the duty of the chief of the fire department to promptly report to the commissioner of public health and safety and to the board of fire and police
commissioners any member of the fire department who may be guilty of any charges listed under article VI, section 4 of the rules and regulations of the
board of fire and police commissioners of the city of Dixon. (Ord. 606, 1-28-1969)
8-1-17: ASSIGNMENT OF HOURS OF DUTY:
The chief of the fire department, under the direction of the commissioner of public health and safety, shall arrange and assign the hours of duty of the
firemen. (1950 Code)
No fireman shall be required to work a total of more than fifty six (56) hours in any one week. The hours, or schedule of hours, shall be worked out by the
chief of the fire department under the direction of the commissioner of public health and safety in accordance with necessity and the efficient operation of
the fire department. (Ord. 213, 11-19-1957)
The members of the fire department are hereby granted pay increases based upon their periods of service and upon their base pay in the amount of one
percent (1%) per year, with maximum of twenty (20) years. (Ord. 146, 5-22-1956)
8-1-18: JANITOR SERVICE:
(Rep. by Ord. 2923, 8-19-2013)
8-1-19: BREACHES OF DUTY:
(Rep. by Ord. 2923, 8-19-2013)
8-1-20: (Rep. by Ord. 606, 1-28-1969)
8-1-21: VOLUNTEER FIRE DEPARTMENT:
There is hereby established in the city a volunteer fire department to be composed of not more than twenty four (24) trained volunteer firefighters to be
trained under the rules and regulations adopted by the commissioner of public health and safety and the chief of the fire department in accordance with
rules and regulations set up by the commissioner and fire chief. (Ord. 606, 1-28-1969; amd. Ord. 791, 9-16-1974)
The volunteer firefighters should be paid the sum of five dollars ($5.00) per hour or fraction thereof for appearing at any training period designated by the
rules and regulations and should be paid the sum of five dollars ($5.00) for the first hour of service, when called upon by the chief of the fire department, or
his assistants, to assist in fighting fires, and should be paid the sum of four dollars ($4.00) per hour for each additional hour. (Ord. 1046, 9-2-1980)
The training and designation of rank of the volunteer fire department shall be entirely under the supervision of the commissioner of public health and safety
and all necessary authority in the administration of the department is hereby granted the commissioner of public health and safety. (Ord. 606, 1-28-1969)
8-1-22: CONFORMANCE OF UNION CONTRACTS; FIRE PERSONNEL:
In conformity with contracts heretofore entered into between the city and the police and fire departments of this city, all employees of the police department
and fire departments of said city with the exception of the chief, captain and in some instances, the sergeants, of the police department and the chief and
assistant chief of the fire department, and in some instances the fire captains in grievance procedures, shall be governed by said respective contracts
above referred to in their employment with the city; and all ordinances, or sections of ordinances, in conflict therewith, are hereby superseded and
repealed; and any ordinance which directly conflicts with the above mentioned union contracts are hereby repealed unless they conform in their meaning
and intent with said union contracts.
All listed salaries for nonunion personnel now on record shall be amended so as to reflect salary changes in said schedule which were put into effect on
December 1, 1970, and made retroactive to May 1, 1970. (Ord. 654, 2-9-1971; amd. Ord. 700, 8-7-1972)
Each regular full time employee of the city who is not covered by a union contract agreement shall receive a cost of living allowance calculated as follows:
By taking the average of the consumer price index, U.S. city averages for urban wage earners and clerical workers, published by the bureau of labor
statistics for the months of October, November and December, 1970, and averaging these indices; and that thereafter each full calendar quarter the index
will be averaged and the amount that is above the average for the last quarter of the year 1970 will represent the increase in the cost of living for which the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 268/357
allowance will be paid; and each 0.5 increase in the average above the base period of the last quarter of 1970 will be paid for at one cent ($0.01) per hour,
with the one cent ($0.01) per hour application to be multiplied at one hundred seventy three (173) hours per month regardless of the number of hours
worked for any particular employee.
At the end of the calendar year a review will be made of the amount of the cost of living being paid and all or some part of it may be included in the
employee's base wage; that part which is not included will be retained in the cost of living allowance.
It is not contemplated that any further revision of base salaries for the classification covered herein in the cost of living allowance and wage adjustment
granted employees as of May 1, 1970, shall be considered until May 1, 1973, at which time said salary structure will be reexamined to determine its
appropriateness and effectiveness. (Ord. 654, 2-9-1971)
Chapter 2
FIRE REGULATIONS
8-2-1: ESCAPES REQUIRED ON CERTAIN BUILDINGS:
All buildings within the city which are three (3) or more stories in height shall be provided with one or more metallic ladders or metallic fire escapes
attached to the outer walls thereof and extending from or suitably near the ground to the uppermost story thereof and provided with platforms of such
forms and dimensions and in such proximity to one or more windows of each story above the first as to render safe access to such ladders or stairs from
each story. (1950 Code)
8-2-2: PUBLIC BUILDINGS; DOORS TO SWING OUTWARD:
All buildings within the city which are used for churches, schoolhouses, colleges, operas, theaters, lecture rooms, hotels or public meetings, in whole or in
part, or in any part or room thereof for the purpose of the meeting or assembling of fraternal or other associations or for dances or which are used for any
purpose whereby a collection of persons may be assembled together for religious worship, amusement, instruction, education or other purpose shall be so
built and constructed that all doors leading from the main hall or place where the collection of persons may be assembled or from the principal room or
rooms which may be used for any of the purposes aforesaid, shall be so hung and constructed that the doors shall open outward; that all means of egress
from the main hall or principal room and from the building shall be through doors which shall open outwards from the main hall or building. (1950 Code)
8-2-3: AISLES TO BE KEPT OPEN:
All buildings within the city which are used in whole or in part as churches, theaters, schools, colleges, lecture rooms or for public meetings and having
fixed and permanent seats shall be occupied only to the extent of the number of such fixed and permanent seats; it is unlawful to permit the admission into
the room or hall used in such buildings of more persons than will occupy the full number of such seats; and it is unlawful to obstruct the aisles,
passageways or other means of exit from such room or hall by chairs, benches, seats or in any other manner. (1950 Code)
8-2-4: EXITS REQUIRED IN PUBLIC BUILDINGS:
All public halls or theaters having a seating capacity of five hundred (500) persons or more, and all such public halls or theaters which shall be hereafter
constructed within the city, shall be so constructed as to have three (3) or more exits from the main or principal floor thereof, each of which shall be six feet
(6') or more in width and shall extend from the main floor to the surface of the ground or street. (1950 Code)
8-2-5: EXITS TO BE MARKED:
The location of each exit and of each fire escape as hereinbefore required to be placed shall be indicated by one or more plain and legible signs in close
proximity thereto, having letters thereon at least six inches (6") in height. (1950 Code)
8-2-6: STORAGE OF INFLAMMABLE LIQUIDS:
(A) Except as provided in this section, it shall be unlawful for any person to construct or maintain any tank or tanks for the storage of fuel oil, gasoline,
distillate, kerosene, naphtha, benzine, benzol, alcohol or other flammable liquids where such tanks have a capacity of more than three hundred (300)
gallons unless such tanks shall be buried in earth, sand or cinders for at least a distance of two feet (2') from the top surface of the tank and the bottom
of the floor of the basement, building or other structure in which the same is so erected or maintained or below the surface of the yard or other
enclosure in which the same is so erected or maintained which earth, sand or cinders shall be firmly compacted above such tanks, said tanks being
supplied with proper vents;
(B) Aboveground storage tanks may be erected and maintained under the following terms and conditions:
1. Any tank used only as a storage tank for inflammable liquids in bulk to be supplied therefrom to tanks on vehicles to be carried on such vehicles for
the purposes of sale to others and not for the propulsion of such vehicles, provided their erection and maintenance shall comply with the
requirements of the state fire marshal pertaining to the erection and maintenance of tanks in bulk stations. (Ord. 1835, 8-1-1994)
2. Tanks for the storage of diesel fuel or gasoline only are permissible provided the following provisions are adhered to prior to installation:
(a) The diesel fuel and gasoline may only be used by the owner of the real estate on which the tank is enclosed.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 269/357
(b) No more than two (2) tanks of one thousand (1,000) gallons each of diesel fuel may be located on the premises. "Premises" shall be defined to
mean the parcel upon which the tanks are to be placed, including all contiguous real estate owned, directly or indirectly, by the applicant.
(c) The location of the aboveground tank must be approved by the building official, fire chief and state fire marshal.
(d) The tanks shall be enclosed by four inch (4") steel pipes, of one-fourth inch (1/4") thickness, located thirty inches (30") above grade, filled with
concrete, set twenty four inches (24") apart and buried not less than forty two inches (42") in the ground and painted with yellow reflective paint.
3. No construction of permitted aboveground tanks shall commence until a permit has been issued by the state and the city.
4. The building official and fire chief are jointly authorized to promulgate and make available a permit application requesting authorization to construct
aboveground storage tanks. Said permit applications shall contain such questions that the responses thereto will evidence compliance with this
section.
5. Aboveground tank storing pentane must have the approval of the building official, fire chief and state fire marshal of the size, location and
construction plans prior to installation. (Ord. 2311, 3-19-2001)
(C) Any person erecting and maintaining tanks for bulk storage shall give to the city a good and sufficient bond with surety to be approved by the mayor in
the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) conditioned to save and keep harmless the city from any and all loss, damage or liability of any sort to
persons or property by the erection or maintenance of any such tanks, only one bond being required to be given for each lot or enclosure containing
such tanks. (Ord. 1835, 8-1-1994)
8-2-7: STORAGE OF INFLAMMABLE LIQUIDS; EXEMPTION:
The foregoing section shall not apply to any storage tank which shall be used only for the storage of inflammable liquids the "flashpoint" of which or the
temperature necessary to make the same inflammable shall be one hundred fifty degrees Fahrenheit (150°F) or more. (1950 Code)
8-2-8: DRY CLEANING:
It shall be unlawful for any person to carry on a dry cleaning business in the city without complying with the following regulations which are established and
promulgated for the prevention of fire and loss of life and property:
(A) For the purpose of this section a "dry cleaning business" is defined to be the business of cleaning cloth, clothing, feathers or any sort of fabrics by the
use of gasoline, naphtha, benzine, benzol or similar light petroleum or coal tar products or cleaning by a process known as dry cleaning.
(B) No such business shall be carried on except in a building separate and apart from other buildings, the doors, window frames and sash of which shall
be covered with metal. The floors of such building shall be of cement construction. No such business shall be carried on in a wooden or frame building,
nor in a building used as a dwelling place.
(C) The walls of such building shall have vent holes at the floor line not less than twenty inches (20") in area and not more than six feet (6') apart from
center to center properly protected by iron bars, or other improved means of ventilation or a proper ventilating exhaust fan system.
(D) There shall be no connection to heat such building by any other than hot water or steam heat.
(E) The lighting must be done by electricity; the wires must be run in conduit; all lamps must be approved vaporproof lamps with keyless sockets and all
switches must be four and one-fourth feet (41/4') above the floor of the building and located near doors so as not to allow opportunity for vapor to
collect near them.
(F) It shall be unlawful to locate, have, use or maintain a steam generating boiler, dynamo or motor within the walls of any dry cleaning building except in a
room entirely separated from the rest of the building.
(G) No storage or dry cleaning building shall be placed, installed, constructed or maintained until an application for permission to do so, with plans and
specifications showing full details of location, construction and connection have been filed with and approved by the commissioner of public health and
safety.
(H) All of the volatile liquids named herein shall be stored in underground tanks of the specifications as required herein.
(I) All storage tanks shall be constructed of steel, coated on the outside with tar or other rust resisting material. Tanks up to one hundred seventy (170)
gallons shall be constructed of not less than 14-gauge galvanized steel, and tanks from one hundred seventy (170) gallons up to five hundred sixty
(560) gallons shall be constructed of not less than 12-gauge galvanized sheet metal; and tanks of five hundred sixty (560) gallons and upwards shall be
constructed of not less than 3/16"-gauge galvanized sheet steel or of one-fourth inch (1/4") open hearth tank steel. Not more than six (6) tanks of two
hundred eighty (280) gallons shall be allowed at the location of any one dry cleaning establishment except by special permit of the chief of the fire
department. All tanks shall be installed underground not less than two feet (2') below the surface entirely surrounded by earth or concrete. Should there
be more than one tank, they shall be separated by at least twelve inches (12") of earth all well tamped in place; the top of all tanks must be below the
level of the lowest pipeline in the building used in connection with the equipment. There must be no openings or pipe connections except on the top of
the tanks. They shall be properly vented and shall not be connected either directly or indirectly with any public or private sewer, drain, catch basin or pit
in the city.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 270/357
(J) All storage tanks shall be provided with a one inch (1") diameter or larger galvanized iron vent pipe to be constructed to the top of the tank, connections
of the tank to be fitted with a brass wire screen with at least thirty (30) mesh.
(K) This vent pipe must be carried up at least four feet (4') above the roof of the building and terminate in a double gooseneck spark protector, openings of
which must be covered with brass wire screen of at least thirty (30) mesh.
(L) No volatile substance in excess of two (2) quarts shall be used for cleaning purposes except in closed machines and must be conveyed from the tanks
to the machines in closed pipes by means of suction pumps controlled by valves and approved by the National Board Of Underwriters.
(M) It shall be unlawful to store or settle any of the volatile substances in open vessels or tanks.
(N) Each tank must be fitted with a galvanized iron fill pipe of a least two inch (2") diameter, arranged to include a venting pipe for tank or each tank may
be fitted with a fill pipe and a filling vent pipe of not less than one and one-fourth inch (11/4") size, in galvanized iron, and all such pipes must terminate
in screw caps securely locked.
(O) Where filler pipe runs to a sidewalk or to an alley or public highway it must terminate in a screw cap securely locked and be protected by a cast iron
filler box flush with the sidewalk, alley or highway, the cover of said filler box to be securely locked.
(P) Dry room shall have an eight inch (8") vent, opening into the atmosphere for each four hundred fifty feet (450') of cubic space or fraction thereof; said
vent pipe shall be carried up to a height of two feet (2') above the roof and terminate in an approved ventilator hood. When dry rooms are located
outside of the dry cleaning building, they shall have vent holes at the floor line not less than twenty (20) square inches in area and not more than six
feet (6') apart from center to center, properly protected by iron bars or other improved means of ventilation1. (1950 Code)
8-2-9: KEY LOCK BOX SYSTEM:
(A) The following structures shall be equipped with a key lock box at or near the main entrance or such other location as required by the Dixon fire chief:
1. Commercial or industrial structures protected by an automatic alarm system or automatic suppression system, or such structures that are secured in
a manner that restricts access during an emergency; and
2. Multi-family residential structures that have restricted access to locked doors and have a common corridor for access to the living units; and
governmental structures and nursing care facilities on the effective date hereof.
3. This subsection (A) shall not apply to owner occupied one- and two-family dwellings.
(B) All newly constructed structures subject to this section shall have a key lock box installed and operational prior to the issuance of an occupancy permit.
All structures in existence on the effective date hereof and subject to this section shall have one year from the effective date hereof to have a key lock
box installed and operational.
(C) The key box system shall be of a UL type and approved by the fire chief of the city. The key lock box shall contain keys to gain necessary access as
required by the fire chief and shall be installed in a manner approved by the fire chief.
(D) The owner or operator of a structure required to have a key lock box shall, at all times, keep a key in the lock box that will allow for access to the
structure.
(E) The fire chief shall be authorized to implement rules and regulations for the use of the lock box system.
(F) Any person who owns or operates a structure subject to this section shall be subject to the penalties set forth in section 1-4-1 of this code for any
violation of this section, provided that the minimum fine for a conviction for a violation of this section shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00). (Ord.
2178, 9-7-1999)
Chapter 3
FIRE PREVENTION CODE
8-3-1: ADOPTION OF INTERNATIONAL FIRE CODE:
(A) A certain document, three (3) copies of which are on file in the office of the fire chief of the city, being marked and designated as the international fire
code, 2015, including the appendices defined in subsection (B) of this section, as published by the International Code Council, Inc., be and hereby is
adopted as the fire prevention code of the city. Each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of the international fire code
are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this chapter verbatim except the additions, insertions, deletions and
changes prescribed in section 8-3-1-1 of this chapter.
(B) The following appendices of the international fire code, 2015, adopted in subsection (A) of this section, are also adopted:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 271/357
1. Appendix B: Fire-Flow Requirements For Buildings;
2. Appendix C: Fire Hydrant Locations And Distribution;
3. Appendix D: Fire Apparatus Access Roads;
4. Appendix F: Hazard Ranking; and

2016)
8-3-1-1: AMENDMENTS TO CODE:
(A) Chapter 1, section 101.1 Title, of the fire prevention code of the city of Dixon shall be amended to read as follows:
101.1 Title. The regulations shall be known as the Fire Prevention Code Of The City Of Dixon, hereinafter referred to as "this code."
(B) Chapter 1, section 109.3 Violation Penalties, of the fire prevention code of the city of Diaxon shall be amended to read as follows:
109.3 Violation Penalties. Persons who shall violate a provision of this code or shall fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof or who shall
erect, install, alter, repair or do work in violation of the approved construction documents or directive of the fire chief of the city, or of a permit or
certificate used under provisions of this code, shall be guilty of a class B misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not less than $100.00 nor more than
$750.00. Each day that a violation continues after due notice shall be deemed a separate offense.
(C) Section 307.1.1 shall be amended to read as follows:
307.1.1 Prohibited Open Burning. Open burning shall be prohibited.
Exceptions:
1. Where approved by the local jurisdiction.
2. Unincorporated areas with a burn ordinance.
(D) Section 307.1.2 is added to read as follows:
307.1.2 Materials. Fuel for all recreational fires and bonfires shall consist only of seasoned dry firewood and other material approved by the fire code
official. The fire shall be ignited with a small quantity of paper. The fire shall not be utilized for waste disposal purposes, and the fuel shall be chosen
to minimize the generation of air contaminants.
(E) Section 307.4.1 is added to read as follows:
307.4.1 Permit. All permits required by section 105.6.31 shall be requested by and issued to the owner of the land upon which the bonfire is to be
kindled.
(F) Section 505.3 is added to read as follows:
505.3 Strip Malls. When a strip mall has multiple tenant spaces and a dedicated sprinkler control/fire alarm room, each alarm room shall have its
own street address.
(G) Section 901.4.2.1 is added to read as follows:
901.4.2.1 Discontinuance Of Use. All non-required fire protection systems shall be approved for discontinuance by the fire code official. All
discontinued equipment and devices, such as pull stations, nozzles, detectors, sprinklers, sensors, panels and hose connections shall be removed
so as not to give a false indication that the structure, area or space is protected.
(H) Section 903.2.11.1 item 3 is added to read as follows:
903.2.11.1 Stories Without Openings.
3. An interior stairway that conforms to requirements of section 1005 with a fire separation assembly enclosure of not less than 1 hour, which has a
door directly to the exterior and the stairway does not connect more than 2 stories. The basement or windowless story floor level shall be 15 feet
(4572 mm) or less vertically from the exterior door threshold level and the door threshold shall be within 10 feet (3048 mm) of grade. Interior stair
doors or openings shall be provided in each 50 linear feet (15 240 mm) or fraction thereof on at least one side of the basement or windowless
story.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 272/357
(I) Section 903.3.9 is added to read as follows:
903.3.9 Interior Control Valves. The fire code official may require interior control valves to be installed to isolate occupancies that share a fire
suppression system. Where valves are installed in a system, valves shall be supervised or locked in the "open" position.
(J) Section 903.3.10 is added to read as follows:
903.3.10 Exterior Control Valves. All exterior fire suppression control valves shall have an exterior indicator valve (PIV or WPIV) provided in a
location approved by the fire code official. Valves shall be locked in the "open position".
(K) 903.4.2.1 is added to read as follows:
903.4.2.1 Strip Malls. Strip malls shall provide individual tenant space notification to comply with IFC 907.1.
(L) 907.1.2.1 is added to read as follows:
907.1.2.1 Qualifications. Shop drawings for fire alarm systems shall be prepared by one of the following:
(1) An Illinois licensed professional engineer with formal training in fire alarm layout/design.
(2) A holder of a valid NICET level III or higher certification in fire alarm system layout, who is either employed by or hired by the fire alarm
installation contractor.
(M) 907.1.4 is added to read as follows:
907.1.4 Strip Malls. Fire alarm systems shall be capable of identifying a fire alarm device activation or waterflow device activation in each tenant
space. An audio/visual device shall be provided at the front entrance to each tenant space to identify the location of an activated device(s).
(N) Section 912.2.2 is added to read as follows:
912.2.2 Existing Buildings. On existing buildings, wherever the fire department connection is not visible to approaching fire apparatus, the fire
department connection shall be indicated by an approved sign mounted on the street front or on the side of the building. Such sign shall be
reflective and constructed of material designed to resist weathering. The sign shall have a white background with all lettering and
graphics red in color. Such sign shall have the letters "FDC" not less than 6 inches (152 mm) high and words in letters not less than 2 inches
(51 mm) high or an arrow to indicate the location not less than 3 inches (75 mm) high. Such signs shall be subject to the approval of the fire code
official.

(O) Section 912.6 is amended to read as follows:
912.6 Backflow Protection. A water supply serving a fire suppression system shall be protected against backflow with a reduced pressure zone
(RPZ) backflow device and comply with the requirements of Illinois plumbing code.
(P) Section 1008.3.3 Rooms And Spaces, is amended to read as follows:
1008.3.3 Rooms And Spaces. In the event of power supply failure, an emergency electrical system shall automatically illuminate all of the following

(Q) Section 5601.2.2 is amended to read as follows:
5601.2.2 Sale And Retail Display. Persons shall not construct a retail display nor offer for sale explosives, explosive materials, or fireworks (1.3G or

(R) Section 5601.1 is amended to read as follows:
5601.1 General. Outdoor fireworks displays, use of pyrotechnics before a proximate audience and pyrotechnic special effects in motion picture,
television, theatrical and group entertainments productions shall comply with section 5608.2 through 5608.10 and NFPA 1123, 1126 and all
requirements of the Illinois office of the state fire marshal (OSFM).
(S) Appendix B, Fire-Flow Requirements For Buildings is added as part of this code.
(T) Appendix C, Fire Hydrant Locations And Distribution is added as part of this code.
(U) Appendix D, Fire Apparatus Access Roads is added as part of this code.
(V) Appendix F, Hazard Ranking is added as part of this code.
(W) Appendix H, Hazardous Materials Management Plan (HMMP) And Hazardous Materials Inventory Statement (HMIS) Instructions is added as part of
this code. (Ord. 2990, 2-1-2016)
8-3-2: ESTABLISHMENT AND DUTIES OF BUREAU OF FIRE PREVENTION:
(A) The fire prevention code shall be enforced by the bureau of fire prevention in the fire department of the city, which is hereby established and which
shall be operated under the supervision of the chief of the fire department.
(B) The chief of the fire department in charge of the bureau of fire prevention shall be and is hereby appointed by the mayor of the city. His appointment
shall continue during good behavior and satisfactory service, and he shall not be removed from office except for cause.
(C) A report of the bureau of fire prevention shall be made annually and transmitted to the mayor; it shall contain all proceedings under the code, with such
statistics as the chief of the fire department may wish to include therein; the chief of the fire department shall also recommend any amendments to the
code, which, in his judgment, shall be desirable. (Ord. 594, 7-23-1968)
8-3-3: MODIFICATIONS:
The chief of the bureau of fire prevention shall have power to modify any of the provisions of the fire prevention code upon application in writing by the
owner or lessee, or his duly authorized agent, when there are practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter of the code, provided that the
spirit of the code shall be observed, public safety secured, and substantial justice done. The particulars of such modification when granted or allowed and
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 274/357
the decision of the chief of the bureau of fire prevention thereon shall be entered upon the records of the department and a signed copy shall be furnished
the applicant. (Ord. 594, 7-23-1968)
8-3-4: APPEALS:
Whenever the chief of the fire department shall disapprove an application or refuse to grant a permit applied for, or when it is claimed that the provisions of
the code do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of the code have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may appeal from the
decision of the chief of the fire department to the bureau of fire prevention appeals within thirty (30) days from the date of the decision appealed. (Ord. 594,
7-23-1968)
8-3-5: NEW MATERIALS, PROCESSES OR OCCUPANCIES WHICH MAY REQUIRE PERMITS:
The mayor and the chief of the fire department shall act as a committee to determine and specify, after giving affected persons an opportunity to be heard,
any new materials, processes or occupancies, which shall require permits in addition to those now enumerated in said code. The chief of the bureau of fire
prevention shall post such list in a conspicuous place in his office, and distribute copies thereof to interested persons. (Ord. 594, 7-23-1968)
8-3-5-1: BURNING:
(A) Open Burning Unlawful; Exceptions: It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, suffer, allow or permit open burning of rubbish, refuse of any kind,
garbage, metal, salvage, waste or any other material in open fire in the city limits as provided by the rules and regulations of the Illinois pollution control
board promulgated October 15, 1971, which were adopted as the rules and regulations for open burning for the city except, however, that it shall not be
unlawful for any owner or tenant to burn or permit to be burned such substances as are reasonably necessary for the purpose of cooking food for
consumption by his family and guests.
(B) Supervision: All burning must be supervised and no fire shall be left unattended.
(C) Leaf Burning Prohibited: Burning shall only be permitted on Saturday and Sunday of each week in the year 2000. Burning shall only be permitted on
Sunday of each week during the year 2001. Thereafter, no leaf burning shall be permitted in the city limits. (Ord. 2990, 2-1-2016)
8-3-6: PENALTIES:
(A) Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of the code hereby adopted or fail to comply therewith, or who shall violate or fail to comply with any
order made thereunder, or who shall build in violation of any detailed statement of specifications or plans submitted and approved thereunder, or any
certificate or permit issued thereunder, and from which no appeal has been taken, or who shall fail to comply with such an order as affirmed or modified
by the chief of the bureau of fire prevention or by a court of competent jurisdiction, within the time fixed herein, shall severally for each and every such
violation and noncompliance respectively, be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00), nor more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) (or by imprisonment for not less than 5 days nor more than 30 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment).
The imposition of one penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue; and all such persons shall be required to correct or
remedy such violations or defects within a reasonable time; and when not otherwise specified, each ten (10) days that prohibited conditions are
maintained shall constitute a separate offense.
(B) The application of the above penalty shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions. (Ord. 2990, 2-1-2016)
Chapter 4
HAZARDOUS MATERIALS
8-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms and phrases when used in this chapter shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context
clearly indicates a different meaning:
COSTS INCURRED BY THE CITY: All costs and expenses of the city incurred in connection with the cleanup or abatement of the discharge of hazardous
materials and shall include, but shall not be limited to, the following: actual labor costs of city personnel involved in the cleanup or abatement of the
discharge (including workers' compensation benefits, fringe benefits and administrative overhead), costs of equipment operations, damage and loss as
published and updated by the finance department of the city, costs of materials obtained directly by the city, and cost of any contract labor and materials.
DISCHARGE: To leak, seep, spill, emit or release, or leakage, seepage, spillage, emission or other.
HAZARDOUS MATERIAL: Any substance or material which, due to its quantity, form, concentration, location or other characteristic, is determined by the
fire chief or his or her authorized representative to pose an unreasonable and imminent risk to the life, health or safety of persons or property or to the
ecological balance of the environment, including, but not limited to, explosives, radioactive materials, petroleum or petroleum products or gases, poisons,
etiologic (biological) agents, flammables, corrosives or any substance determined to be hazardous or toxic under any federal or state law, statute or
regulation.
PERSON: Any natural person or individual, governmental body, firm, association, partnership, copartnership, joint venture, company, corporation, joint
stock company, trust, estate, or any other legal entity, or their representative, agent, or assigns. (Ord. 2462, 11-17-2003)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 275/357
8-4-2: PROHIBITED ACTS:
No person shall cause, threaten or allow the release of hazardous materials into the environment unless such release is in accordance with an appropriate
permit granted by the Illinois environmental protection agency or other state or federal agency having primary jurisdiction over the release and such
release is in such place and manner as will not create a substantial present or potential hazard to human health, property or the environment. (Ord. 2462,
11-17-2003)
8-4-3: LIABILITY FOR CLEANUP OR ABATEMENT:
(A) The fire department is authorized to clean up or abate the effects of any hazardous material discharged upon or into any property or facilities within the
city where such discharge creates a hazard to any individual, property, or the environment. The fire department may be assisted in such cleanup or
abatement by any other city department, the department of any other governmental unit or independent contractors, as necessary to protect against or
eliminate such hazard.
(B) Any person who intentionally, negligently, or otherwise causes a discharge of hazardous material and any person who owns or controls the hazardous
material's container at the time of discharge shall be jointly and severally liable to the city and to any other entity rendering services during the cleanup
or abatement for the payment of all costs incurred by the city or those entities as a result of such cleanup or abatement by the city.
(C) The authority to recover costs under this section shall not include actual fire suppression services that are normally or customarily provided by the fire
department, unless the fire involves hazardous materials, or other services normally or customarily provided by other city departments.
(D) The remedies provided by this section shall be in addition to any other remedies provided by law or this code. (Ord. 2462, 11-17-2003)
8-4-4: BILLING; PAYMENT TO THE CITY:
(A) The city shall, within sixty (60) days of completion of the cleanup or abatement of any hazardous material discharge, send an invoice for the costs
incurred by the city in connection with such discharge to the person determined by the city to be responsible for such discharge pursuant to section 8-
4-3 of this chapter.
(B) The person responsible for such hazardous material discharge shall submit payment for the invoice to the city within thirty (30) days of the receipt of
the invoice. (Ord. 2462, 11-17-2003)
8-4-5: INSPECTIONS AND CORRECTION OF VIOLATIONS:
(A) The fire chief shall inspect as often as may be necessary all specially hazardous manufacturing processes, storage or installations of gases,
chemicals, oils, explosives and flammable materials, all interior fire alarm and automatic sprinkler systems, and such other hazards or appliances as
the fire chief shall designate, and shall issue such orders as may be necessary for the enforcement of the laws and ordinances governing the same
and for safeguarding of life and property from fire.
(B) Whenever any fire inspector shall find in any building or upon any premises, combustible or explosive matter, or dangerous accumulations of rubbish or
unnecessary accumulation of wastepaper, boxes, shavings, any highly flammable materials, or any hazardous materials and which are so situated as
to endanger life or property; or shall find obstructions to or on fire escapes, stairs, passageways, doors, or windows, liable to interfere with the
operations of the fire department or egress of occupants in case of fire, he shall order the same to be removed or remedied.
(C) Any person who fails to correct any violation cited by the fire chief pursuant to this section shall be guilty of an offense, punishable by fines not less
than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. (Ord. 2462, 11-17-2003)
Title 9
POLICE REGULATIONS
Chapter 1
POLICE DEPARTMENT
9-1-1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established a department of the Municipal government of the City, which shall be known as the Police Department and which shall
embrace the Chief of Police, two (2) Lieutenants of Police and six (6) Sergeants and such number of police officers as the Council may determine to be
necessary. (Ord. 2937, 4-21-2014)
9-1-2: APPOINTMENTS:
The Chief of Police shall be appointed by the City Manager for an indefinite period of time. He or she shall, before he or she enters upon the duties of his
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 276/357
or her office, take and sign the oath prescribed by law for City officials. All other police officers shall be appointed in accordance with the provisions of 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/10-1 of the Illinois Municipal Code.
Anything herein to the contrary notwithstanding all members of the Police Department, excepting the Chief of Police, are hereby designated as employees
of the City and not as officials thereof. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
9-1-3: QUALIFICATIONS:
(A) (Rep. by Ord. 2866, 3-19-2012)
(B) No person shall be appointed or employed as Chief of Police, Lieutenant, Sergeant or in any other capacity as a police officer who does not comply
with the requirements stated in article II of the Rules and Regulations of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners of the City. Any person receiving
an appointment or being employed as Chief of Police shall, within six (6) months after such appointment or employment, establish and continually
maintain his or her domicile within the geographic boundaries of Community Unit School District #170 (also known as the Dixon Public School District).
All other persons appointed or employed as a police officer shall, within six (6) months after such appointment or employment, establish his or her
domicile within five (5) miles of the City limits of Dixon, Illinois. Any person failing to adhere to this subsection shall be discharged. (Ord. 3067, 11-6-
2017)
(C) All persons employed as a police officer shall, prior to commencement of employment, be required to execute a police officer training reimbursement
agreement whereby the newly employed officer agrees to reimburse the City for certain costs and expenses as set forth in said reimbursement
agreement, a copy of which is on file with the City Clerk. No person shall commence employment without first executing said reimbursement
agreement. (Ord. 1736, 6-7-1993)
9-1-4: PERIOD OF INSTRUCTION:
Each person employed as a member of the police department shall, during the first six (6) months of his employment, take a course of instruction to qualify
him to perform his duties, said course of instruction to be prescribed by the commissioner of public health and safety with the approval of the council. If the
person does not satisfactorily complete such course within the period of six (6) months, he shall be discharged immediately and shall not be reappointed
as a member of the police department during the period of one year next following such discharge. (1950 Code)
9-1-5: CHIEF OF POLICE; POWERS:
The chief of police shall, subject to the jurisdiction and control of the city manager, have the management and control of the police department. All
regulations and orders thereof shall be promulgated through the chief of police. (Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
9-1-6: CHIEF TO DEVOTE ENTIRE TIME TO DUTIES:
The chief of police shall devote his entire time to the discharge of the duties of his office, shall engage in no other duties of employment except those
designated and approved by the council, and particularly in relation to the duties of civil defense with the county of Lee, Illinois, which said chief of police
may, at the discretion of the council, assume and discharge; and shall be charged with the preservation of the peace, order, safety and cleanliness of the
city and with the duty of protecting the rights of persons and property and enforcing all provisions of this code. (Ord. 520, 7-19-1966)
9-1-7: DUTY TO ABATE NUISANCES:
The chief of police shall take notice of all nuisances, obstructions and defects in streets and alleys or other public places of the city and shall cause the
same to be abated or removed or immediate notice thereof given to the proper officer whose duty it may be to take action in relation thereto. (1950 Code)
9-1-8: REPORT OF IMPROPER CONDUCT:
The chief of police shall promptly report to the commissioner of public health and safety any member of the police force who is guilty of drunkenness,
neglect of duty, disobedience of orders or violation of the rules and regulations of the police department. (1950 Code)
9-1-9: BOOKS AND RECORDS:
The chief of police shall keep, or cause to be kept, books of record of the police department and of all persons arrested by the police, showing the time
and place of each arrest, the offense for which same was made, the magistrate, justice or court before whom such person was taken and the disposition of
the case. (1950 Code)
9-1-10: MONTHLY REPORT TO COUNCIL:
The chief of police shall, on the first Tuesday of each month, make a written report to the council showing the number of arrests made by the police during
the preceding month, the name of each person arrested, the officer making the arrest, the offense charged, the magistrate, justice or court before whom
tried, the disposition of the case, the amount of fine imposed, if any, and the amount of such fine collected. (1950 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 277/357
9-1-11: ANNUAL REPORT TO COUNCIL:
The chief of police shall, on or before April 21 of each year, make a report to the council, in writing, showing the number of arrests made during the year,
the causes of such arrests, disposition of the cases, amount of fines imposed and amount of fines collected together with such other details and
recommendations as may seem to him proper. (1950 Code)
9-1-12: CUSTODY OF POLICE RECORDS AND PROPERTY:
The chief of police shall have the care, custody and control of all books, records, equipment and other property belonging to the police department and of
all stolen goods seized and retained by police authority. Upon the expiration of his term of office or his resignation or removal therefrom he shall surrender
to his successor in office all books, records, equipment and property of every description in his possession belonging to the city or appertaining to his
office. (1950 Code)
9-1-13: POLICE OFFICERS TO DEVOTE ENTIRE TIME TO DUTY:
Each police officer shall devote his entire time to the duties of his office and shall engage in no other duties or employment, and to the best of his ability,
shall see that the laws of the city are enforced. (1950 Code)
9-1-14: POWER TO ARREST:
Each member of the police department shall have the power to arrest, with or without process, all persons within the city who shall break the peace or
violate any provisions of this code or any law of this state or the United States. (1950 Code)
9-1-15: POWER TO SERVE PROCESS:
Each member of the police department shall have the power and authority within the limits of the city, to serve and execute warrants or other legal process
for the apprehension and commitment of persons charged with or held for the commission of any crime or misdemeanor or the violation of any provisions
of this code and while serving or executing or assisting in the serving or executing of any such warrant or legal process shall be vested with all the
common law and statutory powers of constables for such purposes. (1950 Code)
9-1-16: TERRITORIAL JURISDICTION:
Each member of the police department shall also have the power and authority to execute city warrants or other legal process without the limits of the city
and within such distance therefrom as is authorized by law in all cases where any provision of this code shall prescribe a penalty for the violation of any of
its provisions for persons residing, acting or doing business without the limits of the city. (1950 Code)
9-1-17: MAY CALL POSSE COMITATUS:
Any member of the police department may, at any time, call upon any able bodied male person above the age of eighteen (18) years to aid him in
arresting, retaking or holding in custody any person guilty of having committed any unlawful act or charged therewith to aid such officer in preventing the
commission of any unlawful act; and whosoever shall neglect or refuse to give such aid or assistance when so required shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor. (1950 Code)
9-1-18: POLICE TO AID FIRE DEPARTMENT:
Any member of the police department shall aid the fire department in extinguishing fires and in clearing the streets or grounds in the immediate vicinity of
fires so that the firemen shall not be hindered or obstructed in the performance of their duties. (1950 Code)
9-1-19: ASSIGNMENT OF HOURS OF DUTY:
The chief of police, under the direction of the commissioner of public health and safety, shall arrange and assign the hours of duty of the police officers.
(1950 Code)
9-1-20: UNIFORM:
Police officers shall wear a uniform and a badge at all times when on duty. The uniform shall be furnished by the police officer at his own expense and
shall be on a design specified by the commissioner of public health and safety. The badge shall be furnished by the city.
In addition to the compensation established by the city, each member of the police department shall be paid the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00)
annually as an allowance toward the purchase of necessary uniforms. Such allowance shall be paid to him in semiannual installments of fifty dollars
($50.00) each, the first of which payments shall be made at the beginning of the city's fiscal year and the second at the beginning of the second one-half
(1/2) of the fiscal year. (1950 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 278/357
9-1-21: SERVICE INSIGNIA:
(A) The years of service of a police officer with the department may be designated upon the left sleeve of each officer's coat as follows:
1. For all sergeants, lieutenants and the chief of police: For each five (5) years of service, a one inch (1") wide gold bar.
2. For all patrolmen: For each five (5) years of service a one inch (1") wide silver bar.
(B) Years of service of a police officer with the department may also be designated upon the front of the officer's uniform as follows:
1. For all sergeants, lieutenants and the chief of police: A blue ribbon with one gold star for each five (5) years of service.
2. For all patrolmen: A blue ribbon with one silver star for each five (5) years of service. (Ord. 1466, 1-3-1989)
9-1-22: BREACHES OF DUTY:
Any police officer who shall drink any intoxicating liquor while on duty; smoke while on duty; enter any place where intoxicating drinks are sold, while on
duty, except in the immediate discharge of his duty; be absent from duty without leave; neglect his duty; be guilty of immoral or improper conduct; neglect
to pay, within a reasonable time, a just debt; maltreat any person; disobey orders; use obscene, coarse or indecent language; receive a bribe; leave his
post or beat during the time when he is required to be on duty; or eat or drink in any public eating house, soft drink parlor or soda fountain while on duty or
accept any food or drinks without paying for same, shall be deemed guilty of breach of duty and shall be subject to the general penalty. (1950 Code)
9-1-23: REMOVAL FROM OFFICE:
The chief of police, or any police officer may be discharged at any time by a vote of a majority of the members of the council. (1950 Code)
9-1-24: FALSELY REPRESENTING POLICE OFFICER:
Any person who shall falsely represent any of the members of the police department or who shall maliciously or with intent to deceive, use or imitate any of
the signs, signals or devices used by the department or who, not being a police officer, shall wear the police uniform in public shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor. (1950 Code)
9-1-25: TRAFFIC OFFENSES; DUTY OF POLICE:
(A) Any person charged with an offense for which payment of a fine not more than ten dollars ($10.00) may be made to the police magistrate or other
justice of the peace shall have the option of paying such fine within the time specified in the notice of arrest at the police station upon entering a plea of
"guilty" and upon waiving appearance in court; or may have the option of depositing the required lawful bail and upon a plea of "not guilty" shall be
entitled to a trial as authorized by law.
(B) The payment of a fine to the chief of police, or other police officer designated by him, shall be deemed an acknowledgment of conviction of the alleged
offense, and the police department or one of its members, upon accepting the prescribed fine, shall issue a receipt to the violator acknowledging
payment thereof.
(C) The following duties are hereby imposed upon the police department in reference to traffic offenses:
1. It shall accept designated fines, issue receipts to such violators as are permitted and desire to plead guilty and waive court appearance.
2. It shall receive and issue receipts for cash bail from the persons who must or wish to be heard in court, enter the time of their appearance on the
police docket and notify the arresting officer and witnesses, if any, to be present.
3. It shall keep an easily accessible file on all violations of which each person has been guilty during the preceding twelve (12) months, whether such
guilt was established in court or upon appearance in the police department.
4. The police department shall follow such procedure as may be prescribed by the traffic regulations of this code or as may be required by any law of
this state. (Ord. 140, 1-24-1956)
9-1-26: PART TIME POLICE OFFICERS:
(A) Upon the recommendation of the commissioner of public health and safety, the city council may, when, in its judgment, the public welfare of the city
shall so require, appoint part time police officers as may be necessary and in the best interests of the city. Said appointed part time police officers must
successfully complete any training mandated by the Illinois law enforcement training standards board, the city of Dixon or the chief of police.
(B) Said part time officers shall be members of the Dixon police department, except for pension purposes. Said part time officers shall not be assigned
under any circumstances to supervise or direct full time police officers of the Dixon police department and shall not be used as permanent
replacements for permanent full time police officers.
(C) Said part time officers shall be trained under the intergovernmental law enforcement officers in-service training act and in accordance with the
procedures for part time police officers established by the Illinois law enforcement training and standards board. Prior to the hiring of a part time officer,
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 279/357
the applicant shall complete an application, an oral interview, and a background investigation, as determined by the chief of police, and such other
requirements and tests as may be established from time to time by the city council. Said hiring standards shall be submitted to the Illinois law
enforcement training and standards board for its review.
(D) The maximum number of hours a part time police officer may work in a calendar year is restricted to one thousand five hundred sixty (1,560) hours.
(Ord. 2885, 8-6-2012)
9-1-27: CONFORMANCE OF UNION CONTRACTS; POLICE PERSONNEL:
(Rep. by Ord. 2866, 3-19-2012)
9-1-28: AUXILIARY POLICE:
(A) There is hereby established the Dixon auxiliary police force. The number of such force shall be established from time to time as provided herein.
Auxiliary policemen shall not be members of the Dixon police department and shall not supplement members of the police department in the
performance of their assigned and normal duties except as provided herein.
(B) The mayor, with the consent of the city council, shall appoint all members to the Dixon auxiliary police force. (Ord. 1305, 10-21-1985)
(C) Auxiliary policemen shall have the duty of aiding and directing traffic within the city. Auxiliary policemen shall be authorized to issue traffic citations for
the violation of any of the provisions of this code prohibiting or restricting parking. (Ord. 2114, 9-8-1998)
(D) Auxiliary policemen are authorized to wear uniforms and identification symbols designating them as city auxiliary policemen. Said uniforms and
symbols shall be different and distinct from those used by the regular members of the Dixon police department.
(E) Auxiliary policemen shall at all times during the performance of their duties be subject to the direction and control of the chief of police, the mayor and
city council.
(F) Auxiliary policemen shall not be permitted or allowed to carry firearms. (Ord. 1305, 10-21-1985)
9-1-29: COMMUNITY SERVICE OFFICER:
(A) There is hereby created the position of community service officer who shall perform the duties of office under the supervision of the chief of police. The
community service officer shall be appointed by the chief of police by and with the advice and consent of the commissioner of public health and safety.
(B) The community service officer shall perform such duties as are assigned by the chief of police and such duties shall include: 1) enforcement of all
parking regulations and other city ordinances which do not create an immediate hazard, and reporting to the shift supervisor; 2) patrolling downtown
parking areas and other areas as necessary to control and regulate the parking laws and regulations of the city and state; 3) performing dispatch and
clerical duties; 4) assisting in maintaining an effective relationship between the police service and the community; 5) creating and filing records as may
from time to time be required by the chief of police; 6) executing complaints and testifying in court as needed; and 7) performing such other related
duties as may be prescribed from time to time by the city council or the chief of police. (Ord. 2721, 2-2-2009)
Chapter 2
GENERAL OFFENSES
9-2-1: AID IN ESCAPE2:
No person shall aid, abet or encourage the rescue or escape from jail or prison or custody of an officer of any person legally committed or arrested or
supply or attempt to supply any such person with any weapon or intoxicating liquors or with any implement or means of escape while in jail or prison or in
the custody of any officer of the city. (Ord., 12-17-1963)
9-2-2: AID TO AN OFFENSE:
Whoever aids, abets, assists, advises or encourages the commission of any act prohibited by this code or by any indirect means, procures any such
offense to be committed or whoever commits an offense through the intervention of an agent, servant, employee or person under his control shall be
deemed guilty to the same extent, and may be proceeded against in the same manner as though the offense had been committed by him directly. Any
agent, servant or other person doing any prohibited act for and on behalf of another shall be deemed guilty of such act equally with his employer or
principal and be subject to the same penalty, except in cases where a different or other penalty is provided for an agent or employee. (Ord., 12-17-1963)
9-2-3: ANIMALS AND BIRDS; SHOOTING:
No person shall shoot or molest or attempt to shoot or molest any bird or squirrel or rob or attempt to rob the nest of any bird, such bird or squirrel not
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 280/357
being the property of any person so offending. (Ord., 12-17-1963)
9-2-4: ANIMALS; CRUELTY TO3:
No person shall be cruel to an animal by overloading, overdriving, overworking, cruelly beating, torturing, tormenting, mutilating or cruelly killing any
animal, or causing or allowing the same to be done knowingly, or by cruelly working any animal which is maimed, infirm, sick or disabled or causing the
same to be done, or unnecessarily failing to provide an animal in his charge or custody, as owner or otherwise, with proper food, drink and shelter, or
abandoning an old, maimed, infirm, sick or disabled animal, or by keeping or driving or causing to be driven or kept an animal in an unnecessarily cruel
manner. (Ord., 12-17-1963)
9-2-5: ASSAULT4:
No person shall commit an assault or an assault and battery upon the person of another or be guilty of an affray or challenge or offer to fight another.
(Ord., 12-17-1963)
9-2-6: ASSEMBLY; UNLAWFUL5:
No two (2) or more persons shall assemble together for any unlawful purpose, or being assembled, act in concert to do an unlawful act with force and
violence against the property of the City or the person or property of another against the peace or to the terror of citizens or other persons or make any
movement or preparation therefor. (Ord., 12-17-1963)
9-2-7: BARBED WIRE FENCES:
No person as the owner, lessee, or agent of any building or grounds shall erect or maintain or permit to be erected or maintained in or about the entrance
of such building, or along any street, within two feet (2') of the sidewalk thereon, any railing, fence, guard or other protection there shall be affixed or
placed, or in any manner attached, any spike, nail, barb or other pointed instrument or thing of any kind or description which shall be dangerous or likely to
cause injury to the person or wearing apparel of any person frequenting the building or traveling upon the sidewalk. (Ord., 12-17-1963)
9-2-8: BOOKMAKING AND POOL SELLING6:
No person shall keep any room, shed, tenement, tent, booth, or building, or any part thereof, or shall occupy any place upon any public or private ground,
with any book, instrument or device for the purpose of recording or registering bets or wagers, or of selling pools, nor shall any person record or register
bets or wagers, or sell pools upon the result of any trial or contest of skill, speed or power of endurance of man or beast, or upon the result of any political
nomination, appointment or election, or being the owner, lessee or occupant of any such place, shall knowingly permit the same to be used or occupied for
any of these purposes, nor shall any person therein keep, exhibit or employ any device or apparatus for the purpose of recording or registering bets or
wagers, nor shall any person sell pools, or become the custodian or depository for hire or privilege, of any money, property, or thing of value staked,
wagered or pledged upon any such result. (Ord., 12-17-1963)
9-2-9: CONCEALED WEAPONS:
No person shall wear or carry concealed about his person any pistol, revolver, slingshot, metallic knuckles, bowie knife, dirk, razor, stun gun, taser or other
dangerous or deadly weapon or display or flourish any such weapon in a boisterous or threatening manner; provided, that the provisions of this section
shall not apply to any member of the Police Force, Constable or other Peace Officer while in the discharge of his duty nor to any person summoned by any
such officer to aid him in making an arrest or preserving the peace. Further, this section shall not apply to any person carrying or possessing said weapons
in accordance with the Firearm Concealed Carry Act who has been issued a currently valid license under said Act. (Ord. 3030, 3-20-2017)
9-2-10: DISTURBING ASSEMBLIES; PROCESSIONS7:
No person shall interrupt or disturb any congregation or assembly meeting for the purpose of religious worship, or for any lawful purpose by making any
loud or unusual noise or by rude or indecent behavior or by profane, obscene or improper discourse or conduct.
No person shall wilfully interrupt or disturb any funeral procession or assembly.
No person shall conduct himself in a riotous or disorderly manner or disturb the peace at any show, exhibition, theater or other place of amusement or at
any polling place. (Ord., 12-17-1963)
9-2-11: DISTURBING THE PEACE8:
No person shall disturb the peace of the City or the peace and quiet of any neighborhood, family or person in the City by loud or unusual noises or by
tumultuous or offensive carriage or by shouting, cursing, quarrelling, challenging to fight or fighting, threatening, traducing another person or by using
profane, obscene or offensive language or indulge in any conduct toward another tending to provoke a disturbance or breach of the peace or in any
threatening manner, not being a Peace Officer, display any pistol, knife, slingshot, brass, steel or iron knuckles or other weapon or being guilty of any other
manner of disorderly conduct. (Ord., 12-17-1963)
9-2-11-1: LIFE PRESERVERS PROTECTED; PENALTY:

each offense. (Ord. 486, 7-20-1965)

annoyance of any person. (1950 Code)

No person making an excavation upon or adjoining any street or alley or sidewalk or having the same in charge shall leave it open and unprotected so as
to endanger persons or animals. (Ord. 297, 12-8-1959)
9-2-14: FALSE FIRE ALARMS10:

firearms by any police officer or commissioner or other officials of the city in the discharge of their duties. (Ord. 297, 12-8-1959)

9-2-17: GAMBLING12:
Except for the provisions in section 5-13-14 of this code:
(A) No person shall play for money, or other valuable thing, at any game with cards, dice, checks, or at billiards, or with any other article, instrument or
thing whatsoever, which may be used for the purpose of playing or betting upon or winning or losing money, or any other thing or article of value, or
shall bet on any game others may be playing.
(B) Every clock, tape machine, slot machine or other machine or device for the reception of money on chance or upon the action of which money is staked,
hazarded, bet, won or lost is hereby declared a gambling device and shall be subject to seizure, confiscation, and destruction by any member of the
police department.
(C) No person shall keep a common gaming house, or in any building, booth, yard, garden, boat or float, by him or his agent used and occupied, procure
or permit any persons to frequent or to come together to play for money or other valuable thing, at any game, or keep any tables or other apparatus, for
the purpose of playing at any game or sport, for money or any other valuable thing, or knowingly rent any such place for such purposes. (Ord. 2879, 6-
18-2012)
9-2-18: INDECENT EXPOSURE13:

state of nudity or be guilty of any other indecent or lewd act. (Ord. 297, 12-8-1959)
9-2-19: LANDMARKS; REMOVAL OF:

alley or sidewalk or to show the grade of any street, alley or sidewalk. (Ord. 297, 12-8-1959)

9-2-23: PINBALL MACHINES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or use in any place of public resort within the city any tables or implements for any games of bagatelle,
pigeonhole, pinball or horserace. The term "bagatelle, pigeonhole or pinball" as used in this section shall mean a game played with any number of balls or
spheres upon a table or board having holes, pockets or cups into which such balls or spheres may drop or become lodged and having arches, pins, and
springs, or any of them, to control, deflect, or impede the direction or speed of the balls or spheres put into motion by the player. The term horserace
device includes mechanically simulated races whereby a beacon of light travels around a course and mechanically stops on a number or name or horse
marked on the machine. (Ord. 297, 12-8-1959)
9-2-24: POLICE OFFICERS; OBEDIENCE TO:
All persons shall obey the commands and directions of any police officer in the line of duty. (Ord. 1100, 7-20-1981)
9-2-25: PROFANE LANGUAGE17:
No person shall use profane or obscene language in any public place loud enough to be heard. (Ord. 1100, 7-20-1981)
9-2-26: PROSTITUTION18:
No lewd woman or prostitute shall in any manner ply her vocation in or upon the streets, alleys, stairways or halls of public buildings, parks or in other
places of the city by loitering or in any manner soliciting to acts of lewdness or be found loitering on the streets during the nighttime.
No person shall solicit or coax, hire, persuade or induce any female or any prostitute to go to any private or secluded place for the purpose of fornication,
adultery or prostitution. (Ord. 1100, 7-20-1981)
9-2-27: PROSTITUTION; HOUSE OF19:
No person shall be an inmate or occupant of or visit or frequent any house of ill fame or place used for the practice of fornication or adultery.
No person shall within the city or within one mile of the boundaries thereof keep or maintain, directly or indirectly, any bawdy or disorderly house, house of
ill fame or place for the practice of fornication or adultery.
No person shall lease any building or premises owned by him or under his control to be used in whole or in part as a house of ill fame or place for the
practice of fornication or adultery or permit any building or premises owned or controlled by him to be so used. (Ord. 1100, 7-20-1981)
9-2-28: RAILROAD CARS; OBSTRUCTING VISION:
In any public street wherein any railroad switch track or siding may be located, it shall be unlawful for any person to permit any railroad car to stand or
remain within fifteen feet (15') of the nearest side line of any street intersecting such switch track or siding except for the time actually required for the
loading or unloading of any such car by the owner, shopper or consignee of the contents of the car and for the further periods of thirty (30) minutes before
and after such loading or unloading. (Ord. 1100, 7-20-1981)
9-2-29: RESISTING AN OFFICER20:
No person shall hinder, delay, resist or obstruct any city officer or police officer or any person legally authorized by him in the discharge of his duty or aid,
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=443 283/357
abet or encourage any such hindering, delaying, resisting or obstructing or neglect or refuse to obey any lawful order or direction of any such officer. (Ord.
1100, 7-20-1981)
9-2-30: SWINDLING:
No person shall obtain possession of any money, goods, property or any other thing of value or attempt to do so by swindling, cheating, fraud, false
proceedings or by any trick, sleight of hand, game or device or induce or attempt to induce any person to bet, loan or deposit or stake money or other
property upon the result of any game, trick or device. (Ord. 1100, 7-20-1981)
9-2-31: VAGRANCY21:
No person able to work and support himself and not having any visible means to maintain himself shall loiter or stroll about in the city or shall be an idle
and dissolute person; and no person shall go about begging in any part of the city or occupy for the purpose of lodging or for any other purpose any barn,
shed, shop, car or place other than such as is kept for that purpose without the permission of owner or party entitled to the possession thereof; or lead an
idle, immoral or profligate life. (Ord. 1100, 7-20-1981)
9-2-32: FALSE ALARMS:
(A) It shall be unlawful for any person to transmit a false alarm to the city. Any person having an alarm system or device on his premises on the effective
date of this section shall be subject to the following charges for each and every false fire alarm per premises per quarter calendar year, as follows:
First false alarm No charge
Second false alarm No charge
Third false alarm $ 25.00
Fourth false alarm 50.00
Fifth false alarm 75.00
All subsequent false alarms 100.00
(Ord. 1100, 7-20-1981)
The office of the finance director is hereby authorized to bill these charges. If payment is not received by the finance director's office within thirty (30) days,
the finance director may refer the matter to the city attorney for prosecution. The penalty for violation of this section unless otherwise prescribed, shall be a
fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 1100, 7-20-1981; amd. Ord. 2887, 8-20-2012)
(B) In any prosecution for charging a violation of any law regulating alarms, proof that a false alarm occurred at the particular building, place, or premises
described in the complaint, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint owned, operated, maintained, controlled, or leased that
building, place, or premises, shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the person named in the complaint was the person who
transmitted a false alarm to the city. (Ord. 1100, 7-20-1981)
9-2-33: DISTRIBUTION OF WRITTEN MATERIALS:
(A) No persons shall throw, cast, or place in or upon any city right of way, street, avenue, highway, sidewalk, or city owned parking lot any unsolicited print
or other written material, including, but not limited to, newspapers, handbills, circulars, brochures, telephone books, advertising materials, and cards.
(B) No persons shall deliver any unsolicited print or other written materials, including, but not limited to, newspapers, handbills, circulars, brochures,
telephone books, advertising materials, and cards to any premises in the city except by being handed to the recipient, placed on the porch, stoop,
entranceway or front steps of the building or residence, in a manner so as to prevent, to the extent practicable, any such articles from being blown
about in any way causing litter. No such materials may be distributed within the city by means of tossing or otherwise propelling such materials from a
motor vehicle, whether moving or stopped. (Ord. 2624, 2-5-2007)
